1178970_11_ITEM7_P6_S2	An increase in interest rates generally would result in a decrease in the Company s average interest rate spread and net interest income, which could have a negative effect on profitability.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P7_S0	The Company generates non-interest income such as income from retail and business account fees, loan servicing fees, loan origination fees, appreciation in the cash surrender value of Bank-owned life insurance, income from loan or securities sales, fees from wealth management services and investment product sales and other fees.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P7_S1	The Company s operating expenses consist primarily of compensation and benefits expense, occupancy and equipment expense, data processing expense, the amortization of intangible assets, marketing and advertising expense and other general and administrative expenses.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P7_S2	The Company s results of operations are also affected by general economic conditions, changes in market interest rates, changes in asset quality, changes in asset values, actions of regulatory agencies and government policies.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P8_S0	The Company considers certain accounting policies to be critically important to the fair presentation of its financial condition and results of operations.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P8_S1	These policies require management to make complex judgments on matters which by their nature have elements of uncertainty.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P8_S2	The sensitivity of the Company s consolidated financial statements to these critical accounting policies, and the assumptions and estimates applied, could have a significant impact on its financial condition and results of operations.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P8_S3	These assumptions, estimates and judgments made by management can be influenced by a number of factors, including the general economic environment.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P8_S4	The Company has identified the following as critical accounting policies:
1178970_11_ITEM7_P9_S0	Valuation of deferred tax assets The calculation of the allowance for loan losses is a critical accounting policy of the Company.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P10_S0	The allowance for loan losses is a valuation account that reflects management s evaluation of the probable losses in the loan portfolio.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P10_S1	The Company maintains the allowance for loan losses through provisions for loan losses that are charged to income.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P10_S2	Charge-offs against the allowance for loan losses are taken on loans where management determines that the collection of loan principal is unlikely.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P10_S3	Recoveries made on loans that have been charged-off are credited to the allowance for loan losses.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P10_S4	The Company s evaluation of the adequacy of the allowance for loan losses includes a review of all loans on which the collectibility of principal may not be reasonably assured.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P10_S5	For residential mortgage and consumer loans, this is determined primarily by delinquency and collateral values.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P10_S6	For commercial real estate and commercial loans, an extensive review of financial performance, payment history and collateral values is conducted on a quarterly basis.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P11_S0	As part of the evaluation of the adequacy of the allowance for loan losses, each quarter management prepares an analysis that categorizes the entire loan portfolio by certain risk characteristics such as loan type (residential mortgage, commercial mortgage, construction, commercial, etc.) and loan risk rating.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P11_S1	When assigning a risk rating to a loan, management utilizes a nine point internal risk rating system.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P11_S2	Loans deemed to be acceptable quality are rated 1 through 4, with a rating of 1 established for loans with minimal risk.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P11_S3	Loans deemed to be of questionable quality are rated 5 (watch) or 6 (special mention).
1178970_11_ITEM7_P11_S4	Loans with adverse classifications (substandard, doubtful or loss) are rated 7, 8 or 9, respectively.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P11_S5	Commercial mortgage, commercial and construction loans are rated individually and each lending officer is responsible for risk rating loans in their portfolio.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P11_S6	These risk ratings are then reviewed by the department manager and/or the Chief Lending Officer and the Credit Administration Department.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P11_S7	A sample of risk ratings are also reviewed and confirmed through the Loan Review function and periodically, by the Credit Committee in the credit renewal or approval process.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P12_S0	Management assigns general valuation allowance ( GVA ) percentages to each risk rating category for use in allocating the allowance for loan losses, giving consideration to historical loss experience by loan type and other qualitative or environmental factors such as trends and levels of delinquencies, impaired loans, charge-offs, recoveries, loan volume, as well as, the national and local economic trends and conditions.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P12_S1	The appropriateness of these percentages is evaluated by management at least annually.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P12_S2	In the second quarter of 2010, management completed its most recent evaluation of the GVA percentages.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P12_S3	As a result of that evaluation, GVA percentages applied to the marine portfolio were increased to reflect an increase in historical loss experience.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P13_S0	possible increases in interest rates in the absence of economic improvement.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P13_S1	Any one or a combination of these events may adversely affect borrowers ability to repay the loans, resulting in increased delinquencies, loan losses and future levels of provisions.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P13_S2	Accordingly, the Company has provided for loan losses at the current level to address the current risk in its loan portfolio.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P13_S3	Management considers it important to maintain the ratio of the allowance for loan losses to total loans at an acceptable level given current economic conditions, interest rates and the composition of the portfolio.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P13_S4	Although management believes that the Company has established and maintained the allowance for loan losses at appropriate levels, additions may be necessary if future economic and other conditions differ substantially from the current operating environment.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P13_S5	Management evaluates its estimates and assumptions on an ongoing basis giving consideration to historical experience and other factors, including the current economic environment, which management believes to be reasonable under the circumstances.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P13_S6	Such estimates and assumptions are adjusted when facts and circumstances dictate.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P13_S7	Illiquid credit markets, volatile securities markets, and declines in the housing and commercial real estate markets and the economy generally have combined to increase the uncertainty inherent in such estimates and assumptions.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P14_S0	As future events and their effects cannot be determined with precision, actual results could differ significantly from these estimates.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P14_S1	Changes in estimates resulting from continuing changes in the economic environment will be reflected in the financial statements in future periods.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P14_S2	In addition, various regulatory agencies periodically review the adequacy of the Company s allowance for loan losses as an integral part of their examination process.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P14_S3	Such agencies may require the Company to recognize additions to the allowance or additional write-downs based on their judgments about information available to them at the time of their examination.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P14_S4	Although management uses the best information available, the level of the allowance for loan losses remains an estimate that is subject to significant judgment and short-term change.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P14_S5	Additional critical accounting policies relate to judgments about other asset impairments, including goodwill, investment securities and deferred tax assets.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P15_S0	Goodwill is evaluated for impairment on an annual basis, or more frequently if events or changes in circumstances indicate potential impairment between annual measurement dates.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P15_S1	The Company engages an independent third party to perform an annual analysis as of September 30, or more frequently if necessary, to test the aggregate balance of goodwill for impairment.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P15_S2	The fair value of goodwill is determined in the same manner as goodwill recognized in a business combination and uses standard valuation methodologies.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P15_S3	Fair value may be determined using market prices, comparison to similar assets, market multiples, discounted cash flow analysis and other factors.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P16_S0	Estimated cash flows may extend far into the future and by their nature are difficult to determine over an extended time frame.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P16_S1	Factors that may significantly affect the estimates include specific industry or market sector conditions, changes in revenue growth trends, customer behavior, competitive forces, cost structures and changes in discount rates.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P17_S0	The goodwill impairment analysis is a two-step process to evaluate the potential impairment of the goodwill on the financial statements of the Bank.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P17_S1	The first step in the process is estimating the fair value of the Reporting Unit.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P17_S2	For this analysis, the Reporting Unit is defined as the Bank, which includes all core and retail banking operations of the Company but excludes the assets, liabilities, equity, earnings and operations held exclusively at the Company level.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P18_S0	The first step utilizes four standard valuation methodologies common to valuation in business combination transactions involving financial institutions were used: (1) the Public Market Peers approach based on the trading prices of similar publicly traded companies as measured by standard valuation ratios; (2) the Comparable Transactions approach based on pricing ratios recently paid in the sale or merger of comparable banking franchises; (3) the Control Premium approach based on the Company s trading price (a proxy for the Bank s market pricing ratios were it publicly traded) followed by the application of an industry based control premium; and (4) the Discounted Cash Flow ( DCF ) approach where value is estimated based on the present value of projected dividends and a terminal value.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P18_S1	These valuation techniques take into account the Bank s recent operating history, current operating environment and future prospects.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P18_S2	In addition, these valuation techniques are prepared utilizing a GAAP established fair value hierarchy which prioritizes the inputs used to measure fair value.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P19_S0	highest priority to unadjusted quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities, Level 2 measurements, which utilize quoted prices in markets that are not active, or inputs that are observable either directly or indirectly and Level 3 measurements, which are the lowest priority to unobservable inputs and supported by little or no market activity.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P19_S1	The Public Market Peers approach and the Comparable Transactions approach are based on Level 2 inputs.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P19_S2	The Control Premium approach is based on a combination of Level 1 inputs (the quoted price for the Company s common stock) and Level 2 inputs (an estimated control premium based on comparable transactions).
1178970_11_ITEM7_P19_S3	The DCF approach is based on Level 3 inputs including projections of future operations based on assumptions derived from management, the experience of the independent valuation firm that conducted the analysis and information from publicly available sources.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P19_S4	All approaches are considered in the final estimate of fair value, with the approaches weighted based upon their applicability based upon the fair value hierarchy.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P19_S5	These approaches and the resulting fair value conclusions are consistent with standard valuation techniques used by other market participants in evaluating business combinations for financial institutions.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P19_S6	Significant assumptions made in the estimation of the fair value of the Reporting Unit using the Public Market Peers, Comparable Transactions, and Control Premium approaches included the comparability of the selected regional and national peers, subjective adjustments for variations in franchise value and credit risk versus peers, and adjustments for projected market trends.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P19_S7	In addition, assumptions are made in the use of the DCF approach regarding projections of future free cash flow resulting from asset growth, profitability, dividend payouts, and non-cash expenses.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P19_S8	All of these assumptions may be affected by a number of factors, including, but not limited to, changes in interest rates, regulation and legislation, and competition.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P20_S0	For purposes of the most recent impairment evaluation performed as of September 30, 2010, it was assumed that external factors would remain consistent with the then current environment.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P21_S0	If the fair value of the Reporting Unit exceeds its carrying amount, goodwill of the Reporting Unit is considered not impaired.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P21_S1	However, if the carrying amount of the Reporting Unit exceeds its fair value, an additional test must be performed.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P22_S0	The second step test compares the implied fair value of the Reporting Unit s goodwill with the carrying amount of that goodwill.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P22_S1	An impairment loss would be recorded to the extent that the carrying amount of goodwill exceeds its implied fair value.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P22_S2	As reported in the Company s Annual Report on Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2009, the Company determined that the carrying amount of the goodwill exceeded its implied fair value and an impairment charge in the amount of $152.5 million was recognized as of March 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P22_S3	The annual goodwill impairment test as of September 30, 2010 was completed in the fourth quarter of 2010, with no further impairment indicated based on the step one analysis.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P23_S0	The step one analysis at September 30, 2010 indicated that the fair value of the Reporting Unit substantially exceeded the carrying value of the reporting unit by 27.5%.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P23_S1	At September 30, 2010, the carrying value of goodwill was $346.3 million.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P23_S2	The Company s available for sale securities portfolio is carried at estimated fair value, with any unrealized gains or losses, net of taxes, reported as accumulated other comprehensive income or loss in Stockholders Equity.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P23_S3	Estimated fair values are based on market quotations or matrix pricing as discussed in Note 5 to the audited consolidated financial statements.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P24_S0	Securities which the Company has the positive intent and ability to hold to maturity are classified as held to maturity and carried at amortized cost.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P24_S1	The Company conducts a periodic review and evaluation of the securities portfolio to determine if any declines in the fair values of securities are other-than-temporary.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P24_S2	In this evaluation, if such a decline were deemed other-than-temporary, the Company would measure the total credit-related component of the unrealized loss, and recognize that portion of the loss as a charge to current period earnings.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P24_S3	The remaining portion of the unrealized loss would be recognized as an adjustment to accumulated other comprehensive income.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P25_S0	The market value of the securities portfolio is significantly affected by changes in interest rates.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P25_S1	In general, as interest rates rise, the market value of fixed-rate securities decreases and as interest rates fall, the market value of fixed-rate securities increases.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P26_S0	Turmoil in the credit markets resulted in a lack of liquidity in certain sectors of the mortgage-backed securities market.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P27_S0	Increases in delinquencies and foreclosures have resulted in limited trading activity and significant price declines, regardless of favorable movements in interest rates.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P28_S0	The Company determines if it has the intent to sell these securities or if it is more likely than not that the Company would be required to sell the securities before the anticipated recovery.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P28_S1	If either exists, the decline in value is considered other-than-temporary.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P28_S2	In this evaluation, the Company recognized other-than-temporary securities impairment losses in earnings totaling $170,000, $2.0 million and $1.4 million in 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P29_S0	The determination of whether deferred tax assets will be realizable is predicated on the reversal of existing deferred tax liabilities, utilization against carryback years and estimates of future taxable income.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P29_S1	Such estimates are subject to management s judgment.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P30_S0	A valuation allowance is established when management is unable to conclude that it is more likely than not that it will realize deferred tax assets based on the nature and timing of these items.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P30_S1	A valuation reserve of $1.1 million was established in 2009 pertaining primarily to state tax benefits on net operating losses at the Bank and unused capital loss carryforwards.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P30_S2	The valuation allowance remains at $1.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2010.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P30_S3	A valuation reserve of $1.7 million that had been established in 2007 pertaining primarily to state tax benefits on net operating losses at the Bank was eliminated in 2008 due to a large dividend payment the Bank received from a subsidiary, which reduced the state net operating losses to zero at December 31, 2008.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P31_S0	Analysis of Net Interest Income Net interest income represents the difference between income on interest-earning assets and expense on interest-bearing liabilities.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P31_S1	Net interest income depends on the relative amounts of interest-earning assets and interest-bearing liabilities and the rates of interest earned on such assets and paid on such liabilities.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P31_S2	The following table sets forth certain information for the years ended December 31, 2010, 2009 and 2008.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P31_S3	For the periods indicated, the total dollar amount of interest income from average interest-earning assets and the resultant yields, as well as the interest expense on average interest-bearing liabilities is expressed both in dollars and rates.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P31_S4	No tax equivalent adjustments were made.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P32_S0	(1) Average outstanding balance amounts are at amortized cost.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P33_S0	(2) Average outstanding balances are net of the allowance for loan losses, deferred loan fees and expenses, and loan premiums and discounts and include non-accrual loans.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P34_S0	(3) Net interest income divided by average interest-earning assets.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P35_S0	The following table presents the extent to which changes in interest rates and changes in the volume of interest-earning assets and interest-bearing liabilities have affected interest income and interest expense during the periods indicated.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P35_S1	Information is provided in each category with respect to: (i) changes attributable to changes in volume (changes in volume multiplied by prior rate); (ii) changes attributable to changes in rate (changes in rate multiplied by prior volume); and (iii) the net change.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P35_S2	The changes attributable to the combined impact of volume and rate have been allocated proportionately to the changes due to volume and the changes due to rate.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P36_S0	Comparison of Financial Condition at December 31, 2010 and December 31, 2009 Total assets decreased $11.6 million, or 0.2%, to $6.82 billion at December 31, 2010, from $6.84 billion at December 31, 2009, due primarily to decreases in cash and other assets, which were partially offset by increases in investment securities and loans.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P36_S1	Cash and cash equivalents decreased $71.5 million, to $52.2 million at December 31, 2010, from $123.7 million at December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P36_S2	The Company utilized these funds to repay higher-costing maturing certificates of deposit and borrowings, purchase investment securities and originate loans retained for portfolio.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P36_S3	Total investments increased $60.7 million, or 3.6%, during the year ended December 31, 2010.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P37_S0	Securities purchases for the year ended December 31, 2010 consisted primarily of U.S. Government Agency guaranteed mortgage-backed securities.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P37_S1	Total loans increased $25.6 million, or 0.6%, to $4.41 billion at December 31, 2010, from $4.38 billion at December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P37_S2	For the year ended December 31, 2010, loan originations totaling $1.14 billion and loan purchases of $90.4 million were partially offset by repayments of $1.15 billion and loan sales of $18.1 million.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P37_S3	Multi-family loans increased $159.5 million to $387.2 million at December 31, 2010, compared to $227.7 million at December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P37_S4	Commercial real estate loans increased $90.2 million to $1.18 billion at December 31, 2010, compared to $1.09 billion at December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P38_S0	repayments attributable to an active refinance market outpaced originations.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P38_S1	One- to four-family residential mortgage loan originations totaled $152.0 million and one- to four-family residential mortgage loans purchased totaled $90.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2010.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P38_S2	Principal repayments on residential mortgage loans totaled $327.4 million, and residential mortgage loans sold totaled $18.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2010.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P38_S3	Construction loans decreased $70.7 million to $125.2 million at December 31, 2010, compared to $195.9 million at December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P38_S4	The Company has de-emphasized construction lending for the past two years due to adverse market conditions.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P38_S5	Commercial loans decreased $30.3 million to $755.5 million at December 31, 2010, compared to $785.8 million at December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P38_S6	Consumer loans decreased $16.9 million to $569.6 million at December 31, 2010, compared to $586.5 million at December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P38_S7	Commercial loans, consisting of commercial real estate, multi-family, construction and commercial loans, totaled $2.45 billion, accounting for 55.6% of the loan portfolio at December 31, 2010, compared to $2.30 billion, or 52.5% of the loan portfolio at December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P38_S8	The Company intends to continue to focus on the origination of commercially-oriented loans.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P39_S0	Retail loans, which consist of one- to four-family residential mortgage and consumer loans, such as fixed-rate home equity loans and lines of credit, totaled $1.96 billion and accounted for 44.4% of the loan portfolio at December 31, 2010, compared to $2.08 billion, or 47.5%, of the loan portfolio at December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P39_S1	The increase in commercial loans as a percentage of the total loan portfolio was a result of growth in the multi-family and commercial mortgage portfolios, coupled with reductions in retail loans attributable to refinance activity, the market preference for longer-term fixed-rate loans, which the Company chooses to sell rather than retain for portfolio as part of its interest rate risk management process, and lack of qualified retail loan demand.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P40_S0	The Company does not originate or purchase sub-prime or option ARM loans.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P41_S0	Prior to September 30, 2008, the Company originated Alt-A mortgages in the form of stated income loans with a maximum loan-to-value ratio of 50% on a limited basis.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P41_S1	The balance of these Alt-A loans at December 31, 2010 was $14.7 million.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P41_S2	Of this total, 8 loans totaling $2.9 million were 90 days or more delinquent.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P41_S3	General valuation reserves of 10%, or $293,000, were allocated to these loans at December 31, 2010.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P42_S0	The Company participates in loans originated by other banks, including participations designated as Shared National Credits ( SNC ).
1178970_11_ITEM7_P42_S1	The Company s gross commitments and outstanding balances as a participant in SNCs were $106.9 million and $76.1 million, respectively, at December 31, 2010.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P42_S2	The Company s participations in SNCs included five relationships classified as substandard (rated 7) under the Company s loan risk rating system with gross commitments of $49.4 million and outstanding balances of $48.6 million, respectively, at December 31, 2010.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P42_S3	Of these adversely classified SNCs, four loan relationships consisted of commercial construction loans on properties located in New York City and New Jersey, and one was a commercial loan to a Pennsylvania media company.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P42_S4	All of the Company s SNC participations were current as to the payment of principal and interest as of December 31, 2010, with the exception of one $4.3 million commercial mortgage loan for which payments had been received but were unapplied at December 31, 2010, while the terms of an extension were negotiated among lending participants.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P42_S5	This loan was subsequently extended and principal and interest were paid current.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P42_S6	The Company had outstanding junior lien mortgages totaling $297.6 million at December 31, 2010.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P42_S7	Of this total, 52 loans totaling $4.2 million were 90 days or more delinquent.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P42_S8	General valuation reserves of 10%, or $417,000, were allocated to these loans at December 31, 2010.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P42_S9	At December 31, 2010, the Company had outstanding indirect marine loans totaling $67.8 million.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P42_S10	Of this total, 5 loans totaling $429,000 were 90 days or more delinquent.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P42_S11	General valuation reserves of 30%, or $129,000, were allocated to these loans at December 31, 2010.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P43_S0	Marine loans are currently made only on a direct, limited accommodation basis to existing customers.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P43_S1	The allowance for loan losses increased $8.0 million to $68.7 million at December 31, 2010, as a result of provisions for loan losses of $35.5 million, partially offset by net charge-offs of $27.5 million during 2010.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P44_S0	credit risk ratings and an increase in commercial loans as a percentage of the loan portfolio to 55.6% at December 31, 2010, from 52.5% at December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P44_S1	Total non-performing loans at December 31, 2010 were $97.3 million, or 2.21% of total loans, compared with $84.5 million, or 1.93% of total loans at December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P44_S2	At December 31, 2010, impaired loans totaled $47.7 million with related specific reserves of $2.3 million.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P44_S3	Within total impaired loans, there were $31.9 million of loans for which the present value of expected future cash flows or current collateral valuations exceeded the carrying amounts of the loans and for which no specific reserves were required in accordance with GAAP.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P44_S4	At December 31, 2010, the Company s allowance for loan losses was 1.56% of total loans, compared with 1.39% of total loans at December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P44_S5	Non-performing residential mortgage loans increased $12.6 million, to $41.2 million at December 31, 2010, from $28.6 million at December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P44_S6	In addition, non-performing consumer loans increased $44,000, to $6.8 million at December 31, 2010.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P44_S7	The Company attributes the increase in non-performing residential mortgage and consumer loans to continued elevated levels of unemployment, decreased real estate values and increased personal debt levels.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P44_S8	Non-performing commercial loans increased $11.0 million, to $23.5 million at December 31, 2010, from $12.5 million at December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P44_S9	Non-performing commercial loans at December 31, 2010 consisted of 70 loans.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P44_S10	The largest non-performing commercial loan relationship consisted of four loans to a power systems manufacturer with total outstanding balances of $9.6 million at December 31, 2010.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P44_S11	All contractual payments on these loans were current at December 31, 2010.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P44_S12	The Company held one $201,000 non-performing multi-family loan at December 31, 2010.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P44_S13	There were no non-performing multi-family loans at December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P44_S14	Non-performing commercial mortgage loans decreased $7.3 million, to $16.1 million at December 31, 2010, from $23.4 million at December 31, 2009, primarily as a result of gross charge-offs of $10.5 million.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P44_S15	At December 31, 2010, the Company held 11 non-performing commercial mortgage loans.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P44_S16	The largest non-performing commercial mortgage loan relationship consisted of two loans to a single real estate developer related to projects located in Delaware.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P44_S17	The first loan is secured by a planned unit development of 203 single family detached townhouse and age-restricted units that was written down to its current estimated collateral value of $6.2 million.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P44_S18	The second is commercial mortgage loan secured by a 184-unit, age-restricted townhouse project of which 126 units were unsold.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P44_S19	This loan was written down to its current estimated collateral value of $3.9 million at December 31, 2010.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P44_S20	There is no contractual commitment to advance additional funds to this borrower.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P44_S21	Non-performing construction loans decreased $3.8 million, to $9.4 million at December 31, 2010, from $13.2 million at December 31, 2009, as a result of repayments and a completed foreclosure.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P44_S22	At December 31, 2010, non-performing construction loans consisted of a $9.4 million senior participation interest in a $283.0 million SNC.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P44_S23	Proceeds from this construction loan facility are being used to convert an existing 35-story, 631,000 square foot office building in New York City into a mixed-use 346-unit residential condominium and 251-room hotel.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P44_S24	The project has been impacted by additional costs and a decline in sales activity.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P44_S25	While this loan has been classified as non-accrual, the hotel was completed and began operations in 2010.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P44_S26	The loan was current as to principal and interest at December 31, 2010.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P44_S27	The Company estimates a loan-to-value ratio of approximately 85% at December 31, 2010, and therefore, in accordance with GAAP, no specific reserve has been allocated to this loan.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P44_S28	The Company has no additional unfunded commitment on this loan.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P44_S29	At December 31, 2010, the Company held $2.9 million of foreclosed assets, compared with $6.4 million at December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P44_S30	Foreclosed assets at December 31, 2010 are carried at the lower of the outstanding loan balance at the time of foreclosure or fair value, less estimated costs to sell.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P44_S31	Foreclosed assets consisted of $1.1 million of residential properties, $1.0 million of commercial real estate and $745,000 of marine vessels at December 31, 2010.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P44_S32	Non-performing assets totaled $100.1 million, or 1.47% of total assets at December 31, 2010, compared to $90.9 million, or 1.33% of total assets at December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P45_S0	Other assets decreased $13.0 million to $74.6 million at December 31, 2010, compared to $87.6 million at December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P45_S1	This decrease was primarily due to the settlement in 2010 of equity fund redemptions that were pending as of December 31, 2009, and amortization of prepaid FDIC insurance.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P45_S2	Total deposits decreased $21.4 million, or 0.4%, to $4.88 billion at December 31, 2010, from $4.90 billion at December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P45_S3	Core deposits, consisting of savings and demand deposit accounts, increased $207.9 million, or 6.1%, to $3.60 billion at December 31, 2010, from $3.39 billion at December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P45_S4	The majority of the core deposit increase occurred in retail and business checking deposits.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P45_S5	Certificates of deposit decreased $229.3 million, or 15.2%, to $1.28 billion at December 31, 2010, from $1.51 billion at December 31, 2009, with the majority of the decrease occurring in the 15-month and shorter maturity categories.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P45_S6	The Company remains focused on cultivating core deposit relationships, while strategically permitting the run-off of certain higher-cost, single-service time deposits.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P45_S7	Core deposits represented 73.8% of total deposits at December 31, 2010, compared to 69.2% at December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P45_S8	Borrowed funds were reduced by $29.6 million, or 3.0%, during the year ended December 31, 2010, to $969.7 million, as the Company deployed excess liquidity arising from increased core deposit funding.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P45_S9	Borrowed funds represented 14.2% of total assets at December 31, 2010, a reduction from 14.6% at December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P45_S10	Total stockholders equity increased $37.1 million to $921.7 million at December 31, 2010, from $884.6 million at December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P45_S11	This increase was a result of net income of $49.7 million, other comprehensive income of $10.5 million, and the allocation of shares to stock-based compensation plans of $5.6 million, partially offset by cash dividends of $25.0 million, and common stock repurchases of $193,000.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P46_S0	Comparison of Operating Results for the Years Ended December 31, 2010 and December 31, 2009 General.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P46_S1	Net income for the year ended December 31, 2010 was $49.7 million, compared to a net loss of $121.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P46_S2	Basic and diluted earnings per share were $0.88 for the year ended December 31, 2010, compared to a basic and diluted loss per share of $2.16 for 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P47_S0	For the year ended December 31, 2010, the Company recorded an impairment charge of $1.5 million, or $904,000 net of tax, arising from the anticipated sale and relocation of its administrative building in the first half of 2011.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P47_S1	The carrying value of the existing premises and equipment was adjusted to reflect its current estimated realizable value, net of selling expenses.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P47_S2	The Company expects to realize operational efficiencies and reduced occupancy expense as a result of the relocation.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P47_S3	Compared with the year ended December 31, 2009, earnings for the year ended December 31, 2010 reflected a $27.9 million increase in net interest income and lower operating costs of $5.8 million, excluding a $152.5 million goodwill impairment charge incurred in 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P47_S4	These improvements were partially offset by an increase in income tax expense of $9.6 million resulting from increased taxable income and an increase in the provision for loan losses of $5.3 million attributable to increases in non-performing loans, downgrades in credit risk ratings, and an increase in commercial loans as a percentage of the total loan portfolio.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P47_S5	Additionally, earnings for the year ended December 31, 2009 were impacted by an industry-wide special assessment imposed by the FDIC as part of its plan to restore the deposit insurance fund.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P47_S6	The cost of this special assessment to the Company in the second quarter of 2009 was $3.1 million, or $1.9 million net of tax.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P47_S7	Net interest income increased $27.9 million, or 15.4%, to $209.0 million for 2010, from $181.0 million for 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P47_S8	The average interest rate spread increased 45 basis points to 3.27% for 2010, from 2.82% for 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P47_S9	The net interest margin increased 39 basis points to 3.45% for 2010, compared to 3.06% for 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P47_S10	Interest income decreased $6.0 million, or 2.1%, to $286.5 million for 2010, compared to $292.6 million for 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P47_S11	The decrease in interest income was attributable to a decrease in the yield on average earning assets, partially offset by an increase in average earning asset balances.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P47_S12	The yield on interest-earning assets decreased 22 basis points to 4.73% for 2010, from 4.95% for 2009, with reductions in yields experienced in nearly all earning asset classes.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P47_S13	Average interest-earning assets increased $111.1 million, or 1.7%, to $6.06 billion for 2010, compared to $5.92 billion for 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P48_S0	or 20.5%, to $1.31 billion for 2010, compared to $1.09 billion for 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P48_S1	This increase was partially offset by a decrease in average interest-earning deposits, Federal funds sold and short-term investment balances of $46.5 million, or 31.5%, to $100.9 million for 2010, from $147.3 million for 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P48_S2	In addition, average outstanding loan balances decreased $29.3 million, or 0.7%, to $4.27 billion for 2010 from $4.30 billion for 2009, and the average balance of investment securities decreased $4.1 million, or 1.2%, to $335.1 million for 2010, compared to $339.2 million for 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P48_S3	Interest expense decreased $34.0 million, or 30.5%, to $77.6 million for 2010, from $111.5 million for 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P48_S4	The decrease in interest expense was attributable to lower short-term interest rates coupled with a shift in the funding composition to lower-costing core deposits from certificates of deposit and a reduction in average borrowings, partially offset by an increase in average interest-bearing deposit balances.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P48_S5	The average rate paid on interest-bearing liabilities decreased 67 basis points to 1.46% for 2010, from 2.13% for 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P48_S6	The average rate paid on interest-bearing deposits decreased 70 basis points to 1.09% for 2010, from 1.79% for 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P48_S7	The average rate paid on borrowings decreased 32 basis points to 3.18% for 2010, from 3.50% for 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P48_S8	The average balance of interest-bearing liabilities increased $66.9 million, or 1.3%, to $5.30 billion for 2010, compared to $5.23 billion for 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P48_S9	Average interest-bearing deposits increased $184.3 million, or 4.4%, to $4.36 billion for 2010, from $4.18 billion for 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P48_S10	Within average interest-bearing deposits, average interest-bearing core deposits increased $436.6 million, or 17.1%, for 2010, compared with 2009, while average time deposits decreased $252.3 million, or 15.5%, for 2010, compared with 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P48_S11	Further aiding the increase in net interest income, average non-interest bearing deposits increased $50.4 million, or 10.6%, to $528.1 million for 2010, from $477.7 million for 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P48_S12	Average outstanding borrowings decreased $117.4 million, or 11.1%, to $939.3 million for 2010, compared with $1.06 billion for 2009, as deposits replaced wholesale funding.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P49_S0	Provisions for loan losses are charged to operations in order to maintain the allowance for loan losses at a level management considers necessary to absorb probable credit losses inherent in the loan portfolio.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P49_S1	In determining the level of the allowance for loan losses, management considers past and current loss experience, evaluations of real estate collateral, current economic conditions, volume and type of lending, adverse situations that may affect a borrower s ability to repay the loan and the levels of non-performing and other classified loans.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P49_S2	The amount of the allowance is based on estimates and the ultimate losses may vary from such estimates as more information becomes available or later events change.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P49_S3	Management assesses the adequacy of the allowance for loan losses on a quarterly basis and makes provisions for loan losses, if necessary, in order to maintain the adequacy of the allowance.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P49_S4	The Company s emphasis on continued diversification of the loan portfolio through the origination of commercial loans has been one of the more significant factors management has considered in evaluating the allowance for loan losses and provision for loan losses for the past several years.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P49_S5	In the event the Company further increases the amount of such types of loans in the portfolio, management may determine that additional or increased provisions for loan losses are necessary, which could adversely affect earnings.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P49_S6	The provision for loan losses was $35.5 million in 2010, compared to $30.3 million in 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P49_S7	The increase in the provision for loan losses was attributable to an increase in non-performing loans; downgrades in credit risk ratings; an increase in commercial loans as a percentage of the total loan portfolio to 55.6% at December 31, 2010, from 52.5% at December 31, 2009; and the impact of current macroeconomic conditions.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P49_S8	Net charge-offs for 2010 were $27.5 million, compared to $17.2 million for 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P49_S9	Total charge-offs for the year ended December 31, 2010 were $29.5 million, compared to $19.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P49_S10	Recoveries for the year ended December 31, 2010 were $1.9 million, compared to $2.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P49_S11	The allowance for loan losses at December 31, 2010 was $68.7 million, or 1.56% of total loans, compared to $60.7 million, or 1.39% of total loans at December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P49_S12	At December 31, 2010, non-performing loans as a percentage of total loans were 2.21%, compared to 1.93% at December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P49_S13	Non-performing assets as a percentage of total assets were 1.47% at December 31, 2010, compared to 1.33% at December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P49_S14	At December 31, 2010, non-performing loans were $97.3 million, compared to $84.5 million at December 31, 2008, and non-performing assets were $100.1 million at December 31, 2010, compared to $90.9 million at December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P50_S0	For the year ended December 31, 2010, non-interest income totaled $31.6 million, an increase of $100,000, or 0.3%, compared to 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P50_S1	Other income declined $1.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2010, compared with 2009, primarily as a result of a reduction in gains resulting from fewer loan sales and a non-recurring gain recognized on the sale of a Bank-owned parcel of land in 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P50_S2	Fee income for the year ended December 31, 2010 decreased $542,000, or 2.2%, compared to the same period in 2009, primarily as a result of a decrease in equity fund income due to the redemption of equity fund holdings in late 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P50_S3	In addition, net gains on securities transactions declined $513,000 for the year ended December 31, 2010, compared with the same period in 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P50_S4	These net gains on securities transactions totaled $885,000 for the year ended December 31, 2010, compared with net gains of $1.4 million for the same period in 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P50_S5	The Company recognized other-than-temporary impairment charges on securities of $170,000 and $2.0 million during the years ended December 31, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P50_S6	Income related to Bank-owned life insurance increased $558,000 for the year ended December 31, 2010, compared to the same period in 2009, as a result of appreciation in the cash surrender value and the receipt of policy claim proceeds in the second quarter of 2010.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P50_S7	Non-interest expense for the year ended December 31, 2010 was $138.7 million.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P50_S8	Excluding the $152.5 million non-cash goodwill impairment charge recorded in the first quarter of 2009, non-interest expense decreased $5.8 million, or 4.0%, from $144.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P50_S9	FDIC insurance expense decreased $4.1 million to $7.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2010, compared with 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P50_S10	In the prior year, a $3.1 million special assessment was imposed on the Company as part of an industry-wide plan to restore the deposit insurance fund.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P50_S11	In addition, amortization of intangibles decreased $1.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2010, compared with 2009, as a result of scheduled reductions in core deposit intangible amortization and the non-recurring acceleration in core deposit intangible amortization related to the sale of branches in 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P50_S12	Other operating expenses decreased $2.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2010.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P50_S13	This reduction was primarily due to non-recurring costs incurred in 2009 related to branch consolidations and sales, and the dissolution of a real estate joint venture.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P50_S14	These decreases were partially offset by a charge recorded in 2010 related to the planned relocation of the Company s administrative building.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P50_S15	For the year ended December 31, 2010, the Company s income tax expense was $16.6 million, compared with $7.0 million for 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P50_S16	The increase in income tax expense was attributable to increased pre-tax income and a higher effective tax rate.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P50_S17	The Company s effective tax rate was 25.0% for the year ended December 31, 2010, compared with 18.6% for the year ended December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P50_S18	The increase in the effective tax rate was attributable to increased taxable income for 2010.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P51_S0	Comparison of Operating Results for the Years Ended December 31, 2009 and December 31, 2008 General.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P51_S1	The Company realized a net loss of $121.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2009, compared to net income of $41.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2008.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P51_S2	The basic and diluted loss per share was $2.16 for the year ended December 31, 2009, compared to basic and diluted earnings per share of $0.74 for 2008.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P51_S3	The primary reason for the net loss in 2009 was the recognition of a $152.5 million goodwill impairment charge.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P51_S4	The goodwill impairment charge was a non-cash accounting adjustment to the Company s financial statements which did not affect cash flows, liquidity, or tangible capital.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P51_S5	As goodwill is excluded from regulatory capital, the impairment charge did not impact the regulatory capital ratios of the Company or its wholly owned subsidiary, The Provident Bank, both of which remained well-capitalized under then current regulatory requirements.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P51_S6	Earnings for the year ended December 31, 2009 compared with 2008 also reflected an increase in the provision for loan losses due to the following: an increase in non-performing loans; downgrades in credit risk ratings; an increase in commercial loans as a percentage of the total loan portfolio; and the impact of current macroeconomic conditions.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P51_S7	The provision for loan losses was $30.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2009, compared with $15.1 million for 2008.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P51_S8	In addition, earnings for the year ended December 31, 2009 were impacted by a special assessment imposed on the banking industry by the FDIC as part of its plan to restore the deposit insurance fund.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P51_S9	The cost of this special assessment to the Company was $3.1 million, which resulted in a charge of $1.9 million, net of tax, recognized during the second quarter of 2009.

1178970_11_ITEM7_P52_S33	Income from the appreciation in the cash surrender value of Bank-owned life insurance increased $108,000 for the year ended December 31, 2009, compared with 2008.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P53_S0	temporary impairment charges on securities of $2.0 million during the year ended December 31, 2009, compared with other-than-temporary impairment charges of $1.4 million recognized in 2008.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P53_S1	Excluding the $152.5 million goodwill impairment charge recorded in the first quarter of 2009, non-interest expense increased $13.9 million, or 10.7%, to $144.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2009, compared to $130.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2008.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P53_S2	FDIC insurance expense increased $11.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2009, compared with 2008, as a result of deposit growth, increased premium rates and the FDIC special assessment imposed on the industry as part of its plan to restore the deposit insurance fund.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P53_S3	The cost of the FDIC special assessment was $3.1 million.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P53_S4	Other operating expenses increased $3.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2009, compared with 2008, due primarily to $1.3 million of charges related to the consolidation and divestiture of premises and costs associated with the dissolution of a real estate development joint venture.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P53_S5	Compensation and benefits expense increased $968,000 for the year ended December 31, 2009, compared with 2008, primarily due to a $1.5 million increase in severance costs during the year ended December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P53_S6	Severance included costs associated with the retirements of two senior executives in the third quarter of 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P53_S7	These increases were partially offset by a $966,000 decrease in the amortization of intangibles as a result of scheduled reductions in core deposit amortization, and reductions in net occupancy expense totaling $639,000.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P53_S8	For the year ended December 31, 2009, the Company s income tax expense was $7.0 million, compared with $14.9 million for 2008.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P53_S9	The decrease in income tax expense was attributable to lower pre-tax income and a lower effective tax rate.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P53_S10	Excluding the impact of the goodwill impairment charge recognized in the first quarter of 2009, which is not tax deductible, the Company s effective tax rate was 18.6% for the year ended December 31, 2009, compared with 26.4% for the year ended December 31, 2008.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P53_S11	The reduction in the effective tax rate was attributable to a larger proportion of the Company s income being derived from tax-exempt sources.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P54_S0	Liquidity and Capital Resources Liquidity refers to the Company s ability to generate adequate amounts of cash to meet financial obligations to its depositors, to fund loans and securities purchases, deposit outflows and operating expenses.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P54_S1	Sources of funds include scheduled amortization of loans, loan prepayments, scheduled maturities of investments, cash flows from mortgage-backed securities and the ability to borrow funds from the FHLB of New York and approved broker dealers.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P54_S2	The Bank has a $100.0 million overnight line of credit and a $100.0 million one-month overnight repricing line of credit with the FHLB of New York.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P54_S3	These lines of credit are subject to annual renewal.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P54_S4	As of December 31, 2010, there were $53.0 million of borrowings outstanding against these lines of credit.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P55_S0	Cash flows from loan payments and maturing investment securities are a fairly predictable source of funds.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P55_S1	Changes in interest rates, local economic conditions and the competitive marketplace can influence loan prepayments, prepayments on mortgage-backed securities and deposit flows.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P56_S0	For each of the years ended December 31, 2010 and 2009, loan repayments totaled $1.15 billion and $1.13 billion, respectively.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P56_S1	One- to four-family residential loans, consumer loans, commercial real estate loans, multi-family loans and commercial and small business loans are the primary investments of the Company.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P56_S2	Purchasing securities for the investment portfolio is a secondary use of funds and the investment portfolio is structured to complement and facilitate the Company s lending activities and ensure adequate liquidity.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P57_S0	Loan originations and purchases totaled $1.23 billion for the year ended December 31, 2010, compared to $1.20 billion for the year ended December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P57_S1	Purchases for the investment portfolio totaled $626.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2010, compared to $817.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P57_S2	At December 31, 2010, the Bank had outstanding loan commitments to borrowers of $732.2 million, including undisbursed home equity lines and personal credit lines of $258.7 million at December 31, 2010.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P58_S0	deposits decreased $21.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2010.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P59_S0	Deposit activity is affected by changes in interest rates, competitive pricing and product offerings in the marketplace, local economic conditions, customer confidence and other factors such as stock market volatility.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P59_S1	Certificate of deposit accounts that are scheduled to mature within one year totaled $819.5 million at December 31, 2010.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P59_S2	Based on its current pricing strategy and customer retention experience, the Bank expects to retain a significant share of these accounts.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P59_S3	The Bank manages liquidity on a daily basis and expects to have sufficient cash to meet all of its funding requirements.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P59_S4	As of December 31, 2010, the Bank exceeded all minimum regulatory capital requirements.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P59_S5	At December 31, 2010, the Bank s leverage (Tier 1) capital ratio was 7.19%.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P59_S6	FDIC regulations require banks to maintain a minimum leverage ratio of Tier 1 capital to adjusted total assets of 4.00%.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P59_S7	At December 31, 2010, the Bank s total risk-based capital ratio was 12.17%.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P59_S8	Under current regulations, the minimum required ratio of total capital to risk-weighted assets is 8.00%.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P59_S9	A bank is considered to be well-capitalized if it has a leverage (Tier 1) capital ratio of at least 5.00% and a total risk-based capital ratio of at least 10.00%.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P59_S10	Off-balance sheet and contractual obligations as of December 31, 2010, are summarized below:
1178970_11_ITEM7_P60_S0	Off-balance sheet commitments consist of unused commitments to borrowers for term loans, unused lines of credit and outstanding letters of credit.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P60_S1	Total off-balance sheet obligations were $732.2 million at December 31, 2010, a decrease of $35.7 million, or 4.6%, from $767.9 million at December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P60_S2	Contractual obligations consist of operating leases and certificate of deposit liabilities.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P60_S3	There were no securities purchases that were entered into in December 2010 or 2009 that would have settled in January 2010 or 2009, respectively.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P60_S4	Total contractual obligations at December 31, 2010 were $1.31 billion, a decrease of $210.1 million, or 13.8%, compared to $1.52 billion at December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7_P60_S5	Contractual obligations under operating leases increased $19.3 million, or 127.4%, to $34.4 million at December 31, 2010, from $15.1 million at December 31, 2009, and certificate of deposit accounts decreased $229.3 million, or 15.2%, to $1.28 billion at December 31, 2010, from $1.51 billion at December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7A_P0_S0	Company s interest rate risk policy seek to limit the exposure to changes in interest rates that affect the underlying economic value of assets and liabilities, earnings and capital.
1178970_11_ITEM7A_P0_S1	To minimize interest rate risk, the Company generally sells 20- and 30-year fixed-rate mortgage loans at origination.
1178970_11_ITEM7A_P0_S2	Commercial real estate loans generally have interest rates that reset in five years, and other commercial loans such as construction loans and commercial lines of credit reset with changes in the Prime rate, the Federal funds rate or LIBOR.
1178970_11_ITEM7A_P0_S3	Investment securities purchases generally have maturities of five years or less, and mortgage-backed securities have weighted average lives initially between three and five years.
1178970_11_ITEM7A_P1_S0	The management Asset/Liability Committee meets on a monthly basis to review the impact of interest rate changes on net interest income, net interest margin, net income and economic value of equity.
1178970_11_ITEM7A_P1_S1	Members of the Asset/Liability Committee include the Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, as well as other senior officers from the Bank s finance, lending, credit and customer management departments.
1178970_11_ITEM7A_P1_S2	The Asset/Liability Committee reviews a variety of strategies that project changes in asset or liability mix and the impact of those changes on projected net interest income and net income.
1178970_11_ITEM7A_P2_S0	The Company s strategy for liabilities has been to maintain a stable core-funding base by focusing on core deposit account acquisition and increasing products and services per household.
1178970_11_ITEM7A_P3_S0	Certificate of deposit accounts as a percentage of total deposits were 26.2% at December 31, 2010 compared to 30.8% at December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7A_P4_S0	Certificate of deposit accounts are generally short-term.
1178970_11_ITEM7A_P4_S1	As of December 31, 2010, 64.1% of all time deposits had maturities of one year or less compared to 74.0% at December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM7A_P4_S2	The Company s ability to retain maturing certificate of deposit accounts is the result of a strategy to remain competitively priced within the marketplace, typically within the upper quartile of rates offered by competitors.
1178970_11_ITEM7A_P4_S3	The Company s pricing strategy may vary depending upon funding needs and the Company s ability to fund operations through alternative sources, primarily by accessing short-term lines of credit with the FHLB during periods of pricing dislocation.
1178970_11_ITEM7A_P5_S0	Current and future sensitivity to changes in interest rates are measured through the use of balance sheet and income simulation models.
1178970_11_ITEM7A_P5_S1	The analyses capture changes in net interest income using flat rates as a base, a most likely rate forecast and rising and declining interest rate forecasts.
1178970_11_ITEM7A_P5_S2	Changes in net interest income and net income for the forecast period, generally twelve to twenty-four months, are measured and compared to policy limits for acceptable change.
1178970_11_ITEM7A_P5_S3	The Company periodically reviews historical deposit repricing activity and makes modifications to certain assumptions used in its income simulation model regarding the interest rate sensitivity of deposits without maturity dates.
1178970_11_ITEM7A_P5_S4	These modifications are made to more precisely reflect the most likely results under the various interest rate change scenarios.
1178970_11_ITEM7A_P6_S0	Since it is inherently difficult to predict the sensitivity of interest bearing deposits to changes in interest rates, the changes in net interest income due to changes in interest rates cannot be precisely predicted.
1178970_11_ITEM7A_P6_S1	There are a variety of reasons that may cause actual results to vary considerably from the predictions presented below which include, but are not limited to, the timing, magnitude, and frequency of changes in interest rates, interest rate spreads, prepayments, and actions taken in response to such changes.
1178970_11_ITEM7A_P6_S2	Specific assumptions used in the simulation model include:
1178970_11_ITEM7A_P7_S0	Higher-balance demand deposit tiers and promotional demand accounts move at 50% to 75% of the rate ramp in either direction.
1178970_11_ITEM7A_P8_S0	The following table sets forth the results of the twelve month projected net interest income model as of December 31, 2010.
1178970_11_ITEM7A_P8_S1	The above table indicates that as of December 31, 2010, in the event of a 300 basis point increase in interest rates, whereby rates ramp up evenly over a twelve-month period, the Company would experience a 6.1%, or $13.3 million decrease in net interest income.
1178970_11_ITEM7A_P8_S2	In the event of a 100 basis point decrease in interest rates, whereby rates ramp down evenly over a twelve-month period, the Company would experience a 2.0%, or $4.5 million decrease in net interest income.
1178970_11_ITEM7A_P9_S0	Another measure of interest rate sensitivity is to model changes in economic value of equity through the use of immediate and sustained interest rate shocks.
1178970_11_ITEM7A_P9_S1	The following table illustrates the economic value of equity model results as of December 31, 2010.
1178970_11_ITEM7A_P9_S2	The preceding table indicates that as of December 31, 2010, in the event of an immediate and sustained 300 basis point increase in interest rates, the Company would experience a 20.6%, or $234.8 million reduction in the present value of equity.
1178970_11_ITEM7A_P9_S3	If rates were to decrease 100 basis points, the Company would experience a 5.6%, or $63.9 million increase in the present value of equity.
1178970_11_ITEM7A_P10_S0	Certain shortcomings are inherent in the methodologies used in the above interest rate risk measurements.
1178970_11_ITEM7A_P10_S1	Modeling changes in net interest income requires the making of certain assumptions regarding prepayment and deposit decay rates, which may or may not reflect the manner in which actual yields and costs respond to changes in market interest rates.
1178970_11_ITEM7A_P10_S2	While management believes such assumptions are reasonable, there can be no assurance that assumed prepayment rates and decay rates will approximate actual future loan prepayment and deposit withdrawal activity.
1178970_11_ITEM7A_P10_S3	Moreover, the net interest income table presented assumes that the composition of interest sensitive assets and liabilities existing at the beginning of a period remains constant over the period being measured and also assumes that a particular change in interest rates is reflected uniformly across the yield curve regardless of the duration to maturity or repricing of specific assets and liabilities.
1178970_11_ITEM7A_P10_S4	Accordingly, although the net interest income table provides an indication of the Company s interest rate risk exposure at a particular point in time, such measurement is not intended to and does not provide a precise forecast of the effect of changes in market interest rates on net interest income and will differ from actual results.
