1178970_11_ITEM8_P2_S0	Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm The Board of Directors and Stockholders Provident Financial Services, Inc.: We have audited the accompanying consolidated statements of financial condition of Provident Financial Services, Inc. and subsidiary (the Company ) as of December 31, 2010 and 2009, and the related consolidated statements of operations, changes in stockholders equity, and cash flows for each of the years in the three-year period ended December 31, 2010.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P2_S1	These consolidated financial statements are the responsibility of the Company s management.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P2_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these consolidated financial statements based on our audits.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P2_S3	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1178970_11_ITEM8_P2_S4	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P3_S0	An audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P3_S1	An audit also includes assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P3_S2	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P3_S3	In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of Provident Financial Services, Inc. and subsidiary as of December 31, 2010 and 2009, and the results of their operations and their cash flows for each of the years in the three-year period ended December 31, 2010, in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P4_S0	As discussed in Note 1 to the consolidated financial statements, the Company changed its method of evaluating other-than-temporary impairment of debt securities due to the adoption of new accounting requirements issued by the Financial Accounting Standards Board, as of April 1, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P4_S1	We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), Provident Financial Services, Inc. s internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2010, based on criteria established in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission ( COSO ), and our report dated March 1, 2011 expressed an unqualified opinion on the effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P5_S0	The Board of Directors and Stockholders Provident Financial Services, Inc.:
1178970_11_ITEM8_P6_S0	We have audited Provident Financial Services, Inc. s (the Company ) internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2010, based on criteria established in Internal Control-Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission ( COSO ) .
1178970_11_ITEM8_P6_S1	The Company s management is responsible for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting, included in the accompanying Management s Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P6_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the Company s internal control over financial reporting based on our audit.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P6_S3	We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1178970_11_ITEM8_P6_S4	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P6_S5	Our audit included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists and testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P6_S6	Our audit also included performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P6_S7	We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P7_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P7_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P7_S2	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P7_S3	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P7_S4	In our opinion, Provident Financial Services, Inc. maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2010, based on criteria established in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the COSO.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P7_S5	We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), the consolidated statements of financial condition of Provident Financial Services, Inc. and subsidiary as of December 31, 2010 and 2009, and the related consolidated statements of operations, changes in stockholders equity, and cash flows for each of the years in the three-year period ended December 31, 2010, and our report dated March 1, 2011 expressed an unqualified opinion on those consolidated financial statements.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P8_S0	See accompanying notes to consolidated financial statements.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P9_S0	See accompanying notes to consolidated financial statements.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P10_S0	The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of Provident Financial Services, Inc. (the Company ), The Provident Bank (the Bank ) and their wholly owned subsidiaries.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P10_S1	All intercompany balances and transactions have been eliminated in consolidation.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P11_S0	Business The Company, through the Bank, provides a full range of banking services to individual and business customers through branch offices in New Jersey.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P11_S1	The Bank is subject to competition from other financial institutions and to the regulations of certain federal and state agencies, and undergoes periodic examinations by those regulatory authorities.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P12_S0	The consolidated financial statements of the Company have been prepared in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles ( GAAP ).
1178970_11_ITEM8_P13_S0	In preparing the consolidated financial statements, management is required to make estimates and assumptions about future events.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P13_S1	These estimates and the underlying assumptions affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosures about contingent assets and liabilities as of the dates of the consolidated statements of financial condition, and revenues and expenses for the periods then ended.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P13_S2	Such estimates are used in connection with the determination of the allowance for loan losses, evaluation of goodwill for impairment, evaluation of other-than-temporary impairment on securities, evaluation of the need for valuation allowances on deferred tax assets, and determination of liabilities related to retirement and other post-retirement benefits, among others.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P13_S3	These estimates and assumptions are based on management s best estimates and judgment.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P13_S4	Management evaluates its estimates and assumptions on an ongoing basis using historical experience and other factors, including the current economic environment, which management believes to be reasonable under the circumstances.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P13_S5	Such estimates and assumptions are adjusted when facts and circumstances dictate.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P13_S6	Illiquid credit markets, volatile securities markets, and declines in the housing market and the economy generally have combined to increase the uncertainty inherent in such estimates and assumptions.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P13_S7	As future events and their effects cannot be determined with precision, actual results could differ significantly from these estimates.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P13_S8	Changes in estimates resulting from continuing changes in the economic environment will be reflected in the financial statements in future periods.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P14_S0	Cash and Cash Equivalents For purposes of reporting cash flows, cash and cash equivalents include cash and due from banks, Federal funds sold and commercial paper with maturity dates less than 90 days.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P15_S0	Securities Securities include investment securities held to maturity and securities available for sale.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P15_S1	Securities that the Company has the positive intent and ability to hold to maturity are classified as investment securities held to maturity and reported at amortized cost.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P15_S2	Securities to be held for indefinite periods of time and not intended to be held to maturity are classified as securities available for sale and are reported at estimated fair value, with unrealized gains and losses excluded from earnings and reported as a separate component of stockholders equity, net of deferred taxes.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P16_S0	PROVIDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES, INC. AND SUBSIDIARY Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements December 31, 2010, 2009 and 2008 The estimated fair values of the Company s securities are affected by changes in interest rates, credit spreads, and market illiquidity.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P16_S1	The Company conducts a periodic review and evaluation of the securities portfolio to determine if any declines in the fair values of securities are other-than-temporary.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P16_S2	To determine if a decline in value is other-than- temporary, the Company evaluates if it has the intent to sell these securities or if it is more likely than not that the Company would be required to sell the securities before the anticipated recovery.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P16_S3	If such a decline were deemed other-than-temporary, the Company would measure the total credit-related component of the unrealized loss, and recognize that portion of the loss as a charge to current period earnings.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P16_S4	The remaining portion of the unrealized loss would be recognized as an adjustment to accumulated other comprehensive income.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P17_S0	In general, as interest rates rise, the market value of fixed-rate securities decreases and as interest rates fall, the market value of fixed-rate securities increases.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P18_S0	Turmoil in the credit markets resulted in a lack of liquidity in certain sectors of the mortgage-backed securities market.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P18_S1	Increases in delinquencies and foreclosures have resulted in limited trading activity and significant price declines, regardless of favorable movements in interest rates.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P19_S0	To determine if a decline in value is other-than- temporary, the Company evaluates if it has the intent to sell these securities or if it is more likely than not that the Company would be required to sell the securities before the anticipated recovery.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P20_S0	Premiums and discounts on securities are amortized and accreted to income using a method that approximates the interest method over the remaining period to contractual maturity, adjusted for anticipated prepayments.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P20_S1	Dividend and interest income are recognized when earned.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P21_S0	The cost of securities sold is based on the specific identification method.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P22_S0	Fair Value of Financial Instruments GAAP establishes a fair value hierarchy that prioritizes the inputs to valuation techniques used to measure fair value.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P22_S1	The hierarchy gives the highest priority to unadjusted quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities (level 1 measurements) and the lowest priority to unobservable inputs (level 3 measurements).
1178970_11_ITEM8_P22_S2	The three levels of fair value hierarchy are as follows:
1178970_11_ITEM8_P23_S0	Prices or valuation techniques that require inputs that are both significant to the fair value measurement and unobservable (i.e., supported by little or no market activity).
1178970_11_ITEM8_P24_S0	A financial instrument s level within the fair value hierarchy is based on the lowest level of input that is significant to the fair value measurement.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P25_S0	Federal Home Loan Bank of New York Stock The Bank, as a member of the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York ( FHLB ), is required to hold shares of capital stock of the FHLB at cost based on a specified formula.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P25_S1	The Bank carries this investment at cost, which approximates fair value.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P25_S2	Loans Loans receivable are carried at unpaid principal balances plus unamortized premiums, purchase accounting mark-to-market adjustments, certain deferred direct loan origination costs and deferred loan origination fees and discounts, less the allowance for loan losses.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P26_S0	The Bank defers loan origination fees and certain direct loan origination costs and accretes such amounts as an adjustment of yield over the expected lives of the related loans using the interest method.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P26_S1	Premiums and discounts on loans purchased are amortized or accreted as an adjustment of yield over the contractual lives, of the related loans, adjusted for prepayments when applicable, using methodologies which approximate the interest method.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P26_S2	Loans are generally placed on non-accrual status when they are past due 90 days or more as to contractual obligations or when other circumstances indicate that collection is questionable.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P26_S3	When a loan is placed on non-accrual status, any interest accrued but not received is reversed against interest income.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P26_S4	Payments received on a non-accrual loan are either applied to the outstanding principal balance or recorded as interest income, depending on an assessment of the ability to collect the loan.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P26_S5	A non-accrual loan is restored to accrual status when principal and interest payments become less than 90 days past due and its future collectibility is reasonably assured.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P27_S0	An impaired loan is defined as a loan for which it is probable, based on current information, that the lender will not collect all amounts due under the contractual terms of the loan agreement.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P27_S1	Impaired loans are individually assessed to determine that each loan s carrying value is not in excess of the fair value of the related collateral or the present value of the expected future cash flows.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P27_S2	Residential mortgage and consumer loans are deemed smaller balance homogeneous loans which are evaluated collectively for impairment and are therefore excluded from the population of impaired loans.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P28_S0	Allowance for Loan Losses Losses on loans are charged to the allowance for loan losses.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P28_S1	Additions to this allowance are made by recoveries of loans previously charged off and by a provision charged to expense.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P29_S0	The determination of the balance of the allowance for loan losses is based on an analysis of the loan portfolio, economic conditions, historical loan loss experience and other factors that warrant recognition in providing for an adequate allowance.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P29_S1	While management uses available information to recognize losses on loans, future additions to the allowance for loan losses may be necessary based on changes in economic conditions in the Bank s market area.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P29_S2	In addition, various regulatory agencies, as an integral part of their examination process, periodically review the Bank s allowance for loan losses.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P29_S3	Such agencies may require the Bank to recognize additions to the allowance or additional write-downs based on their judgments about information available to them at the time of their examination.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P30_S0	Foreclosed Assets Assets acquired through foreclosure or deed in lieu of foreclosure are carried at the lower of the outstanding loan balance at the time of foreclosure or fair value, less estimated costs to sell.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P30_S1	Fair value is generally based on recent appraisals.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P30_S2	When an asset is acquired, the excess of the loan balance over fair value, less estimated costs to sell, is charged to the allowance for loan losses.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P31_S0	A reserve for foreclosed assets may be established to provide for possible write-downs and selling costs that occur subsequent to foreclosure.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P31_S1	Foreclosed assets are carried net of the related reserve.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P32_S0	Operating results from real estate owned, including rental income, operating expenses, and gains and losses realized from the sales of real estate owned, are recorded as incurred.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P32_S1	Banking Premises and Equipment Land is carried at cost.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P33_S0	(generally 25 to 40 years for buildings and 3 to 5 years for furniture and equipment).
1178970_11_ITEM8_P34_S0	Leasehold improvements, carried at cost, net of accumulated depreciation, are amortized over the terms of the leases or the estimated useful lives of the assets, whichever are shorter, using the straight-line method.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P34_S1	Maintenance and repairs are charged to expense as incurred.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P35_S0	Income Taxes The Company uses the asset and liability method of accounting for income taxes.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P35_S1	Under this method, deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the estimated future tax consequences attributable to differences between the financial statement carrying amounts of existing assets and liabilities and their respective tax bases.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P35_S2	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured using enacted tax rates in effect for the year in which those temporary differences are expected to be recovered or settled.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P35_S3	The effect on deferred tax assets and liabilities of a change in tax rates is recognized in income in the period that includes the enactment date.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P35_S4	The determination of whether deferred tax assets will be realizable is predicated on estimates of future taxable income.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P35_S5	Such estimates are subject to management s judgment.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P36_S0	A valuation reserve is established when management is unable to conclude that it is more likely than not that it will realize deferred tax assets based on the nature and timing of these items.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P37_S0	The Company recognizes, when applicable, interest and penalties related to unrecognized tax benefits in the provision for income taxes.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P38_S0	Trust Assets Trust assets consisting of securities and other property (other than cash on deposit held by the Bank in fiduciary or agency capacities for customers of the Bank s Wealth Management Group) are not included in the accompanying consolidated statements of financial condition because such properties are not assets of the Bank.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P38_S1	Intangible Assets Intangible assets of the Bank consist of goodwill, core deposit premiums, and mortgage servicing rights.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P38_S2	Goodwill represents the excess of the purchase price over the estimated fair value of identifiable net assets acquired through purchase acquisitions.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P38_S3	In accordance with GAAP, goodwill with an indefinite useful life is not amortized, but is evaluated for impairment on an annual basis, or more frequently if events or changes in circumstances indicate potential impairment between annual measurement dates.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P38_S4	Goodwill is analyzed for impairment each year at September 30, and the impairment test at September 30, 2010 indicated that there was no impairment.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P39_S0	Core deposit premiums represent the intangible value of depositor relationships assumed in purchase acquisitions and are amortized on an accelerated basis over 8.8 years.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P40_S0	Mortgage servicing rights are recorded when purchased or when originated mortgage loans are sold, with servicing rights retained.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P40_S1	Mortgage servicing rights are amortized on an accelerated method based upon the estimated lives of the related loans, adjusted for prepayments.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P40_S2	Mortgage servicing rights are carried at the lower of amortized cost or fair value.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P41_S0	Bank-owned Life Insurance Bank-owned life insurance is accounted for using the cash surrender value method and is recorded at its realizable value.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P42_S0	The Bank maintains a pension plan which covers full-time employees hired prior to April 1, 2003.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P42_S1	The Bank s policy is to fund at least the minimum contribution required by the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P42_S2	On April 1, 2003, the pension plan was frozen.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P43_S0	GAAP requires an employer to: (a) recognize in its statement of financial position the over-funded or under-funded status of a defined benefit postretirement plan measured as the difference between the fair value of plan assets and the benefit obligation; (b) measure a plan s assets and its obligations that determine its funded status at the end of the employer s fiscal year (with limited exceptions); and (c) recognize as a component of other comprehensive income, net of tax, the actuarial gains and losses and the prior service costs and credits that arise during the period.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P44_S0	The Bank has a 401(k) plan covering substantially all employees of the Bank.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P44_S1	The Bank may match a percentage of the first 6% contributed by participants.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P44_S2	The Bank s matching contribution, if any, is determined by the Board of Directors in its sole discretion.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P45_S0	The Bank has an Employee Stock Ownership Plan ( ESOP ).
1178970_11_ITEM8_P45_S1	The funds borrowed by the ESOP from the Company to purchase the Company s common stock are being repaid from the Bank s contributions and dividends paid on unallocated ESOP shares over a period of up to 30 years.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P45_S2	The Company s common stock not allocated to participants is recorded as a reduction of stockholders equity at cost.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P45_S3	Compensation expense for the ESOP is based on the average price of the Company s stock during each quarter.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P45_S4	Expense related to stock options is based on the fair value of the options at the date of the grant and is recognized ratably over the vesting period of the options.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P45_S5	Expense related to stock awards is based on the fair value of the common stock at the date of the grant and is recognized ratably over the vesting period of the awards.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P46_S0	In connection with the First Sentinel acquisition in July 2004, the Company assumed the First Savings Bank Directors Deferred Fee Plan (the DDFP ).
1178970_11_ITEM8_P46_S1	The DDFP was frozen prior to the acquisition.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P46_S2	The Company recorded a deferred compensation equity instrument and corresponding contra-equity account for the value of the shares held by the DDFP at the July 14, 2004 acquisition date.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P46_S3	These accounts will be liquidated as shares are distributed from the DDFP in accordance with the plan document.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P46_S4	At December 31, 2010, there were 428,003 shares held by the DDFP.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P47_S0	The Bank provides postretirement health care and life insurance plans to certain of its employees.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P47_S1	The life insurance coverage is noncontributory to the participant.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P47_S2	Participants contribute to the cost of medical coverage based on the employee s length of service with the Bank.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P47_S3	The costs of such benefits are accrued based on actuarial assumptions from the date of hire to the date the employee is fully eligible to receive the benefits.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P48_S0	On December 31, 2002, the Bank eliminated postretirement healthcare benefits for employees with less than 10 years of service.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P49_S0	GAAP requires an employer to: (a) recognize in its statement of financial position the over-funded or under-funded status of a defined benefit postretirement plan measured as the difference between the fair value of plan assets and the benefit obligation; (b) measure a plan s assets and its obligations that determine its funded status as of the end of the employer s fiscal year (with limited exceptions); and (c) recognize as a component of other comprehensive income, net of tax, the actuarial gains and losses and the prior service costs and credits that arise during the period.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P50_S0	PROVIDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES, INC. AND SUBSIDIARY Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements December 31, 2010, 2009 and 2008 Comprehensive Income Comprehensive income is divided into net income and other comprehensive income.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P50_S1	Other comprehensive income includes items previously recorded directly to equity, such as unrealized gains and losses on securities available for sale and amortization related to post-retirement obligations.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P50_S2	Comprehensive income is presented in the Statements of Changes in Stockholders Equity.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P51_S0	Reporting The Company s operations are solely in the financial services industry and include providing to its customers traditional banking and other financial services.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P52_S0	The Company operates primarily in the geographical regions of northern and central New Jersey.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P53_S0	Management makes operating decisions and assesses performance based on an ongoing review of the Bank s consolidated financial results.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P53_S1	Therefore, the Company has a single operating segment for financial reporting purposes.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P54_S0	Basic earnings per share is computed by dividing income available to common stockholders by the weighted average number of shares outstanding for the period.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P54_S1	Diluted earnings per share reflects the potential dilution that could occur if securities or other contracts to issue common stock (such as stock options) were exercised or resulted in the issuance of common stock.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P54_S2	These potentially dilutive shares would then be included in the weighted average number of shares outstanding for the period using the treasury stock method.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P55_S0	Shares issued and shares reacquired during the period are weighted for the portion of the period that they were outstanding.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P56_S0	Impact of Recent Accounting Pronouncements In January 2011, the Financial Accounting Standards Board ( FASB ) issued guidance temporarily delaying the effective date of additional disclosures about troubled debt restructurings.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P56_S1	The delay is intended to allow the FASB time to complete its deliberations on what constitutes a troubled debt restructuring.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P56_S2	The effective date of the new disclosures about troubled debt restructurings for public entities and the guidance for determining what constitutes a troubled debt restructuring will then be coordinated.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P56_S3	The deferral is effective upon issuance.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P57_S0	In July 2010, the FASB issued guidance to enhance the disclosures that an entity provides about the credit quality of its financing receivables and the related allowance for credit losses.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P57_S1	As a result of this guidance, an entity is required to disaggregate by portfolio segment or class certain existing disclosures and provide certain new disclosures about its financing receivables and related allowance for credit losses.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P57_S2	The disclosures as of the end of a reporting period are effective for interim and annual reporting periods ending on or after December 15, 2010.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P57_S3	The disclosures about activity that occurs during a reporting period are effective for interim and annual reporting periods beginning on or after December 15, 2010.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P57_S4	The amendments in this guidance encourage, but do not require, comparative disclosures for earlier reporting periods that ended before initial adoption.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P57_S5	However, an entity should provide comparative disclosures for those reporting periods ending after initial adoption.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P57_S6	The adoption of this guidance is reflected in the Company s consolidated financial statements at December 31, 2010.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P58_S0	In April 2010, the FASB issued guidance under which modifications of loans that are accounted for within a pool do not result in the removal of those loans from the pool even if the modification of those loans would otherwise be considered a troubled debt restructuring.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P58_S1	An entity will continue to be required to consider whether the pool of assets in which the loan is included is impaired if expected cash flows for the pool change.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P59_S0	update became effective for the Company for the interim reporting period beginning after June 15, 2010 and did not have a material impact on the Company s financial condition, results of operations or financial statement disclosures.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P59_S1	In January 2010, the FASB issued guidance that will require more robust disclosures about: the different classes of assets and liabilities measured at fair value; the valuation techniques and inputs used; the activity in Level 3 fair value measurements; and the transfers between Levels 1, 2, and 3.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P59_S2	The disclosure requirements relating to Level 3 measurements are effective for fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2010, and for interim periods within those fiscal years.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P59_S3	All other requirements of this guidance are effective in interim and annual periods beginning after December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P59_S4	The adoption of the required components of this guidance did not have a material impact on the Company s financial condition, results of operations or financial statement disclosures.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P59_S5	Effective January 1, 2010, the Company adopted the amended guidance on the consolidation of variable interest entities.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P59_S6	This guidance affects all entities and enterprises currently within its scope, as well as qualifying special purpose entities that were previously outside of its scope, and is effective for fiscal years beginning after November 15, 2009, with early adoption prohibited.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P59_S7	The adoption of this guidance did not have a material impact on the Company s financial condition, results of operations or financial statement disclosures.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P60_S0	On January 15, 2003, the Bank completed its plan of conversion, and the Bank became a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Company.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P60_S1	The Company sold 59.6 million shares of common stock (par value $0.01 per share) at $10.00 per share.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P60_S2	The Company received net proceeds in the amount of $567.2 million.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P60_S3	In connection with the Bank s commitment to its community, the plan of conversion provided for the establishment of a charitable foundation.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P60_S4	Provident donated $4.8 million in cash and 1.92 million of authorized but unissued shares of common stock to the foundation, which amounted to $24.0 million in aggregate.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P61_S0	The Company recognized an expense, net of income tax benefit, equal to the cash and fair value of the stock during 2003.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P61_S1	Conversion costs were deferred and deducted from the proceeds of the shares sold in the offering.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P61_S2	Upon completion of the plan of conversion, a liquidation account was established in an amount equal to the total equity of the Bank as of the latest practicable date prior to the conversion.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P61_S3	The liquidation account was established to provide a limited priority claim to the assets of the Bank to eligible account holders and supplemental eligible account holders as defined in the Plan, who continue to maintain deposits in the Bank after the conversion.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P61_S4	In the unlikely event of a complete liquidation of the Bank, and only in such event, each eligible account holder and supplemental eligible account holder would receive a liquidation distribution, prior to any payment to the holder of the Bank s common stock.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P61_S5	This distribution would be based upon each eligible account holder s and supplemental eligible account holder s proportionate share of the then total remaining qualifying deposits.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P61_S6	At December 31, 2010, the liquidation account, which is an off-balance sheet memorandum account, amounted to $25,959,000.

1178970_11_ITEM8_P80_S0	An impaired loan is defined as a non-homogenous loan greater than $1.0 million for which it is probable, based on current information, that the Bank will not collect all amounts due under the contractual terms of the loan agreement.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P80_S1	Impaired loans also include all loans modified as troubled debt restructurings ( TDRs ).
1178970_11_ITEM8_P80_S2	A loan is deemed to be a TDR when a modification resulting in a concession is made by the Bank in an effort to mitigate potential loss arising from a borrower s financial difficulty.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P80_S3	Smaller balance homogeneous loans including residential mortgages and other consumer loans are evaluated collectively for impairment and are excluded from the definition of impaired loans.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P81_S0	Impaired loans are individually identified and reviewed to determine that each loan s carrying value is not in excess of the fair value of the related collateral or the present value of the expected future cash flows.

1178970_11_ITEM8_P81_S2	Included in this total were 6 TDRs to 5 borrowers totaling $7.6 million that were performing in accordance with their restructured terms and which continued to accrue interest at December 31, 2010.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P82_S0	The Company separately calculates the reserve for loan loss on impaired loans.

1178970_11_ITEM8_P86_S0	In the normal course of conducting its business, the Bank extends credit to meet the financing needs of its customers through commitments.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P86_S1	Commitments and contingent liabilities, such as commitments to extend credit (including loan commitments of $474,208,000 and $517,624,000, at December 31, 2010 and 2009, respectively, and undisbursed home equity and personal credit lines of $258,012,000 and $250,269,000, at December 31, 2010 and 2009, respectively), exist, which are not reflected in the accompanying consolidated financial statements.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P87_S0	These instruments involve elements of credit and interest rate risk in excess of the amount recognized in the consolidated financial statements.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P88_S0	The Bank uses the same credit policies and collateral requirements in making commitments and conditional obligations as it does for on-balance sheet loans.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P88_S1	Commitments generally have fixed expiration dates or other termination clauses and may require payment of a fee.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P88_S2	Since the commitments may expire without being drawn upon, the total commitment amounts do not necessarily represent future cash requirements.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P89_S0	The Bank evaluates each customer s creditworthiness on a case-by-case basis.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P89_S1	The amount of collateral obtained, if deemed necessary by the Bank upon extension of credit, is based on management s credit evaluation of the borrower.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P90_S0	The Bank grants residential real estate loans on single- and multi-family dwellings to borrowers primarily in New Jersey.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P90_S1	Its borrowers abilities to repay their obligations are dependent upon various factors, including the borrowers income and net worth, cash flows generated by the underlying collateral, value of the underlying collateral, and priority of the Bank s lien on the property.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P90_S2	Such factors are dependent upon various economic conditions and individual circumstances beyond the Bank s control; the Bank is therefore subject to risk of loss.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P90_S3	The Bank believes that its lending policies and procedures adequately minimize the potential exposure to such risks and that adequate provisions for loan losses are provided for all known and inherent risks.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P91_S0	Collateral and/or guarantees are required for virtually all loans.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P91_S1	The Company utilizes an internal nine-point risk rating system to summarize its loan portfolio into categories with similar characteristics.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P91_S2	Loans deemed to be acceptable quality are rated 1 through 4, with a rating of 1 established for loans with minimal risk.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P91_S3	Loans that are deemed to be of questionable quality are rated 5 (watch) or 6 (special mention).
1178970_11_ITEM8_P91_S4	Loans with adverse classifications (substandard, doubtful or loss) are rated 7, 8 or 9, respectively.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P91_S5	Commercial mortgage, commercial, multi-family and construction loans are rated individually, and each lending officer is responsible for risk rating loans in his or her portfolio.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P91_S6	These risk ratings are then reviewed by the department manager and/or the Chief Lending Officer and by the Credit Administration Department.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P91_S7	The risk ratings are also confirmed through periodic loan review examinations, which are currently performed by an independent third party.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P91_S8	Reports by the independent third party are presented directly to the Audit Committee of the Board of Directors.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P92_S0	Loans receivable by credit quality risk rating indicator is as follows (in thousands):

1178970_11_ITEM8_P100_S0	The Bank has a noncontributory defined benefit pension plan covering its full-time employees who had attained age 21 with at least one year of service as of April 1, 2003.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P100_S1	The pension plan was frozen on April 1, 2003.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P101_S0	All participants in the pension plan are 100% vested.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P101_S1	The pension plan s assets are invested in investment funds and group annuity contracts currently managed by the Principal Financial Group and Allmerica Financial.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P101_S2	Based on the measurement date of December 31, 2010, management believes that no contributions will be made to the pension plan in 2011.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P102_S0	In addition to pension benefits, certain healthcare and life insurance benefits are currently made available to certain of the Bank s retired employees.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P102_S1	The costs of such benefits are accrued based on actuarial assumptions from the date of hire to the date the employee is fully eligible to receive the benefits.

1178970_11_ITEM8_P105_S1	The most significant of these is the discount rate used to calculate the period-end present value of the benefit obligations, and the expense to be included in the following year s financial statements.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P105_S2	A lower discount rate will result in a higher benefit obligation and expense, while a higher discount rate will result in a lower benefit obligation and expense.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P105_S3	The discount rate assumption was determined based on a cash flow-yield curve model specific to the Company s pension and post-retirement plans.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P105_S4	We compare this rate to certain market indices, such as long-term treasury bonds, or the Citigroup pension liability indices, for reasonableness.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P106_S0	A discount rate of 5.50% was selected for the December 31, 2010 measurement date and the 2010 expense calculation.

1178970_11_ITEM8_P116_S0	The Bank maintains a Retirement Plan for the Board of Directors of the Bank, a non-qualified plan that provides cash payments for up to ten years to eligible retired board members based on age and length of service requirements.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P116_S1	The maximum payment under this plan to a board member, who terminates service on or after the age of 72 with at least ten years of service on the board, is forty quarterly payments of $1,250.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P116_S2	The Bank may suspend payments under this plan if it does not meet Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation or New Jersey Department of Banking and Insurance minimum capital requirements.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P116_S3	The Bank may terminate this plan at any time although such termination may not reduce or eliminate any benefit previously accrued to a board member without his or her consent.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P116_S4	The plan further provides that, in the event of a change in control (as defined in the plan), the undistributed balance of a director s accrued benefit will be distributed to him or her within 60 days of the change in control.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P116_S5	The Bank paid $15,000 to former board members under this plan for each of the years ended December 31, 2010, 2009 and 2008.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P116_S6	At December 31, 2010 and 2009, $221,000 and $229,000, respectively, were recorded in other liabilities on the consolidated statements of financial condition for this retirement plan.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P116_S7	A decrease of $14,000, an increase of $29,000, and a decrease of $4,000, net of tax, were recorded in other comprehensive income for 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively, in connection with this plan.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P116_S8	The plan was amended in December 2005 to terminate benefits under this plan for any directors who had less than ten years of service on the board of directors of the Bank as of December 31, 2006.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P117_S0	The ESOP is a tax-qualified plan designed to invest primarily in the Company s common stock that provides employees with the opportunity to receive a funded retirement benefit from the Bank, based primarily on the value of the Company s common stock.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P117_S1	The ESOP purchased 4,769,464 shares of the Company s common stock at an average price of $17.09 per share with the proceeds of a loan from the Company to the ESOP.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P117_S2	The outstanding loan principal at December 31, 2010, was $65.4 million.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P117_S3	Shares of the Company s common stock pledged as collateral for the loan are released from the pledge for allocation to participants as loan payments are made.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P117_S4	For the ESOP years ending December 31, 2010 and 2009, 178,510 shares and 175,474 shares were released, respectively.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P117_S5	Unallocated ESOP shares held in suspense totaled 3,429,300 at December 31, 2010, and had a fair market value of $51.9 million.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P117_S6	ESOP compensation expense for the years ended December 31, 2010, 2009 and 2008 was $1,840,000, $1,494,000 and $2,162,000, respectively.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P118_S0	The Supplemental Executive Savings Plan is a non-qualified plan that provides supplemental benefits to certain executives who are prevented from receiving the full benefits contemplated by the 401(k) Plan s and the ESOP s benefit formulas under tax law limits for tax-qualified plans.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P118_S1	The Supplemental Executive Savings Plan was frozen effective December 31, 2003, and all benefit distributions have been made.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P119_S0	Effective January 1, 2004, the Bank established a deferred compensation plan for executive management and key employees of the Bank, known as The Provident Bank Non-Qualified Supplemental Employee Stock Ownership Plan (the Supplemental ESOP ).
1178970_11_ITEM8_P119_S1	The Supplemental ESOP was amended and restated as the Non-Qualified Supplemental Defined Contribution Plan (the Supplemental DC Plan ), effective January 1, 2010.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P119_S2	The Supplemental DC Plan is a non-qualified plan that provides additional benefits to certain executives whose benefits under the 401(k) Plan and ESOP are limited by tax law limitations applicable to tax-qualified plans.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P119_S3	The Supplemental DC Plan requires a contribution by the Bank for each participant who also participates in the 401(k) Plan and ESOP equal to the amount that would have been contributed under the terms of the of the 401(k) Plan and ESOP but for the tax law limitations, less the amount actually contributed under the 401(k) Plan and ESOP.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P119_S4	The Supplemental DC Plan provides for a phantom stock allocation for qualified contributions that may not be accrued in the qualified ESOP and for matching contributions that may not be accrued in the qualified 401(k) Plan due to tax law limitations.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P119_S5	Under the Supplemental 401(k) provision, the estimated expense for the year ending December 31, 2010 was approximately $5,000 and included the matching contributions plus interest credited at an annual rate equal to the ten-year bond-equivalent yield on US Treasury securities.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P119_S6	Under the Supplemental ESOP provision, the estimated expense for the year ending December 31, 2010 was $17,000.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P119_S7	The phantom equity will be treated as equity awards (expensed at the time of allocation) and not liability awards which would require periodic adjustment to market, since participants do not have an option to take their distribution in cash.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P119_S8	Prior year expense under the Supplemental ESOP for years ended December 31,2009 and 2008 was ($46,000) and $33,000 respectively.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P120_S0	Long-Term Equity Incentive Plan Upon stockholders approval of the 2008 Long-Term Equity Incentive Plan on April 23, 2008, shares available for stock awards and stock options under the 2003 Stock Award Plan and the 2003 Stock Option Plan were reserved for issuance under the new 2008 Long-Term Equity Incentive Plan.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P120_S1	No additional grants of stock awards and stock options will be made under the 2003 Stock Award Plan and the 2003 Stock Option Plan.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P120_S2	The new plan authorized the issuance of up to 2,481,382 shares of Company common stock with no more than 1,850,000 shares permitted to be issued as stock awards.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P120_S3	Shares previously awarded under the 2003 plans that are subsequently forfeited or expire may also be issued under the new plan.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P121_S0	Stock Awards As a general rule, restricted stock grants are held in escrow for the benefit of the award recipient until vested.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P121_S1	Awards outstanding generally vest in three or five annual installments, commencing one year from the date of the award.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P121_S2	Additionally, certain awards are three-year performance vesting awards, which may or may not vest depending upon the attainment of certain corporate financial targets.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P121_S3	Expense attributable to stock awards amounted to $2,422,000, $1,888,000 and $2,701,000 for the years ended December 31, 2010, 2009 and 2008, respectively.

1178970_11_ITEM8_P123_S0	Each stock option granted entitles the holder to purchase one share of the Company s common stock at an exercise price not less than the fair market value of a share of the Company s common stock at the date of grant.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P123_S1	Options generally vest over a five-year period from the date of grant and expire no later than 10 years following the grant date.

1178970_11_ITEM8_P127_S0	The fair value of the Company stock option awards are expensed on a straight-line basis over the vesting period of the stock option.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P127_S1	The risk-free rate is based on the implied yield on a U.S. Treasury bond with a term approximating the expected term of the option.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P127_S2	The expected volatility computation is based on historical volatility over a period approximating the expected term of the option.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P127_S3	The dividend yield is based on the annual dividend payment per share, divided by the grant date stock price.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P128_S0	The expected option term is a function of the option life and the vesting period.

1178970_11_ITEM8_P133_S8	In order to fully realize the net deferred tax asset, the Company will need to generate future taxable income.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P133_S9	Management has projected that the Company will generate sufficient taxable income to utilize the net deferred tax asset; however, there can be no assurance that such levels of taxable income will be generated.

1178970_11_ITEM8_P137_S1	In the opinion of management, the consolidated financial position of the Company will not be materially affected by the outcome of such commitments or contingent liabilities.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P138_S0	A substantial portion of the Bank s loans are one- to four-family residential first mortgage loans secured by real estate located in New Jersey.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P138_S1	Accordingly, the collectability of a substantial portion of the Bank s loan portfolio and the recovery of a substantial portion of the carrying amount of other real estate owned are susceptible to changes in local real estate market conditions.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P139_S0	(15) Regulatory Capital Requirements FDIC regulations require banks to maintain minimum levels of regulatory capital.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P139_S1	Under the regulations in effect at December 31, 2010 and 2009, the Bank is required to maintain (i) a minimum leverage ratio of Tier 1 capital to total adjusted assets of 4.00%, and (ii) minimum ratios of Tier 1 and total capital to risk-weighted assets of 4.00% and 8.00%, respectively.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P140_S0	Under its prompt corrective action regulations, the FDIC is required to take certain supervisory actions (and may take additional discretionary actions) with respect to an undercapitalized institution.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P140_S1	Such actions could have a direct material effect on an institution s financial statements.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P141_S0	classification of savings institutions into five categories: well capitalized, adequately capitalized, undercapitalized, significantly undercapitalized, and critically undercapitalized.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P142_S0	Generally, an institution is considered well capitalized if it has a leverage (Tier 1) capital ratio of at least 5.00%; a Tier 1 risk-based capital ratio of at least 6.00%; and a total risk-based capital ratio of at least 10.00%.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P143_S0	The foregoing capital ratios are based in part on specific quantitative measures of assets, liabilities and certain off-balance sheet items as calculated under regulatory accounting practices.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P143_S1	Capital amounts and classifications are also subject to qualitative judgments by the FDIC about capital components, risk weightings and other factors.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P144_S0	As of December 31, 2010 and 2009, the Bank exceeded all minimum capital adequacy requirements to which it is subject.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P144_S1	Further, the most recent FDIC notification categorized the Bank as a well capitalized institution under the prompt corrective action regulations.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P144_S2	There have been no conditions or events since that notification that management believes have changed the Bank s capital classification.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P145_S0	The Company is regulated as a bank holding company, and as such, is subject to examination, regulation and periodic reporting under the Bank Holding Company Act, as administered by the Federal Reserve Board ( FRB ).
1178970_11_ITEM8_P145_S1	The FRB has adopted capital adequacy guidelines for bank holding companies on a consolidated basis substantially similar to those of the FDIC for the Bank.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P145_S2	As of December 31, 2010 and 2009, the Company was well capitalized under FRB guidelines.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P146_S0	Regulations of the FRB provide that a bank holding company must serve as a source of strength to any of its subsidiary banks and must not conduct its activities in an unsafe or unsound manner.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P146_S1	Under the prompt corrective action provisions discussed above, a bank holding company parent of an undercapitalized subsidiary bank would be directed to guarantee, within limitations, the capital restoration plan that is required of such an undercapitalized bank.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P146_S2	If the undercapitalized bank fails to file an acceptable capital restoration plan or fails to implement an accepted plan, the FRB may prohibit the bank holding company parent of the undercapitalized bank from paying any dividend or making any other form of capital distribution without the prior approval of the FRB.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P147_S0	The following is a summary of the Company s actual capital amounts and ratios as of December 31, 2010 and 2009, compared to the FRB minimum capital adequacy requirements and the FRB requirements for classification as a well-capitalized institution (dollars in thousands).
1178970_11_ITEM8_P148_S0	The following is a summary of the Bank s actual capital amounts and ratios as of December 31, 2010 and 2009, compared to the FDIC minimum capital adequacy requirements and the FDIC requirements for classification as a well-capitalized institution (dollars in thousands).
1178970_11_ITEM8_P149_S0	The following tables present the assets and liabilities reported on the consolidated statements of financial condition at their fair value as of December 31, 2010 and 2009, by level within the fair value hierarchy (in thousands).
1178970_11_ITEM8_P150_S0	The following valuation techniques are based upon the unpaid principal balance only and exclude any accrued interest or dividends at the measurement date.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P150_S1	Interest income and expense and dividend income are recorded within the consolidated statements of income depending on the nature of the instrument using the effective interest method based on acquired discount or premium.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P151_S0	The valuation techniques described below were used to measure fair value of financial instruments in the preceding table on a recurring basis during the years ended December 31, 2010 and 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P152_S0	For securities available for sale, fair value was estimated using a market approach.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P153_S0	The majority of the Company s securities are fixed income instruments that are not quoted on an exchange, but are traded in active markets.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P153_S1	Prices for these instruments are obtained through third party data service providers or dealer market participants with which the Company has historically transacted both purchases and sales of securities.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P153_S2	Prices obtained from these sources include market quotations and matrix pricing.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P154_S0	Matrix pricing, a Level 2 input, is a mathematical technique used principally to value certain securities to benchmark or comparable securities.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P154_S1	The Company evaluates the quality of Level 2 matrix pricing through comparison to similar assets with greater liquidity and evaluation of projected cash flows.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P154_S2	The Company also may hold equity securities and debt instruments issued by the U.S. government and U.S. government-sponsored agencies that are traded in active markets with readily accessible quoted market prices that are considered Level 1 inputs.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P155_S0	The valuation techniques described below were used to measure fair value of financial instruments in the preceding table on a non-recurring basis during the years ended December 31, 2010 and 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P156_S0	For loans measured for impairment based on the fair value of the underlying collateral, fair value was estimated using a market approach.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P156_S1	The Company measures the fair value of collateral underlying impaired loans primarily through obtaining independent appraisals that rely upon quoted market prices for similar assets in active markets.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P156_S2	These appraisals include adjustments to comparable assets based on the appraisers market knowledge and experience, and are considered Level 3 inputs.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P157_S0	Assets acquired through foreclosure or deed in lieu of foreclosure included in the preceding table are carried at fair value, less estimated costs to sell.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P158_S0	quoted market prices for similar assets in active markets.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P158_S1	These appraisals include adjustments to comparable assets based on the appraisers market knowledge and experience, and are considered Level 3 inputs.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P159_S0	When an asset is acquired, the excess of the loan balance over fair value, less estimated costs to sell, is charged to the allowance for loan losses.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P160_S0	A reserve for foreclosed assets may be established to provide for possible write-downs and selling costs that occur subsequent to foreclosure.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P160_S1	Foreclosed assets are carried net of the related reserve.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P161_S0	Operating results from real estate owned, including rental income, operating expenses, and gains and losses realized from the sales of real estate owned, are recorded as incurred.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P162_S0	The fair value of goodwill is determined in the same manner as goodwill recognized in a business combination and uses standard valuation methodologies.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P162_S1	Fair value may be determined using market prices, comparison to similar assets, market multiples, discounted cash flow analysis and other factors.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P163_S0	Estimated cash flows may extend far into the future and by their nature are difficult to determine over an extended time frame.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P163_S1	Factors that may significantly affect the estimates include specific industry or market sector conditions, changes in revenue growth trends, customer behavior, competitive forces, cost structures and changes in discount rates.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P164_S0	The Company recognized a goodwill impairment charge of $152.5 million during the year ended December 31, 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P164_S1	There were no changes to the valuation techniques for fair value measurement during the years ended December 31, 2010 and 2009.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P165_S0	(17) Fair Value of Financial Instruments Fair value estimates, methods and assumptions are set forth below for the Company s financial instruments.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P166_S0	Cash and Cash Equivalents For cash and due from banks, federal funds sold and short-term investments, the carrying amount approximates fair value.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P167_S0	The fair value of investment securities and securities available for sale is estimated using a market approach.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P167_S1	The majority of the Company s securities are fixed income instruments that are not quoted on an exchange, but are traded in active markets.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P167_S2	Prices for these instruments are obtained through third party data service providers or dealer market participants with which the Company has historically transacted both purchases and sales of securities.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P167_S3	Prices obtained from these sources include market quotations and matrix pricing.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P167_S4	The Company also holds debt instruments issued by the U.S. government and U.S. government-sponsored agencies that are traded in active markets with readily accessible quoted market prices.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P168_S0	FHLB-NY stock The carrying value of FHLB-NY stock is its cost.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P168_S1	The fair value of FHLB-NY stock is based on redemption at par value.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P169_S0	Loans Fair values are estimated for portfolios of loans with similar financial characteristics.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P169_S1	Loans are segregated by type such as residential mortgage, construction and consumer.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P169_S2	Each loan category is further segmented into fixed and adjustable rate interest terms and into performing and non-performing categories.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P170_S0	PROVIDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES, INC. AND SUBSIDIARY Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements December 31, 2010, 2009 and 2008 The fair value of performing loans is estimated using a combination of techniques, including discounting estimated future cash flows and quoted market prices of similar instruments, where available.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P170_S1	The fair value for significant non-performing loans is based on recent external appraisals of collateral securing such loans, adjusted for the timing of anticipated cash flows.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P171_S0	Deposits The fair value of deposits with no stated maturity, such as non-interest bearing demand deposits and savings deposits, is equal to the amount payable on demand.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P171_S1	The fair value of certificates of deposit is based on the discounted value of contractual cash flows.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P171_S2	The discount rate is estimated using the rates currently offered for deposits with similar remaining maturities.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P171_S3	The fair value of borrowed funds is estimated by discounting future cash flows using rates available for debt with similar terms and maturities.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P171_S4	The fair value of commitments to extend credit and letters of credit is estimated using the fees currently charged to enter into similar agreements, taking into account the remaining terms of the agreements and the present creditworthiness of the counterparties.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P172_S0	For fixed rate loan commitments, fair value also considers the difference between current levels of interest rates and the committed rates.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P172_S1	The fair value estimates of commitments to extend credit and standby letters of credit are deemed immaterial.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P172_S2	The estimated fair values of the Company s financial instruments as of December 31, 2010 and 2009 are presented in the following table (in thousands): Limitations Fair value estimates are made at a specific point in time, based on relevant market information and information about the financial instrument.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P172_S3	These estimates do not reflect any premium or discount that could result from offering for sale at one time the Company s entire holdings of a particular financial instrument.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P173_S0	estimates are based on judgments regarding future expected loss experience, current economic conditions, risk characteristics of various financial instruments, and other factors.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P173_S1	These estimates are subjective in nature and involve uncertainties and matters of significant judgment and, therefore, cannot be determined with precision.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P173_S2	Changes in assumptions could significantly affect the estimates.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P174_S0	Fair value estimates are based on existing on- and off-balance sheet financial instruments without attempting to estimate the value of anticipated future business and the value of assets and liabilities that are not considered financial instruments.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P174_S1	Significant assets and liabilities that are not considered financial assets or liabilities include deferred tax assets and premises and equipment.
1178970_11_ITEM8_P174_S2	In addition, the tax ramifications related to the realization of the unrealized gains and losses can have a significant effect on fair value estimates and have not been considered in the estimates.

1178970_11_ITEM9A_P0_S0	of Disclosure Controls and Procedures Christopher Martin, the Company s Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer, and Thomas M. Lyons, the Company s Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, conducted an evaluation of the effectiveness of the Company s disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Rule 13a-14(c) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended) as of December 31, 2010.
1178970_11_ITEM9A_P0_S1	Based upon their evaluation, they each found that the Company s disclosure controls and procedures were effective to ensure that information required to be disclosed in the reports that the Company files and submits under the Exchange Act is recorded, processed, summarized and reported as and when required and that such information is accumulated and communicated to the Company s management as appropriate to allow timely decisions regarding required disclosures.
1178970_11_ITEM9A_P1_S0	There has been no change in the Company s internal control over financial reporting during the Company s fourth fiscal quarter that has materially affected, or is reasonably likely to affect, the Company s internal control over financial reporting.
1178970_11_ITEM9A_P2_S0	The management of Provident Financial Services, Inc. (the Company ) is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting.
1178970_11_ITEM9A_P2_S1	The Company s internal control system is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance to the Company s management and board of directors regarding the preparation and fair presentation of published financial statements.
1178970_11_ITEM9A_P2_S2	The Company s internal control over financial reporting includes policies and procedures that pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect transactions and dispositions of assets; provide reasonable assurances that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and the directors of the Company; and provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use or disposition of the Company s assets that could have a material effect on its financial statements.
1178970_11_ITEM9A_P2_S3	All internal control systems, no matter how well designed, have inherent limitations.
1178970_11_ITEM9A_P2_S4	Therefore, even those systems determined to be effective can provide only reasonable assurance with respect to financial statement preparation and presentation.
1178970_11_ITEM9A_P2_S5	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
1178970_11_ITEM9A_P3_S0	Management assessed the effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2010.
1178970_11_ITEM9A_P3_S1	In making this assessment, we used the criteria set forth by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission in Internal Control-Integrated Framework .
1178970_11_ITEM9A_P3_S2	Based on the assessment management believes that, as of December 31, 2010, the Company s internal control over financial reporting is effective based on those criteria.
1178970_11_ITEM9A_P3_S3	The Company s independent registered public accounting firm that audited the consolidated financial statements has issued an audit report on the effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2010.
