1178970_12_ITEM5_P5_S1	The repurchase program has no expiration date.
1178970_12_ITEM6_P0_S0	The summary information presented below at or for each of the periods presented is derived in part from and should be read in conjunction with the consolidated financial statements of the Company presented in Item 8.
1178970_12_ITEM6_P1_S0	(1) Loans are shown net of allowance for loan losses, deferred fees and unearned discount.
1178970_12_ITEM6_P2_S0	(1) Averages presented are daily averages.
1178970_12_ITEM6_P3_S0	(2) Net interest income divided by average interest earning assets.
1178970_12_ITEM6_P4_S0	(3) Represents the ratio of non-interest expense divided by the sum of net interest income and non-interest income.
1178970_12_ITEM6_P5_S0	(4) Leverage capital ratios are presented as a percentage of quarterly average tangible assets.
1178970_12_ITEM6_P5_S1	Risk-based capital ratios are presented as a percentage of risk-weighted assets.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P0_S0	for the Bank, following the completion of the conversion of the Bank to a stock-chartered bank.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P1_S0	The Company issued an aggregate of 59,618,300 shares of its common stock in a subscription offering to eligible depositors.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P1_S1	Concurrent with the conversion, the Company contributed an additional 1,920,000 shares of its common stock and $4.8 million in cash to The Provident Bank Foundation, a charitable foundation established by the Bank.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P2_S0	The Company conducts business through its subsidiary, the Bank, a community- and customer-oriented bank currently operating 82 full-service branches throughout northern and central New Jersey.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P2_S1	Strategy Established in 1839, the Bank is the oldest New Jersey-chartered bank in the state.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P2_S2	The Bank offers a full range of retail and commercial loan and deposit products, and emphasizes personal service and convenience.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P2_S3	The Bank s strategy is to grow profitably through a commitment to credit quality and expanding market share by acquiring, retaining and expanding customer relationships, while carefully managing interest rate risk.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P2_S4	In recent years, the Bank has focused on commercial real estate, multi-family and commercial loans as part of its strategy to diversify the loan portfolio and reduce interest rate risk.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P2_S5	These types of loans generally have adjustable rates that initially are higher than residential mortgage loans and generally have a higher rate of risk.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P3_S0	The Bank s credit policy focuses on quality underwriting standards and close monitoring of the loan portfolio.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P3_S1	At December 31, 2011, commercial loans accounted for 59.8% of the loan portfolio and retail loans accounted for 40.2%.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P3_S2	The Company intends to continue to diversify the loan portfolio and to focus on commercial real estate and commercial and industrial lending relationships.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P4_S0	The Company s relationship banking strategy focuses on increasing core accounts and expanding relationships through its branch network, online banking and telephone banking touch points.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P4_S1	The Company continues to evaluate opportunities to increase market share by expanding within existing and contiguous markets.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P5_S0	Core deposits, consisting of all savings and demand deposit accounts, are generally a stable, relatively inexpensive source of funds.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P5_S1	At December 31, 2011, core deposits were 78.1% of total deposits.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P6_S0	The Company s results of operations are primarily dependent upon net interest income, the difference between interest earned on interest-earning assets and the interest paid on interest-bearing liabilities.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P6_S1	Changes in interest rates could have an adverse effect on net interest income to the extent the Company s interest-bearing assets and interest-bearing liabilities reprice or mature at different times or relative interest rates.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P6_S2	An increase in interest rates generally would result in a decrease in the Company s average interest rate spread and net interest income, which could have a negative effect on profitability.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P7_S0	The Company generates non-interest income such as income from retail and business account fees, loan servicing fees, loan origination fees, appreciation in the cash surrender value of Bank-owned life insurance, income from loan or securities sales, fees from wealth management services and investment product sales and other fees.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P7_S1	The Company s operating expenses consist primarily of compensation and benefits expense, occupancy and equipment expense, data processing expense, the amortization of intangible assets, marketing and advertising expense and other general and administrative expenses.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P7_S2	The Company s results of operations are also affected by general economic conditions, changes in market interest rates, changes in asset quality, changes in asset values, actions of regulatory agencies and government policies.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P8_S0	On August 11, 2011, the Company s wholly owned subsidiary, The Provident Bank, completed its acquisition of Beacon Trust Company, a New Jersey limited purpose trust company, and Beacon Global Asset Management, Inc., an SEC-registered investment advisor incorporated in Delaware (collectively Beacon ).
1178970_12_ITEM7_P9_S0	Pursuant to the terms of the Stock Purchase Agreement announced on May 19, 2011, Beacon s former parent company, Beacon Financial Corporation, may be paid cash consideration in an amount up to $10.5 million, based upon the acquired companies financial performance in the three years following the closing of the transaction.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P10_S0	The Company considers certain accounting policies to be critically important to the fair presentation of its financial condition and results of operations.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P10_S1	These policies require management to make complex judgments on matters which by their nature have elements of uncertainty.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P10_S2	The sensitivity of the Company s consolidated financial statements to these critical accounting policies, and the assumptions and estimates applied, could have a significant impact on its financial condition and results of operations.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P10_S3	These assumptions, estimates and judgments made by management can be influenced by a number of factors, including the general economic environment.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P10_S4	The Company has identified the following as critical accounting policies:
1178970_12_ITEM7_P11_S0	Valuation of deferred tax assets The calculation of the allowance for loan losses is a critical accounting policy of the Company.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P12_S0	The allowance for loan losses is a valuation account that reflects management s evaluation of the probable losses in the loan portfolio.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P12_S1	The Company maintains the allowance for loan losses through provisions for loan losses that are charged to income.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P12_S2	Charge-offs against the allowance for loan losses are taken on loans where management determines that the collection of loan principal is unlikely.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P12_S3	Recoveries made on loans that have been charged-off are credited to the allowance for loan losses.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P12_S4	The Company s evaluation of the adequacy of the allowance for loan losses includes a review of all loans on which the collectibility of principal may not be reasonably assured.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P12_S5	For residential mortgage and consumer loans, this is determined primarily by delinquency and collateral values.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P12_S6	For commercial real estate and commercial loans, an extensive review of financial performance, payment history and collateral values is conducted on a quarterly basis.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P13_S0	As part of the evaluation of the adequacy of the allowance for loan losses, each quarter management prepares an analysis that categorizes the entire loan portfolio by certain risk characteristics such as loan type (residential mortgage, commercial mortgage, construction, commercial, etc.) and loan risk rating.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P13_S1	When assigning a risk rating to a loan, management utilizes a nine point internal risk rating system.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P13_S2	Loans deemed to be acceptable quality are rated 1 through 4, with a rating of 1 established for loans with minimal risk.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P13_S3	Loans deemed to be of questionable quality are rated 5 (watch) or 6 (special mention).
1178970_12_ITEM7_P13_S4	Loans with adverse classifications (substandard, doubtful or loss) are rated 7, 8 or 9, respectively.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P13_S5	Commercial mortgage, commercial and construction loans are rated individually and each lending officer is responsible for risk rating loans in their portfolio.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P13_S6	These risk ratings are then reviewed by the department manager and/or the Chief Lending Officer and the Credit Administration Department.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P13_S7	A sample of risk ratings are also reviewed and confirmed through the Loan Review function and periodically, by the Credit Committee in the credit renewal or approval process.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P14_S0	Management assigns general valuation allowance ( GVA ) percentages to each risk rating category for use in allocating the allowance for loan losses, giving consideration to historical loss experience by loan type and other qualitative or environmental factors such as trends and levels of delinquencies, impaired loans, charge-offs, recoveries, loan volume, as well as, the national and local economic trends and conditions.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P14_S1	The appropriateness of these percentages is evaluated by management at least annually and monitored on a quarterly basis, with changes made when they are required.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P14_S2	In the second quarter of 2011, management completed its most recent evaluation of the GVA percentages.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P14_S3	As a result of that evaluation, GVA percentages applied to the marine portfolio were increased to reflect an increase in historical loss experience.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P15_S0	change in methodology was made to the GVA allocation process whereby residential mortgage loans greater than or equal to 120 days past due were segregated from the rest of the residential mortgage loan population and assigned a GVA percentage based upon a review of actual losses recorded at foreclosure.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P15_S1	This change was undertaken in recognition of the fact that residential mortgages are charged down to estimated fair value when they are four payments past due.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P15_S2	Valuations are subsequently obtained on an annual basis and ultimately at foreclosure, with additional charge-offs recorded if require.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P16_S0	Management believes the primary risks inherent in the portfolio are a continued decline in the economy, generally, a continued decline in real estate market values, rising unemployment or a protracted period of unemployment at current elevated levels, increasing vacancy rates in commercial investment properties and possible increases in interest rates in the absence of economic improvement.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P16_S1	Any one or a combination of these events may adversely affect borrowers ability to repay the loans, resulting in increased delinquencies, loan losses and future levels of provisions.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P16_S2	Accordingly, the Company has provided for loan losses at the current level to address the current risk in its loan portfolio.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P16_S3	Management considers it important to maintain the ratio of the allowance for loan losses to total loans at an acceptable level given current economic conditions, interest rates and the composition of the portfolio.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P16_S4	Although management believes that the Company has established and maintained the allowance for loan losses at appropriate levels, additions may be necessary if future economic and other conditions differ substantially from the current operating environment.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P16_S5	Management evaluates its estimates and assumptions on an ongoing basis giving consideration to historical experience and other factors, including the current economic environment, which management believes to be reasonable under the circumstances.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P16_S6	Such estimates and assumptions are adjusted when facts and circumstances dictate.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P16_S7	Illiquid credit markets, volatile securities markets, and declines in the housing and commercial real estate markets and the economy generally have combined to increase the uncertainty inherent in such estimates and assumptions.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P17_S0	As future events and their effects cannot be determined with precision, actual results could differ significantly from these estimates.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P17_S1	Changes in estimates resulting from continuing changes in the economic environment will be reflected in the financial statements in future periods.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P17_S2	In addition, various regulatory agencies periodically review the adequacy of the Company s allowance for loan losses as an integral part of their examination process.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P17_S3	Such agencies may require the Company to recognize additions to the allowance or additional write-downs based on their judgments about information available to them at the time of their examination.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P17_S4	Although management uses the best information available, the level of the allowance for loan losses remains an estimate that is subject to significant judgment and short-term change.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P17_S5	Additional critical accounting policies relate to judgments about other asset impairments, including goodwill, investment securities and deferred tax assets.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P18_S0	Goodwill is evaluated for impairment on an annual basis, or more frequently if events or changes in circumstances indicate potential impairment between annual measurement dates.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P18_S1	Effective September 30, 2011, the Company early adopted amended guidance related to the annual goodwill impairment assessment.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P18_S2	The new guidance provides the option to qualitatively determine whether it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying amount before performing Step 1 of the goodwill impairment test.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P18_S3	If a company concludes that it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying amount, the entity would be required to perform Step 1 of the assessment and then, if needed, Step 2 to determine whether goodwill is impaired.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P18_S4	However, if it is more likely than not that the fair value of the reporting unit is more than its carrying amount, the entity does not need to apply the two-step impairment test.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P19_S0	For this analysis, the Reporting Unit is defined as the Bank, which includes all core and retail banking operations of the Company but excludes the assets, liabilities, equity, earnings and operations held exclusively at the Company level.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P20_S0	The guidance provides certain factors a company should consider in its qualitative assessment in determining whether it is more likely than not that a reporting unit s fair value is less than its carrying amount.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P21_S0	Macroeconomic conditions, such as deterioration in economic condition and limited access to capital.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P22_S0	Industry and market considerations, such as increased competition, regulatory developments and decline in market-dependent multiples.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P23_S0	Cost factors, such as increased labor costs, cost of materials and other operating costs.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P24_S0	Overall financial performance, such as declining cash flows and decline in revenue or earnings.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P25_S0	Other relevant entity-specific events, such as changes in management, strategy or customers, litigation and contemplation of bankruptcy.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P26_S0	Reporting unit events, such as selling or disposing a portion of a reporting unit and a change in composition of assets.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P26_S1	The Company completed its annual goodwill impairment test as of September 30, 2011.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P26_S2	Based upon its qualitative assessment of goodwill, the Company concluded it is more likely than not that the fair value of the reporting unit exceeds its carrying amount, goodwill is not impaired and no further quantitative analysis (Step 1) is warranted.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P27_S0	The Company may, based upon its qualitative assessment, or at its option, perform the two-step process to evaluate the potential impairment of goodwill.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P27_S1	If, based upon Step 1, the fair value of the Reporting Unit exceeds its carrying amount, goodwill of the Reporting Unit is considered not impaired.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P27_S2	However, if the carrying amount of the Reporting Unit exceeds its fair value, an additional test must be performed.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P28_S0	The second step test compares the implied fair value of the Reporting Unit s goodwill with the carrying amount of that goodwill.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P28_S1	An impairment loss would be recorded to the extent that the carrying amount of goodwill exceeds its implied fair value.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P29_S0	The Company s available for sale securities portfolio is carried at estimated fair value, with any unrealized gains or losses, net of taxes, reported as accumulated other comprehensive income or loss in Stockholders Equity.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P29_S1	Estimated fair values are based on market quotations or matrix pricing as discussed in Note 5 to the audited consolidated financial statements.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P30_S0	Securities which the Company has the positive intent and ability to hold to maturity are classified as held to maturity and carried at amortized cost.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P30_S1	The Company conducts a periodic review and evaluation of the securities portfolio to determine if any declines in the fair values of securities are other-than-temporary.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P30_S2	In this evaluation, if such a decline were deemed other-than-temporary, the Company would measure the total credit-related component of the unrealized loss, and recognize that portion of the loss as a charge to current period earnings.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P30_S3	The remaining portion of the unrealized loss would be recognized as an adjustment to accumulated other comprehensive income.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P31_S0	The fair value of the securities portfolio is significantly affected by changes in interest rates.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P31_S1	In general, as interest rates rise, the fair value of fixed-rate securities decreases and as interest rates fall, the fair value of fixed-rate securities increases.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P32_S0	Turmoil in the credit markets resulted in a lack of liquidity in certain sectors of the mortgage-backed securities market.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P32_S1	Increases in delinquencies and foreclosures have resulted in limited trading activity and significant price declines, regardless of favorable movements in interest rates.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P33_S0	The Company determines if it has the intent to sell these securities or if it is more likely than not that the Company would be required to sell the securities before the anticipated recovery.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P33_S1	If either exists, the decline in value is considered other-than-temporary.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P33_S2	In this evaluation, the Company recognized other-than-temporary securities impairment losses in earnings totaling $302,000, $170,000 and $2.0 million in 2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P34_S0	The determination of whether deferred tax assets will be realizable is predicated on the reversal of existing deferred tax liabilities, utilization against carryback years and estimates of future taxable income.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P34_S1	Such estimates are subject to management s judgment.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P35_S0	A valuation allowance is established when management is unable to conclude that it is more likely than not that it will realize deferred tax assets based on the nature and timing of these items.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P35_S1	A valuation reserve of $1.1 million was established in 2009 pertaining primarily to state tax benefits on net operating losses at the Bank and unused capital loss carryforwards.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P35_S2	In 2011, management released the valuation allowance associated with the state net operating losses, approximately $840,000, due to expectation of current and future taxable income.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P36_S0	Analysis of Net Interest Income Net interest income represents the difference between income on interest-earning assets and expense on interest-bearing liabilities.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P36_S1	Net interest income depends on the relative amounts of interest-earning assets and interest-bearing liabilities and the rates of interest earned on such assets and paid on such liabilities.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P36_S2	The following table sets forth certain information for the years ended December 31, 2011, 2010 and 2009.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P36_S3	For the periods indicated, the total dollar amount of interest income from average interest-earning assets and the resultant yields, as well as the interest expense on average interest-bearing liabilities is expressed both in dollars and rates.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P36_S4	No tax equivalent adjustments were made.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P37_S0	(1) Average outstanding balance amounts are at amortized cost.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P38_S0	(2) Average outstanding balances are net of the allowance for loan losses, deferred loan fees and expenses, and loan premiums and discounts and include non-accrual loans.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P39_S0	(3) Net interest income divided by average interest-earning assets.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P40_S0	The following table presents the extent to which changes in interest rates and changes in the volume of interest-earning assets and interest-bearing liabilities have affected interest income and interest expense during the periods indicated.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P40_S1	Information is provided in each category with respect to: (i) changes attributable to changes in volume (changes in volume multiplied by prior rate); (ii) changes attributable to changes in rate (changes in rate multiplied by prior volume); and (iii) the net change.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P40_S2	The changes attributable to the combined impact of volume and rate have been allocated proportionately to the changes due to volume and the changes due to rate.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P41_S0	Comparison of Financial Condition at December 31, 2011 and December 31, 2010 Total assets increased $272.9 million, or 4.0%, to $7.10 billion at December 31, 2011, from $6.82 billion at December 31, 2010, primarily due to an increase in net loans outstanding.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P41_S1	Cash and cash equivalents increased $17.4 million to $69.6 million at December 31, 2011, from $52.2 million at December 31, 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P41_S2	The Company expects to deploy these cash balances to fund loan originations and investment purchases and repay maturing borrowings.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P41_S3	Total loans increased $238.1 million, or 5.5%, to $4.58 billion at December 31, 2011, from $4.41 billion at December 31, 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P41_S4	For the year ended December 31, 2011, loan originations totaling $1.51 billion and loan purchases of $79.5 million were partially offset by repayments of $1.30 billion and loan sales of $12.9 million.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P41_S5	Multi-family loans increased $177.0 million to $564.1 million at December 31, 2011, compared to $387.2 million at December 31, 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P41_S6	Commercial loans increased $93.5 million to $849.0 million at December 31, 2011, compared to $755.5 million at December 31, 2010, and commercial real estate loans increased $73.4 million to $1.25 billion at December 31, 2011, compared to $1.18 billion at December 31, 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P41_S7	Residential mortgage loans decreased $77.7 million to $1.31 billion at December 31, 2011, compared to $1.39 billion at December 31, 2010, as loan repayments attributable to an active refinance market outpaced originations.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P41_S8	One- to four-family residential mortgage loan originations totaled $146.7 million and one- to four-family residential mortgage loans purchased totaled $79.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2011.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P42_S0	the year ended December 31, 2011.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P42_S1	Construction loans decreased $10.4 million to $114.8 million at December 31, 2011, compared to $125.2 million at December 31, 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P42_S2	The Company has de-emphasized construction lending for the past two years due to adverse market conditions.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P42_S3	Consumer loans decreased $8.6 million to $561.0 million at December 31, 2011, compared to $569.6 million at December 31, 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P42_S4	Commercial loans, consisting of commercial real estate, multi-family, construction and commercial loans, totaled $2.78 billion, accounting for 59.8% of the loan portfolio at December 31, 2011, compared to $2.45 billion, or 55.6% of the loan portfolio at December 31, 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P42_S5	The Company intends to continue to focus on the origination of commercially-oriented loans.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P43_S0	Retail loans, which consist of one- to four-family residential mortgage and consumer loans, such as fixed-rate home equity loans and lines of credit, totaled $1.87 billion and accounted for 40.2% of the loan portfolio at December 31, 2011, compared to $1.96 billion, or 44.4%, of the loan portfolio at December 31, 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P43_S1	The increase in commercial loans as a percentage of the total loan portfolio was a result of growth in the multi-family and commercial mortgage portfolios, coupled with reductions in retail loans attributable to refinance activity, the market preference for longer-term fixed-rate loans, which the Company chooses to sell rather than retain for portfolio as part of its interest rate risk management process, and lack of qualified retail loan demand.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P44_S0	The Company does not originate or purchase sub-prime or option ARM loans.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P45_S0	Prior to September 30, 2008, the Company originated Alt-A mortgages in the form of stated income loans with a maximum loan-to-value ratio of 50% on a limited basis.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P45_S1	The balance of these Alt-A loans at December 31, 2011 was $11.3 million.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P45_S2	Of this total, 8 loans totaling $3.0 million were 90 days or more delinquent.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P45_S3	General valuation reserves of 6.5%, or $195,000, were allocated to these loans at December 31, 2011.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P46_S0	The Company participates in loans originated by other banks, including participations designated as Shared National Credits ( SNC ).
1178970_12_ITEM7_P46_S1	The Company s gross commitments and outstanding balances as a participant in SNCs were $82.1 million and $58.6 million, respectively, at December 31, 2011.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P46_S2	The Company s participations in SNCs included four relationships classified as substandard (rated 7) under the Company s loan risk rating system with gross commitments and outstanding balances of $34.6 million at December 31, 2011.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P46_S3	Of these adversely classified SNCs, three loan relationships consisted of commercial construction loans on properties located in New York City and New Jersey, and one was a commercial loan to a Pennsylvania media company.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P46_S4	All of the Company s SNC participations were current as to the payment of principal and interest as of December 31, 2011.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P46_S5	The Company had outstanding junior lien mortgages totaling $278.3 million at December 31, 2011.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P46_S6	Of this total, 47 loans totaling $5.5 million were 90 days or more delinquent.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P46_S7	General valuation reserves of 10%, or $550,000, were allocated to these loans at December 31, 2011.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P46_S8	At December 31, 2011, the Company had outstanding indirect marine loans totaling $51.5 million.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P46_S9	Of this total, 3 loans totaling $838,000 were 90 days or more delinquent.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P46_S10	General valuation reserves of 40%, or $335,000, were allocated to these loans at December 31, 2011.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P47_S0	Marine loans are currently made only on a direct, limited accommodation basis to existing customers.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P47_S1	The allowance for loan losses increased $5.6 million to $74.4 million at December 31, 2011, as a result of provisions for loan losses of $28.9 million, partially offset by net charge-offs of $23.3 million during 2011.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P47_S2	The increase in the allowance for loan losses was attributable to an increase in non-performing loans, and an increase in commercial loans as a percentage of the loan portfolio to 59.8% at December 31, 2011, from 55.6% at December 31, 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P47_S3	Total non-performing loans at December 31, 2011 were $122.5 million, or 2.63% of total loans, compared with $97.3 million, or 2.21% of total loans at December 31, 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P47_S4	At December 31, 2011, impaired loans totaled $103.2 million with related specific reserves of $9.3 million.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P47_S5	Within total impaired loans, there were $9.3 million of loans for which the present value of expected future cash flows or current collateral valuations exceeded the carrying amounts of the loans and for which no specific reserves were required in accordance with GAAP.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P47_S6	At December 31, 2011, the Company s allowance for loan losses was 1.60% of total loans, compared with 1.56% of total loans at December 31, 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P48_S0	Non-performing commercial mortgage loans increased $13.4 million, to $29.5 million at December 31, 2011, from $16.1 million at December 31, 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P48_S1	At December 31, 2011, the Company held 13 non-performing commercial mortgage loans.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P48_S2	The largest non-performing commercial mortgage loan was a $13.4 million loan secured by a first mortgage on a 200,000 square foot office/industrial building located in Eatontown, New Jersey, which has been negatively impacted by the loss of a major tenant that relied upon contracts with the Federal Government.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P48_S3	The loan has been restructured and payments are current at December 31, 2011.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P48_S4	The borrower continues to make efforts to lease the property.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P48_S5	There is no contractual commitment to advance additional funds to this borrower.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P48_S6	Non-performing commercial loans increased $8.6 million, to $32.1 million at December 31, 2011, from $23.5 million at December 31, 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P48_S7	Non-performing commercial loans at December 31, 2011 consisted of 19 loans.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P48_S8	The largest non-performing commercial loan relationship consisted of four loans to a power systems manufacturer with total outstanding balances of $9.1 million at December 31, 2011.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P48_S9	All contractual payments on these loans were current at December 31, 2011.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P48_S10	Non-performing construction loans increased $1.6 million, to $11.0 million at December 31, 2011, from $9.4 million at December 31, 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P48_S11	At December 31, 2011, non-performing construction loans consisted of two loans to the same borrower secured by a first mortgage on a 77,000 square foot newly constructed Class A office building, a 7,000 square foot fully leased retail building and a parcel of land with approvals for a 110,000 square foot office building located in Parsippany, New Jersey.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P48_S12	The office building is completed, except for tenant improvements, but not leased due to weakness in the market.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P48_S13	The property is being marketed and the principals are supporting the project.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P48_S14	The loan was current as to the payment of principal and interest at December 31, 2011.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P48_S15	The Company has an unfunded commitment of $3.6 million on this loan at December 31, 2011.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P48_S16	Non-performing multi-family loans at December 31, 2011, consisted of one loan for $997,000, compared to a $201,000 non-performing multi-family loan at December 31, 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P48_S17	In addition, non-performing consumer loans increased $1.7 million, to $8.5 million at December 31, 2011.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P48_S18	The Company attributes the increase in non-performing consumer loans to continued elevated levels of unemployment, decreased property values and increased personal debt levels.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P48_S19	At December 31, 2011, the Company held $12.8 million of foreclosed assets, compared with $2.9 million at December 31, 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P48_S20	Foreclosed assets at December 31, 2011 are carried at fair value based on recent appraisals and valuation estimates, less estimated selling costs.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P48_S21	Foreclosed assets consisted of $6.6 million of commercial real estate, $5.5 million of residential properties, and $0.7 million of marine vessels at December 31, 2011.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P48_S22	Non-performing assets totaled $135.4 million, or 1.91% of total assets at December 31, 2011, compared to $100.1 million, or 1.47% of total assets at December 31, 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P48_S23	If the non-accrual loans had performed in accordance with their original terms, interest income would have increased by $3.5 million during the year ended December 31, 2011.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P48_S24	Total deposits increased $278.9 million, or 5.7%, during the year ended December 31, 2011 to $5.16 billion.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P48_S25	Core deposits, consisting of savings and demand deposit accounts, increased $428.4 million, or 11.9%, to $4.03 billion at December 31, 2011.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P48_S26	The majority of the core deposit increase was in commercial checking deposits, retail checking deposits and money market deposits, partially offset by a decline in savings deposits.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P48_S27	Time deposits decreased $149.5 million, or 11.7%, to $1.13 billion at December 31, 2011, with the majority of the decrease occurring in the 15-month and shorter maturity categories.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P48_S28	The Company remains focused on developing core deposit relationships, while strategically permitting the run-off of higher-cost time deposits.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P48_S29	Core deposits represented 78.1% of total deposits at December 31, 2011, compared to 73.8% at December 31, 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P48_S30	Borrowed funds were reduced $49.5 million, or 5.1% during the year ended December 31, 2011, to $920.2 million, as wholesale funding was replaced with core deposit growth.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P48_S31	Borrowed funds represented 13.0% of total assets at December 31, 2011, a reduction from 14.2% at December 31, 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P49_S0	Total stockholders equity increased $30.8 million to $952.5 million at December 31, 2011, from $921.7 million at December 31, 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P49_S1	This increase was a result of net income of $57.3 million and the allocation of shares to stock-based compensation plans of $6.4 million, partially offset by cash dividends of $26.8 million, other comprehensive income of $5.2 million and common stock repurchases of $4.1 million Comparison of Operating Results for the Years Ended December 31, 2011 and December 31, 2010 General.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P49_S2	Net income for the year ended December 31, 2011 was $57.3 million, compared to $49.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P49_S3	Basic and diluted earnings per share were $1.01 for the year ended December 31, 2011, compared to a basic and diluted loss per share of $0.88 for 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P49_S4	Earnings for the year ended December 31, 2011 reflect actions taken to reduce funding costs, with net interest income increasing $7.0 million, compared with the same period in 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P49_S5	In addition, the provision for loan losses decreased $6.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2011, compared with the year ended December 31, 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P49_S6	These improvements were partially offset by an increase in non-interest expense of $3.7 million for year ended December 31, 2011, compared with the same period in 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P49_S7	Net interest income increased $7.0 million, or 3.4%, to $216.0 million for 2011, from $209.0 million for 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P49_S8	The average interest rate spread increased 6 basis points to 3.33% for 2011, from 3.27% for 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P49_S9	The net interest margin increased 4 basis points to 3.49% for 2011, compared to 3.45% for 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P49_S10	For the year ended December 31, 2011, the favorable effects of an increase in average loans outstanding and reductions in funding costs outpaced the impact of the downward repricing of earning assets and accelerated premium amortization on mortgage-backed securities.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P49_S11	Interest income decreased $10.8 million, or 3.8%, to $275.7 million for 2011, compared to $286.5 million for 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P49_S12	The decrease in interest income was attributable to a decrease in the yield on average earning assets, partially offset by an increase in average earning asset balances.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P49_S13	The yield on interest-earning assets decreased 27 basis points to 4.46% for 2011, from 4.73% for 2010, with reductions in yields experienced in nearly all earning asset classes.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P49_S14	Average interest-earning assets increased $101.0 million, or 16.7%, to $6.16 billion for 2011, compared to $6.06 billion for 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P49_S15	The average outstanding loan balances increased $148.6 million, or 3.5%, to $4.42 billion for 2011 from $4.27 billion for 2010, and the average balance of investment securities increased $10.4 million, or 3.1%, to $345.5 million for 2011, compared to $335.1 million for 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P49_S16	These increases were partially offset by a decrease in average interest-earning deposits, Federal funds sold and short-term investment balances of $51.7 million, or 51.3%, to $49.2 million for 2011, from $100.9 million for 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P49_S17	In addition, the average balance of securities available for sale decreased $9.6 million, or 0.7%, to $1.30 billion for 2011, compared to $1.31 billion for 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P49_S18	Interest expense decreased $17.8 million, or 23.0%, to $59.7 million for 2011, from $77.6 million for 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P49_S19	The decrease in interest expense was attributable to lower short-term interest rates coupled with a shift in the funding composition to lower-costing core deposits from certificates of deposit and a reduction in average borrowings, partially offset by an increase in average interest-bearing deposit balances.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P49_S20	The average rate paid on interest-bearing liabilities decreased 33 basis points to 1.13% for 2011, from 1.46% for 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P49_S21	The average rate paid on interest-bearing deposits decreased 26 basis points to 0.83% for 2011, from 1.09% for 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P49_S22	The average rate paid on borrowings decreased 63 basis points to 2.55% for 2011, from 3.18% for 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P49_S23	The average balance of interest-bearing liabilities decreased $5.1 million, or 0.1%, to $5.29 billion for 2011, compared to $5.30 billion for 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P49_S24	Average interest-bearing deposits increased $24.7 million, or 0.6%, to $4.39 billion for 2011, from $4.36 billion for 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P49_S25	Within average interest-bearing deposits, average interest-bearing core deposits increased $188.6 million, or 6.3%, for 2011, compared with 2010, while average time deposits decreased $163.9 million, or 11.9%, for 2011, compared with 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P49_S26	Further aiding the increase in net interest income, average non-interest bearing deposits increased $77.7 million, or 14.7%, to $605.8 million for 2011, from $528.1 million for 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P49_S27	Average outstanding borrowings decreased $29.8 million, or 3.2%, to $909.5 million for 2011, compared with $939.3 million for 2010, as deposits replaced wholesale funding.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P50_S0	Provisions for loan losses are charged to operations to maintain the allowance for loan losses at a level management considers necessary to absorb probable credit losses inherent in the loan portfolio.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P50_S1	In determining the level of the allowance for loan losses, management considers past and current loss experience, evaluations of real estate collateral, current economic conditions, volume and type of lending, adverse situations that may affect a borrower s ability to repay the loan and the levels of non-performing and other classified loans.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P50_S2	The amount of the allowance is based on estimates and the ultimate losses may vary from such estimates as more information becomes available or later events change.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P50_S3	Management assesses the adequacy of the allowance for loan losses on a quarterly basis and makes provisions for loan losses, if necessary, in order to maintain the adequacy of the allowance.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P50_S4	The Company s emphasis on continued diversification of the loan portfolio through the origination of commercial loans has been one of the more significant factors management has considered in evaluating the allowance for loan losses and provision for loan losses for the past several years.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P50_S5	In the event the Company further increases the amount of such types of loans in the portfolio, management may determine that additional or increased provisions for loan losses are necessary, which could adversely affect earnings.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P50_S6	The provision for loan losses was $28.9 million in 2011, compared to $35.5 million in 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P50_S7	The decrease in the provision for loan losses was primarily attributable to a reduction in loan delinquencies, a decline in non-performing loan formation and an improvement in credit risk ratings.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P50_S8	Net charge-offs for 2011 were $23.3 million, compared to $27.5 million for 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P50_S9	Total charge-offs for the year ended December 31, 2011 were $25.1 million, compared to $29.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P50_S10	Recoveries for the year ended December 31, 2011, were $1.8 million, compared to $1.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P50_S11	The allowance for loan losses at December 31, 2011 was $74.4 million, or 1.60% of total loans, compared to $68.7 million, or 1.56% of total loans at December 31, 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P50_S12	At December 31, 2011, non-performing loans as a percentage of total loans were 2.63%, compared to 2.21% at December 31, 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P50_S13	Non-performing assets as a percentage of total assets were 1.91% at December 31, 2011, compared to 1.47% at December 31, 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P50_S14	At December 31, 2011, non-performing loans were $122.5 million, compared to $97.3 million at December 31, 2010, and non-performing assets were $135.4 million at December 31, 2011, compared to $100.1 million at December 31, 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P50_S15	For the year ended December 31, 2011, non-interest income totaled $32.5 million, an increase of $990,000, or 3.1%, compared to the same period in 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P50_S16	Fee income totaled $25.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2011, an increase of $1.7 million compared with the same period in 2010, largely due to increased wealth management fees related to the Beacon acquisition, an increase in revenue from loan related activity and increased revenue associated with annuity sales.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P50_S17	These increases were partially offset by a reduction in overdraft fees.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P50_S18	Other income increased $266,000 for the year ended December 31, 2011, compared with the same period in 2010, primarily as a result of net gains recognized on the sale of foreclosed real estate and an increase in gains resulting from a larger number of loan sales, partially offset by the losses incurred on the sales of the Company s previously occupied administrative facilities.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P50_S19	Offsetting these increases, income related to Bank-owned life insurance decreased $706,000 for the year ended December 31, 2011, compared to the same period last year, primarily due to the receipt of policy claim proceeds in the second quarter of 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P50_S20	Additionally, net gains on securities transactions declined $177,000 for the year ended December 31, 2011, compared with the same period in 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P50_S21	These net gains on securities transactions totaled $708,000 for the year ended December 31, 2011, compared with net gains of $885,000 for the same period in 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P50_S22	The Company recognized net other-than-temporary impairment charges of $302,000 and $170,000 for the years ended December 31, 2011 and December 31, 2010, respectively, related to an investment in a non-Agency mortgage-backed security.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P50_S23	Non-interest expense for the year ended December 31, 2011 was $142.4 million, an increase of $3.7 million, or 2.7%, from $138.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P51_S0	Company s incentive compensation and Employee Stock Ownership plans and the higher average share price of the Company s common stock in 2011 compared with 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P51_S1	In addition, net occupancy expense increased $1.4 million, to $21.1 million, compared to $19.8 million for the same period in 2010, due to expenses associated with the relocation of the Company s administrative offices and carrying costs on previously occupied facilities owned by the Company, which were sold in November 2011.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P51_S2	In addition, approximately $227,000 in damages attributable to Hurricane Irene were also included in occupancy expense for the year ended December 31, 2011.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P51_S3	Data processing expense totaled $9.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2011, compared to $9.0 million for the same period in 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P51_S4	The $516,000 increase was primarily due to higher software maintenance and core processing fees.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P51_S5	Other operating expenses increased $157,000 for the year ended December 31, 2011, compared with the same period last year, due to increased loan collection expense and costs associated with the Beacon acquisition.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P51_S6	Partially offsetting these increases, FDIC insurance expense decreased $1.7 million to $5.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2011, compared with $7.6 million for the same period in 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P51_S7	The decrease was primarily due to a lower assessment rate charged on deposits in the first quarter of 2011 and a change in assessment methodology from a deposit-based to an asset-based assessment, effective in the second quarter of 2011.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P51_S8	Additionally, amortization of intangibles decreased $801,000 for the year ended December 31, 2011, compared with the same period of 2010, as a result of scheduled reductions in core deposit intangible amortization, partially offset by the amortization of the customer relationship intangible arising from the Beacon acquisition.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P51_S9	Impairment of premises and equipment declined $721,000, for the year ended December 31, 2011, compared to the same period last year, as the Company recognized a $1.5 million impairment charge in the fourth quarter of 2010 related to the then anticipated sale and relocation of its administrative office, compared to an $807,000 impairment charge in the first quarter of 2011 related to the then anticipated sale and relocation of its former loan administration center.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P51_S10	Advertising and promotions expense decreased $98,000 for the year ended December 31, 2011, compared with the same period last year.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P51_S11	For the year ended December 31, 2011, the Company s income tax expense was $19.8 million, compared with $16.6 million in 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P51_S12	The increase in income tax expense was primarily attributable to an increase in pre-tax income.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P51_S13	The Company s effective tax rate was 25.7% for the year ended December 31, 2011, compared with 25.0% for the year ended December 31, 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P51_S14	The effective tax rate for 2011 was affected by an increase in taxable income, partially offset by the reduction of a valuation allowance against subsidiary company New Jersey state net operating losses.

1178970_12_ITEM7_P57_S0	Liquidity and Capital Resources Liquidity refers to the Company s ability to generate adequate amounts of cash to meet financial obligations to its depositors, to fund loans and securities purchases, deposit outflows and operating expenses.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P57_S1	Sources of funds include scheduled amortization of loans, loan prepayments, scheduled maturities of investments, cash flows from mortgage-backed securities and the ability to borrow funds from the FHLB of New York and approved broker dealers.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P58_S0	Cash flows from loan payments and maturing investment securities are a fairly predictable source of funds.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P58_S1	Changes in interest rates, local economic conditions and the competitive marketplace can influence loan prepayments, prepayments on mortgage-backed securities and deposit flows.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P59_S0	For each of the years ended December 31, 2011 and 2010, loan repayments totaled $1.30 billion and $1.15 billion, respectively.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P59_S1	One- to four-family residential loans, consumer loans, commercial real estate loans, multi-family loans and commercial and small business loans are the primary investments of the Company.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P59_S2	Purchasing securities for the investment portfolio is a secondary use of funds and the investment portfolio is structured to complement and facilitate the Company s lending activities and ensure adequate liquidity.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P60_S0	Loan originations and purchases totaled $1.59 billion for the year ended December 31, 2011, compared to $1.23 billion for the year ended December 31, 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P60_S1	Purchases for the investment portfolio totaled $531.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2011, compared to $626.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P60_S2	At December 31, 2011, the Bank had outstanding loan commitments to borrowers of $770.4 million, including undisbursed home equity lines and personal credit lines of $273.2 million at December 31, 2011.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P60_S3	Total deposits increased $278.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2011.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P61_S0	Deposit activity is affected by changes in interest rates, competitive pricing and product offerings in the marketplace, local economic conditions, customer confidence and other factors such as stock market volatility.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P61_S1	Certificate of deposit accounts that are scheduled to mature within one year totaled $755.1 million at December 31, 2011.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P61_S2	Based on its current pricing strategy and customer retention experience, the Bank expects to retain a significant share of these accounts.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P61_S3	The Bank manages liquidity on a daily basis and expects to have sufficient cash to meet all of its funding requirements.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P61_S4	As of December 31, 2011, the Bank exceeded all minimum regulatory capital requirements.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P61_S5	At December 31, 2011, the Bank s leverage (Tier 1) capital ratio was 7.42%.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P61_S6	FDIC regulations require banks to maintain a minimum leverage ratio of Tier 1 capital to adjusted total assets of 4.00%.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P61_S7	At December 31, 2011, the Bank s total risk-based capital ratio was 12.13%.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P61_S8	Under current regulations, the minimum required ratio of total capital to risk-weighted assets is 8.00%.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P61_S9	A bank is considered to be well-capitalized if it has a leverage (Tier 1) capital ratio of at least 5.00% and a total risk-based capital ratio of at least 10.00%.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P61_S10	Off-balance sheet and contractual obligations as of December 31, 2011, are summarized below:
1178970_12_ITEM7_P62_S0	Off-balance sheet commitments consist of unused commitments to borrowers for term loans, unused lines of credit and outstanding letters of credit.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P62_S1	Total off-balance sheet obligations were $770.4 million at December 31, 2011, an increase of $38.2 million, or 5.2%, from $732.2 million at December 31, 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P63_S0	Contractual obligations consist of operating leases and certificate of deposit liabilities.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P63_S1	There were no securities purchases that were entered into in December 2011 or 2010 that would have settled in January 2012 or 2011, respectively.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P63_S2	Total contractual obligations at December 31, 2011 were $1.17 billion, a decrease of $141.8 million, or 10.8%, compared to $1.31 billion at December 31, 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7_P63_S3	Contractual obligations under operating leases increased $7.7 million, or 22.5%, to $42.1 million at December 31, 2011, from $34.4 million at December 31, 2010, and certificate of deposit accounts decreased $149.5 million, or 11.7%, to $1.13 billion at December 31, 2011, from $1.28 billion at December 31, 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7A_P0_S0	Company s interest rate risk policy seek to limit the exposure to changes in interest rates that affect the underlying economic value of assets and liabilities, earnings and capital.
1178970_12_ITEM7A_P0_S1	To minimize interest rate risk, the Company generally sells 20- and 30-year fixed-rate mortgage loans at origination.
1178970_12_ITEM7A_P0_S2	Commercial real estate loans generally have interest rates that reset in five years, and other commercial loans such as construction loans and commercial lines of credit reset with changes in the Prime rate, the Federal funds rate or LIBOR.
1178970_12_ITEM7A_P0_S3	Investment securities purchases generally have maturities of five years or less, and mortgage-backed securities have weighted average lives initially between three and five years.
1178970_12_ITEM7A_P1_S0	The management Asset/Liability Committee meets on a monthly basis to review the impact of interest rate changes on net interest income, net interest margin, net income and economic value of equity.
1178970_12_ITEM7A_P1_S1	Members of the Asset/Liability Committee include the Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, as well as other senior officers from the Bank s finance, lending, credit and customer management departments.
1178970_12_ITEM7A_P1_S2	The Asset/Liability Committee reviews a variety of strategies that project changes in asset or liability mix and the impact of those changes on projected net interest income and net income.
1178970_12_ITEM7A_P2_S0	The Company s strategy for liabilities has been to maintain a stable core-funding base by focusing on core deposit account acquisition and increasing products and services per household.
1178970_12_ITEM7A_P3_S0	Certificate of deposit accounts as a percentage of total deposits were 21.9% at December 31, 2011 compared to 26.2% at December 31, 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7A_P4_S0	Certificate of deposit accounts are generally short-term.
1178970_12_ITEM7A_P4_S1	As of December 31, 2011, 66.9% of all time deposits had maturities of one year or less compared to 64.1% at December 31, 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM7A_P4_S2	The Company s ability to retain maturing certificate of deposit accounts is the result of a strategy to remain competitively priced within the marketplace, typically within the upper quartile of rates offered by competitors.
1178970_12_ITEM7A_P4_S3	The Company s pricing strategy may vary depending upon funding needs and the Company s ability to fund operations through alternative sources, primarily by accessing short-term lines of credit with the FHLB during periods of pricing dislocation.
1178970_12_ITEM7A_P5_S0	Current and future sensitivity to changes in interest rates are measured through the use of balance sheet and income simulation models.
1178970_12_ITEM7A_P5_S1	The analyses capture changes in net interest income using flat rates as a base, a most likely rate forecast and rising and declining interest rate forecasts.
1178970_12_ITEM7A_P5_S2	Changes in net interest income and net income for the forecast period, generally twelve to twenty-four months, are measured and compared to policy limits for acceptable change.
1178970_12_ITEM7A_P5_S3	The Company periodically reviews historical deposit repricing activity and makes modifications to certain assumptions used in its income simulation model regarding the interest rate sensitivity of deposits without maturity dates.
1178970_12_ITEM7A_P5_S4	These modifications are made to more precisely reflect the most likely results under the various interest rate change scenarios.
1178970_12_ITEM7A_P6_S0	Since it is inherently difficult to predict the sensitivity of interest bearing deposits to changes in interest rates, the changes in net interest income due to changes in interest rates cannot be precisely predicted.
1178970_12_ITEM7A_P6_S1	There are a variety of reasons that may cause actual results to vary considerably from the predictions presented below which include, but are not limited to, the timing, magnitude, and frequency of changes in interest rates, interest rate spreads, prepayments, and actions taken in response to such changes.
1178970_12_ITEM7A_P6_S2	Specific assumptions used in the simulation model include:
1178970_12_ITEM7A_P7_S0	Higher-balance demand deposit tiers and promotional demand accounts move at 50% to 75% of the rate ramp in either direction.
1178970_12_ITEM7A_P8_S0	The following table sets forth the results of the twelve month projected net interest income model as of December 31, 2011.
1178970_12_ITEM7A_P8_S1	The above table indicates that as of December 31, 2011, in the event of a 300 basis point increase in interest rates, whereby rates ramp up evenly over a twelve-month period, the Company would experience a 4.2%, or $9.1 million decrease in net interest income.
1178970_12_ITEM7A_P8_S2	In the event of a 100 basis point decrease in interest rates, whereby rates ramp down evenly over a twelve-month period, the Company would experience a 3.9%, or $8.4 million decrease in net interest income.
1178970_12_ITEM7A_P9_S0	Another measure of interest rate sensitivity is to model changes in economic value of equity through the use of immediate and sustained interest rate shocks.
1178970_12_ITEM7A_P9_S1	The following table illustrates the economic value of equity model results as of December 31, 2011.
1178970_12_ITEM7A_P9_S2	The preceding table indicates that as of December 31, 2011, in the event of an immediate and sustained 300 basis point increase in interest rates, the Company would experience a 14.1%, or $173.9 million reduction in the present value of equity.
1178970_12_ITEM7A_P9_S3	If rates were to decrease 100 basis points, the Company would experience a 0.9%, or $11.0 million decrease in the present value of equity.
1178970_12_ITEM7A_P10_S0	Certain shortcomings are inherent in the methodologies used in the above interest rate risk measurements.
1178970_12_ITEM7A_P10_S1	Modeling changes in net interest income requires the making of certain assumptions regarding prepayment and deposit decay rates, which may or may not reflect the manner in which actual yields and costs respond to changes in market interest rates.
1178970_12_ITEM7A_P10_S2	While management believes such assumptions are reasonable, there can be no assurance that assumed prepayment rates and decay rates will approximate actual future loan prepayment and deposit withdrawal activity.
1178970_12_ITEM7A_P11_S0	sensitive assets and liabilities existing at the beginning of a period remains constant over the period being measured and also assumes that a particular change in interest rates is reflected uniformly across the yield curve regardless of the duration to maturity or repricing of specific assets and liabilities.
1178970_12_ITEM7A_P11_S1	Accordingly, although the net interest income table provides an indication of the Company s interest rate risk exposure at a particular point in time, such measurement is not intended to and does not provide a precise forecast of the effect of changes in market interest rates on net interest income and will differ from actual results.
