1178970_12_ITEM8_P2_S0	Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm The Board of Directors and Stockholders Provident Financial Services, Inc.: We have audited the accompanying consolidated statements of financial condition of Provident Financial Services, Inc. and subsidiary (the Company ) as of December 31, 2011 and 2010, and the related consolidated statements of operations, changes in stockholders equity, and cash flows for each of the years in the three-year period ended December 31, 2011.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P2_S1	These consolidated financial statements are the responsibility of the Company s management.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P2_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these consolidated financial statements based on our audits.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P2_S3	We conducted our audits in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1178970_12_ITEM8_P2_S4	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P3_S0	An audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial statements.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P3_S1	An audit also includes assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P3_S2	We believe that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P3_S3	In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of Provident Financial Services, Inc. and subsidiary as of December 31, 2011 and 2010, and the results of their operations and their cash flows for each of the years in the three-year period ended December 31, 2011, in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P4_S0	As discussed in Note 1 to the consolidated financial statements, the Company changed its method of evaluating other-than-temporary impairment of debt securities due to the adoption of new accounting requirements issued by the Financial Accounting Standards Board, as of April 1, 2009.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P4_S1	We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), Provident Financial Services, Inc. s internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2011, based on criteria established in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission ( COSO ), and our report dated February 29, 2012 expressed an unqualified opinion on the effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P5_S0	Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm The Board of Directors and Stockholders Provident Financial Services, Inc.: We have audited Provident Financial Services, Inc. s and subsidiary (the Company ) internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2011, based on criteria established in Internal Control-Integrated Framework issued by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission ( COSO ) .
1178970_12_ITEM8_P5_S1	The Company s management is responsible for maintaining effective internal control over financial reporting and for its assessment of the effectiveness of internal control over financial reporting, included in the accompanying Management s Report on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P5_S2	Our responsibility is to express an opinion on the Company s internal control over financial reporting based on our audit.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P5_S3	We conducted our audit in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States).
1178970_12_ITEM8_P5_S4	Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable assurance about whether effective internal control over financial reporting was maintained in all material respects.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P5_S5	Our audit included obtaining an understanding of internal control over financial reporting, assessing the risk that a material weakness exists and testing and evaluating the design and operating effectiveness of internal control based on the assessed risk.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P5_S6	Our audit also included performing such other procedures as we considered necessary in the circumstances.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P5_S7	We believe that our audit provides a reasonable basis for our opinion.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P6_S0	A company s internal control over financial reporting is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance regarding the reliability of financial reporting and the preparation of financial statements for external purposes in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P6_S1	A company s internal control over financial reporting includes those policies and procedures that (1) pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect the transactions and dispositions of the assets of the company; (2) provide reasonable assurance that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures of the company are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and directors of the company; and (3) provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use, or disposition of the company s assets that could have a material effect on the financial statements.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P6_S2	Because of its inherent limitations, internal control over financial reporting may not prevent or detect misstatements.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P6_S3	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P6_S4	In our opinion, Provident Financial Services, Inc. and subsidiary maintained, in all material respects, effective internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2011, based on criteria established in Internal Control Integrated Framework issued by the COSO.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P6_S5	We also have audited, in accordance with the standards of the Public Company Accounting Oversight Board (United States), the consolidated statements of financial condition of Provident Financial Services, Inc. and subsidiary as of December 31, 2011 and 2010, and the related consolidated statements of operations, changes in stockholders equity, and cash flows for each of the years in the three-year period ended December 31, 2011, and our report dated February 29, 2012 expressed an unqualified opinion on those consolidated financial statements.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P7_S0	See accompanying notes to consolidated financial statements.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P8_S0	See accompanying notes to consolidated financial statements.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P9_S0	The consolidated financial statements include the accounts of Provident Financial Services, Inc. (the Company ), The Provident Bank (the Bank ) and their wholly owned subsidiaries.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P9_S1	All intercompany balances and transactions have been eliminated in consolidation.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P10_S0	Business The Company, through the Bank, provides a full range of banking services to individual and business customers through branch offices in New Jersey.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P10_S1	The Bank is subject to competition from other financial institutions and to the regulations of certain federal and state agencies, and undergoes periodic examinations by those regulatory authorities.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P11_S0	The consolidated financial statements of the Company have been prepared in conformity with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles ( GAAP ).
1178970_12_ITEM8_P12_S0	In preparing the consolidated financial statements, management is required to make estimates and assumptions about future events.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P12_S1	These estimates and the underlying assumptions affect the reported amounts of assets and liabilities and disclosures about contingent assets and liabilities as of the dates of the consolidated statements of financial condition, and revenues and expenses for the periods then ended.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P12_S2	Such estimates are used in connection with the determination of the allowance for loan losses, evaluation of goodwill for impairment, evaluation of other-than-temporary impairment on securities, evaluation of the need for valuation allowances on deferred tax assets, and determination of liabilities related to retirement and other post-retirement benefits, among others.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P12_S3	These estimates and assumptions are based on management s best estimates and judgment.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P12_S4	Management evaluates its estimates and assumptions on an ongoing basis using historical experience and other factors, including the current economic environment, which management believes to be reasonable under the circumstances.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P12_S5	Such estimates and assumptions are adjusted when facts and circumstances dictate.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P12_S6	Illiquid credit markets, volatile securities markets, and declines in the housing market and the economy generally have combined to increase the uncertainty inherent in such estimates and assumptions.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P12_S7	As future events and their effects cannot be determined with precision, actual results could differ significantly from these estimates.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P12_S8	Changes in estimates resulting from continuing changes in the economic environment will be reflected in the financial statements in future periods.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P13_S0	Cash and Cash Equivalents For purposes of reporting cash flows, cash and cash equivalents include cash and due from banks, Federal funds sold and commercial paper with maturity dates less than 90 days.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P14_S0	Securities Securities include investment securities held to maturity and securities available for sale.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P14_S1	Securities that the Company has the positive intent and ability to hold to maturity are classified as investment securities held to maturity and reported at amortized cost.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P14_S2	Securities to be held for indefinite periods of time and not intended to be held to maturity are classified as securities available for sale and are reported at estimated fair value, with unrealized gains and losses excluded from earnings and reported as a separate component of stockholders equity, net of deferred taxes.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P15_S0	PROVIDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES, INC. AND SUBSIDIARY Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements December 31, 2011, 2010 and 2009 The estimated fair values of the Company s securities are affected by changes in interest rates, credit spreads, and market illiquidity.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P15_S1	The Company conducts a periodic review and evaluation of the securities portfolio to determine if any declines in the fair values of securities are other-than-temporary.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P15_S2	As a result of the Company s adoption of new guidance under Financial Accounting Standards Board ( FASB ) Accounting Standard Codification ( ASC ) Topic 320 Investments-Debt and Equity Securities on April 1, 2009, to determine if a decline in value is other-than- temporary, the Company evaluates if it has the intent to sell these securities or if it is more likely than not that the Company would be required to sell the securities before the anticipated recovery.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P15_S3	If such a decline were deemed other-than-temporary, the Company would measure the total credit-related component of the unrealized loss, and recognize that portion of the loss as a charge to current period earnings.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P15_S4	The remaining portion of the unrealized loss would be recognized as an adjustment to accumulated other comprehensive income.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P16_S0	In general, as interest rates rise, the market value of fixed-rate securities decreases and as interest rates fall, the market value of fixed-rate securities increases.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P16_S1	The market for non-investment grade, privately issued mortgage-backed securities remains illiquid and prices have not appreciated despite favorable movements in interest rates.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P16_S2	To determine if a decline in value is other-than-temporary, the Company evaluates if it has the intent to sell these securities or if it is more likely than not that the Company would be required to sell the securities before the anticipated recovery.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P17_S0	Premiums and discounts on securities are amortized and accreted to income using a method that approximates the interest method over the remaining period to contractual maturity, adjusted for anticipated prepayments.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P17_S1	Dividend and interest income are recognized when earned.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P17_S2	Realized gains and losses are recognized when securities are sold or called based on the specific identification method.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P18_S0	Fair Value of Financial Instruments GAAP establishes a fair value hierarchy that prioritizes the inputs to valuation techniques used to measure fair value.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P18_S1	The hierarchy gives the highest priority to unadjusted quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities (level 1 measurements) and the lowest priority to unobservable inputs (level 3 measurements).
1178970_12_ITEM8_P18_S2	The three levels of fair value hierarchy are as follows:
1178970_12_ITEM8_P19_S0	Prices or valuation techniques that require inputs that are both significant to the fair value measurement and unobservable (i.e., supported by little or no market activity).
1178970_12_ITEM8_P20_S0	A financial instrument s level within the fair value hierarchy is based on the lowest level of input that is significant to the fair value measurement.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P21_S0	Federal Home Loan Bank of New York Stock The Bank, as a member of the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York ( FHLB ), is required to hold shares of capital stock of the FHLB at cost based on a specified formula.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P21_S1	The Bank carries this investment at cost, which approximates fair value.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P22_S0	PROVIDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES, INC. AND SUBSIDIARY Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements December 31, 2011, 2010 and 2009 Loans Loans receivable are carried at unpaid principal balances plus unamortized premiums, purchase accounting mark-to-market adjustments, certain deferred direct loan origination costs and deferred loan origination fees and discounts, less the allowance for loan losses.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P22_S1	The Bank defers loan origination fees and certain direct loan origination costs and accretes such amounts as an adjustment of yield over the expected lives of the related loans using the interest method.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P22_S2	Premiums and discounts on loans purchased are amortized or accreted as an adjustment of yield over the contractual lives, of the related loans, adjusted for prepayments when applicable, using methodologies which approximate the interest method.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P22_S3	Loans are generally placed on non-accrual status when they are past due 90 days or more as to contractual obligations or when other circumstances indicate that collection is questionable.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P22_S4	When a loan is placed on non-accrual status, any interest accrued but not received is reversed against interest income.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P22_S5	Payments received on a non-accrual loan are either applied to the outstanding principal balance or recorded as interest income, depending on an assessment of the ability to collect the loan.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P22_S6	A non-accrual loan is restored to accrual status when principal and interest payments become less than 90 days past due and its future collectibility is reasonably assured.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P23_S0	An impaired loan is defined as a loan for which it is probable, based on current information, that the lender will not collect all amounts due under the contractual terms of the loan agreement.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P23_S1	Impaired loans are individually assessed to determine that each loan s carrying value is not in excess of the fair value of the related collateral or the present value of the expected future cash flows.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P23_S2	Residential mortgage and consumer loans are deemed smaller balance homogeneous loans which are evaluated collectively for impairment and are therefore excluded from the population of impaired loans.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P24_S0	Allowance for Loan Losses Losses on loans are charged to the allowance for loan losses.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P24_S1	Additions to this allowance are made by recoveries of loans previously charged off and by a provision charged to expense.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P25_S0	The determination of the balance of the allowance for loan losses is based on an analysis of the loan portfolio, economic conditions, historical loan loss experience and other factors that warrant recognition in providing for an adequate allowance.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P25_S1	While management uses available information to recognize losses on loans, future additions to the allowance for loan losses may be necessary based on changes in economic conditions in the Bank s market area.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P25_S2	In addition, various regulatory agencies, as an integral part of their examination process, periodically review the Bank s allowance for loan losses.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P25_S3	Such agencies may require the Bank to recognize additions to the allowance or additional write-downs based on their judgments about information available to them at the time of their examination.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P26_S0	Foreclosed Assets Assets acquired through foreclosure or deed in lieu of foreclosure are carried at the lower of the outstanding loan balance at the time of foreclosure or fair value, less estimated costs to sell.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P26_S1	Fair value is generally based on recent appraisals.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P26_S2	When an asset is acquired, the excess of the loan balance over fair value, less estimated costs to sell, is charged to the allowance for loan losses.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P27_S0	possible write-downs and selling costs that occur subsequent to foreclosure.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P28_S0	Foreclosed assets are carried net of the related reserve.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P29_S0	Operating results from real estate owned, including rental income, operating expenses, and gains and losses realized from the sales of real estate owned, are recorded as incurred.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P29_S1	Banking Premises and Equipment Land is carried at cost.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P29_S2	Banking premises, furniture, fixtures and equipment are carried at cost, less accumulated depreciation, computed using the straight-line method based on their estimated useful lives (generally 25 to 40 years for buildings and 3 to 5 years for furniture and equipment).
1178970_12_ITEM8_P29_S3	Leasehold improvements, carried at cost, net of accumulated depreciation, are amortized over the terms of the leases or the estimated useful lives of the assets, whichever are shorter, using the straight-line method.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P29_S4	Maintenance and repairs are charged to expense as incurred.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P30_S0	Income Taxes The Company uses the asset and liability method of accounting for income taxes.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P30_S1	Under this method, deferred tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the estimated future tax consequences attributable to differences between the financial statement carrying amounts of existing assets and liabilities and their respective tax bases.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P30_S2	Deferred tax assets and liabilities are measured using enacted tax rates in effect for the year in which those temporary differences are expected to be recovered or settled.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P30_S3	The effect on deferred tax assets and liabilities of a change in tax rates is recognized in income in the period that includes the enactment date.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P30_S4	The determination of whether deferred tax assets will be realizable is predicated on estimates of future taxable income.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P30_S5	Such estimates are subject to management s judgment.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P31_S0	A valuation reserve is established when management is unable to conclude that it is more likely than not that it will realize deferred tax assets based on the nature and timing of these items.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P32_S0	The Company recognizes, when applicable, interest and penalties related to unrecognized tax benefits in the provision for income taxes.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P33_S0	Trust Assets Trust assets consisting of securities and other property (other than cash on deposit held by the Bank in fiduciary or agency capacities for customers of the Bank s wholly owned subsidiary, Beacon Trust Company) are not included in the accompanying consolidated statements of financial condition because such properties are not assets of the Bank.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P33_S1	Intangible Assets Intangible assets of the Bank consist of goodwill, core deposit premiums, customer relationship premium and mortgage servicing rights.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P33_S2	Goodwill represents the excess of the purchase price over the estimated fair value of identifiable net assets acquired through purchase acquisitions.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P33_S3	In accordance with GAAP, goodwill with an indefinite useful life is not amortized, but is evaluated for impairment on an annual basis, or more frequently if events or changes in circumstances indicate potential impairment between annual measurement dates.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P33_S4	Goodwill is analyzed for impairment each year at September 30, and the impairment test at September 30, 2011 indicated that there was no impairment.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P34_S0	Core deposit premiums represent the intangible value of depositor relationships assumed in purchase acquisitions and are amortized on an accelerated basis over 8.8 years.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P34_S1	Customer relationship premiums represent the intangible value of customer relationships assumed in the purchase acquisition of Beacon and are amortized on an accelerated basis over 12.0 years.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P35_S0	originated mortgage loans are sold, with servicing rights retained.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P35_S1	Mortgage servicing rights are amortized on an accelerated method based upon the estimated lives of the related loans, adjusted for prepayments.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P35_S2	Mortgage servicing rights are carried at the lower of amortized cost or fair value.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P36_S0	Bank-owned Life Insurance Bank-owned life insurance is accounted for using the cash surrender value method and is recorded at its realizable value.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P37_S0	Employee Benefit Plans The Bank maintains a pension plan which covers full-time employees hired prior to April 1, 2003, the date on which the pension plan was frozen.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P37_S1	The Bank s policy is to fund at least the minimum contribution required by the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P37_S2	GAAP requires an employer to: (a) recognize in its statement of financial position the over-funded or under-funded status of a defined benefit postretirement plan measured as the difference between the fair value of plan assets and the benefit obligation; (b) measure a plan s assets and its obligations that determine its funded status at the end of the employer s fiscal year (with limited exceptions); and (c) recognize as a component of other comprehensive income, net of tax, the actuarial gains and losses and the prior service costs and credits that arise during the period.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P38_S0	The Bank has a 401(k) plan covering substantially all employees of the Bank.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P38_S1	The Bank may match a percentage of the first 6% contributed by participants.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P38_S2	The Bank s matching contribution, if any, is determined by the Board of Directors in its sole discretion.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P39_S0	The Bank has an Employee Stock Ownership Plan ( ESOP ).
1178970_12_ITEM8_P39_S1	The funds borrowed by the ESOP from the Company to purchase the Company s common stock are being repaid from the Bank s contributions and dividends paid on unallocated ESOP shares over a period of up to 30 years.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P39_S2	The Company s common stock not allocated to participants is recorded as a reduction of stockholders equity at cost.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P39_S3	Compensation expense for the ESOP is based on the average price of the Company s stock during each quarter.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P39_S4	Expense related to stock options is based on the fair value of the options at the date of the grant and is recognized ratably over the vesting period of the options.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P39_S5	Expense related to stock awards is based on the fair value of the common stock at the date of the grant and is recognized ratably over the vesting period of the awards.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P40_S0	In connection with the First Sentinel acquisition in July 2004, the Company assumed the First Savings Bank Directors Deferred Fee Plan (the DDFP ).
1178970_12_ITEM8_P40_S1	The DDFP was frozen prior to the acquisition.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P40_S2	The Company recorded a deferred compensation equity instrument and corresponding contra-equity account for the value of the shares held by the DDFP at the July 14, 2004 acquisition date.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P40_S3	These accounts will be liquidated as shares are distributed from the DDFP in accordance with the plan document.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P40_S4	At December 31, 2011, there were 422,723 shares held by the DDFP.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P41_S0	The Bank provides postretirement health care and life insurance plans to certain of its employees.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P41_S1	The life insurance coverage is noncontributory to the participant.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P41_S2	Participants contribute to the cost of medical coverage based on the employee s length of service with the Bank.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P42_S0	actuarial assumptions from the date of hire to the date the employee is fully eligible to receive the benefits.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P43_S0	On December 31, 2002, the Bank eliminated postretirement healthcare benefits for employees with less than 10 years of service.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P44_S0	GAAP requires an employer to: (a) recognize in its statement of financial position the over-funded or under-funded status of a defined benefit postretirement plan measured as the difference between the fair value of plan assets and the benefit obligation; (b) measure a plan s assets and its obligations that determine its funded status as of the end of the employer s fiscal year (with limited exceptions); and (c) recognize as a component of other comprehensive income, net of tax, the actuarial gains and losses and the prior service costs and credits that arise during the period.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P45_S0	Comprehensive Income Comprehensive income is divided into net income and other comprehensive income.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P45_S1	Other comprehensive income includes items previously recorded directly to equity, such as unrealized gains and losses on securities available for sale and amortization related to post-retirement obligations.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P45_S2	Comprehensive income is presented in the Statements of Changes in Stockholders Equity.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P46_S0	Reporting The Company s operations are solely in the financial services industry and include providing to its customers traditional banking and other financial services.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P47_S0	The Company operates primarily in the geographical regions of northern and central New Jersey.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P48_S0	Management makes operating decisions and assesses performance based on an ongoing review of the Bank s consolidated financial results.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P48_S1	Therefore, the Company has a single operating segment for financial reporting purposes.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P49_S0	Basic earnings per share is computed by dividing income available to common stockholders by the weighted average number of shares outstanding for the period.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P49_S1	Diluted earnings per share reflects the potential dilution that could occur if securities or other contracts to issue common stock (such as stock options) were exercised or resulted in the issuance of common stock.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P49_S2	These potentially dilutive shares would then be included in the weighted average number of shares outstanding for the period using the treasury stock method.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P50_S0	Shares issued and shares reacquired during the period are weighted for the portion of the period that they were outstanding.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P51_S0	Impact of Recent Accounting Pronouncements Effective September 30, 2011, the Company early adopted amended guidance on goodwill impairment assessment.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P51_S1	In June 2011, the FASB issued guidance that would simplify the assessment process, under which an entity has the option to first consider qualitative factors to determine whether it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying amount before applying Step 1 of the goodwill impairment assessment.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P51_S2	If a company concludes that it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying amount, the entity would be required to perform Step 1 of the assessment and then, if needed, Step 2 to determine whether goodwill is impaired.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P51_S3	However, if it is more likely than not that the fair value of the reporting unit is more than its carrying amount, the entity does not need to apply the two-step impairment test.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P51_S4	The qualitative assessment is optional and an entity is permitted to go directly to Step 1 without performing the qualitative assessment.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P51_S5	This guidance is effective for annual and interim goodwill impairment tests performed in fiscal years beginning after December 15, 2011.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P51_S6	The adoption of this guidance did not have a material effect on the Company s consolidated statement of condition or results of operations.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P52_S0	PROVIDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES, INC. AND SUBSIDIARY Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements December 31, 2011, 2010 and 2009 In June 2011, the FASB issued guidance regarding the presentation of comprehensive income.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P52_S1	Under this guidance, an entity has the option to present the total of comprehensive income, the components of net income, and the components of other comprehensive income either in a single continuous statement of comprehensive income or in two separate but consecutive statements.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P52_S2	In both choices, an entity is required to present each component of net income along with total net income, each component of other comprehensive income along with a total for other comprehensive income, and a total amount for comprehensive income.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P52_S3	This guidance eliminates the option to present the components of other comprehensive income as part of the statement of changes in stockholders equity.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P53_S0	As originally issued, ASU 2011-5 requires entities to present reclassification adjustments out of accumulated other comprehensive income by component in the statement in which net income is presented and the statement in which other comprehensive income is presented (for both interim and annual financial statements).
1178970_12_ITEM8_P53_S1	This requirement was deferred by ASU 2011-12, Comprehensive Income (Topic 220) Deferral of the Effective Date for Amendments to the Presentation of Reclassifications of Items Out of Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income in Accounting Standards.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P54_S0	ASU No. 2011-05 is effective for all interim and annual periods beginning on or after December 15, 2011 with early adoption permitted, and must be applied retrospectively.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P54_S1	The adoption of this guidance is not expected to have a material effect on the Company s consolidated statement of condition or results of operations.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P55_S0	In May 2011, the FASB issued guidance which results in common principles and requirements for measuring fair value and for disclosing information about fair value measurements in accordance with GAAP and International Financial Reporting Standards.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P55_S1	This guidance is to be applied prospectively and is effective during interim and annual periods beginning after December 15, 2011.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P55_S2	The adoption of this guidance is not expected to have a material effect on the Company s consolidated statement of condition or results of operations In April 2011, the FASB issued guidance regarding a creditor s determination of whether a restructuring is a TDR.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P56_S0	The guidance clarifies which loan modifications constitute TDRs.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P56_S1	It is intended to assist creditors in determining whether a modification of the terms of a receivable meets the criteria to be considered a TDR, both for purposes of recording an impairment loss and for disclosure of TDRs.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P57_S0	This guidance applies retrospectively to restructurings occurring on or after the beginning of the fiscal year of adoption.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P57_S1	The adoption of this guidance on July 1, 2011 did not have a material effect on the Company s consolidated statement of condition or results of operations.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P58_S0	In April 2011, the FASB issued guidance to improve financial reporting of repurchase agreements and other agreements that both entitle and obligate a transferor to repurchase or redeem financial assets before their maturity.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P58_S1	The amendments to this guidance remove from the assessment of effective control: (1) the criterion requiring the transferor to have the ability to repurchase or redeem the financial assets on substantially the agreed terms, even in the event of default by the transferee, and (2) the collateral maintenance implementation guidance related to that criterion.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P58_S2	Other criteria applicable to the assessment of effective control are not changed by this new guidance.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P58_S3	Those criteria indicate that the transferor is deemed to have maintained effective control over the financial assets transferred (and thus must account for the transaction as a secured borrowing) for agreements that both entitle and obligate the transferor to repurchase or redeem the financial assets before their maturity if all of the following conditions are met: (1) the financial assets to be repurchased or redeemed are the same or substantially the same as those transferred; (2) the agreement is to repurchase or redeem them before maturity, at a fixed or determinable price; and (3) the agreement is entered into contemporaneously with, or in contemplation of, the transfer.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P59_S0	This guidance is effective for the first interim or annual period beginning on or after December 15, 2011, and should be applied prospectively to transactions or modifications of existing transactions that occur on or after the effective date.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P59_S1	The adoption of this guidance is not expected to have a material effect on the Company s consolidated statement of condition or results of operations.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P60_S0	PROVIDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES, INC. AND SUBSIDIARY Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements December 31, 2011, 2010 and 2009 In December 2010, the FASB issued guidance regarding business combinations.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P60_S1	When a business combination occurs, the guidance requires entities to disclose certain pro forma information about revenues and earnings of the combined entity within the notes to the financial statements.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P60_S2	This guidance requires that the pro forma information be presented as if the business combination occurred at the beginning of the prior annual reporting period for purposes of calculating both the current reporting period and the prior reporting period pro forma financial information.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P60_S3	It also requires that this disclosure be accompanied by a narrative description of the amount and nature of material non-recurring pro forma adjustments.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P61_S0	This guidance pertains to business combinations with effective dates on or after December 15, 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P61_S1	The adoption of this guidance did not have a material effect on the Company s consolidated statement of condition or results of operations.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P62_S0	On January 15, 2003, the Bank completed its plan of conversion, and the Bank became a wholly-owned subsidiary of the Company.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P62_S1	The Company sold 59.6 million shares of common stock (par value $0.01 per share) at $10.00 per share.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P62_S2	The Company received net proceeds in the amount of $567.2 million.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P62_S3	In connection with the Bank s commitment to its community, the plan of conversion provided for the establishment of a charitable foundation.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P62_S4	Provident donated $4.8 million in cash and 1.92 million of authorized but unissued shares of common stock to the foundation, which amounted to $24.0 million in aggregate.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P63_S0	The Company recognized an expense, net of income tax benefit, equal to the cash and fair value of the stock during 2003.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P63_S1	Conversion costs were deferred and deducted from the proceeds of the shares sold in the offering.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P63_S2	Upon completion of the plan of conversion, a liquidation account was established in an amount equal to the total equity of the Bank as of the latest practicable date prior to the conversion.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P63_S3	The liquidation account was established to provide a limited priority claim to the assets of the Bank to eligible account holders and supplemental eligible account holders as defined in the Plan, who continue to maintain deposits in the Bank after the conversion.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P63_S4	In the unlikely event of a complete liquidation of the Bank, and only in such event, each eligible account holder and supplemental eligible account holder would receive a liquidation distribution, prior to any payment to the holder of the Bank s common stock.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P63_S5	This distribution would be based upon each eligible account holder s and supplemental eligible account holder s proportionate share of the then total remaining qualifying deposits.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P63_S6	At December 31, 2011, the liquidation account, which is an off-balance sheet memorandum account, amounted to $22,592,000.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P64_S0	On August 11, 2011, the Company s wholly owned subsidiary, The Provident Bank, completed its acquisition of Beacon Trust Company, a New Jersey limited purpose trust company, and Beacon Global Asset Management, Inc., an SEC-registered investment advisor incorporated in Delaware (collectively Beacon ).
1178970_12_ITEM8_P64_S1	Pursuant to the terms of the Stock Purchase Agreement announced on May 19, 2011, Beacon s former parent company, Beacon Financial Corporation may be paid cash consideration in an amount up to $10.5 million, based upon the acquired companies financial performance in the three years following the closing of the transaction.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P64_S2	The purpose of the Beacon acquisition was to significantly expand the Company s wealth management business throughout the state of New Jersey.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P65_S0	Beacon s expertise in trust and wealth management services strategically positions the Company to increase market share and enhance the Company s non-interest earnings growth.

1178970_12_ITEM8_P81_S3	The following table summarizes the aging of loans receivable by portfolio segment and class as follows (in thousands):
1178970_12_ITEM8_P82_S0	Included in loans receivable are loans for which the accrual of interest income has been discontinued due to deterioration in the financial condition of the borrowers.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P82_S1	The principal amount of these nonaccrual loans was $122,549,000 and $97,264,000 at December 31, 2011 and 2010, respectively.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P82_S2	There were no loans ninety days or greater past due and still accruing interest at December 31, 2011, or 2010.

1178970_12_ITEM8_P82_S4	The amount of cash basis interest income that was recognized on impaired loans during the years ended December 31, 2011, 2010 and 2009 was insignificant for the periods presented.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P83_S0	The Company defines an impaired loan as a non-homogenous loan greater than $1.0 million for which it is probable, based on current information, that the Bank will not collect all amounts due under the contractual terms of the loan agreement.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P83_S1	Impaired loans also include all loans modified as troubled debt restructurings ( TDRs ).
1178970_12_ITEM8_P83_S2	A loan is deemed to be a TDR when a loan modification resulting in a concession is made by the Bank in an effort to mitigate potential loss arising from a borrower s financial difficulty.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P83_S3	Smaller balance homogeneous loans including residential mortgages and other consumer loans are evaluated collectively for impairment and are excluded from the definition of impaired loans, unless modified as TDRs.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P84_S0	The Company separately calculates the reserve for loan loss on impaired loans.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P84_S1	The Company may recognize impairment of a loan based upon (1) the present value of expected cash flows discounted at the effective interest rate; or (2) if a loan is collateral dependent, the fair value of collateral; or (3) the market price of the loan.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P84_S2	Additionally, if impaired loans have risk characteristics in common, those loans may be aggregated and historical statistics may be used as a means of measuring those impaired loans.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P85_S0	The Company uses third-party appraisals to determine the fair value of the underlying collateral in its analyses of collateral dependent impaired loans.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P85_S1	A third party appraisal is generally ordered as soon as a loan is designated as a collateral dependent impaired loan and updated annually, or more frequently if required.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P85_S2	A specific allocation of the allowance for loan losses is established for each impaired loan with a carrying balance greater than the collateral s fair value, less estimated costs to sell.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P85_S3	Charge-offs are generally taken for the amount of the specific allocation when operations associated with the respective property cease and it is determined that collection of amounts due will be derived primarily from the disposition of the collateral.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P86_S0	time, including rent rolls, borrower financial statements and tax returns, prior appraisals, management s knowledge of the market and collateral, and internally prepared collateral valuations based upon market assumptions regarding vacancy and capitalization rates, each as and where applicable.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P87_S0	Once the appraisal is received and reviewed, the specific reserves are adjusted to reflect the appraised value.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P87_S1	The Company believes there have been no significant time lapses during the process described.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P88_S0	At December 31, 2011, there were 65 impaired loans totaling $103.2 million, of which 48 loans totaling $63.1 million were TDRs.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P88_S1	Included in this total were 38 TDRs related to 36 borrowers totaling $38.9 million that were performing in accordance with their restructured terms and which continued to accrue interest at December 31, 2011.

1178970_12_ITEM8_P88_S3	Included in this total were 6 TDRs related to 5 borrowers totaling $7.6 million that were performing in accordance with their restructured terms and which continued to accrue interest at December 31, 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P88_S4	Loans receivable summarized by portfolio segment and impairment method are as follows (in thousands):
1178970_12_ITEM8_P89_S0	PROVIDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES, INC. AND SUBSIDIARY Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements December 31, 2011, 2010 and 2009 Loan modifications to customers experiencing financial difficulties that are considered TDRs primarily involve lowering the monthly payments on such loans through either a reduction in interest rate below a market rate, an extension of the term of the loan without a corresponding adjustment to the risk premium reflected in the interest rate, or a combination of these two methods.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P89_S1	These modifications generally do not result in the forgiveness of principal or accrued interest.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P89_S2	In addition, the Company attempts to obtain additional collateral or guarantor support when modifying such loans.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P90_S0	If the borrower has demonstrated performance under the previous terms and our underwriting process shows the borrower has the capacity to continue to perform under the restructured terms, the loan will continue to accrue interest.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P90_S1	Non-accruing restructured loans may be returned to accrual status when there has been a sustained period of repayment performance (generally six consecutive months of payments) and both principal and interest are deemed collectible.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P91_S0	In the third quarter of 2011, the Company adopted new accounting guidance issued by the FASB, and reassessed all restructurings that occurred between January 1, 2011 and September 30, 2011 for identification as TDRs.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P91_S1	As a result of this reassessment, the Company identified an additional five loan relationships totaling $10.8 million as TDRs, $9.2 million of which had been previously identified as non-accrual impaired loans.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P91_S2	The following tables present the number of loans modified as TDRs during the year ended December 31, 2011 and their balances immediately prior to the modification date and post-modification as of December 31, 2011.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P91_S3	All TDRs are impaired loans, which are individually evaluated for impairment, as previously discussed.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P91_S4	Estimated collateral values of collateral dependent impaired loans modified during the year ended December 31, 2011 exceeded the carrying amounts of such loans.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P91_S5	As a result, there were no charge-offs recorded on collateral dependent impaired loans presented in the preceding tables for the year ended December 31, 2011.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P91_S6	The allowance for loan losses associated with the TDRs presented in the preceding tables totaled $5.5 million at December 31, 2011, and was included in the allowance for loan losses for loans individually evaluated for impairment.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P91_S7	The TDRs presented in the preceding tables had a weighted average modified interest rate of approximately 4.58 percent, compared to a yield of 5.65 percent prior to modification for the year ended December 31, 2011.

1178970_12_ITEM8_P93_S0	TDRs that subsequently default are considered collateral dependent impaired loans and are evaluated for impairment based on the estimated fair value of the underlying collateral less expected selling costs.

1178970_12_ITEM8_P98_S0	In the normal course of conducting its business, the Bank extends credit to meet the financing needs of its customers through commitments.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P98_S1	Commitments and contingent liabilities, such as commitments to extend credit (including loan commitments of $497,219,000 and $474,208,000, at December 31, 2011 and 2010, respectively, and undisbursed home equity and personal credit lines of $273,170,000 and $258,012,000, at December 31, 2011 and 2010, respectively), exist, which are not reflected in the accompanying consolidated financial statements.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P99_S0	These instruments involve elements of credit and interest rate risk in excess of the amount recognized in the consolidated financial statements.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P100_S0	The Bank uses the same credit policies and collateral requirements in making commitments and conditional obligations as it does for on-balance sheet loans.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P100_S1	Commitments generally have fixed expiration dates or other termination clauses and may require payment of a fee.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P100_S2	Since the commitments may expire without being drawn upon, the total commitment amounts do not necessarily represent future cash requirements.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P101_S0	The Bank evaluates each customer s creditworthiness on a case-by-case basis.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P101_S1	The amount of collateral obtained, if deemed necessary by the Bank upon extension of credit, is based on management s credit evaluation of the borrower.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P102_S0	The Bank grants residential real estate loans on single- and multi-family dwellings to borrowers primarily in New Jersey.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P102_S1	Its borrowers abilities to repay their obligations are dependent upon various factors, including the borrowers income and net worth, cash flows generated by the underlying collateral, value of the underlying collateral, and priority of the Bank s lien on the property.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P102_S2	Such factors are dependent upon various economic conditions and individual circumstances beyond the Bank s control; the Bank is therefore subject to risk of loss.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P102_S3	The Bank believes that its lending policies and procedures adequately minimize the potential exposure to such risks and that adequate provisions for loan losses are provided for all known and inherent risks.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P103_S0	Collateral and/or guarantees are required for virtually all loans.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P103_S1	The Company utilizes an internal nine-point risk rating system to summarize its loan portfolio into categories with similar risk characteristics.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P103_S2	Loans deemed to be acceptable quality are rated 1 through 4, with a rating of 1 established for loans with minimal risk.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P103_S3	Loans that are deemed to be of questionable quality are rated 5 (watch) or 6 (special mention).
1178970_12_ITEM8_P103_S4	Loans with adverse classifications (substandard, doubtful or loss) are rated 7, 8 or 9, respectively.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P103_S5	Commercial mortgage, commercial, multi-family and construction loans are rated individually, and each lending officer is responsible for risk rating loans in his or her portfolio.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P103_S6	These risk ratings are then reviewed by the department manager and/or the Chief Lending Officer and by the Credit Administration Department.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P103_S7	The risk ratings are also confirmed through periodic loan review examinations, which are currently performed by an independent third party.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P103_S8	Reports by the independent third party are presented directly to the Audit Committee of the Board of Directors.

1178970_12_ITEM8_P119_S0	PROVIDENT FINANCIAL SERVICES, INC. AND SUBSIDIARY Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements December 31, 2011, 2010 and 2009 Net periodic benefit cost (increase) for the years ending December 31, 2011, 2010 and 2009, included the following components (in thousands): The weighted average actuarial assumptions used in the plan determinations at December 31, 2011, 2010 and 2009 were as follows: The Company provides its actuary with certain rate assumptions used in measuring the benefit obligation.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P119_S1	The most significant of these is the discount rate used to calculate the period-end present value of the benefit obligations, and the expense to be included in the following year s financial statements.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P119_S2	A lower discount rate will result in a higher benefit obligation and expense, while a higher discount rate will result in a lower benefit obligation and expense.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P119_S3	The discount rate assumption was determined based on a cash flow-yield curve model specific to the Company s pension and post-retirement plans.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P119_S4	We compare this rate to certain market indices, such as long-term treasury bonds, or the Citigroup pension liability indices, for reasonableness.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P120_S0	A discount rate of 4.50% was selected for the December 31, 2011 measurement date and the 2011 expense calculation.

1178970_12_ITEM8_P127_S0	The Bank maintains a non-qualified supplemental retirement plan for certain senior officers of the Bank.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P127_S1	This plan was frozen as of April 1, 2003.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P128_S0	The Supplemental Executive Retirement Plan, which is unfunded, provides benefits in excess of the benefits permitted to be paid by the pension plan under provisions of the tax law.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P128_S1	Amounts expensed under this supplemental retirement plan amounted to $173,000, $173,000 and $184,000 for the years 2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P128_S2	At December 31, 2011 and 2010, $2,165,000 and $2,136,000, respectively, were recorded in other liabilities on the consolidated statements of condition for this supplemental retirement plan.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P128_S3	An increase of $117,000 and decreases of $9,000, and $20,000, net of tax, were recorded in other comprehensive income for 2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively, in connection with this supplemental retirement plan.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P129_S0	The Bank maintains a Retirement Plan for the Board of Directors of the Bank, a non-qualified plan that provides cash payments for up to ten years to eligible retired board members based on age and length of service requirements.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P129_S1	The maximum payment under this plan to a board member, who terminates service on or after the age of 72 with at least ten years of service on the board, is forty quarterly payments of $1,250.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P129_S2	The Bank may suspend payments under this plan if it does not meet Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation or New Jersey Department of Banking and Insurance minimum capital requirements.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P129_S3	The Bank may terminate this plan at any time although such termination may not reduce or eliminate any benefit previously accrued to a board member without his or her consent.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P129_S4	The plan further provides that, in the event of a change in control (as defined in the plan), the undistributed balance of a director s accrued benefit will be distributed to him or her within 60 days of the change in control.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P129_S5	The Bank paid $15,000 to former board members under this plan for each of the years ended December 31, 2011, 2010 and 2009.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P129_S6	At December 31, 2011 and 2010, $211,000 and $221,000, respectively, were recorded in other liabilities on the consolidated statements of financial condition for this retirement plan.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P129_S7	An increase of $13,000, a decrease of $14,000, and an increase of $29,000, net of tax, were recorded in other comprehensive income for 2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively, in connection with this plan.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P130_S0	The plan was amended in December 2005 to terminate benefits under this plan for any directors who had less than ten years of service on the board of directors of the Bank as of December 31, 2006.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P131_S0	The ESOP is a tax-qualified plan designed to invest primarily in the Company s common stock that provides employees with the opportunity to receive a funded retirement benefit from the Bank, based primarily on the value of the Company s common stock.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P131_S1	The ESOP purchased 4,769,464 shares of the Company s common stock at an average price of $17.09 per share with the proceeds of a loan from the Company to the ESOP.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P131_S2	The outstanding loan principal at December 31, 2011, was $62.8 million.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P131_S3	Shares of the Company s common stock pledged as collateral for the loan are released from the pledge for allocation to participants as loan payments are made.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P131_S4	For the ESOP years ending December 31, 2011 and 2010, 183,024 shares and 178,510 shares were released, respectively.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P131_S5	Unallocated ESOP shares held in suspense totaled 3,246,276 at December 31, 2011, and had a fair value of $43.5 million.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P131_S6	ESOP compensation expense for the years ended December 31, 2011, 2010 and 2009 was $1,926,000, $1,840,000 and $1,494,000, respectively.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P132_S0	The Supplemental Executive Savings Plan is a non-qualified plan that provides supplemental benefits to certain executives who are prevented from receiving the full benefits contemplated by the 401(k) Plan s and the ESOP s benefit formulas under tax law limits for tax-qualified plans.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P132_S1	The Supplemental Executive Savings Plan was frozen effective December 31, 2003, and all benefit distributions have been made.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P133_S0	Effective January 1, 2004, the Bank established a deferred compensation plan for executive management and key employees of the Bank, known as The Provident Bank Non-Qualified Supplemental Employee Stock Ownership Plan (the Supplemental ESOP ).
1178970_12_ITEM8_P133_S1	The Supplemental ESOP was amended and restated as the Non-Qualified Supplemental Defined Contribution Plan (the Supplemental DC Plan ), effective January 1, 2010.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P133_S2	The Supplemental DC Plan is a non-qualified plan that provides additional benefits to certain executives whose benefits under the 401(k) Plan and ESOP are limited by tax law limitations applicable to tax-qualified plans.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P133_S3	The Supplemental DC Plan requires a contribution by the Bank for each participant who also participates in the 401(k) Plan and ESOP equal to the amount that would have been contributed under the terms of the of the 401(k) Plan and ESOP but for the tax law limitations, less the amount actually contributed under the 401(k) Plan and ESOP.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P133_S4	The Supplemental DC Plan provides for a phantom stock allocation for qualified contributions that may not be accrued in the qualified ESOP and for matching contributions that may not be accrued in the qualified 401(k) Plan due to tax law limitations.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P133_S5	Under the Supplemental 401(k) provision, the estimated expense for the year ending December 31, 2011 and 2010 was $6,000 and $5,000 and included the matching contributions plus interest credited at an annual rate equal to the ten-year bond-equivalent yield on US Treasury securities.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P133_S6	Under the Supplemental ESOP provision, the estimated expense for the year ending December 31, 2011 and 2010 was $24,000 and 17,000, respectively.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P133_S7	The phantom equity is treated as equity awards (expensed at the time of allocation) and not liability awards which would require periodic adjustment to market, as participants do not have an option to take their distribution in cash.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P134_S0	2008 Long-Term Equity Incentive Plan Upon stockholders approval of the 2008 Long-Term Equity Incentive Plan on April 23, 2008, shares available for stock awards and stock options under the 2003 Stock Award Plan and the 2003 Stock Option Plan were reserved for issuance under the new 2008 Long-Term Equity Incentive Plan.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P134_S1	No additional grants of stock awards and stock options will be made under the 2003 Stock Award Plan and the 2003 Stock Option Plan.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P134_S2	The new plan authorized the issuance of up to 2,481,382 shares of Company common stock with no more than 1,850,000 shares permitted to be issued as stock awards.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P134_S3	Shares previously awarded under the 2003 plans that are subsequently forfeited or expire may also be issued under the new plan.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P135_S0	Stock Awards As a general rule, restricted stock grants are held in escrow for the benefit of the award recipient until vested.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P135_S1	Awards outstanding generally vest in three or five annual installments, commencing one year from the date of the award.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P135_S2	Additionally, certain awards are three-year performance vesting awards, which may or may not vest depending upon the attainment of certain corporate financial targets.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P135_S3	Expense attributable to stock awards amounted to $3,169,000, $2,422,000 and $1,888,000 for the years ended December 31, 2011, 2010 and 2009, respectively.

1178970_12_ITEM8_P141_S0	The fair value of the Company stock option awards are expensed on a straight-line basis over the vesting period of the stock option.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P141_S1	The risk-free rate is based on the implied yield on a U.S. Treasury bond with a term approximating the expected term of the option.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P141_S2	The expected volatility computation is based on historical volatility over a period approximating the expected term of the option.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P141_S3	The dividend yield is based on the annual dividend payment per share, divided by the grant date stock price.
1178970_12_ITEM8_P142_S0	The expected option term is a function of the option life and the vesting period.
