1178970_13_ITEM1_P87_S0	The allowance for loan losses is a valuation account that reflects an evaluation of the probable losses in the loan portfolio.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P87_S1	The allowance for loan losses is maintained through provisions for loan losses that are charged to income.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P87_S2	Charge-offs against the allowance for loan losses are taken on loans where it is determined the collection of loan principal is unlikely.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P87_S3	Recoveries made on loans that have been charged-off are credited to the allowance for loan losses.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P88_S0	Management s evaluation of the adequacy of the allowance for loan losses includes the review of all loans on which the collectability of principal may not be reasonably assured.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P89_S0	For residential mortgage and consumer loans this is determined primarily by delinquency and collateral values.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P89_S1	For commercial real estate and commercial loans, an extensive review of financial performance, payment history and collateral values is conducted on a quarterly basis.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P90_S0	As part of the evaluation of the adequacy of the allowance for loan losses, each quarter management prepares an analysis that categorizes the entire loan portfolio by certain risk characteristics such as loan type (residential mortgage, commercial mortgage, construction, commercial, etc.) and loan risk rating.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P90_S1	The factors considered in assessing the adequacy of the allowance for loan losses include the following:
1178970_13_ITEM1_P91_S0	duration and breadth of the current business cycle.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P92_S0	When assigning a risk rating to a loan, management utilizes the Bank s internal nine-point risk rating system.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P92_S1	Loans deemed to be acceptable quality are rated 1 through 4, with a rating of 1 established for loans with minimal risk.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P92_S2	Loans that are deemed to be of questionable quality are rated 5 (watch) or 6 (special mention).
1178970_13_ITEM1_P92_S3	Loans with adverse classifications (substandard, doubtful or loss) are rated 7, 8 or 9, respectively.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P92_S4	Commercial mortgage, commercial, multi-family and construction loans are rated individually, and each lending officer is responsible for risk rating loans in his or her portfolio.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P92_S5	These risk ratings are then reviewed by the department manager and/or the Chief Lending Officer and by the Credit Administration Department.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P92_S6	The risk ratings for loans requiring Credit Committee approval are periodically reviewed by the Credit Committee in the credit approval or renewal process.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P92_S7	The risk ratings are also confirmed through periodic loan review examinations, which are currently performed by an independent third party.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P92_S8	Reports by the independent third party are presented directly to the Audit and Risk Committees of the Board of Directors.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P93_S0	Each quarter, the lending groups prepare individual Credit Risk Management Reports for the Credit Administration Department.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P93_S1	These reports review all commercial loans and commercial mortgage loans that have been determined to involve above-average risk (risk rating of 5 or worse).
1178970_13_ITEM1_P93_S2	The Credit Risk Management Reports contain the reason for the risk rating assigned to each loan, status of the loan and any current developments.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P93_S3	These reports are submitted to a committee chaired by the Chief Credit Officer.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P93_S4	Each loan officer reviews the loan and the corresponding Credit Risk Management Report with the committee and the risk rating is evaluated for appropriateness.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P93_S5	Management assigns general valuation allowance ( GVA ) percentages to each risk rating category for use in allocating the allowance for loan losses, giving consideration to historical loss experience by loan type, as well as qualitative and environmental factors such as:
1178970_13_ITEM1_P94_S0	effects of changes in credit concentration.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P94_S1	The appropriateness of these percentages is evaluated by management at least annually and monitored on a quarterly basis, with changes made when they are required.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P94_S2	In the first quarter of 2012, management completed its most recent evaluation of the GVA percentages.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P94_S3	As a result of that evaluation, GVA percentages applied to the marine portfolio were increased to reflect an increase in historical loss experience.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P95_S0	The reserve factors applied to each loan risk rating are inherently subjective in nature.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P96_S0	Reserve factors are assigned to each of the risk rating categories.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P96_S1	This methodology permits adjustments to the allowance for loan losses in the event that, in management s judgment, significant conditions impacting the credit quality and collectability of the loan portfolio as of the evaluation date are not otherwise adequately reflected in the analysis.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P96_S2	The provision for loan losses is established after considering the allowance for loan loss analysis, the amount of the allowance for loan losses in relation to the total loan balance, loan portfolio growth, loan portfolio composition, loan delinquency trends and peer group analysis.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P96_S3	As a result of this process, management has established an unallocated portion of the allowance for loan losses.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P97_S0	loan losses is warranted based on factors such as the geographic concentration of the loan portfolio, current economic conditions and the losses inherent in commercial lending, as these types of loans are typically riskier than residential mortgages.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P97_S1	Management believes the primary risks inherent in the portfolio are a continued decline in the economy, generally, a continued decline in real estate market values, rising unemployment or a protracted period of unemployment at current elevated levels, increasing vacancy rates in commercial investment properties and possible increases in interest rates in the absence of economic improvement.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P97_S2	Any one or a combination of these events may adversely affect borrowers ability to repay the loans, resulting in increased delinquencies, loan losses and future levels of provisions.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P97_S3	Accordingly, the Company has provided for loan losses at the current level to address the current risk in its loan portfolio.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P97_S4	Management considers it important to maintain the ratio of the allowance for loan losses to total loans at an acceptable level given current economic conditions, interest rates and the composition of the portfolio.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P97_S5	Management will continue to review the entire loan portfolio to determine the extent, if any, to which further additional loan loss provisions may be deemed necessary.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P97_S6	The allowance for loan losses is maintained at a level that represents management s best estimate of probable losses related to specifically identified loans as well as probable losses inherent in the remaining loan portfolio.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P97_S7	There can be no assurance that the allowance for loan losses will be adequate to cover all losses that may in fact be realized in the future or that additional provisions for loan losses will not be required.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P98_S0	Analysis of the Allowance for Loan Losses.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P98_S1	The following table sets forth the analysis of the allowance for loan losses for the periods indicated.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P99_S0	Allocation of Allowance for Loan Losses.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P99_S1	The following table sets forth the allocation of the allowance for loan losses by loan category for the periods indicated.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P99_S2	This allocation is based on management s assessment, as of a given point in time, of the risk characteristics of each of the component parts of the total loan portfolio and is subject to changes as and when the risk factors of each such component part change.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P99_S3	The allocation is neither indicative of the specific amounts or the loan categories in which future charge-offs may be taken, nor is it an indicator of future loss trends.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P99_S4	The allocation of the allowance to each category does not restrict the use of the allowance to absorb losses in any category.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P100_S0	The Board of Directors annually approves the Investment Policy for the Bank and the Company.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P100_S1	The Chief Financial Officer and the Treasurer are authorized by the Board to implement the Investment Policy and establish investment strategies.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P100_S2	The Chief Executive Officer, Chief Financial Officer, Treasurer and Assistant Treasurer are authorized to make investment decisions consistent with the Investment Policy.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P100_S3	Investment transactions for the Bank are reported to the Board of Directors of the Bank on a monthly basis.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P100_S4	The Investment Policy is designed to generate a favorable rate of return, consistent with established guidelines for liquidity, safety and diversification, and to complement the lending activities of the Bank.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P100_S5	Investment decisions are made in accordance with the policy and are based on credit quality, interest rate risk, balance sheet composition, market expectations, liquidity, income and collateral needs.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P100_S6	The Investment Policy does not currently permit the purchase of any securities that are below investment grade.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P100_S7	The investment strategy is to maximize the return on the investment portfolio consistent with guidelines that have been established for liquidity, safety, duration and diversification.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P100_S8	The investment strategy also considers the Bank s and the Company s interest rate risk position as well as liquidity, loan demand and other factors.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P101_S0	Acceptable investment securities include U.S. Treasury and Agency obligations, collateralized mortgage obligations ( CMOs ), corporate debt obligations, municipal bonds, mortgage-backed securities, commercial paper, mutual funds, bankers acceptances and Federal funds.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P101_S1	Securities purchased for the investment portfolio require a minimum credit rating of A by Moody s or Standard Poor s at the time of purchase.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P102_S0	Securities in the investment portfolio are classified as held to maturity, available for sale or held for trading.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P102_S1	Securities that are classified as held to maturity are securities that the Bank or the Company has the intent and ability to hold until their contractual maturity date and are reported at cost.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P102_S2	Securities that are classified as available for sale are reported at fair value.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P103_S0	obligations, U.S. Agency and privately-issued CMOs, corporate debt obligations and equities.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P103_S1	Sales of securities may occur from time to time in response to changes in market rates and liquidity needs and to facilitate balance sheet reallocation to effectively manage interest rate risk.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P104_S0	At the present time, there are no securities that are classified as held for trading.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P104_S1	Management conducts a periodic review and evaluation of the securities portfolio to determine if any securities with a market value below book value were other-than-temporarily impaired.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P104_S2	If such an impairment were deemed other-than-temporary, management would measure the total credit-related component of the unrealized loss, and the Company would recognize that portion of the loss as a charge to current period earnings.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P104_S3	The remaining portion of the unrealized loss would be recognized as an adjustment to accumulated other comprehensive income.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P105_S0	The fair value of the securities portfolio is significantly affected by changes in interest rates.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P105_S1	In general, as interest rates rise, the fair value of fixed-rate securities decreases and as interest rates fall, the fair value of fixed-rate securities increases.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P105_S2	The market for non-investment grade, privately issued mortgage-backed securities remains illiquid and prices have not appreciated despite favorable movements in interest rates.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P105_S3	The Company evaluates if it has the intent to sell these securities and if it is not more likely than not that the Company would be required to sell the securities before the anticipated recovery.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P106_S0	CMOs are a type of debt security issued by a special-purpose entity that aggregates pools of mortgages and mortgage-related securities and creates different classes of CMO securities with varying maturities and amortization schedules as well as a residual interest with each class possessing different risk characteristics.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P106_S1	In contrast to pass-through mortgage-backed securities from which cash flow is received (and prepayment risk is shared) pro rata by all securities holders, the cash flow from the mortgages or mortgage-related securities underlying CMOs is paid in accordance with predetermined priority to investors holding various tranches of such securities or obligations.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P106_S2	A particular tranche of CMOs may therefore carry prepayment risk that differs from that of both the underlying collateral and other tranches.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P106_S3	Accordingly, CMOs attempt to moderate risks associated with conventional mortgage-related securities resulting from unexpected prepayment activity.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P106_S4	In declining interest rate environments, the Bank attempts to purchase CMOs with principal lock-out periods, reducing prepayment risk in the investment portfolio.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P106_S5	During rising interest rate periods, the Bank s strategy is to purchase CMOs that are receiving principal payments that can be reinvested at higher current yields.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P106_S6	Investments in CMOs involve a risk that actual prepayments will differ from those estimated in pricing the security, which may result in adjustments to the net yield on such securities.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P106_S7	Additionally, the fair value of such securities may be adversely affected by changes in the market interest rates.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P106_S8	Management believes these securities may represent attractive alternatives relative to other investments due to the wide variety of maturity, repayment and interest rate options available.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P106_S9	At December 31, 2012, the Bank held $42.0 million in privately-issued CMOs in the investment portfolio.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P106_S10	The Bank and the Company do not invest in collateralized debt obligations, mortgage-related securities secured by sub-prime loans, or any preferred equity securities.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P107_S0	Amortized Cost and Fair Value of Securities.

1178970_13_ITEM1_P112_S0	(1) Yields are not tax equivalent SOURCES OF FUNDS General.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P113_S0	Primary sources of funds consist of principal and interest cash flows received from loans and mortgage-backed securities, contractual maturities on investments, deposits, Federal Home Loan Bank of New York ( FHLB ) advances and proceeds from sales of loans and investments.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P113_S1	These sources of funds are used for lending, investing and general corporate purposes, including acquisitions and common stock repurchases.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P114_S0	The Bank offers a variety of deposits for retail and business accounts.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P114_S1	Deposit products include savings accounts, checking accounts, interest-bearing checking accounts, money market deposit accounts and certificate of deposit accounts at varying interest rates and terms.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P114_S2	The Bank also offers IRA and KEOGH accounts.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P114_S3	Business customers are offered several checking account and savings plans, cash management services, remote deposit capture services, payroll origination services, escrow account management and business credit cards.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P115_S0	The Bank focuses on relationship banking for retail and business customers to enhance the customer experience.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P116_S0	Deposit activity is influenced by state and local economic conditions, changes in interest rates, internal pricing decisions and competition.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P116_S1	Deposits are primarily obtained from the areas surrounding the Bank s branch locations.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P116_S2	To attract and retain deposits, the Bank offers competitive rates, quality customer service and a wide variety of products and services that meet customers needs, including online banking.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P116_S3	The Bank has no brokered deposits.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P116_S4	Deposit pricing strategy is monitored monthly by the management Asset/Liability Committee and Pricing Committee.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P116_S5	Deposit pricing is set weekly by the Bank s Treasury Department.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P116_S6	When setting deposit pricing, the Bank considers competitive market rates, FHLB advance rates and rates on other sources of funds.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P117_S0	defined as savings accounts, interest and non-interest bearing checking accounts and money market deposit accounts represented 82.4% of total deposits at December 31, 2012 and 78.1% of total deposits at December 31, 2011.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P117_S1	As of December 31, 2012 and December 31, 2011, time deposits maturing in less than one year amounted to $624 million and $755 million, respectively.

1178970_13_ITEM1_P118_S0	The following table sets forth certain information regarding certificates of deposit.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P118_S1	At December 31, 2012, the Bank had $803.3 million of borrowed funds.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P118_S2	Borrowed funds consist primarily of FHLB advances and repurchase agreements.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P119_S0	Repurchase agreements are contracts for the sale of securities owned or borrowed by the Bank, with an agreement to repurchase those securities at an agreed-upon price and date.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P119_S1	The Bank uses wholesale repurchase agreements, as well as retail repurchase agreements as an investment vehicle for its commercial sweep checking product.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P119_S2	Bank policies limit the use of repurchase agreements to collateral consisting of U.S. Treasury obligations, U.S. government agency obligations or mortgage-related securities.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P119_S3	As a member of the FHLB, the Bank is eligible to obtain advances upon the security of the FHLB common stock owned and certain residential mortgage loans, provided certain standards related to credit-worthiness have been met.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P119_S4	FHLB advances are available pursuant to several credit programs, each of which has its own interest rate and range of maturities.

1178970_13_ITEM1_P121_S0	As part of the Company s strategy to increase its wealth management business, on August 11, 2011, the Company s wholly owned subsidiary, The Provident Bank, completed its acquisition of Beacon Trust Company, a New Jersey limited purpose trust company, and Beacon Global Asset Management, Inc., an SEC-registered investment advisor incorporated in Delaware (collectively Beacon ).
1178970_13_ITEM1_P121_S1	Subsequent to the acquisition, Beacon Global Asset Management was merged with and into Beacon Trust Company.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P122_S0	Beacon s expertise in trust and wealth management services strategically positions the Company to increase market share and enhance the Company s non-interest earnings growth.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P123_S0	In addition to its trust and estate administrative services, Beacon is a provider of asset management services in New Jersey.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P123_S1	The services are often introduced to existing clients through the Bank s extensive branch network throughout the state.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P123_S2	It offers a full range of asset management services to individuals, municipalities, non-profits, corporations and pension funds.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P123_S3	These services include investment management, asset allocation, trust and fiduciary services, financial planning, family office services, estate settlement services and custody.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P124_S0	Beacon focuses on delivering personalized investment strategies based on the client s risk profile.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P124_S1	These strategies are focused on maximizing clients investment returns, while minimizing expenses.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P125_S0	Most of the fee income generated by Beacon is based on assets under management.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P126_S0	SUBSIDIARY ACTIVITIES PFS Insurance Services, Inc., formerly Provident Investment Services, Inc., is a wholly owned subsidiary of the Bank, and a New Jersey licensed insurance producer that sells insurance and investment products, including annuities to customers through a third-party networking arrangement.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P126_S1	Dudley Investment Corporation is a wholly owned subsidiary of the Bank which operates as a New Jersey Investment Company.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P126_S2	Dudley Investment Corporation owns all of the outstanding common stock of Gregory Investment Corporation.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P126_S3	Gregory Investment Corporation is a wholly owned subsidiary of Dudley Investment Corporation.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P126_S4	Gregory Investment Corporation operates as a Delaware Investment Company.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P126_S5	Gregory Investment Corporation owns all of the outstanding common stock of PSB Funding Corporation.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P127_S0	PSB Funding Corporation is a majority owned subsidiary of Gregory Investment Corporation.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P127_S1	It was established as a New Jersey corporation to engage in the business of a real estate investment trust for the purpose of acquiring mortgage loans and other real estate related assets from the Bank.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P128_S0	TPB Realty, LLC, is a wholly owned subsidiary of the Bank formed to invest in real estate development joint ventures principally targeted at meeting the housing needs of low- and moderate-income communities in the Bank s market.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P128_S1	At December 31, 2012, TPB Realty, LLC had total assets of $2.9 million.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P129_S0	Bergen Avenue Realty, LLC, is a wholly owned subsidiary of the Bank formed to manage and sell real estate acquired through foreclosure.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P129_S1	At December 31, 2012, Bergen Avenue Realty, LLC had total assets of $1.1 million.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P130_S0	Bergen Delaware Realty, LLC, is a wholly owned subsidiary of the Bank formed to manage and sell real estate acquired through foreclosure.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P130_S1	At December 31, 2012, Bergen Delaware Realty, LLC had total assets of $5.5 million.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P131_S0	Beacon Trust Company, a New Jersey limited purpose trust company, is a wholly owned subsidiary of the Bank acquired on August 11, 2011.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P131_S1	As of December 31, 2012, the Company had 827 full-time and 114 part-time employees.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P131_S2	None of the Company s employees are represented by a collective bargaining group.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P131_S3	The Company believes its working relationship with its employees is good.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P132_S0	REGULATION and SUPERVISION General As a bank holding company controlling the Bank, the Company is subject to the Bank Holding Company Act of 1956, as amended ( BHCA ), and the rules and regulations of the Federal Reserve Board under the BHCA.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P132_S1	The Company is also subject to the provisions of the New Jersey Banking Act of 1948 (the New Jersey Banking Act ) and the regulations of the Commissioner of the New Jersey Department of Banking and Insurance ( Commissioner ) under the New Jersey Banking Act applicable to bank holding companies.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P133_S0	The Federal Reserve Board and the Commissioner conduct periodic examinations to assess the Company s compliance with various regulatory requirements.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P133_S1	The Company files certain reports with, and otherwise complies with, the rules and regulations of the SEC under the federal securities laws and the listing requirements of the New York Stock Exchange.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P134_S0	The Bank is a New Jersey chartered savings bank, and its deposit accounts are insured up to applicable limits by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation ( FDIC ).
1178970_13_ITEM1_P134_S1	The Bank is subject to extensive regulation, examination and supervision by the Commissioner as the issuer of its charter, and by the FDIC as its deposit insurer.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P134_S2	The Bank files reports with the Commissioner and the FDIC concerning its activities and financial condition, and it must obtain regulatory approval prior to entering into certain transactions, such as mergers with, or acquisitions of, other depository institutions and opening or acquiring branch offices.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P134_S3	The Commissioner and the FDIC conduct periodic examinations to assess the Bank s compliance with various regulatory requirements.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P134_S4	This regulation and supervision establishes a comprehensive framework of activities in which a savings bank can engage and is intended primarily for the protection of the deposit insurance fund and depositors.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P134_S5	The regulatory structure also gives the regulatory authorities extensive discretion in connection with their supervisory and enforcement activities and examination policies, including policies with respect to the classification of assets and the establishment of adequate loan loss reserves for regulatory purposes.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P135_S0	Any change in applicable laws and regulations, whether by the Commissioner, the FDIC, the Federal Reserve Board or through legislation, could have a material adverse impact on the Company and the Bank and their operations.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P136_S0	The Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act of 2010 (the Dodd-Frank Act ) made extensive changes in the regulation of depository institutions and their holding companies.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P136_S1	Certain provisions of the Dodd-Frank Act are impacting the Company and the Bank.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P136_S2	For example, the Dodd-Frank Act created the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau as an independent bureau of the Federal Reserve Board.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P136_S3	The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has assumed responsibility for the implementation of the federal financial consumer protection and fair lending laws and regulations, a function currently assigned to principal regulators, and will have authority to impose new requirements.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P136_S4	However, institutions of less than $10 billion in assets, such as the Bank, will continue to be examined for compliance with consumer protection and fair lending laws and regulations by, and be subject to the enforcement authority of, their principal regulator, although the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau will have back-up authority to examine and enforce consumer protection laws against all institutions, including those with less than $10 billion in assets.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P136_S5	The material laws and regulations applicable to the Company and the Bank are summarized below and elsewhere in the Form 10-K. New Jersey Banking Regulation Activity Powers.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P137_S0	The Bank derives its lending, investment and other activity powers primarily from the applicable provisions of the New Jersey Banking Act and its related regulations.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P137_S1	Under these laws and regulations, savings banks, including the Bank, generally may, subject to certain limits, invest in:
1178970_13_ITEM1_P138_S0	A savings bank may also invest pursuant to a leeway power that permits investments not otherwise permitted by the New Jersey Banking Act, subject to certain restrictions imposed by the FDIC.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P139_S0	Leeway investments must comply with a number of limitations on the individual and aggregate amounts of leeway investments.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P139_S1	A savings bank may also exercise trust powers upon the approval of the Commissioner.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P139_S2	New Jersey savings banks may exercise those powers, rights, benefits or privileges authorized for national banks or out-of-state banks or for federal or out-of-state savings banks or savings associations, provided that before exercising any such power, right, benefit or privilege, prior approval by the Commissioner by regulation or by specific authorization is required.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P139_S3	The exercise of these lending, investment and activity powers is limited by federal law and the related regulations.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P139_S4	See Federal Banking Regulation Activity Restrictions on State-Chartered Bank below.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P140_S0	With certain specified exceptions, a New Jersey chartered savings bank may not make loans or extend credit to a single borrower and to entities related to the borrower in an aggregate amount that would exceed 15% of the bank s capital funds.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P140_S1	A New Jersey chartered savings bank may lend an additional 10% of the bank s capital funds if secured by collateral meeting the requirements of the New Jersey Banking Act.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P140_S2	The Bank currently complies with applicable loans-to-one-borrower limitations.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P141_S0	Under the New Jersey Banking Act, a stock savings bank may declare and pay a dividend on its capital stock only to the extent that the payment of the dividend would not impair the capital stock of the savings bank.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P141_S1	In addition, a stock savings bank may not pay a dividend unless the savings bank would, after the payment of the dividend, have a surplus of not less than 50% of its capital stock, or the payment of the dividend would not reduce the surplus.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P141_S2	Federal law may also limit the amount of dividends that may be paid by the bank.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P142_S0	Regulations of the Commissioner impose on New Jersey chartered depository institutions, including the Bank, minimum capital requirements similar to those imposed by the FDIC on insured state banks.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P142_S1	At December 31, 2012, the Bank was considered well capitalized under FDIC guidelines.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P142_S2	The New Jersey Department of Banking and Insurance may examine the Company and the Bank whenever it deems an examination advisable.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P142_S3	The Department examines the Bank at least every two years.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P143_S0	The Commissioner may order any savings bank to discontinue any violation of law or unsafe or unsound business practice and may direct any director, officer, attorney or employee of a savings bank engaged in an objectionable activity, after the Commissioner has ordered the activity to be terminated, to show cause at a hearing before the Commissioner why such person should not be removed.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P144_S0	FDIC regulations require banks to maintain minimum levels of capital.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P144_S1	The FDIC regulations define two tiers, or classes, of capital.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P144_S2	Tier 1 capital is comprised of:
1178970_13_ITEM1_P145_S0	minority interests in consolidated subsidiaries minus all intangible assets, other than qualifying servicing rights and any net unrealized loss on marketable equity securities.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P146_S0	Tier 2 capital is comprised of:
1178970_13_ITEM1_P147_S0	up to 45% of pre-tax net unrealized holding gains on available for sale equity securities with readily determinable fair values.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P147_S1	The allowance for loan losses may be includible in Tier 2 capital up to a maximum of 1.25% of risk-weighted assets.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P147_S2	Overall, the amount of Tier 2 capital that may be included in total capital cannot exceed 100% of Tier 1 capital.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P148_S0	The FDIC regulations establish a minimum leverage capital requirement for banks in the strongest financial and managerial condition, with a rating of 1 (the highest examination rating of the FDIC for banks) under the Uniform Financial Institutions Rating System that are not anticipating or experiencing significant growth, of not less than a ratio of 3.0% of Tier 1 capital to total assets.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P148_S1	For all other banks, the minimum leverage capital requirement is 4.0%, unless a higher leverage capital ratio is warranted by the particular circumstances or risk profile of the bank.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P149_S0	The FDIC regulations also establish a risk-based capital standard.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P149_S1	The risk-based capital standard requires the maintenance of a ratio of total capital, which is defined as the sum of Tier 1 capital and Tier 2 capital, to risk-weighted assets of at least 8% and a ratio of Tier 1 capital to risk-weighted assets of at least 4%.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P149_S2	In determining the amount of a bank s risk-weighted assets, all assets, plus certain off balance sheet items, are multiplied by a risk-weight of 0% to 100%, based on the risks the FDIC believes are inherent in the type of asset or item.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P149_S3	The federal banking agencies, including the FDIC, have also adopted regulations to require an assessment of a bank s exposure to declines in the economic value of a bank s capital due to changes in interest rates when assessing such bank s capital adequacy.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P149_S4	Under such a risk assessment, examiners will evaluate a bank s capital for interest rate risk on a case-by-case basis, with consideration of both quantitative and qualitative factors.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P149_S5	According to the agencies, applicable considerations include:
1178970_13_ITEM1_P150_S0	the level of other risks at the bank for which capital is needed.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P150_S1	Institutions with significant interest rate risk may be required to maintain additional capital.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P150_S2	The following table shows the Bank s leverage ratio, Tier 1 risk-based capital ratio, and total risk-based capital ratio, at December 31, 2012:
1178970_13_ITEM1_P151_S0	(1) For purposes of calculating Regulatory Tier 1 leverage capital, assets are based on adjusted total leverage assets.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P151_S1	In calculating Tier 1 risk-based capital and total risk-based capital, assets are based on total risk-weighted assets.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P152_S0	As of December 31, 2012, the Bank was considered well capitalized under FDIC guidelines.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P153_S0	On June 6, 2012, the FDIC and the other federal bank regulatory agencies issued a series of proposed rules that would revise their leverage and risk-based capital requirements and the method for calculating risk-weighted assets to make them consistent with agreements that were reached by the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision and certain provisions of the Dodd-Frank Act.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P153_S1	The proposed rules would apply to all depository institutions, top-tier bank holding companies with total consolidated assets of $500 million or more and top-tier savings and loan holding companies.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P153_S2	Among other things, the proposed rules would establish a new common equity Tier 1 minimum capital requirement (4.5% of risk-weighted assets) and a higher minimum Tier 1 capital to risk-based assets requirement (6% of risk-weighted assets) and assign higher risk weight (150%) to exposures that are more than 90 days past due or are on nonaccrual status and certain commercial real estate facilities that finance the acquisition, development or construction of real property.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P153_S3	The proposed rules would also require unrealized gains and losses on certain securities holdings to be included for purposes of calculating regulatory capital requirements.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P153_S4	The proposed rules would limit a banking organization s capital distributions and certain discretionary bonus payments if the banking organization does not hold a capital conservation buffer consisting of a specified amount of common equity Tier 1 capital in addition to the amount necessary to meet its minimum risk-based capital requirements.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P153_S5	The proposed rules indicated that the final rules would become effective on January 1, 2013, and the changes set forth in the final rules will be phased in from January 1, 2013 through January 1, 2019.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P153_S6	However, the agencies subsequently indicated that, due to the volume of public comments received, the final rule has been delayed past January 1, 2013.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P154_S0	Federal law and FDIC regulations generally limit the activities and investments of state-chartered FDIC insured banks and their subsidiaries to those permissible for national banks and their subsidiaries, unless such activities and investments are specifically exempted by law or consented to by the FDIC.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P154_S1	Before making a new investment or engaging in a new activity that is not permissible for a national bank or otherwise permissible under federal law or FDIC regulations, an insured bank must seek approval from the FDIC to make such investment or engage in such activity.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P154_S2	The FDIC will not approve the activity unless the bank meets its minimum capital requirements and the FDIC determines that the activity does not present a significant risk to the FDIC insurance fund.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P155_S0	Certain activities of subsidiaries that are engaged in activities permitted for national banks only through a financial subsidiary are subject to additional restrictions.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P155_S1	Federal law permits a state-chartered savings bank to engage, through financial subsidiaries, in any activity in which a national bank may engage through a financial subsidiary and on substantially the same terms and conditions.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P155_S2	In general, the law permits a national bank that is well-capitalized and well-managed to conduct, through a financial subsidiary, any activity permitted for a financial holding company other than insurance underwriting, insurance investments, real estate investment or development or merchant banking.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P155_S3	The total assets of all such financial subsidiaries may not exceed the lesser of 45% of the bank s total assets or $50 billion.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P155_S4	The bank must have policies and procedures to assess the financial subsidiary s risk and protect the bank from such risk and potential liability, must not consolidate the financial subsidiary s assets with the bank s and must exclude from its own assets and equity all equity investments, including retained earnings, in the financial subsidiary.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P155_S5	The Bank currently meets all conditions necessary to establish and engage in permitted activities through financial subsidiaries.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P156_S0	The Bank is a member of the FHLB system which consists of twelve regional FHLBs, each subject to supervision and regulation by the Federal Housing Finance Agency ( FHFA ).
1178970_13_ITEM1_P156_S1	The FHLB provides a central credit facility primarily for member institutions.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P156_S2	The Bank, as a member of the FHLB of New York, is required to purchase and hold shares of capital stock in that FHLB in an amount as required by that FHLB s capital plan and minimum capital requirements.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P156_S3	The Bank is in compliance with these requirements.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P156_S4	The Bank has received dividends on its FHLB stock, although no assurance can be given that these dividends will continue to be paid.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P156_S5	For the year ended December 31, 2012, dividends paid by the FHLB to the Bank totaled $37.5 million.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P157_S0	As a member institution of the FDIC, deposit accounts at the Bank are generally insured up to a maximum of $250,000 for each separately insured depositor.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P158_S0	The Dodd-Frank Act provided certain non-interest-bearing transaction accounts with full insurance regardless of the dollar amount until December 31, 2012.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P159_S0	Under the FDIC s risk-based assessment system, insured institutions are assigned a risk category based on supervisory evaluations, regulatory capital levels and certain other factors.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P159_S1	An institution s assessment rate depends upon the category to which it is assigned, and certain adjustments specified by FDIC regulations.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P159_S2	Institutions deemed less risky pay lower assessments.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P160_S0	The FDIC may adjust the scale uniformly, except that no adjustment can deviate more than two basis points from the base scale without notice and comment.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P161_S0	No institution may pay a dividend if in default of the federal deposit insurance assessment.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P162_S0	On May 22, 2009, the FDIC issued a final rule imposing a 5 basis point special assessment on each insured depository institution s assets minus Tier 1 capital as of June 30, 2009.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P162_S1	The amount of the special assessment for any institution did not exceed 10 basis points times the institution s assessment base for the second quarter of 2009.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P162_S2	The Bank paid this special assessment in the amount of $3.1 million on September 30, 2009.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P163_S0	On November 12, 2009, the FDIC issued a rule that required depository institutions to prepay their estimated quarterly risk-based assessments for the fourth quarter of 2009 and for all of 2010, 2011 and 2012.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P163_S1	These assessments were payable on December 30, 2009.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P163_S2	The total prepaid assessment of $31.3 million was remitted to the FDIC on that date.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P163_S3	Of that amount, $27.4 million was recorded as a prepaid asset as of December 31, 2009.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P163_S4	Beginning in the first quarter of 2010, the Company recorded an expense for its regular assessment for each quarter, with an offsetting credit to the prepaid asset until it was fully expensed.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P164_S0	The Dodd-Frank Act required the FDIC to revise its procedures to base its assessments upon each insured institution s total assets less tangible equity instead of deposits.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P164_S1	The FDIC finalized a rule, effective April 1, 2011, that set the assessment range at 2.5 to 45 basis points of total assets less tangible equity.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P164_S2	On February 7, 2011, the FDIC issued a final rule that establishes a target size for the Deposit Insurance Fund ( DIF ) at 2 percent of insured deposits as mandated by the Dodd-Frank Act.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P164_S3	The rule also implements a lower assessment rate schedule when the DIF reaches 1.15 percent of total insured deposits.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P165_S0	The FDIC may terminate the insurance of an institution s deposits upon a finding that the institution has engaged in unsafe or unsound practices, is in an unsafe or unsound condition to continue operations or has violated any applicable law, regulation, rule, order or condition imposed by the FDIC.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P165_S1	Management is not aware of any practice, condition or violation that might lead to termination of the Bank s deposit insurance.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P166_S0	The FDIC has extensive enforcement authority over insured savings banks, including the Bank.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P166_S1	This enforcement authority includes, among other things, the ability to assess civil money penalties, to issue cease and desist orders and to remove directors and officers.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P166_S2	In general, these enforcement actions may be initiated in response to violations of law and to unsafe or unsound practices.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P167_S0	Transactions between an insured bank, such as the Bank, and any of its affiliates are governed by Sections 23A and 23B of the Federal Reserve Act and its implementing regulations.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P168_S0	An affiliate of a bank is any company or entity that controls, is controlled by or is under common control with the bank.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P168_S1	A subsidiary of a bank that is not also a depository institution, financial subsidiary or other entity defined by the regulation generally is not treated as an affiliate of the bank for purposes of Sections 23A and 23B. Section 23A:
1178970_13_ITEM1_P169_S0	requires that all such transactions be on terms that are consistent with safe and sound banking practices.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P170_S0	The term covered transaction includes the making of loans, purchase of assets, issuance of guarantees and other similar types of transactions.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P170_S1	Further, most loans by a bank to any of its affiliates must be secured by collateral in amounts ranging from 100 to 130 percent of the loan amounts.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P170_S2	In addition, any covered transaction by a bank with an affiliate and any purchase of assets or services by a bank from an affiliate must be on terms that are substantially the same, or at least as favorable to the bank, as those that would be provided to a non-affiliate.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P171_S0	Banks are subject to statutory prohibitions on certain tying arrangements.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P171_S1	A depository institution is prohibited, subject to certain exceptions, from extending credit to or offering any other service, or fixing or varying the consideration for such extension of credit or service, on the condition that the customer obtain some additional service from the institution or its affiliates or that the customer not obtain services of a competitor of the institution.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P172_S0	FDIC regulations require the Company and the Bank to disclose their privacy policies, including identifying with whom they share non-public personal information to customers at the time of establishing the customer relationship and annually thereafter.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P172_S1	The FDIC regulations also require the Company and the Bank to provide their customers with initial and annual notices that accurately reflect their privacy policies and practices.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P172_S2	In addition, the Company and the Bank are required to provide their customers with the ability to opt-out of having the Company and the Bank share their non-public personal information with unaffiliated third parties before they can disclose such information, subject to certain exceptions.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P173_S0	Community Reinvestment Act and Fair Lending Laws.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P174_S0	All FDIC insured institutions have a responsibility under the Community Reinvestment Act and related regulations to help meet the credit needs of their communities, including low- and moderate-income neighborhoods.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P174_S1	In connection with its examination of a state chartered savings bank, the FDIC is required to assess the institution s record of compliance with the Community Reinvestment Act.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P174_S2	Among other things, the current Community Reinvestment Act regulations replace the prior process-based assessment factors with a new evaluation system that rates an institution based on its actual performance in meeting community needs.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P174_S3	In particular, the current evaluation system focuses on three tests:
1178970_13_ITEM1_P175_S0	a service test, to evaluate the institution s delivery of services through its branches, ATMs and other offices.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P176_S0	An institution s failure to comply with the provisions of the Community Reinvestment Act could, at a minimum, result in regulatory restrictions on its activities, including, but not limited to, engaging in acquisitions and mergers.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P176_S1	The Bank received an Outstanding Community Reinvestment Act rating in its most recently completed federal examination, which was conducted by the FDIC as of August 2011.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P176_S2	In addition, the Equal Credit Opportunity Act and the Fair Housing Act prohibit lenders from discriminating in their lending practices on the basis of characteristics specified in those statutes.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P176_S3	An institution s failure to comply with the Equal Credit Opportunity Act and the Fair Housing Act could result in enforcement actions by the FDIC, as well as other federal regulatory agencies and the Department of Justice.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P177_S0	In general, the guidelines require, among other things, appropriate systems and practices to identify and manage the risks and exposures specified in the guidelines.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P178_S0	The guidelines prohibit excessive compensation as an unsafe and unsound practice and describe compensation as excessive when the amounts paid are unreasonable or disproportionate to the services performed by an executive officer, employee, director, or principal stockholder.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P178_S1	In addition, FDIC regulations require a bank that is given notice by the FDIC that it is not satisfying any of such safety and soundness standards to submit a compliance plan to the FDIC.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P178_S2	If, after being so notified, a bank fails to submit an acceptable compliance plan or fails in any material respect to implement an accepted compliance plan, the FDIC may issue an order directing corrective and other actions of the types to which a significantly undercapitalized institution is subject under the prompt corrective action provisions discussed below.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P178_S3	If a bank fails to comply with such an order, the FDIC may seek to enforce such an order in judicial proceedings and to impose civil monetary penalties.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P179_S0	Federal law requires the FDIC and the other federal banking regulators to promptly resolve the problems of undercapitalized institutions.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P179_S1	Federal law also establishes five categories, consisting of well capitalized, adequately capitalized, undercapitalized, significantly undercapitalized and critically undercapitalized.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P179_S2	The FDIC s regulations define the five capital categories as follows:
1178970_13_ITEM1_P179_S3	An institution will be treated as well capitalized if:
1178970_13_ITEM1_P180_S0	its ratio of Tier 1 capital to total assets is at least 5%, and it is not subject to any order or directive by the FDIC to meet a specific capital level.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P181_S0	An institution will be treated as adequately capitalized if:
1178970_13_ITEM1_P182_S0	its ratio of Tier 1 capital to total assets is at least 4% (3% if the bank receives the highest rating under the Uniform Financial Institutions Rating System) and it is not a well-capitalized institution.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P182_S1	An institution will be treated as undercapitalized if:
1178970_13_ITEM1_P183_S0	its leverage ratio is less than 4% (or less than 3% if the institution receives the highest rating under the Uniform Financial Institutions Rating System).
1178970_13_ITEM1_P184_S0	An institution will be treated as significantly undercapitalized if:
1178970_13_ITEM1_P185_S0	its leverage ratio is less than 3%.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P185_S1	An institution that has a tangible capital to total assets ratio equal to or less than 2% would be deemed critically undercapitalized.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P185_S2	The FDIC is required, with some exceptions, to appoint a receiver or conservator for an insured state bank if that bank is critically undercapitalized.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P185_S3	The FDIC may also appoint a conservator or receiver for an insured state bank on the basis of the institution s financial condition or upon the occurrence of certain events, including:
1178970_13_ITEM1_P186_S0	insufficient capital, or the incurring or likely incurring of losses that will substantially deplete all of the institution s capital with no reasonable prospect of replenishment of capital without federal assistance.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P186_S1	The recently proposed rules that would increase regulatory capital standards would adjust the prompt corrective action categories accordingly.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P187_S0	Loans to a Bank s Insiders Federal Regulation.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P187_S1	A bank s loans to its executive officers, directors, any owner of 10% or more of its stock (each, an insider) and any of certain entities affiliated with any such person (an insider s related interest) are subject to the conditions and limitations imposed by Section 22(h) of the Federal Reserve Act and the Federal Reserve Board s Regulation O.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P187_S2	Under these restrictions, the aggregate amount of the loans to any insider and the insider s related interests may not exceed the loans-to-one-borrower limit applicable to national banks, which is comparable to the loans-to-one-borrower limit applicable to loans by the Bank.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P187_S3	All loans by a bank to all insiders and insiders related interests in the aggregate may not exceed the bank s unimpaired capital and unimpaired surplus.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P187_S4	With certain exceptions, loans to an executive officer, other than loans for the education of the officer s children and certain loans secured by the officer s residence may not exceed at any one time the higher of 2.5% of the bank s unimpaired capital and unimpaired surplus or $25,000, but in no event more than $100,000.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P187_S5	Regulation O also requires that any proposed loan to an insider or a related interest of that insider be approved in advance by a majority of the board of directors of the bank, with any interested directors not participating in the voting, if such loan, when aggregated with any existing loans to that insider and the insider s related interests, would exceed either (1) $500,000; or (2) the greater of $25,000 or 5% of the bank s unimpaired capital and surplus.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P188_S0	Generally, loans to insiders must be made on substantially the same terms as, and follow credit underwriting procedures that are not less stringent than, those that are prevailing at the time for comparable transactions with other persons, and not involve more than the normal risk of payment or present other unfavorable features.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P188_S1	An exception may be made for extensions of credit made pursuant to a benefit or compensation plan of a bank that is widely available to employees of the bank and that does not give any preference to insiders of the bank over other employees of the bank.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P188_S2	In addition, federal law prohibits extensions of credit to a bank s insiders and their related interests by any other institution that has a correspondent banking relationship with the bank, unless such extension of credit is on substantially the same terms as those prevailing at the time for comparable transactions with other persons and does not involve more than the normal risk of repayment or present other unfavorable features.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P189_S0	The Bank does not, as a matter of policy, make loans to its directors or to their immediate family members and related interests.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P190_S0	Provisions of the New Jersey Banking Act impose conditions and limitations on the liabilities to a savings bank of its directors and executive officers and of corporations and partnerships controlled by such persons that are comparable in many respects to the conditions and limitations imposed on the loans and extensions of credit to insiders and their related interests under Regulation O, as discussed above.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P190_S1	The New Jersey Banking Act also provides that a savings bank that is in compliance with Regulation O is deemed to be in compliance with such provisions of the New Jersey Banking Act.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P191_S0	Federal Reserve System Under Federal Reserve Board regulations, the Bank is required to maintain non-interest earning reserves against its transaction accounts.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P192_S0	be maintained against aggregate transaction accounts over $12.4 million and up to $79.5 million, and 10% against that portion of total transaction accounts in excess of up to $79.5 million.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P192_S1	The first $12.4 million of otherwise reservable balances are exempted from the reserve requirements.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P192_S2	The Bank is in compliance with these requirements.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P192_S3	These requirements are adjusted annually by the Federal Reserve Board.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P192_S4	Because required reserves must be maintained in the form of either vault cash, a non-interest bearing account at a Federal Reserve Bank or a pass-through account as defined by the Federal Reserve Board, the effect of this reserve requirement is to reduce the Bank s interest-earning assets.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P193_S0	The Bank is authorized to borrow from the Federal Reserve Bank discount window.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P194_S0	Internet Banking Technological developments continue to significantly alter the ways in which financial institutions conduct their business.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P194_S1	The growth of the Internet has caused banks to adopt and refine alternative distribution and marketing systems.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P194_S2	The federal bank regulatory agencies have conducted seminars and published materials targeted to various aspects of internet banking, and have indicated their intention to reevaluate their regulations to ensure that they encourage banks efficiency and competitiveness consistent with safe and sound banking practices.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P194_S3	There can be no assurance that the bank regulatory agencies will adopt new regulations that will not materially affect the Bank s internet operations or restrict any such further operations.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P195_S0	The Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P196_S0	On July 21, 2010, the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (the Dodd-Frank Act ) was enacted.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P196_S1	This law has significantly changed the current bank regulatory structure and is affecting the lending, deposit, investment, trading and operating activities of depository institutions and their holding companies.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P197_S0	The Dodd-Frank Act requires various federal agencies to adopt a broad range of new implementing rules and regulations, and to prepare numerous studies and reports for Congress.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P197_S1	The federal agencies are given significant discretion in drafting the implementing rules and regulations, and consequently, many of the details and much of the impact of the Dodd-Frank Act may not be known for some time.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P198_S0	A provision of the Dodd-Frank Act that became effective on July 1, 2011, repealed the federal prohibitions on paying interest on demand deposits, thus permitting depository institutions to pay interest on business transaction and other accounts.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P198_S1	Depending on competitive responses, this significant change to existing law could increase interest expense at depository institutions like the Bank.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P198_S2	The legislation also provided for originators of certain securitized loans to retain a percentage of the risk for transferred credits, directed the Federal Reserve Board to regulate pricing of certain debit card interchange fees and contained a number of reforms related to mortgage origination.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P199_S0	The Dodd-Frank Act required publicly traded companies to give stockholders a non-binding vote on executive compensation and so-called golden parachute payments.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P199_S1	The legislation also directed the Federal Reserve Board to promulgate rules prohibiting excessive compensation paid to bank holding company executives, regardless of whether the company is publicly traded or not.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P200_S0	The USA PATRIOT Act The USA PATRIOT Act gives the federal government powers to address terrorist threats through enhanced domestic security measures, expanded surveillance powers, increased information sharing, and broadened anti-money laundering requirements.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P200_S1	By way of amendments to the Bank Secrecy Act, Title III of the USA PATRIOT Act included measures intended to encourage information sharing among bank regulatory agencies and law enforcement bodies.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P200_S2	Further, certain provisions of Title III imposed affirmative obligations on a broad range of financial institutions, including banks, thrifts, brokers, dealers, credit unions, money transfer agents and parties registered under the Commodity Exchange Act.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P201_S0	The bank regulatory agencies have increased the regulatory scrutiny of the Bank Secrecy Act and anti-money laundering programs maintained by financial institutions.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P202_S0	other supervisory orders may be imposed on a financial institution for non-compliance with these requirements.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P202_S1	In addition, the federal bank regulatory agencies must consider the effectiveness of financial institutions engaging in a merger transaction in combating money laundering activities.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P202_S2	The Bank has adopted policies and procedures which are in compliance with these requirements.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P202_S3	The Company is regulated as a bank holding company, and as such, is subject to examination, regulation and periodic reporting under the Bank Holding Company Act, as administered by the Federal Reserve Board.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P202_S4	The Federal Reserve Board has adopted capital adequacy guidelines for bank holding companies on a consolidated basis structured similarly, but not identically, to those of the FDIC for the Bank.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P202_S5	As of December 31, 2012, the Company s total capital and Tier 1 capital ratios exceed these minimum capital requirements.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P202_S6	The following table shows the Company s Tier 1 leverage ratio, Tier 1 risk-based capital ratio and the Total risk-based capital ratio as of December 31, 2012:
1178970_13_ITEM1_P203_S0	(1) For purposes of calculating Regulatory Tier 1 leverage capital, assets are based on adjusted total leverage assets.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P203_S1	In calculating Tier 1 risk-based capital and Total risk-based capital, assets are based on total risk-weighted assets.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P203_S2	As of December 31, 2012, the Company was well capitalized under Federal Reserve Board guidelines.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P204_S0	The Dodd-Frank Act directs the Federal Reserve Board to issue consolidated capital requirements for depository institution holding companies that are not less stringent, both quantitatively and in terms of components of capital, than those applicable to institutions themselves.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P204_S1	That will eliminate from Tier 1 capital the inclusion of certain instruments such as trust preferred securities that are currently includable by bank holding companies.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P204_S2	Instruments issued prior to May 19, 2010 are grandfathered for bank holding companies of under $15 billion in consolidated assets.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P204_S3	The Company has no trust preferred securities in its Tier 1 capital.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P205_S0	Regulations of the Federal Reserve Board provide that a bank holding company must serve as a source of strength to any of its subsidiary banks and must not conduct its activities in an unsafe or unsound manner.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P205_S1	Federal Reserve Board policies generally provide that bank holding companies should pay dividends only out of current earnings and only if the prospective rate of earnings retention in the holding company appears consistent with the organization s capital needs, asset quality and overall financial condition.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P206_S0	Under the prompt corrective action provisions discussed above, a bank holding company parent of an undercapitalized subsidiary bank would be directed to guarantee, within limitations, the capital restoration plan that is required of such an undercapitalized bank.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P206_S1	If the undercapitalized bank fails to file an acceptable capital restoration plan or fails to implement an accepted plan, the Federal Reserve Board may prohibit the bank holding company parent of the undercapitalized bank from paying any dividends or making any other form of capital distribution without the prior approval of the Federal Reserve Board.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P207_S0	As a bank holding company, the Company is required to obtain the prior approval of the Federal Reserve Board to acquire all, or substantially all, of the assets of any bank or bank holding company.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P207_S1	Prior Federal Reserve Board approval will be required for the Company to acquire direct or indirect ownership or control of any voting securities of any bank or bank holding company if, after giving effect to such acquisition, it would, directly or indirectly, own or control more than 5% of any class of voting shares of such bank or bank holding company.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P208_S0	A bank holding company is required to give the Federal Reserve Board prior written notice of any purchase or redemption of its outstanding equity securities if the gross consideration for the purchase or redemption, when combined with the net consideration paid for all such purchases or redemptions during the preceding 12 months will be equal to 10% or more of the company s consolidated net worth.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P208_S1	The Federal Reserve Board may disapprove such a purchase or redemption if it determines that the proposal would constitute an unsafe and unsound practice, or would violate any law, regulation, Federal Reserve Board order or directive, or any condition imposed by, or written agreement with, the Federal Reserve Board.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P208_S2	Such notice and approval is not required for a bank holding company that would be treated as well capitalized under applicable regulations of the Federal Reserve Board, is well-managed, and that is not the subject of any unresolved supervisory issues.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P208_S3	In addition, a bank holding company which does not opt to become a financial holding company under applicable federal law is generally prohibited from engaging in, or acquiring direct or indirect control of any company engaged in non-banking activities.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P208_S4	One of the principal exceptions to this prohibition is for activities found by the Federal Reserve Board to be so closely related to banking or managing or controlling banks as to be permissible.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P208_S5	Some of the principal activities that the Federal Reserve Board has determined by regulation to be so closely related to banking as to be permissible are:
1178970_13_ITEM1_P209_S0	acquiring a savings and loan association.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P210_S0	Bank holding companies that qualify and opt to become a financial holding company may engage in activities that are financial in nature or incident to activities which are financial in nature.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P210_S1	The Company has not elected to qualify as a financial holding company under federal regulations, although it may seek to do so in the future.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P210_S2	Bank holding companies may qualify to become a financial holding company if:
1178970_13_ITEM1_P211_S0	the bank holding company has filed a certification with the Federal Reserve Board that it elects to become a financial holding company.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P212_S0	Under federal law, depository institutions are liable to the FDIC for losses suffered or anticipated by the FDIC in connection with the default of a commonly controlled depository institution or any assistance provided by the FDIC to such an institution in danger of default.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P212_S1	This law would potentially be applicable to the Company if it ever acquired as a separate subsidiary, a depository institution in addition to the Bank.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P213_S0	Under the New Jersey Banking Act, a company owning or controlling a savings bank is regulated as a bank holding company.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P213_S1	The New Jersey Banking Act defines the terms company and bank holding company as such terms are defined under the BHCA.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P213_S2	Each bank holding company controlling a New Jersey chartered bank or savings bank must file certain reports with the Commissioner and is subject to examination by the Commissioner.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P214_S0	Under federal law and under the New Jersey Banking Act, no person may acquire control of the Company or the Bank without first obtaining approval of such acquisition of control from the Federal Reserve Board and the Commissioner.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P215_S0	The Company s common stock is registered with the SEC under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P215_S1	The Company is subject to the information, proxy solicitation, insider trading restrictions and other requirements under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P215_S2	The Company is incorporated under the laws of the State of Delaware.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P215_S3	As a result, the rights of its stockholders are governed by the Delaware General Corporate Law and the Company s Certificate of Incorporation and Bylaws.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P215_S4	The Company is subject to federal income taxation in the same general manner as other corporations, with some exceptions discussed below.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P215_S5	The following discussion of federal taxation is intended only to summarize certain pertinent federal income tax matters and is not a comprehensive description of the tax rules applicable to the Company.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P215_S6	For federal income tax purposes, the Company currently reports its income and expenses on the accrual method of accounting and uses a tax year ending December 31 for filing its consolidated federal income tax returns.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P216_S0	Prior to the Small Business Protection Act of 1996 (the 1996 Act ), the Bank was permitted to establish a reserve for bad debts and to make annual additions to the reserve.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P216_S1	These additions could, within specified formula limits, be deducted in arriving at taxable income.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P217_S0	The Bank was required to use the direct charge-off method to compute its bad debt deduction beginning with its 1996 federal income tax return.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P218_S0	Savings institutions were required to recapture any excess reserves over those established as of December 31, 1987 (base year reserve).
1178970_13_ITEM1_P218_S1	Prior to the 1996 Act, bad debt reserves created prior to January 1, 1988 were subject to recapture into taxable income should the Bank fail to meet certain asset and definitional tests.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P218_S2	Federal legislation has eliminated these recapture rules.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P219_S0	Retained earnings at December 31, 2012 included approximately $51.8 million for which no provisions for income tax had been made.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P219_S1	This amount represents an allocation of income to bad debt deductions for tax purposes only.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P219_S2	Events that would result in taxation of these reserves include failure to qualify as a bank for tax purposes, distributions in complete or partial liquidation, stock redemptions and excess distributions to shareholders.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P219_S3	At December 31, 2012, the Bank had an unrecognized tax liability of $21.2 million with respect to this reserve.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P220_S0	The Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended (the Code ), imposes an alternative minimum tax (AMT) at a rate of 20% on a base of regular taxable income plus certain tax preferences (alternative minimum taxable income or AMTI).
1178970_13_ITEM1_P220_S1	The AMT is payable to the extent such AMTI is in excess of an exemption amount and the AMT exceeds the regular income tax.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P220_S2	Net operating losses can offset no more than 90% of AMTI.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P221_S0	Certain payments of alternative minimum tax may be used as credits against regular tax liabilities in future years.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P221_S1	The Company has not been subject to the alternative minimum tax and has no such amounts available as credits for carryover.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P222_S0	Under the general rule, a financial institution may carry back net operating losses to the preceding two taxable years and forward to the succeeding 20 taxable years.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P222_S1	At December 31, 2012, the Company had no net operating loss carryforwards for federal income tax purposes.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P223_S0	The Company may exclude from its income 100% of dividends received from the Bank as a member of the same affiliated group of corporations.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P224_S0	State Taxation New Jersey State Taxation.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P224_S1	The Company and the Bank file New Jersey Corporation Business Tax returns.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P225_S0	Generally, the income of financial institutions in New Jersey, which is calculated based on federal taxable income subject to certain adjustments, is subject to New Jersey tax.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P225_S1	The Company and the Bank are currently subject to the corporate business tax ( CBT ) at 9% of taxable income.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P225_S2	New Jersey tax law does not and has not allowed for a taxpayer to file a tax return on a combined or consolidated basis with another member of the affiliated group where there is common ownership.
1178970_13_ITEM1_P225_S3	However, if the taxpayer cannot demonstrate by clear and convincing evidence that the tax filing discloses the true earnings of the taxpayer on its business carried on in the State of New Jersey, the Director of the New Jersey Division of Taxation may, at the director s discretion, require the taxpayer to file a consolidated return of the entire operations of the affiliated group or controlled group, including its own operations and income.
1178970_13_ITEM1A_P0_S0	ordinary course of operating our business, we are exposed to a variety of risks that are inherent to the financial services industry.
1178970_13_ITEM1A_P0_S1	The following discusses the significant risk factors that could affect our business and operations, as well as other significant risk factors which are particularly relevant during the current period of continued economic and market disruption.
1178970_13_ITEM1A_P0_S2	If any of the following risks actually occur, our business, financial condition or results of operations could be negatively affected, the market price for your investment in the Company s common stock could decline, and you could lose all or a part of your investment in the Company s common stock.
1178970_13_ITEM1A_P0_S3	Deterioration in the housing sector and related markets and prolonged elevated unemployment levels may adversely affect our business and financial results.
1178970_13_ITEM1A_P1_S0	During 2012, general economic conditions did not materially improve.
1178970_13_ITEM1A_P1_S1	While we did not invest in sub-prime mortgages and related investments, our lending business and investments in mortgage-backed securities are tied, in large part, to the housing market.
1178970_13_ITEM1A_P2_S0	Lower home prices, the continued high level of foreclosures, the protracted foreclosure process in New Jersey and high unemployment have adversely impacted the credit performance of real estate related loans, resulting in reductions in collateral values.
1178970_13_ITEM1A_P2_S1	The housing slump has resulted in reduced demand for the construction of single-family housing, declines in home prices, and has contributed to elevated delinquencies on residential and commercial mortgage loans.
1178970_13_ITEM1A_P2_S2	These conditions may potentially cause a reduction in loan demand, and increases in our non-performing assets, net charge-offs and provisions for loan losses.
1178970_13_ITEM1A_P2_S3	A worsening of these negative economic conditions could adversely impact our prospects for growth, asset and goodwill valuations, and could result in a decrease in our interest income and a material increase in our provision for loan losses.
1178970_13_ITEM1A_P2_S4	Our commercial real estate, multi-family, and commercial loans expose us to increased lending risks.
1178970_13_ITEM1A_P2_S5	Our strategy continues to be to increase our commercial mortgage loans, commercial loans and, to a lesser extent, construction loans.
1178970_13_ITEM1A_P2_S6	These loans are generally regarded as having a higher risk of default and loss than single-family residential mortgage loans, because repayment of these loans often depends on the successful operation of a business or of the underlying property.
1178970_13_ITEM1A_P2_S7	In addition, our construction loans, commercial mortgage loans and commercial loans have significantly larger average loan balances compared to our single-family residential mortgage loans.
1178970_13_ITEM1A_P2_S8	At December 31, 2012, the average loan size for a construction loan was $3.6 million, for a commercial mortgage loan was $2.0 million, and for a commercial loan was $428,000, compared to an average loan size of $206,000 for a single-family residential mortgage loan.
1178970_13_ITEM1A_P3_S0	these types of loans have more than one loan outstanding with us.
1178970_13_ITEM1A_P3_S1	Consequently, any adverse development with respect to one loan or one credit relationship can expose us to a significantly greater risk of loss compared to an adverse development with respect to one single-family residential mortgage loan.
1178970_13_ITEM1A_P3_S2	Our continuing concentration of loans in our primary market area may increase our risk.
1178970_13_ITEM1A_P3_S3	Our success depends primarily on the general economic conditions in northern and central New Jersey.
1178970_13_ITEM1A_P3_S4	Unlike some larger banks that are more geographically diversified, we provide banking and financial services to customers primarily in northern and central New Jersey.
1178970_13_ITEM1A_P3_S5	The local economic conditions in northern and central New Jersey, including an unemployment rate of 9.6% at December 31, 2012, have a significant impact on our construction loans, commercial mortgage loans, commercial loans, and residential mortgage loans, the ability of the borrowers to repay these loans and the value of the collateral securing these loans.
1178970_13_ITEM1A_P3_S6	A further decline in local economic conditions caused by inflation, recession, unemployment or other factors beyond our control would impact these local economic conditions and could negatively affect the financial results of our banking operations.
1178970_13_ITEM1A_P3_S7	Additionally, because we have a significant amount of real estate loans, further declines in real estate values and the continued slump in real estate sales may also have a negative effect on the ability of many of our borrowers to make timely repayments of their loans, which would have an adverse impact on our earnings and overall financial condition.
1178970_13_ITEM1A_P4_S0	We target our business development and marketing strategy for loans to serve primarily the banking and financial services needs of small- to medium-sized businesses in northern and central New Jersey.
