1178970_14_ITEM1A_P31_S3	Events such as these may become more common in the future and could cause significant damage, cause disruption of power and communication services, impact the stability of our facilities and result in additional expenses, impair the ability of our borrowers to repay their loans, reduce the value of collateral securing the repayment of our loans, and result in the loss of revenue.
1178970_14_ITEM1A_P31_S4	While we have established and regularly test disaster recovery procedures, the occurrence of any such event could have a material adverse effect on our business, operations and financial condition.
1178970_14_ITEM1A_P31_S5	Strong competition within our market area may limit our growth and profitability.
1178970_14_ITEM1A_P32_S0	Competition in the banking and financial services industry is intense.
1178970_14_ITEM1A_P32_S1	In our market area, we compete with commercial banks, savings institutions, mortgage banking firms, credit unions, finance companies, mutual funds, insurance companies, and brokerage and investment banking firms operating locally and elsewhere.
1178970_14_ITEM1A_P32_S2	In particular, over the past decade, New Jersey has experienced the effects of substantial banking consolidation, and large out-of-state competitors have grown significantly.
1178970_14_ITEM1A_P32_S3	There are also a number of strong locally-based competitors in our market.
1178970_14_ITEM1A_P32_S4	Many of these competitors have substantially greater resources and lending limits than we do, and may offer certain deposit and loan pricing, services or credit criteria that we do not or cannot provide.
1178970_14_ITEM1A_P32_S5	Our profitability depends upon our continued ability to successfully compete in our market area.
1178970_14_ITEM1B_P0_S0	There are no unresolved comments from the staff of the SEC to report.
1178970_14_ITEM2_P0_S0	Property At December 31, 2013 , the Bank conducted business through 77 full-service branch offices located in Hudson, Bergen, Essex, Mercer, Middlesex, Monmouth, Morris, Ocean, Passaic, Somerset and Union Counties, New Jersey.
1178970_14_ITEM2_P0_S1	The aggregate net book value of premises and equipment was $ 66.4 million at December 31, 2013 .
1178970_14_ITEM2_P0_S2	In the first quarter of 2011, the Company s executive offices were relocated to a leased facility at 239 Washington Street, Jersey City, New Jersey, which is also the Bank s Main Office .
1178970_14_ITEM2_P0_S3	This was necessitated by the relocation of the Bank s administrative offices from 830 Bergen Avenue, Jersey City, New Jersey to a leased facility at 100 Wood Avenue South, Iselin, New Jersey, which was completed during the second quarter 2011.
1178970_14_ITEM2_P0_S4	The Bank s 830 Bergen Avenue administrative office building and its former loan administration center building at 1000 Woodbridge Center Drive, Woodbridge, New Jersey were sold in the fourth quarter of 2011.
1178970_14_ITEM3_P0_S0	The Company is involved in various legal actions and claims arising in the normal course of its business.
1178970_14_ITEM3_P0_S1	In the opinion of management, these legal actions and claims are not expected to have a material adverse impact on the Company s financial condition and results of operations.
1178970_14_ITEM5_P0_S0	The Company s common stock trades on the New York Stock Exchange ( NYSE ) under the symbol PFS.
1178970_14_ITEM5_P0_S1	Trading in the Company s common stock commenced on January 16, 2003.
1178970_14_ITEM5_P0_S2	As of December 31, 2013 , there were 83,209,293 shares of the Company s common stock issued and 59,917,649 shares outstanding, and 5,415 stockholders of record.
1178970_14_ITEM5_P0_S3	The table below shows the high and low closing prices reported on the NYSE for the Company s common stock, as well as the cash dividends paid per common share during the periods indicated.
1178970_14_ITEM5_P1_S0	On January 30, 2014, the Board of Directors declared a quarterly cash dividend of $0.15 per common share, which was paid on February 28, 2014, to common stockholders of record as of the close of business on February 14, 2014.
1178970_14_ITEM5_P1_S1	The Company paid a special dividend of $0.20 per common share on December 31, 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM5_P1_S2	The Company s Board of Directors intends to review the payment of dividends quarterly and plans to continue to maintain a regular quarterly cash dividend in the future, subject to financial condition, results of operations, tax considerations, industry standards, economic conditions, regulatory restrictions that affect the payment of dividends by the Bank to the Company and other relevant factors.
1178970_14_ITEM5_P1_S3	The Company is subject to the requirements of Delaware law that generally limit dividends to an amount equal to the difference between the amount by which total assets exceed total liabilities and the amount equal to the aggregate par value of the outstanding shares of capital stock.
1178970_14_ITEM5_P1_S4	If there is no difference between these amounts, dividends are limited to net income for the current and/or immediately preceding year.
1178970_14_ITEM5_P2_S0	Stock Performance Graph Set forth below is a stock performance graph comparing (a) the cumulative total return on the Company s common stock for the period December 31, 2008 through December 31, 2013 , (b) the cumulative total return on stocks included in the Russell 2000 Index over such period, and (c) the cumulative total return of the SNL Thrift Index over such period.
1178970_14_ITEM5_P3_S0	The SNL Thrift Index, produced by SNL Financial LC, contains all thrift institutions traded on the New York and NASDAQ stock exchanges.
1178970_14_ITEM5_P4_S0	Cumulative return assumes the reinvestment of dividends and is expressed in dollars based on an assumed investment of $100 on December 31, 2008.
1178970_14_ITEM5_P5_S0	(1) On October 24, 2007, the Company s Board of Directors approved the purchase of up to 3,107,077 shares of its common stock under a seventh general repurchase program which commenced upon completion of the previous repurchase program.
1178970_14_ITEM5_P5_S1	The repurchase program has no expiration date.
1178970_14_ITEM5_P5_S2	(2) On December 20, 2012, the Company s Board of Directors approved the purchase of up to 3,017,770 shares of its common stock under an eighth general repurchase program which will commence upon completion of the previous repurchase program.
1178970_14_ITEM5_P5_S3	The repurchase program has no expiration date.
1178970_14_ITEM5_P6_S0	Common stock repurchases for the three months ended December 31, 2013 were in connection with employee income tax withholding on stock-based compensation.
1178970_14_ITEM6_P0_S0	The summary information presented below at or for each of the periods presented is derived in part from and should be read in conjunction with the consolidated financial statements of the Company presented in Item 8.
1178970_14_ITEM6_P1_S0	(1) Loans are shown net of allowance for loan losses, deferred fees and unearned discount.
1178970_14_ITEM6_P2_S0	(1) Averages presented are daily averages.
1178970_14_ITEM6_P2_S1	(2) Net interest income divided by average interest earning assets.
1178970_14_ITEM6_P3_S0	(3) Represents the ratio of non-interest expense divided by the sum of net interest income and non-interest income.
1178970_14_ITEM6_P3_S1	(4) Leverage capital ratios are presented as a percentage of quarterly average tangible assets.
1178970_14_ITEM6_P3_S2	Risk-based capital ratios are presented as a percentage of risk-weighted assets.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P0_S0	General On January 15, 2003, the Company became the holding company for the Bank, following the completion of the conversion of the Bank to a stock-chartered bank.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P1_S0	The Company issued an aggregate of 59,618,300 shares of its common stock in a subscription offering to eligible depositors.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P1_S1	Concurrent with the conversion, the Company contributed an additional 1,920,000 shares of its common stock and $4.8 million in cash to The Provident Bank Foundation, a charitable foundation established by the Bank.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P2_S0	The Company conducts business through its subsidiary, the Bank, a community- and customer-oriented bank currently operating 77 full-service branches throughout northern and central New Jersey.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P2_S1	Strategy Established in 1839, the Bank is the oldest New Jersey-chartered bank in the state.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P2_S2	The Bank offers a full range of retail and commercial loan and deposit products, and emphasizes personal service and convenience.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P2_S3	The Bank s strategy is to grow profitably through a commitment to credit quality and expanding market share by acquiring, retaining and expanding customer relationships, while carefully managing interest rate risk.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P2_S4	In recent years, the Bank has focused on commercial real estate, multi-family and commercial loans as part of its strategy to diversify the loan portfolio and reduce interest rate risk.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P2_S5	These types of loans generally have adjustable rates that initially are higher than residential mortgage loans and generally have a higher rate of risk.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P3_S0	The Bank s credit policy focuses on quality underwriting standards and close monitoring of the loan portfolio.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P3_S1	At December 31, 2013 , commercial loans accounted for 66.3% of the loan portfolio and retail loans accounted for 33.7%.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P3_S2	The Company intends to continue to diversify the loan portfolio and to focus on commercial real estate, multi-family and commercial and industrial lending relationships.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P4_S0	The Company s relationship banking strategy focuses on increasing core accounts and expanding relationships through its branch network, mobile banking, online banking and telephone banking touch points.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P4_S1	The Company continues to evaluate opportunities to increase market share by expanding within existing and contiguous markets.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P5_S0	Core deposits, consisting of all savings and demand deposit accounts, are generally a stable, relatively inexpensive source of funds.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P5_S1	At December 31, 2013 , core deposits were 84.5 % of total deposits.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P6_S0	The Company s results of operations are primarily dependent upon net interest income, the difference between interest earned on interest-earning assets and the interest paid on interest-bearing liabilities.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P6_S1	Changes in interest rates could have an adverse effect on net interest income to the extent the Company s interest-bearing assets and interest-bearing liabilities reprice or mature at different times or relative interest rates.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P6_S2	An increase in interest rates generally would result in a decrease in the Company s average interest rate spread and net interest income, which could have a negative effect on profitability.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P7_S0	The Company generates non-interest income such as income from retail and business account fees, loan servicing fees, loan origination fees, appreciation in the cash surrender value of Bank-owned life insurance, income from loan or securities sales, fees from wealth management services and investment product sales and other fees.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P7_S1	The Company s operating expenses consist primarily of compensation and benefits expense, occupancy and equipment expense, data processing expense, the amortization of intangible assets, marketing and advertising expense and other general and administrative expenses.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P7_S2	The Company s results of operations are also affected by general economic conditions, changes in market interest rates, changes in asset quality, changes in asset values, actions of regulatory agencies and government policies.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P8_S0	Acquisition On December 20, 2013, the Company announced that it had entered into an agreement under which Team Capital Bank ("Team Capital") will merge with and into the Company's subsidiary, The Provident Bank.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P8_S1	Consideration will be paid to Team Capital stockholders in a combination of stock and cash valued at approximately $122.0 million on the day of the announcement.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P8_S2	The transaction is subject to regulatory approvals and Team Capital's stockholder approval.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P8_S3	The merger will add twelve branches to The Provident Bank branch network, with five branches in Pennsylvania and seven in New Jersey.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P9_S0	On August 11, 2011, the Company s wholly owned subsidiary, The Provident Bank, completed its acquisition of Beacon Trust Company, a New Jersey limited purpose trust company, and Beacon Global Asset Management, Inc., an SEC-registered investment advisor incorporated in Delaware (collectively Beacon ).
1178970_14_ITEM7_P9_S1	Pursuant to the terms of the Stock Purchase Agreement announced on May 19, 2011, Beacon s former parent company, Beacon Financial Corporation, may be paid cash consideration in an amount up to $10.5 million, based upon the acquired companies financial performance in the three years following the closing of the transaction.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P9_S2	Subsequent to the acquisition, Beacon Global Asset Management was merged with and into Beacon Trust Company.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P10_S0	The Company considers certain accounting policies to be critically important to the fair presentation of its financial condition and results of operations.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P10_S1	These policies require management to make complex judgments on matters which by their nature have elements of uncertainty.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P10_S2	The sensitivity of the Company s consolidated financial statements to these critical accounting policies, and the assumptions and estimates applied, could have a significant impact on its financial condition and results of operations.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P10_S3	These assumptions, estimates and judgments made by management can be influenced by a number of factors, including the general economic environment.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P10_S4	The Company has identified the following as critical accounting policies:
1178970_14_ITEM7_P11_S0	Valuation of deferred tax assets The calculation of the allowance for loan losses is a critical accounting policy of the Company.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P12_S0	The allowance for loan losses is a valuation account that reflects management s evaluation of the probable losses in the loan portfolio.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P12_S1	The Company maintains the allowance for loan losses through provisions for loan losses that are charged to income.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P12_S2	Charge-offs against the allowance for loan losses are taken on loans where management determines that the collection of loan principal is unlikely.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P12_S3	Recoveries made on loans that have been charged-off are credited to the allowance for loan losses.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P12_S4	The Company s evaluation of the adequacy of the allowance for loan losses includes a review of all loans on which the collectibility of principal may not be reasonably assured.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P12_S5	For residential mortgage and consumer loans, this is determined primarily by delinquency and collateral values.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P12_S6	For commercial real estate and commercial loans, an extensive review of financial performance, payment history and collateral values is conducted on a quarterly basis.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P13_S0	As part of the evaluation of the adequacy of the allowance for loan losses, each quarter management prepares an analysis that categorizes the entire loan portfolio by certain risk characteristics such as loan type (residential mortgage, commercial mortgage, construction, commercial, etc.) and loan risk rating.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P13_S1	When assigning a risk rating to a loan, management utilizes a nine point internal risk rating system.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P13_S2	Loans deemed to be acceptable quality are rated 1 through 4, with a rating of 1 established for loans with minimal risk.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P13_S3	Loans deemed to be of questionable quality are rated 5 (watch) or 6 (special mention).
1178970_14_ITEM7_P13_S4	Loans with adverse classifications (substandard, doubtful or loss) are rated 7, 8 or 9, respectively.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P13_S5	Commercial mortgage, commercial and construction loans are rated individually and each lending officer is responsible for risk rating loans in their portfolio.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P13_S6	These risk ratings are then reviewed by the department manager and/or the Chief Lending Officer and the Credit Administration Department.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P13_S7	The risk ratings are also confirmed through periodic loan review examinations, which are currently performed by an independent third party and periodically, by the Credit Committee in the credit renewal or approval.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P13_S8	In addition, the Bank requires an annual review be performed for commercial and commercial real estate loans above certain dollar thresholds, depending on loan type, to help determine the appropriate risk ratings.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P14_S0	Management assigns general valuation allowance ( GVA ) percentages to each risk rating category for use in allocating the allowance for loan losses, giving consideration to historical loss experience by loan type and other qualitative or environmental factors such as trends and levels of delinquencies, impaired loans, charge-offs, recoveries, loan volume, as well as the national and local economic trends and conditions.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P14_S1	The appropriateness of these percentages is evaluated by management at least annually and monitored on a quarterly basis, with changes made when they are required.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P14_S2	In the second quarter of 2013, management completed its most recent evaluation of the GVA percentages.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P15_S0	mortgage loans, first-lien home equity loans and commercial mortgage loans were reduced to reflect the decrease in the historical loss experience.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P15_S1	In addition, multi-family loans were segregated from other commercial mortgage loans as a result of differing risk characteristics and were assigned GVA percentages accordingly.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P15_S2	Multi-family GVAs were established at levels lower than when previously included with other commercial mortgage loans as a result of lower historical loss experience resulting from the diverse cash flow sources supporting these loans.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P16_S0	Management believes the primary risks inherent in the portfolio are a decline in the economy, generally, a decline in real estate market values, rising unemployment or a protracted period of unemployment at current elevated levels, increasing vacancy rates in commercial investment properties and possible increases in interest rates in the absence of economic improvement.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P16_S1	Any one or a combination of these events may adversely affect borrowers ability to repay their loans, resulting in increased delinquencies, loan losses and future levels of provisions.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P16_S2	Accordingly, the Company has provided for loan losses at the current level to address the current risk in its loan portfolio.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P16_S3	Management considers it important to maintain the ratio of the allowance for loan losses to total loans at an acceptable level given current economic conditions, interest rates and the composition of the portfolio.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P16_S4	Although management believes that the Company has established and maintained the allowance for loan losses at appropriate levels, additions may be necessary if future economic and other conditions differ substantially from the current operating environment.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P16_S5	Management evaluates its estimates and assumptions on an ongoing basis giving consideration to historical experience and other factors, including the current economic environment, which management believes to be reasonable under the circumstances.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P16_S6	Such estimates and assumptions are adjusted when facts and circumstances dictate.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P16_S7	Illiquid credit markets, volatile securities markets, and declines in the housing and commercial real estate markets and the economy generally have combined to increase the uncertainty inherent in such estimates and assumptions.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P17_S0	As future events and their effects cannot be determined with precision, actual results could differ significantly from these estimates.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P17_S1	Changes in estimates resulting from continuing changes in the economic environment will be reflected in the financial statements in future periods.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P17_S2	In addition, various regulatory agencies periodically review the adequacy of the Company s allowance for loan losses as an integral part of their examination process.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P17_S3	Such agencies may require the Company to recognize additions to the allowance or additional write-downs based on their judgments about information available to them at the time of their examination.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P17_S4	Although management uses the best information available, the level of the allowance for loan losses remains an estimate that is subject to significant judgment and short-term change.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P17_S5	Additional critical accounting policies relate to judgments about other asset impairments, including goodwill, investment securities and deferred tax assets.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P18_S0	Goodwill is evaluated for impairment on an annual basis, or more frequently if events or changes in circumstances indicate potential impairment between annual measurement dates.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P18_S1	The Company qualitatively determines whether it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying amount before performing Step 1 of the goodwill impairment test.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P18_S2	If an entity concludes that it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying amount, the entity would be required to perform Step 1 of the assessment and then, if needed, Step 2 to determine whether goodwill is impaired.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P18_S3	However, if it is more likely than not that the fair value of the reporting unit is more than its carrying amount, the entity does not need to apply the two-step impairment test.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P19_S0	For this analysis, the Reporting Unit is defined as the Bank, which includes all core and retail banking operations of the Company but excludes the assets, liabilities, equity, earnings and operations held exclusively at the Company level.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P20_S0	The guidance provides certain factors an entity should consider in its qualitative assessment in determining whether it is more likely than not that a reporting unit s fair value is less than its carrying amount.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P21_S0	Macroeconomic conditions, such as deterioration in economic condition and limited access to capital.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P22_S0	Industry and market considerations, such as increased competition, regulatory developments and decline in market-dependent multiples.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P23_S0	Cost factors, such as increased labor costs, cost of materials and other operating costs.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P24_S0	Overall financial performance, such as declining cash flows and decline in revenue or earnings.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P25_S0	Other relevant entity-specific events, such as changes in management, strategy or customers, litigation and contemplation of bankruptcy.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P26_S0	Reporting unit events, such as selling or disposing a portion of a reporting unit and a change in composition of assets.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P26_S1	The Company completed its annual goodwill impairment test as of September 30, 2013.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P26_S2	Based upon its qualitative assessment of goodwill, the Company concluded it is more likely than not that the fair value of the reporting unit exceeds its carrying amount, goodwill was not impaired and no further quantitative analysis (Step 1) was warranted.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P27_S0	The Company may, based upon its qualitative assessment, or at its option, perform the two-step process to evaluate the potential impairment of goodwill.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P27_S1	If, based upon Step 1, the fair value of the Reporting Unit exceeds its carrying amount, goodwill of the Reporting Unit is considered not impaired.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P27_S2	However, if the carrying amount of the Reporting Unit exceeds its fair value, an additional test must be performed.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P28_S0	The second step test compares the implied fair value of the Reporting Unit s goodwill with the carrying amount of that goodwill.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P28_S1	An impairment loss would be recorded to the extent that the carrying amount of goodwill exceeds its implied fair value.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P29_S0	The Company s available for sale securities portfolio is carried at estimated fair value, with any unrealized gains or losses, net of taxes, reported as accumulated other comprehensive income or loss in Stockholders Equity.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P29_S1	Estimated fair values are based on market quotations or matrix pricing as discussed in Note 5 to the audited consolidated financial statements.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P30_S0	Securities which the Company has the positive intent and ability to hold to maturity are classified as held to maturity and carried at amortized cost.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P30_S1	The Company conducts a periodic review and evaluation of the securities portfolio to determine if any declines in the fair values of securities are other-than-temporary.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P30_S2	In this evaluation, if such a decline were deemed other-than-temporary, the Company would measure the total credit-related component of the unrealized loss, and recognize that portion of the loss as a charge to current period earnings.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P30_S3	The remaining portion of the unrealized loss would be recognized as an adjustment to accumulated other comprehensive income.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P31_S0	The fair value of the securities portfolio is significantly affected by changes in interest rates.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P31_S1	In general, as interest rates rise, the fair value of fixed-rate securities decreases and as interest rates fall, the fair value of fixed-rate securities increases.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P32_S0	Turmoil in the credit markets resulted in a lack of liquidity in certain sectors of the mortgage-backed securities market.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P32_S1	Increases in delinquencies and foreclosures have resulted in limited trading activity and significant price declines, regardless of favorable movements in interest rates.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P33_S0	The Company determines if it has the intent to sell these securities or if it is more likely than not that the Company would be required to sell the securities before the anticipated recovery.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P33_S1	If either exists, the decline in value is considered other-than-temporary.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P33_S2	In this evaluation, the Company recognized an other-than-temporary securities impairment loss in 2013 and 2011, totaling $ 434,000 and $ 302,000 , respectively.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P33_S3	No other-than-temporary securities impairment loss was incurred in 2012.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P34_S0	The determination of whether deferred tax assets will be realizable is predicated on the reversal of existing deferred tax liabilities, utilization against carryback years and estimates of future taxable income.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P34_S1	Such estimates are subject to management s judgment.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P35_S0	A valuation allowance is established when management is unable to conclude that it is more likely than not that it will realize deferred tax assets based on the nature and timing of these items.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P35_S1	A valuation reserve of $1.1 million was established in 2009 pertaining primarily to state tax benefits on net operating losses at the Bank and unused capital loss carryforwards.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P35_S2	In 2011, management released the valuation allowance associated with the state net operating losses, approximately $840,000, due to expectation of current and future taxable income.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P35_S3	At December 31, 2013, the Company maintained a valuation allowance of $242,000, related to unused capital loss carryforwards.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P36_S0	Analysis of Net Interest Income Net interest income represents the difference between income on interest-earning assets and expense on interest-bearing liabilities.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P36_S1	Net interest income depends on the relative amounts of interest-earning assets and interest-bearing liabilities and the rates of interest earned on such assets and paid on such liabilities.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P36_S2	The following table sets forth certain information for the years ended December 31, 2013 , 2012 and 2011 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P36_S3	For the periods indicated, the total dollar amount of interest income from average interest-earning assets and the resultant yields, as well as the interest expense on average interest-bearing liabilities is expressed both in dollars and rates.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P36_S4	No tax equivalent adjustments were made.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P37_S0	(1) Average outstanding balance amounts are at amortized cost.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P37_S1	(2) Average outstanding balances are net of the allowance for loan losses, deferred loan fees and expenses, and loan premiums and discounts and include non-accrual loans.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P37_S2	(3) Net interest income divided by average interest-earning assets.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P38_S0	The following table presents the extent to which changes in interest rates and changes in the volume of interest-earning assets and interest-bearing liabilities have affected interest income and interest expense during the periods indicated.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P38_S1	Information is provided in each category with respect to: (i) changes attributable to changes in volume (changes in volume multiplied by prior rate); (ii) changes attributable to changes in rate (changes in rate multiplied by prior volume); and (iii) the net change.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P38_S2	The changes attributable to the combined impact of volume and rate have been allocated proportionately to the changes due to volume and the changes due to rate.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P39_S0	Comparison of Financial Condition at December 31, 2013 and December 31, 2012 Total assets increased $ 203.6 million, or 2.8 %, to $ 7.49 billion at December 31, 2013 , from $ 7.28 billion at December 31, 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P39_S1	The increase was primarily due to increases in total loans, partially offset by a decline in total securities.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P39_S2	Total loans increased $ 290.1 million, or 5.9 %, to $ 5.19 billion at December 31, 2013 , from $ 4.90 billion at December 31, 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P39_S3	For the year ended December 31, 2013 , loan originations totaling $ 1.77 billion and loan purchases of $ 34.8 million were partially offset by repayments of $ 1.47 billion and loan sales of $ 31.0 million.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P39_S4	Multi-family loans increased $ 204.9 million to $ 928.9 million at December 31, 2013 , compared to $ 724.0 million at December 31, 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P39_S5	Commercial loans increased $ 65.8 million to $ 932.2 million at December 31, 2013 , compared to $ 866.4 million at December 31, 2012 , commercial real estate loans increased $ 50.7 million to $ 1.40 billion at December 31, 2013 , compared to $ 1.35 billion at December 31, 2012 , and construction loans increased $ 63.2 million to $ 183.3 million at December 31, 2013 , compared to $ 120.1 million at December 31, 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P39_S6	Residential mortgage loans decreased $ 91.0 million to $ 1.17 billion at December 31, 2013 , compared to $ 1.27 billion at December 31, 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P39_S7	One- to four-family residential mortgage loan originations totaled $ 122.5 million and one-to four-family residential mortgage loans purchased totaled $ 34.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P39_S8	Principal repayments on residential mortgage loans totaled $ 228.2 million, and residential mortgage loans sold totaled $ 31.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P39_S9	Consumer loans decreased $ 1.6 million to $ 577.6 million at December 31, 2013 , compared to $ 579.2 million at December 31, 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P39_S10	Commercial loans, consisting of commercial real estate, multi-family, construction and commercial loans, totaled $3.45 billion, accounting for 66.3% of the loan portfolio at December 31, 2013 , compared to $3.06 billion, or 62.4% of the loan portfolio at December 31, 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P39_S11	The Company intends to continue to focus on the origination of commercially-oriented loans.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P40_S0	Retail loans, which consist of one- to four-family residential mortgage and consumer loans, such as fixed-rate home equity loans and lines of credit, totaled $1.75 billion and accounted for 33.7% of the loan portfolio at December 31, 2013 , compared to $1.84 billion, or 37.6%, of the loan portfolio at December 31, 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P41_S0	was a result of growth in the multi-family and commercial mortgage portfolios, coupled with reductions in retail loans attributable to refinance activity, the market preference for longer-term fixed-rate loans, which the Company chooses to sell rather than retain for portfolio as part of its interest rate risk management process, and lack of qualified retail loan demand.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P42_S0	The Company does not originate or purchase sub-prime or option ARM loans.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P43_S0	Prior to September 30, 2008, the Company originated Alt-A mortgages in the form of stated income loans with a maximum loan-to-value ratio of 50% on a limited basis.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P43_S1	The balance of these Alt-A loans at December 31, 2013 was $7.5 million.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P43_S2	Of this total, 5 loans totaling $493,000 were 90 days or more delinquent.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P43_S3	General valuation reserves of 6.5%, or $32,000, were allocated to these loans at December 31, 2013 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P44_S0	The Company participates in loans originated by other banks, including participations designated as Shared National Credits ( SNC ).
1178970_14_ITEM7_P44_S1	The Company s gross commitments and outstanding balances as a participant in SNCs were $53.2 million and $12.3 million, respectively, at December 31, 2013 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P44_S2	At December 31, 2013 , no SNC relationships were classified as substandard The Company had outstanding junior lien mortgages totaling $226.4 million at December 31, 2013 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P44_S3	Of this total, 29 loans totaling $2.0 million were 90 days or more delinquent.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P44_S4	General valuation reserves of 10%, or $203,000, were allocated to these loans at December 31, 2013 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P44_S5	At December 31, 2013 , the Company had outstanding indirect marine loans totaling $33.4 million.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P44_S6	Of this total, 5 loans totaling $367,000 were 90 days or more delinquent.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P44_S7	General valuation reserves of 60%, or $220,000, were allocated to these loans at December 31, 2013 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P45_S0	Marine loans are currently made only on a direct, limited accommodation basis to existing customers.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P45_S1	The allowance for loan losses decreased $ 5.7 million to $ 64.7 million at December 31, 2013 , as a result of net charge-offs of $ 11.2 million, partially offset by provisions for loan losses of $ 5.5 million during 2013 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P45_S2	The decrease in the allowance for loan losses was attributable to a decrease in non-performing loans, and an improvement in the average risk rating of the loan portfolio.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P45_S3	Total non-performing loans at December 31, 2013 were $ 76.7 million, or 1.48 % of total loans, compared with $99.0 million, or 2.02% of total loans at December 31, 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P45_S4	At December 31, 2013 , impaired loans totaled $ 106.4 million with related specific reserves of $ 10.2 million.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P45_S5	Within total impaired loans, there were $30.2 million of loans for which the present value of expected future cash flows or current collateral valuations exceeded the carrying amounts of the loans and for which no specific reserves were required in accordance with GAAP.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P45_S6	At December 31, 2013 , the Company s allowance for loan losses was 1.24 % of total loans, compared with 1.43 % of total loans at December 31, 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P45_S7	Non-performing commercial mortgage loans decreased $ 10.4 million to $ 18.7 million at December 31, 2013 , from $ 29.1 million at December 31, 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P45_S8	At December 31, 2013 , the Company held 13 non-performing commercial mortgage loans.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P45_S9	The largest non-performing commercial mortgage loan was a $12.5 million loan secured by a first mortgage on a 200,000 square foot office/industrial building located in Eatontown, New Jersey, which has been negatively impacted by the loss of a major tenant that relied upon contracts with the Federal government.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P45_S10	The loan has been restructured and payments are current at December 31, 2013 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P45_S11	The borrower continues to make efforts to lease the property.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P45_S12	There is no contractual commitment to advance additional funds to this borrower.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P45_S13	Non-performing residential mortgage loans decreased $6.3 million to $ 23.0 million at December 31, 2013 , from $ 29.3 million at December 31, 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P45_S14	Gross charge-offs of residential loans were $ 3.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P45_S15	Non-performing commercial loans decreased $3.3 million, to $ 22.2 million at December 31, 2013 , from $ 25.5 million at December 31, 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P45_S16	Non-performing commercial loans at December 31, 2013 consisted of 33 loans.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P45_S17	The largest non-performing commercial loan relationship consisted of five loans to a power systems manufacturer with total outstanding balances of $8.0 million at December 31, 2013 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P45_S18	All contractual payments on these loans, based upon modified terms, were current at December 31, 2013 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P45_S19	Non-performing consumer loans decreased $1.9 million, to $ 3.9 million at December 31, 2013 , from $ 5.9 million at December 31, 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P45_S20	Gross consumer loan charge-offs were $ 3.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P45_S21	Non-performing construction loans decreased $448,000, to $ 8.4 million at December 31, 2013 , from $ 8.9 million at December 31, 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P45_S22	At December 31, 2013 , non-performing construction loans consisted of one loan secured by a first mortgage on a 77,000 square foot newly constructed Class A office building, and a parcel of land with approvals for an 110,000 square foot office building located in Parsippany, New Jersey.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P45_S23	The office building is completed, except for tenant improvements, but not leased due to weakness in the market.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P45_S24	The property is being marketed and the principals are supporting the project.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P45_S25	All contractual payments on this loan, based upon modified terms, were current at December 31, 2013 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P45_S26	The Company has an unfunded commitment of $3.6 million on this loan at December 31, 2013 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P45_S27	Non-performing multi-family loans declined $9,000 to $ 403,000 at December 31, 2013 , from $ 412,000 at December 31, 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P46_S0	At December 31, 2013 , the Company held $ 5.5 million of foreclosed assets, compared with $ 12.5 million at December 31, 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P46_S1	Foreclosed assets at December 31, 2013 are carried at fair value based on recent appraisals and valuation estimates, less estimated selling costs.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P46_S2	Foreclosed assets consisted primarily of $3.0 million of residential properties, $2.4 million of commercial real estate and $59,000 of marine vessels at December 31, 2013 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P46_S3	Non-performing assets totaled $ 82.2 million, or 1.10 % of total assets at December 31, 2013 , compared to $ 111.5 million, or 1.53 % of total assets at December 31, 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P46_S4	If the non-accrual loans had performed in accordance with their original terms, interest income would have increased by $1.9 million during the year ended December 31, 2013 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P46_S5	Total deposits decreased $ 226.5 million, or 4.2 %, during the year ended December 31, 2013 to $ 5.20 billion from $ 5.43 billion at December 31, 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P46_S6	Core deposits, consisting of savings and all demand deposit accounts, decreased $ 75.8 million, or 1.7 %, to $ 4.40 billion at December 31, 2013 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P46_S7	The largest decrease was in time deposits which decreased $ 150.7 million, or 15.7 %, to $ 806.8 million at December 31, 2013 , with the majority of the decrease occurring in the 6-, 12- and 60-month maturity categories.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P46_S8	The Company continued to develop core deposit relationships, while strategically permitting the run-off of higher-costing time deposits.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P46_S9	Core deposits represented 84.5 % of total deposits at December 31, 2013 , compared to 82.4 % at December 31, 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P46_S10	Borrowed funds increased $ 400.6 million, or 49.9 % during the year ended December 31, 2013 , to $ 1.20 billion, as longer-term wholesale funding was added to mitigate interest rate risk, and shorter-term wholesale funding was used to manage the outflow of deposits.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P46_S11	Borrowed funds represented 16.1 % of total assets at December 31, 2013 , an increase from 11.0 % at December 31, 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P46_S12	Total stockholders equity increased $ 29.5 million to $ 1.01 billion at December 31, 2013 , from $ 981.2 million at December 31, 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P46_S13	This increase was a result of net income of $ 70.5 million, the allocation of shares to stock-based compensation plans of $8.2 million and the reissuance of shares for the dividend reinvestment program of $ 1.2 million, partially offset by cash dividends of $ 32.3 million, other comprehensive loss of $ 12.6 million and common stock repurchases of $ 5.9 million.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P47_S0	Comparison of Operating Results for the Years Ended December 31, 2013 and December 31, 2012 General.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P47_S1	Net income for the year ended December 31, 2013 was $70.5 million, compared to $67.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P47_S2	Basic and diluted earnings per share were $ 1.23 for the year ended December 31, 2013 , compared to basic and diluted earnings per share of $ 1.18 for 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P47_S3	Earnings for year ended December 31, 2013 was favorably impacted by the continued improvement in asset quality and related reductions in the provision for loan losses compared with the same period last year.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P47_S4	In addition, growth in both average loans outstanding and non-interest bearing demand deposits has contributed to the improvement in earnings.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P48_S0	Net income for the year ended December 31, 2013 was adversely impacted by the write-off of a deferred tax asset related to non-qualified stock options issued shortly after the Company's 2003 initial public offering, all of which expired unused in July 2013.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P48_S1	The write-off of the related $3.9 million deferred tax asset resulted in a $3.2 million charge to income tax expense and a $735,000 charge to equity in the third quarter of 2013.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P48_S2	This write-off reduced both basic and diluted earnings per share for the year ended December 31, 2013 by $0.06.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P48_S3	Net interest income decreased $ 1.3 million to $ 216.0 million for 2013 , from $ 217.3 million for 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P48_S4	The average interest rate spread declined 6 basis points to 3.19 % for 2013 , from 3.25 % for 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P48_S5	The net interest margin decreased 7 basis points to 3.31 % for 2013 , compared to 3.38 % for 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P48_S6	For the year ended December 31, 2013 , net interest income was unfavorably impacted by compression in net interest margin, which was mitigated by an increase in average loans outstanding, funded in part by growth in non-interest bearing demand deposits.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P48_S7	Interest income decreased $ 9.5 million, or 3.6%, to $ 252.8 million for 2013 , compared to $ 262.3 million for 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P48_S8	The decrease in interest income was attributable to a decrease in the yield on average earning assets, partially offset by an increase in average earning asset balances.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P48_S9	The yield on interest-earning assets decreased 21 basis points to 3.87 % for 2013 , from 4.08 % for 2012 , with reductions in yields experienced in nearly all earning asset classes.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P48_S10	Average interest-earning assets increased $ 93.5 million, or 1.5 %, to $ 6.53 billion for 2013 , compared to $ 6.43 billion for 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P48_S11	The average outstanding loan balances increased $ 263.8 million, or 5.7 %, to $ 4.92 billion for 2013 from $ 4.66 billion for 2012 , the average balance of securities available for sale decreased $ 160.1 million, or 11.9 %, to $ 1.19 billion for 2013 , compared to $ 1.35 billion for 2012 , and the average balance of investment securities held to maturity increased $ 1.7 million, or 0.5 %, to $ 353.6 million for 2013 , compared to $ 352.0 million for 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P48_S12	These increases were partially offset by a decrease in average interest-earning deposits, Federal funds sold and short-term investment balances of $ 16.8 million, to $ 16.8 million for 2013 , from $ 33.6 million for 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P48_S13	Interest expense decreased $ 8.2 million, or 18.2 %, to $ 36.8 million for 2013 , from $ 44.9 million for 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P48_S14	The decrease in interest expense was attributable to lower short-term interest rates coupled with a shift in the funding composition to lower-costing core deposits from certificates of deposit and a reduction in the average cost of borrowings.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P48_S15	This was partially offset by an increase in average borrowings, which replaced average deposit outflow and funded a portion of the growth in average interest-earning assets.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P48_S16	The average rate paid on interest-bearing liabilities decreased 15 basis points to 0.68 % for 2013 , from 0.83 % for 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P49_S0	The average rate paid on interest-bearing deposits decreased 16 basis points to 0.40 % for 2013 , from 0.56 % for 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P49_S1	The average rate paid on borrowings decreased 20 basis points to 2.06 % for 2013 , from 2.26 % for 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P49_S2	The average balance of interest-bearing liabilities decreased $8.2 million to $ 5.37 billion for 2013 , compared to $ 5.39 billion for 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P49_S3	Average interest-bearing deposits decreased $ 65.7 million, or 1.45 %, to $ 4.46 billion for 2013 , from $ 4.52 billion for 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P49_S4	Within average interest-bearing deposits, average interest-bearing core deposits increased $ 97.5 million, or 2.8 %, for 2013 , compared with 2012 , while average time deposits decreased $ 163.1 million, or 15.66% , for 2013 , compared with 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P49_S5	Also contributing to the decrease in interest expense, average non-interest bearing deposits increased $ 96.2 million, or 12.9 %, to $ 839.3 million for 2013 , from $ 743.1 million for 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P49_S6	Average outstanding borrowings increased $ 44.1 million, or 5.1 %, to $ 908.8 million for 2013 , compared with $ 864.7 million for 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P50_S0	Provisions for loan losses are charged to operations to maintain the allowance for loan losses at a level management considers necessary to absorb probable credit losses inherent in the loan portfolio.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P50_S1	In determining the level of the allowance for loan losses, management considers past and current loss experience, evaluations of real estate collateral, current economic conditions, volume and type of lending, adverse situations that may affect a borrower s ability to repay the loan and the levels of non-performing and other classified loans.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P50_S2	The amount of the allowance is based on estimates and the ultimate losses may vary from such estimates as more information becomes available or later events change.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P50_S3	Management assesses the adequacy of the allowance for loan losses on a quarterly basis and makes provisions for loan losses, if necessary, in order to maintain the adequacy of the allowance.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P50_S4	The Company s emphasis on continued diversification of the loan portfolio through the origination of commercial loans has been one of the more significant factors management has considered in evaluating the allowance for loan losses and provision for loan losses for the past several years.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P50_S5	In the event the Company further increases the amount of such types of loans in the portfolio, management may determine that additional or increased provisions for loan losses are necessary, which could adversely affect earnings.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P50_S6	The provision for loan losses was $ 5.5 million in 2013 , compared to $ 16.0 million in 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P50_S7	The decrease in the provision for loan losses was primarily attributable to a decline in non-performing loan formation and an improvement in credit risk ratings.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P50_S8	Net charge-offs for 2013 were $ 11.2 million, compared to $ 20.0 million for 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P50_S9	Total charge-offs for the year ended December 31, 2013 were $ 14.4 million, compared to $ 23.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P50_S10	Recoveries for the year ended December 31, 2013 , were $ 3.2 million, compared to $ 3.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P50_S11	The allowance for loan losses at December 31, 2013 was $ 64.7 million, or 1.24 % of total loans, compared to $ 70.3 million, or 1.43 % of total loans at December 31, 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P50_S12	At December 31, 2013 , non-performing loans as a percentage of total loans were 1.48 %, compared to 2.02 % at December 31, 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P50_S13	Non-performing assets as a percentage of total assets were 1.10 % at December 31, 2013 , compared to 1.53 % at December 31, 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P50_S14	At December 31, 2013 , non-performing loans were $ 76.7 million, compared to $ 99.0 million at December 31, 2012 , and non-performing assets were $ 82.2 million at December 31, 2013 , compared to $ 111.5 million at December 31, 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P50_S15	For the year ended December 31, 2013 , non-interest income totaled $44.2 million, an increase of $540,000, or 1.2%, compared to the same period in 2012.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P50_S16	Fee income increased $3.7 million, to $34.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 , compared with the same period in 2012, largely due to increases in prepayment fees on commercial loans, wealth management income and deposit fees.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P50_S17	BOLI income increased $1.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 , compared to the same period in the prior year, principally due to the recognition of a policy claim.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P50_S18	These increases were partially offset by a $3.5 million decrease in net gains on securities transactions for the year ended December 31, 2013 , compared to the same period in 2012.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P50_S19	Other income decreased $554,000 for the year ended December 31, 2013 , compared with the same period in 2012, primarily due to a $491,000 decrease in gains on loan sales, a $525,000 decrease associated with the sale of a parcel of land in 2012, partially offset by a $478,000 increase in net gains on the sales of foreclosed real estate.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P50_S20	Additionally, for the year ended December 31, 2013, the Company recognized a $434,000 net other-than-temporary impairment charge related to an investment in a previously impaired non-Agency mortgage-backed security.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P50_S21	For the year ended December 31, 2013 , non-interest expense was $148.8 million, a decrease of $65,000 from the year ended December 31, 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P50_S22	Other operating expenses decreased $2.0 million, primarily due to a reduction in non-performing asset related expenses and charges incurred in the prior year period, which included $545,000 related to damages sustained in Superstorm Sandy, $213,000 associated with the termination of a software contract in connection with the Beacon integration and $222,000 related to the consolidation of underperforming branches.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P50_S23	In addition, the amortization of intangibles decreased $842,000 for the year ended December 31, 2013 , compared with the same period in 2012, as a result of scheduled reductions in core deposit intangible amortization.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P50_S24	FDIC insurance costs declined $417,000 as a result of a lower assessment rate and advertising expense decreased $249,000 to $3.9 million.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P50_S25	Partially offsetting these reductions, compensation and benefits expense increased $3.2 million and data processing expense increased $232,000, respectively, for the year ended December 31, 2013 , compared to the same period last year.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P51_S0	The increase in data processing expense was attributable to increased software maintenance and Internet-banking costs.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P51_S1	For the year ended December 31, 2013 , the Company s income tax expense was $35.4 million, compared with $28.9 million, for the same period in 2012.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P51_S2	The increase in income tax expense for the year ended December 31, 2013 was primarily attributable to a $3.2 million charge associated with the write-off of a deferred tax asset related to expired non-qualified stock options in the third quarter of 2013, and growth in pre-tax income from taxable sources.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P51_S3	The Company s effective tax rate was 33.4% for the year ended December 31, 2013 , compared with 30.0% for the year ended December 31, 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P52_S0	Comparison of Operating Results for the Years Ended December 31, 2012 and December 31, 2011 General.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P52_S1	Net income for the year ended December 31, 2012 was $ 67.3 million, compared to $ 57.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2011 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P52_S2	Basic and diluted earnings per share were $ 1.18 for the year ended December 31, 2012 , compared to basic and diluted earnings per share of $ 1.01 for 2011 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P52_S3	The increase in earnings for the year ended December 31, 2012 , was largely attributable to continued improvements in asset quality and related reductions in the provision for loan losses, inclusive of consideration for possible loan losses related to Superstorm Sandy, while growth in both average loans outstanding and average lower-costing core deposits more than offset the impact of compression in asset yields.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P52_S4	Net interest income increased $ 1.3 million to $ 217.3 million for 2012 , from $ 216.0 million for 2011 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P52_S5	The average interest rate spread declined 8 basis points to 3.25% for 2012 , from 3.33% for 2011 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P52_S6	The net interest margin decreased 11 basis points to 3.38% for 2012 , compared to 3.49% for 2011 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P52_S7	For the year ended December 31, 2012 , the favorable effects of an increase in average loans outstanding and reductions in funding costs outpaced the impact of the downward repricing of earning assets.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P52_S8	Interest income decreased $ 13.5 million, or 4.9 %, to $ 262.3 million for 2012 , compared to $ 275.7 million for 2011 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P52_S9	The decrease in interest income was attributable to a decrease in the yield on average earning assets, partially offset by an increase in average earning asset balances.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P52_S10	The yield on interest-earning assets decreased 38 basis points to 4.08% for 2012 , from 4.46% for 2011 , with reductions in yields experienced in nearly all earning asset classes.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P52_S11	Average interest-earning assets increased $273.2 million, or 4.4%, to $6.43 billion for 2012 , compared to $6.16 billion for 2011 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P52_S12	The average outstanding loan balances increased $235.3 million, or 5.3%, to $4.66 billion for 2012 from $4.42 billion for 2011 , the average balance of securities available for sale increased $46.1 million, or 3.5%, to $1.35 billion for 2012 , compared to $1.30 billion for 2011 , and the average balance of investment securities increased $6.5 million, or 1.9%, to $352.0 million for 2012 , compared to $345.5 million for 2011 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P52_S13	These increases were partially offset by a decrease in average interest-earning deposits, Federal funds sold and short-term investment balances of $15.5 million, or 31.6%, to $33.6 million for 2012 , from $49.2 million for 2011 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P52_S14	Interest expense decreased $ 14.8 million, or 24.8 %, to $ 44.9 million for 2012 , from $ 59.7 million for 2011 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P52_S15	The decrease in interest expense was attributable to lower short-term interest rates coupled with a shift in the funding composition to lower-costing core deposits from certificates of deposit and a reduction in average borrowings, partially offset by an increase in average interest-bearing deposit balances.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P52_S16	The average rate paid on interest-bearing liabilities decreased 30 basis points to 0.83% for 2012 , from 1.13% for 2011 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P52_S17	The average rate paid on interest-bearing deposits decreased 27 basis points to 0.56% for 2012 , from 0.83% for 2011 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P52_S18	The average rate paid on borrowings decreased 29 basis points to 2.26% for 2012 , from 2.55% for 2011 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P52_S19	The average balance of interest-bearing liabilities increased $94.8 million, or 1.8%, to $5.39 billion for 2012 , compared to $5.29 billion for 2011 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P52_S20	Average interest-bearing deposits increased $139.6 million, or 3.2%, to $4.52 billion for 2012 , from $4.39 billion for 2011 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P52_S21	Within average interest-bearing deposits, average interest-bearing core deposits increased $311.4 million, or 9.8%, for 2012 , compared with 2011 , while average time deposits decreased $171.8 million, or 14.2%, for 2012 , compared with 2011 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P52_S22	Further aiding the increase in net interest income, average non-interest bearing deposits increased $137.3 million, or 22.7%, to $743.1 million for 2012 , from $605.8 million for 2011 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P52_S23	Average outstanding borrowings decreased $44.8 million, or 4.9%, to $864.7 million for 2012 , compared with $909.5 million for 2011 , as deposits replaced wholesale funding.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P52_S24	The provision for loan losses was $ 16.0 million in 2012 , compared to $ 28.9 million in 2011 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P52_S25	The provision for loan losses for 2012 included $1.5 million for possible loan losses related to Superstorm Sandy.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P52_S26	The decrease in the provision for loan losses was primarily attributable to a decline in non-performing loan formation and an improvement in credit risk ratings.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P52_S27	Net charge-offs for 2012 were $ 20.0 million, compared to $ 23.3 million for 2011 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P52_S28	Total charge-offs for the year ended December 31, 2012 were $ 23.9 million, compared to $ 25.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2011 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P52_S29	Recoveries for the year ended December 31, 2012 , were $ 3.9 million, compared to $ 1.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2011 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P52_S30	The allowance for loan losses at December 31, 2012 was $ 70.3 million, or 1.43 % of total loans, compared to $ 74.4 million, or 1.60% of total loans at December 31, 2011 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P52_S31	At December 31, 2012 , non-performing loans as a percentage of total loans were 2.02 %, compared to 2.63% at December 31, 2011 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P52_S32	Non-performing assets as a percentage of total assets were 1.53 % at December 31, 2012 , compared to 1.91% at December 31, 2011 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P52_S33	At December 31, 2012 , non-performing loans were $ 99.0 million, compared to $122.5 million at December 31, 2011 , and non-performing assets were $ 111.5 million at December 31, 2012 , compared to $135.4 million at December 31, 2011 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P53_S0	For the year ended December 31, 2012 , non-interest income totaled $ 43.6 million, an increase of $ 11.1 million, or 34.0 %, compared to the same period in 2011 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P53_S1	Fee income totaled $ 30.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 , an increase of $ 4.9 million compared with the same period in 2011 , largely due to an increase in wealth management fees attributable to the August 2011 acquisition of Beacon Trust Company ( Beacon ) and increased prepayment fees on commercial loans, which were partially offset by lower overdraft fee income.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P53_S2	Net gains on securities transactions totaled $ 4.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 , compared to $ 708,000 for the same period in 2011 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P53_S3	During the year, the Company identified and sold certain mortgage-backed securities which had a high risk of accelerated prepayment.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P53_S4	The proceeds from the sales were reinvested in similar securities with more stable projected cash flows.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P53_S5	Also contributing to the increase in non-interest income, other income increased $2.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 , compared with the same period in 2011 , primarily due to a $525,000 net gain recognized on the sale of a vacant parcel of land, $568,000 in income associated with the termination of the Company s debit card rewards program, losses previously recorded in 2011 related to the sale of the Company s former administrative facilities, and an increase in gains resulting from a larger number of loan sales.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P53_S6	Other-than-temporary impairment charges on investment securities declined $302,000 for the year ended December 31, 2012 , compared to last year, as the Company did not experience any other-than-temporary impairment on its securities portfolio in 2012.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P53_S7	Non-interest expense for the year ended December 31, 2012 was $148.8 million, an increase of $6.4 million, or 4.5%, from the year ended December 31, 2011 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P53_S8	Compensation and benefits expense increased $6.0 million, to $80.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 compared to the year ended December 31, 2011 , due to higher salary expense associated with annual merit increases, personnel added as a result of the Beacon acquisition, an increased incentive compensation accrual and increased employee medical and retirement benefit costs.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P53_S9	In addition, other operating expense increased $2.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 compared to the same period in 2011 , due primarily to increased non-performing asset related expenses, net expenses of $624,000 incurred due to damages sustained in Superstorm Sandy, a $213,000 charge related to the termination of a software contract in connection with the Beacon integration and $222,000 in charges related to the consolidation of underperforming branches.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P53_S10	Data processing expense increased $818,000 for the year ended December 31, 2012 , compared to the same period in 2011 , due to an increase in software maintenance expense, primarily associated with technology enhancements at Beacon, and increased core processing fees.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P53_S11	Partially offsetting these increases, impairment of premises and equipment declined $807,000 for the year ended December 31, 2012 , compared to last year, due to an impairment charge incurred in the first quarter of 2011 related to the then planned sale and relocation of the Company s former loan center.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P53_S12	FDIC insurance expense decreased $788,000 to $5.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 , compared with the same period in 2011 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P53_S13	The decrease was primarily due to a lower assessment rate and a change in assessment methodology from a deposit-based to an asset-based assessment, effective in the second quarter of 2012.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P53_S14	Net occupancy expense decreased $644,000 to $20.5 million, compared to the same period last year, due to the consolidation and relocation of the Company s administrative offices in April 2011 and the elimination of prior year carrying costs on previously occupied facilities owned by the Company that were sold in November 2011.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P53_S15	Additionally, amortization of intangibles decreased $564,000 for the year ended December 31, 2012 , compared with the same period of 2011 , as a result of scheduled reductions in core deposit intangible amortization, partially offset by the amortization of the customer relationship intangible arising from the Beacon acquisition.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P53_S16	For the year ended December 31, 2012 , the Company s income tax expense was $28.9 million, compared with $19.8 million in 2011 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P53_S17	The increase in income tax expense was primarily attributable to an increase in pre-tax income.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P53_S18	The Company s effective tax rate was 30.0% for the year ended December 31, 2012 , compared with 25.7% for the year ended December 31, 2011 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P53_S19	The increase in the effective tax rate and income tax expense was primarily a function of growth in pre-tax income from taxable sources.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P54_S0	Liquidity and Capital Resources Liquidity refers to the Company s ability to generate adequate amounts of cash to meet financial obligations to its depositors, to fund loans and securities purchases, deposit outflows and operating expenses.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P54_S1	Sources of funds include scheduled amortization of loans, loan prepayments, scheduled maturities of investments, cash flows from mortgage-backed securities and the ability to borrow funds from the FHLB of New York and approved broker dealers.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P54_S2	Cash flows from loan payments and maturing investment securities are a fairly predictable source of funds.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P54_S3	Changes in interest rates, local economic conditions and the competitive marketplace can influence loan prepayments, prepayments on mortgage-backed securities and deposit flows.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P55_S0	For each of the years ended December 31, 2013 and 2012 , loan repayments totaled $ 1.47 billion and $ 1.41 billion, respectively.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P55_S1	One- to four-family residential loans, consumer loans, commercial real estate loans, multi-family loans and commercial and small business loans are the primary investments of the Company.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P55_S2	Purchasing securities for the investment portfolio is a secondary use of funds and the investment portfolio is structured to complement and facilitate the Company s lending activities and ensure adequate liquidity.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P56_S0	$ 1.73 billion for the year ended December 31, 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P56_S1	Purchases for the investment portfolio totaled $401.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 , compared to $585.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P56_S2	At December 31, 2013 , the Bank had outstanding loan commitments to borrowers of $910.1 million, including undisbursed home equity lines and personal credit lines of $252.5 million.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P56_S3	Total deposits decreased $ 226.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P57_S0	Deposit activity is affected by changes in interest rates, competitive pricing and product offerings in the marketplace, local economic conditions, customer confidence and other factors such as stock market volatility.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P57_S1	Certificate of deposit accounts that are scheduled to mature within one year totaled $ 529.9 million at December 31, 2013 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P57_S2	Based on its current pricing strategy and customer retention experience, the Bank expects to retain a significant share of these accounts.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P57_S3	The Bank manages liquidity on a daily basis and expects to have sufficient cash to meet all of its funding requirements.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P57_S4	As of December 31, 2013 , the Bank exceeded all minimum regulatory capital requirements.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P57_S5	At December 31, 2013 , the Bank s leverage (Tier 1) capital ratio was 8.34 %.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P57_S6	FDIC regulations require banks to maintain a minimum leverage ratio of Tier 1 capital to adjusted total assets of 4.00 %.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P57_S7	At December 31, 2013 , the Bank s total risk-based capital ratio was 12.67 %.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P57_S8	Under current regulations, the minimum required ratio of total capital to risk-weighted assets is 8.00 %.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P57_S9	A bank is considered to be well-capitalized if it has a leverage (Tier 1) capital ratio of at least 5.00 % and a total risk-based capital ratio of at least 10.00 %.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P57_S10	Off-balance sheet and contractual obligations as of December 31, 2013 , are summarized below:
1178970_14_ITEM7_P58_S0	Off-balance sheet commitments consist of unused commitments to borrowers for term loans, unused lines of credit and outstanding letters of credit.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P58_S1	Total off-balance sheet obligations were $910.1 million at December 31, 2013 , an increase of $41.1 million, or 4.7%, from $869.0 million at December 31, 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P58_S2	Contractual obligations consist of operating leases and certificate of deposit liabilities.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P58_S3	There was one securities purchase of $139,000 that was entered into in 2013 and that settled in 2014.
1178970_14_ITEM7_P58_S4	There were no securities purchases that were entered into in 2012 that would have settled in 2013 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P58_S5	Total contractual obligations at December 31, 2013 were $851.0 million, a decrease of $154.6 million, or 15.4%, compared to $1.01 billion at December 31, 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7_P58_S6	Contractual obligations under operating leases decreased $3.8 million, or 8.0%, to $44.3 million at December 31, 2013 , from $48.1 million at December 31, 2012 , and certificate of deposit accounts decreased $ 150.7 million, or 15.7 %, to $ 806.8 million at December 31, 2013 , from $ 957.5 million at December 31, 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7A_P0_S0	Interest rate risk is the exposure of a bank s current and future earnings and capital arising from adverse movements in interest rates.
1178970_14_ITEM7A_P0_S1	The guidelines of the Company s interest rate risk policy seek to limit the exposure to changes in interest rates that affect the underlying economic value of assets and liabilities, earnings and capital.
1178970_14_ITEM7A_P0_S2	To minimize interest rate risk, the Company generally sells 20- and 30-year fixed-rate mortgage loans at origination.
1178970_14_ITEM7A_P0_S3	Commercial real estate loans generally have interest rates that reset in five years, and other commercial loans such as construction loans and commercial lines of credit reset with changes in the Prime rate, the Federal funds rate or LIBOR.
1178970_14_ITEM7A_P0_S4	Investment securities purchases generally have maturities of five years or less, and mortgage-backed securities have weighted average lives initially between three and five years.
1178970_14_ITEM7A_P1_S0	The Asset/Liability Committee meets on at least a monthly basis to review the impact of interest rate changes on net interest income, net interest margin, net income and economic value of equity.
1178970_14_ITEM7A_P2_S0	Chief Executive Officer and Chief Financial Officer, as well as other senior officers from the Bank s finance, lending, credit and customer management departments.
1178970_14_ITEM7A_P3_S0	The Asset/Liability Committee reviews a variety of strategies that project changes in asset or liability mix and the impact of those changes on projected net interest income and net income.
1178970_14_ITEM7A_P4_S0	The Company s strategy for liabilities has been to maintain a stable core-funding base by focusing on core deposit account acquisition and increasing products and services per household.
1178970_14_ITEM7A_P5_S0	Certificate of deposit accounts as a percentage of total deposits were 15.5 % at December 31, 2013 , compared to 17.6 % at December 31, 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7A_P6_S0	Certificate of deposit accounts are generally short-term.
1178970_14_ITEM7A_P6_S1	As of December 31, 2013 , 65.7 % of all time deposits had maturities of one year or less compared to 65.2 % at December 31, 2012 .
1178970_14_ITEM7A_P6_S2	The Company s ability to retain maturing certificate of deposit accounts is the result of a strategy to remain competitively priced within the marketplace.
1178970_14_ITEM7A_P6_S3	The Company s pricing strategy may vary depending upon funding needs and the Company s ability to fund operations through alternative sources, primarily by accessing short-term lines of credit with the FHLB of New York during periods of pricing dislocation.
1178970_14_ITEM7A_P7_S0	Current and future sensitivity to changes in interest rates are measured through the use of balance sheet and income simulation models.
1178970_14_ITEM7A_P7_S1	The analyses capture changes in net interest income using flat rates as a base, a most likely rate forecast and rising and declining interest rate forecasts.
1178970_14_ITEM7A_P7_S2	Changes in net interest income and net income for the forecast period, generally twelve to twenty-four months, are measured and compared to policy limits for acceptable change.
1178970_14_ITEM7A_P7_S3	The Company periodically reviews historical deposit repricing activity and makes modifications to certain assumptions used in its income simulation model regarding the interest rate sensitivity of deposits without maturity dates.
1178970_14_ITEM7A_P7_S4	These modifications are made to more precisely reflect the most likely results under the various interest rate change scenarios.
1178970_14_ITEM7A_P8_S0	Since it is inherently difficult to predict the sensitivity of interest bearing deposits to changes in interest rates, the changes in net interest income due to changes in interest rates cannot be precisely predicted.
1178970_14_ITEM7A_P8_S1	There are a variety of reasons that may cause actual results to vary considerably from the predictions presented below which include, but are not limited to, the timing, magnitude, and frequency of changes in interest rates, interest rate spreads, prepayments, and actions taken in response to such changes.
1178970_14_ITEM7A_P8_S2	Specific assumptions used in the simulation model include:
1178970_14_ITEM7A_P9_S0	Higher-balance demand deposit tiers and promotional demand accounts move at 50% to 75% of the rate ramp in either direction.
1178970_14_ITEM7A_P10_S0	The following table sets forth the results of the twelve month projected net interest income model as of December 31, 2013 .
1178970_14_ITEM7A_P11_S0	The above table indicates that as of December 31, 2013 , in the event of a 300 basis point increase in interest rates, whereby rates ramp up evenly over a twelve-month period, the Company would experience a 7.3 %, or $ 16.0 million decrease in net interest income.
1178970_14_ITEM7A_P11_S1	In the event of a 100 basis point decrease in interest rates, whereby rates ramp down evenly over a twelve-month period, the Company would experience a 0.8 %, or $ 1.7 million decrease in net interest income.
1178970_14_ITEM7A_P12_S0	Another measure of interest rate sensitivity is to model changes in economic value of equity through the use of immediate and sustained interest rate shocks.
1178970_14_ITEM7A_P12_S1	The following table illustrates the economic value of equity model results as of December 31, 2013 .
1178970_14_ITEM7A_P13_S0	The preceding table indicates that as of December 31, 2013 , in the event of an immediate and sustained 300 basis point increase in interest rates, the Company would experience a 16.6 %, or $ 203.7 million reduction in the present value of equity.
1178970_14_ITEM7A_P13_S1	If rates were to decrease 100 basis points, the Company would experience a 5.7 %, or $ 70.6 million increase in the present value of equity.
1178970_14_ITEM7A_P14_S0	Certain shortcomings are inherent in the methodologies used in the above interest rate risk measurements.
1178970_14_ITEM7A_P14_S1	Modeling changes in net interest income requires the making of certain assumptions regarding prepayment and deposit decay rates, which may or may not reflect the manner in which actual yields and costs respond to changes in market interest rates.
1178970_14_ITEM7A_P14_S2	While management believes such assumptions are reasonable, there can be no assurance that assumed prepayment rates and decay rates will approximate actual future loan prepayment and deposit withdrawal activity.
1178970_14_ITEM7A_P14_S3	Moreover, the net interest income table presented assumes that the composition of interest sensitive assets and liabilities existing at the beginning of a period remains constant over the period being measured and also assumes that a particular change in interest rates is reflected uniformly across the yield curve regardless of the duration to maturity or repricing of specific assets and liabilities.
1178970_14_ITEM7A_P14_S4	Accordingly, although the net interest income table provides an indication of the Company s interest rate risk exposure at a particular point in time, such measurement is not intended to and does not provide a precise forecast of the effect of changes in market interest rates on net interest income and will differ from actual results.
1178970_14_ITEM8_P0_S0	The following are included in this item: (A) Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm (B) Report of Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm on Internal Control Over Financial Reporting (C) Consolidated Financial Statements: (6) Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements (D) Provident Financial Services, Inc., Condensed Financial Statements: The supplementary data required by this Item (selected quarterly financial data) is provided in Note 19 of the Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements.
