1178970_14_ITEM15_P20_S0	Exhibit 32 Certification pursuant to 18 U.S.C. Section 1350, as adopted pursuant to Section 906 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002 Christopher Martin, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer and Thomas M. Lyons, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer of Provident Financial Services, Inc. (the Company ) each certify in his capacity as an officer of the Company that he has reviewed the annual report of the Company on Form 10-K for the fiscal ended December 31, 2013 and that to the best of his knowledge: (1) the report fully complies with the requirements of Sections 13(a) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934; and (2) the information contained in the report fairly presents, in all material respects, the financial condition and results of operations.
1178970_14_ITEM15_P20_S1	The purpose of this statement is solely to comply with Title 18, Chapter 63, Section 1350 of the United States Code, as amended by Section 906 of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act of 2002.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P0_S0	The Company is a Delaware corporation which became the holding company for The Provident Bank (the Bank ) on January 15, 2003, following the completion of the conversion of the Bank to a New Jersey-chartered capital stock savings bank.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P0_S1	On January 15, 2003, the Company issued an aggregate of 59,618,300 shares of its common stock, par value $0.01 per share in a subscription offering, and contributed $4.8 million in cash and 1,920,000 shares of its common stock to The Provident Bank Foundation, a charitable foundation established by the Bank.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P0_S2	As a result of the conversion and related stock offering, the Company raised $567.2 million in net proceeds, of which $293.2 million was utilized to acquire all of the outstanding common stock of the Bank.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P1_S0	The Company owns all of the outstanding common stock of the Bank, and as such, is a bank holding company subject to regulation by the Federal Reserve Board.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P2_S0	On May 30, 2014, the Company completed its acquisition of Team Capital Bank ("Team Capital"), which, after purchase accounting adjustments, added $964.0 million to total assets, $631.2 million to loans, and $769.9 million to deposits.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P2_S1	Total consideration paid for Team Capital was $115.1 million: $31.6 million in cash and 4.9 million shares of common stock valued at $83.5 million on the acquisition date.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P2_S2	Team Capital was merged with and into the Company's subsidiary, The Provident Bank as of the close of business on the date of acquisition.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P2_S3	At December 31, 2014 , the Company had total assets of $ 8.52 billion, loans of $ 6.09 billion, total deposits of $ 5.79 billion, and total stockholders equity of $ 1.14 billion.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P2_S4	The Company s mailing address is 239 Washington Street, Jersey City, New Jersey 07302, and the Company s telephone number is (732) 590-9200.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P2_S5	The Company paid cash dividends totaling $ 36.1 million and repurchased 264,118 shares of its common stock at a cost of $4.4 million in 2014 .
1178970_15_ITEM1_P2_S6	At December 31, 2014 , 3.4 million shares were eligible for repurchase under the board approved stock repurchase program.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P3_S0	The Company and the Bank were well capitalized at December 31, 2014 under current regulatory standards.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P4_S0	The Company is a public company, and files interim, quarterly and annual reports with the Securities and Exchange Commission ( SEC ).
1178970_15_ITEM1_P4_S1	These respective reports are on file and a matter of public record with the SEC and may be read and copied at the SEC s Public Reference Room at 100 F Street, NE, Room 1580, Washington, DC 20549.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P4_S2	The public may obtain information on the operation of the Public Reference Room by calling the SEC at 1-800-SEC-0330.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P5_S0	The SEC maintains an Internet site that contains reports, proxy and information statements, and other information regarding issuers that file electronically with the SEC (http://www.sec.gov).
1178970_15_ITEM1_P5_S1	All filed SEC reports and interim filings can also be obtained from the Bank s website, www.providentnj.com, on the Investor Relations page, without charge from the Company.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P6_S0	The Provident Bank Established in 1839, the Bank is a New Jersey-chartered capital stock savings bank currently operating 86 full-service branch offices in the New Jersey counties of Hudson, Bergen, Essex, Mercer, Hunterdon, Middlesex, Monmouth, Morris, Ocean, Passaic, Somerset, Union and Warren, as well as in Bucks, Lehigh and Northampton counties in Pennsylvania.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P6_S1	As a community- and customer-oriented institution, the Bank emphasizes personal service and customer convenience in serving the financial needs of the individuals, families and businesses residing in its primary market areas.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P6_S2	The Bank attracts deposits from the general public and businesses primarily in the areas surrounding its banking offices and uses those funds, together with funds generated from operations and borrowings, to originate commercial real estate loans, commercial business loans, residential mortgage loans, and consumer loans.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P6_S3	The Bank also invests in mortgage-backed securities and other permissible investments.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P7_S0	The following are highlights of The Provident Bank s operations: Diversified Loan Portfolio.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P7_S1	To improve asset yields and reduce its exposure to interest rate risk, the Bank has diversified its loan portfolio and has emphasized the origination of commercial real estate loans, multi-family loans and commercial business loans.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P7_S2	These loans generally have adjustable rates or shorter fixed terms and interest rates that are higher than the rates applicable to one- to four-family residential mortgage loans.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P7_S3	However, these loans generally have a higher risk of loss than one- to four- family residential mortgage loans.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P7_S4	As of December 31, 2014 , non-performing assets were $ 59.0 million or 0.69 % of total assets, compared to $ 82.2 million or 1.10 % of total assets at December 31, 2013 .
1178970_15_ITEM1_P7_S5	The Bank s non-performing asset levels continued to decline from higher levels reported in prior years as local and nationial economic conditions have gradually improved.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P7_S6	The Bank continues to focus on conservative underwriting criteria and on active and timely collection efforts.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P7_S7	Emphasis on Relationship Banking and Core Deposits.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P7_S8	The Bank emphasizes the acquisition and retention of core deposit accounts, consisting of savings and all demand deposit accounts, and expanding customer relationships.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P7_S9	Core deposit accounts totaled $ 4.97 billion at December 31, 2014 , representing 85.7 % of total deposits, compared with $ 4.40 billion, or 84.5 % of total deposits at December 31, 2013 .
1178970_15_ITEM1_P7_S10	The Bank also focuses on increasing the number of households and businesses served and the number of banking products per customer.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P7_S11	The Bank s focus on transaction accounts and expanded products and services has enabled the Bank to generate non-interest income.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P7_S12	Fees derived from core deposit accounts are a primary source of non-interest income.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P7_S13	The Bank also offers investment, wealth and asset management services through its subsidiaries to generate non-interest income.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P7_S14	Total non-interest income was $ 41.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , compared with $ 44.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 , of which fee income was $ 31.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 , compared with $ 34.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2013 .
1178970_15_ITEM1_P8_S0	The Bank manages its exposure to interest rate risk through the origination and retention of adjustable rate and shorter-term loans.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P8_S1	In addition, the Bank uses its investments in securities to manage interest rate risk.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P8_S2	At December 31, 2014 , 53.2% of the Bank s loan portfolio had a term to maturity of one year or less, or had adjustable interest rates.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P8_S3	At December 31, 2014 , the Bank s securities portfolio totaled $1.61 billion and had an expected average life of 4.22 years.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P9_S0	MARKET AREA The Company and the Bank are headquartered in Jersey City, which is located in Hudson County, New Jersey.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P9_S1	At December 31, 2014 , the Bank operated a network of 86 full-service banking offices throughout thirteen counties in northern and central New Jersey, as well as in Bucks, Lehigh and Northampton counties in Pennsylvania.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P9_S2	The Bank also maintains its administrative offices in Iselin, New Jersey and satellite loan production offices in Convent Station, Flemington, Paramus, Princeton and West Orange, New Jersey, as well as Bethlehem and Newtown, Pennsylvania.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P9_S3	The Bank s lending activities, though concentrated in the communities surrounding its offices, extend predominantly throughout New Jersey and eastern Pennsylvania.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P9_S4	The Bank s primary market area includes a mix of urban and suburban communities, and has a diversified mix of industries including pharmaceutical and other manufacturing companies, network communications, insurance and financial services, healthcare, and retail.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P10_S0	According to the U.S. Census Bureau s most recent population data, the Bank s New Jersey market area has a population of 6.9 million, which was 77.6% of the state s total population.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P10_S1	The Bank s Pennsylvania market area has a population of 1.3 million, which was 10.0% of that state s total population.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P11_S0	Because of the diversity of industries within the Bank s market area and, to a lesser extent, its proximity to the New York City financial markets, the area s economy can be significantly affected by changes in national and international economies.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P12_S0	According to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, the unemployment rate in New Jersey remained elevated at 6.2% at December 31, 2014 , although a decrease from 7.3% at December 31, 2013 .
1178970_15_ITEM1_P12_S1	The unemployment rate in Pennsylvania decreased to 4.8% at December 31, 2014 , from 6.8% at December 31, 2013 .
1178970_15_ITEM1_P13_S0	Within its primary market areas in New Jersey and Pennsylvania, the Bank had an approximate 2.22% and 1.26% share of bank deposits as of June 30, 2014, respectively, the latest date for which statistics are available.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P13_S1	On a statewide basis, the Bank had an approximate 1.93% deposit share of the New Jersey market and an approximate 0.11% deposit share of the Pennsylvania market.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P14_S0	The Bank faces intense competition in originating loans, retaining loans and attracting deposits.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P15_S0	The northern and central New Jersey and eastern Pennsylvania market areas have a high concentration of financial institutions, including large money center and regional banks, community banks, credit unions, investment brokerage firms and insurance companies.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P15_S1	The Bank faces direct competition for loans from each of these institutions as well as from mortgage companies and other loan origination firms operating in its market area.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P15_S2	The Bank s most direct competition for deposits has come from several commercial banks and savings banks in its market area.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P15_S3	Certain of these banks have substantially greater financial resources than the Bank.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P15_S4	In addition, the Bank faces significant competition for deposits from the mutual fund and investment advisory industries and from investors direct purchases of short-term money market securities and other corporate and government securities.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P15_S5	The Bank competes in this environment by maintaining a diversified product line, including mutual funds, annuities and other investment services made available through its investment subsidiaries.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P15_S6	Relationships with customers are built and maintained through the Bank s branch network, its deployment of branch ATMs, and its mobile, telephone and web-based banking services.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P16_S0	The Bank originates commercial real estate loans, commercial business loans, fixed-rate and adjustable-rate mortgage loans collateralized by one- to four-family residential real estate and other consumer loans, for borrowers generally located within its primary market area.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P16_S1	Residential mortgage loans are primarily underwritten to standards that allow the sale of the loans to the secondary markets, primarily to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation ( FHLMC or Freddie Mac ), the Federal National Mortgage Association ( FNMA or Fannie Mae ) and the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York ("FHLBNY").
1178970_15_ITEM1_P17_S0	To manage interest rate risk, the Bank generally sells fixed-rate residential mortgages that it originates with terms greater than 15 years.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P17_S1	The Bank commonly retains biweekly payment fixed-rate residential mortgage loans with a maturity of 30 years or less and a majority of the originated adjustable rate mortgages for its portfolio.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P18_S0	The Bank originates commercial real estate loans that are secured by income-producing properties such as multi-family apartment buildings, office buildings, and retail and industrial properties.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P18_S1	Generally, these loans have maturities of either 5 or 10 years.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P18_S2	For loans greater than $5.0 million originated with maturities in excess of 7 years, the bank generally requires loan-level interest rate swaps.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P19_S0	The Bank has historically provided construction loans for both single family and condominium projects intended for sale and commercial projects, including residential for rent projects, that will be retained as investments by the borrower.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P19_S1	The Bank underwrites most construction loans for a term of three years or less.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P19_S2	The majority of these loans are underwritten on a floating rate basis.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P20_S0	The Bank recognizes that there is higher risk in construction lending than permanent lending.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P20_S1	As such, the Bank takes certain precautions to mitigate this risk, including the retention of an outside engineering firm to perform plan and cost reviews and to review all construction advances made against work in place and a limitation on how and when loan proceeds are advanced.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P20_S2	In most cases, for the single family and condominium projects, the Bank limits its exposure against houses or units that are not under contract.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P20_S3	Similarly, commercial construction loans usually have commitments for significant pre-leasing, or funds are held back until the leases are finalized.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P21_S0	Funding requirements and loan structure for residential for-rent projects vary depending on whether such projects are vertical or horizontal construction.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P22_S0	The Bank originates consumer loans that are secured, in most cases, by a borrower s assets.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P22_S1	Home equity loans and home equity lines of credit that are secured by a first or second mortgage lien on the borrower s residence comprise the largest category of the Bank s consumer loan portfolio.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P23_S0	Commercial loans are made to businesses of varying size and type within the Bank s market.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P23_S1	The Bank lends to established businesses, and the loans are generally secured by business assets such as equipment, receivables, inventory, real estate or marketable securities.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P23_S2	On a limited basis, the Bank makes unsecured commercial loans.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P23_S3	Most commercial lines of credit are made on a floating interest rate basis and most term loans are made on a fixed interest rate basis, usually with terms of five years or less.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P24_S0	Set forth below is selected information concerning the composition of the loan portfolio by type, including Purchased Credit Impaired ("PCI") loans, (after deductions for deferred fees and costs, unearned discounts and premiums and allowances for losses) at the dates indicated.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P25_S0	The following table sets forth certain information as of December 31, 2014 , regarding the maturities of loans in the loan portfolio, including PCI loans.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P25_S1	Demand loans having no stated schedule of repayment and no stated maturity, and overdrafts are reported as due within one year.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P26_S0	The following table sets forth at December 31, 2014 , the dollar amount of all fixed-rate and adjustable-rate loans due after December 31, 2015.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P27_S0	The Bank originates residential mortgage loans secured by first mortgages on one- to four-family residences, generally located in the State of New Jersey.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P27_S1	The Bank originates residential mortgages primarily through commissioned mortgage representatives and through the Internet.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P27_S2	The Bank originates both fixed-rate and adjustable-rate mortgages.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P27_S3	As of December 31, 2014 , $ 1.25 billion or 20.8 % of the total portfolio consisted of residential real estate loans.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P27_S4	Of the one- to four-family loans at that date, 62.1% were fixed-rate and 37.9% were adjustable-rate loans.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P28_S0	The Bank originates fixed-rate fully amortizing residential mortgage loans with the principal and interest due each month, that typically have maturities ranging from 10 to 30 years.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P28_S1	The Bank also originates fixed-rate residential mortgage loans with maturities of 10, 15, 20 and 30 years that require the payment of principal and interest on a biweekly basis.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P28_S2	Fixed-rate jumbo residential mortgage loans (loans over the maximum that one of the government-sponsored agencies will purchase) are originated with maturities of up to 30 years.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P28_S3	The Bank has offered adjustable-rate mortgage loans with a fixed-rate period of 1, 3, 5, 7 or 10 years prior to the first annual interest rate adjustment.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P28_S4	In October 2009, the Bank discontinued the origination of one- and three-year adjustable rate mortgage loans.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P29_S0	The standard adjustment formula is the one-year constant maturity Treasury rate plus 2 3 / 4 %, adjusting annually after its first re-set period, with a 2% maximum annual adjustment and a 6% maximum adjustment over the life of the loan.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P30_S0	Residential mortgage loans are primarily underwritten to Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae standards.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P30_S1	The Bank s standard maximum loan to value ratio is 80%.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P30_S2	However, working through mortgage insurance companies, the Bank underwrites loans for sale to Freddie Mac or Fannie Mae programs that will finance up to 95% of the value of the residence.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P30_S3	Generally all fixed-rate loans with terms of 20 years or more are sold into the secondary market with servicing rights retained.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P30_S4	Fixed-rate residential mortgage loans retained in the Bank s portfolio generally include loans with a term of 15 years or less and biweekly payment residential mortgage loans with a term of 30 years or less.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P30_S5	The Bank retains the majority of the originated adjustable-rate mortgages for its portfolio.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P30_S6	Loans are sold without recourse, generally with servicing rights retained by the Bank.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P30_S7	The percentage of loans sold into the secondary market will vary depending upon interest rates and the Bank s strategies for reducing exposure to interest rate risk.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P30_S8	In 2014 , $12.6 million or 16.7% of residential real estate loans originated were sold into the secondary market.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P30_S9	All of the loans sold in 2014 were long-term, fixed-rate mortgages.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P30_S10	The retention of adjustable-rate mortgages, as opposed to longer-term, fixed-rate residential mortgage loans, helps reduce the Bank s exposure to interest rate risk.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P30_S11	However, adjustable-rate mortgages generally pose credit risks different from the credit risks inherent in fixed-rate loans primarily because as interest rates rise, the underlying debt service payments of the borrowers rise, thereby increasing the potential for default.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P30_S12	The Bank believes that these credit risks, which have not had a material adverse effect on the Bank to date, generally are less onerous than the interest rate risk associated with holding 20- and 30-year fixed-rate loans in its loan portfolio.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P31_S0	For many years, the Bank has offered discounted rates on residential mortgage loans to low- to moderate-income individuals.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P31_S1	Loans originated in this category over the last five years have totaled $31.9 million.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P31_S2	The Bank also offers a special rate program for first-time homebuyers under which originations have totaled over $4.9 million for the past five years.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P31_S3	The Bank does not originate or purchase sub-prime or option ARM loans.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P32_S0	The Bank originates loans secured by mortgages on various commercial income producing properties, including multi-family apartment buildings, office buildings and retail and industrial properties.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P33_S0	loans were 28.2 % of the loan portfolio at December 31, 2014 .
1178970_15_ITEM1_P33_S1	A substantial majority of the Bank s commercial real estate loans are secured by properties located in the State of New Jersey.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P34_S0	The Bank originates commercial real estate loans with adjustable rates and with fixed interest rates for a period that is generally five to ten years or less, which may adjust after the initial period.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P34_S1	Typically these loans are written for maturities of ten years or less and generally have an amortization schedule of 20 or 25 years.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P34_S2	As a result, the typical amortization schedule will result in a substantial principal payment upon maturity.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P35_S0	The Bank generally underwrites commercial real estate loans to a maximum 75% advance against either the appraised value of the property, or its purchase price (for loans to fund the acquisition of real estate), whichever is less.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P35_S1	The Bank generally requires minimum debt service coverage of 1.20 times.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P35_S2	There is a potential risk that the borrower may be unable to pay off or refinance the outstanding balance at the loan maturity date.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P36_S0	The Bank typically lends to experienced owners or developers who have knowledge and contacts in the commercial real estate market.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P36_S1	Among the reasons for the Bank s continued emphasis on commercial real estate lending is the desire to invest in assets bearing interest rates that are generally higher than interest rates on residential mortgage loans and more sensitive to changes in market interest rates.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P36_S2	Commercial real estate loans, however, entail significant additional credit risk as compared to one- to four-family residential mortgage loans, as they typically involve larger loan balances concentrated with single borrowers or groups of related borrowers.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P36_S3	In addition, the payment experience on commercial real estate loans secured by income-producing properties is typically dependent on the successful operation of the related real estate project and thus may be more significantly impacted by adverse conditions in the real estate market or in the economy generally.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P36_S4	The Bank performs more extensive due diligence in underwriting commercial real estate loans than loans secured by owner-occupied one- to four-family residential properties due to the larger loan amounts and the riskier nature of such loans.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P36_S5	The Bank assesses and mitigates the risk in several ways, including inspection of all such properties and the review of the overall financial condition of the borrower and guarantors, which may include, for example, the review of the rent rolls and the verification of income.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P36_S6	If applicable, a tenant analysis and market analysis are part of the underwriting.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P37_S0	Generally, for commercial real estate secured loans in excess of $1.0 million and for all other commercial real estate loans where it is deemed appropriate, the Bank requires environmental experts to inspect the property and ascertain any potential environmental risks.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P38_S0	The Bank requires a full independent appraisal for commercial real estate in accordance with regulatory guidelines.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P38_S1	The appraiser must be selected from the Bank s approved list, or otherwise approved by the Chief Credit Officer in instances such as out-of-state or special use property.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P38_S2	The Bank also employs an independent review appraiser to ensure that the appraisal meets the Bank s standards.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P38_S3	In addition, financial statements are required annually for review.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P38_S4	The Bank s policy also requires that a property inspection of commercial mortgages over $2.5 million be completed at least every 18 months, or more frequently when warranted.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P39_S0	The Bank s largest commercial mortgage loan as of December 31, 2014 was a $27.9 million loan secured by a first mortgage lien on a 378 room, full service hotel and a 422 car parking garage located in Elizabeth, New Jersey.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P39_S1	The loan has a risk rating of 4 (loans rated 1-4 are deemed to be acceptable quality see discussion of the Bank s nine-point risk rating system for loans under Allowance for Loan Losses in the Asset Quality section) and was performing in accordance with its terms and conditions as of December 31, 2014 .
1178970_15_ITEM1_P40_S0	The Bank underwrites loans secured by apartment buildings that have five or more units.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P40_S1	The Bank considers multi-family lending a component of the commercial real estate lending portfolio.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P40_S2	The underwriting standards and procedures that are used to underwrite commercial real estate loans are used to underwrite multi-family loans, except the loan-to-value ratio shall not exceed 80% of the appraised value of the property, the debt-service coverage should be a minimum of 1.15 times and an amortization period of up to 30 years may be used.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P41_S0	The Bank s largest multi-family loan as of December 31, 2014 was a $39.8 million loan secured by a first mortgage lien on a newly constructed 250-unit luxury multi-family apartment project located in Woolwich Township, Gloucester County, New Jersey.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P42_S0	The project sponsors have extensive experience and a successful track record in the development and management of multi-family projects.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P43_S0	The loan has a risk rating of 2 (loans rated 1-4 are deemed to be acceptable quality see discussion of the Bank s nine-point risk rating system for loans under Allowance for Loan Losses in the Asset Quality section) and was performing in accordance with its terms and conditions as of December 31, 2014 .
1178970_15_ITEM1_P44_S0	The Bank originates commercial construction loans.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P44_S1	Commercial construction lending includes both new construction of residential and commercial real estate projects and the reconstruction of existing structures.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P44_S2	The Bank s commercial construction financing takes two forms: projects that are constructed for investment purposes (rental property) and projects for sale (single family/condominiums).
1178970_15_ITEM1_P45_S0	or condominiums be under contract to support construction loan advances; and requires other covenants on residential for rent projects depending on whether the project is vertical or horizontal construction.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P46_S0	The Bank underwrites construction loans for a term of three years or less.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P46_S1	The majority of the Bank s construction loans are floating-rate loans with a maximum 75% loan-to-value ratio for the completed project.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P46_S2	The Bank employs professional engineering firms to assist in the review of construction cost estimates and make site inspections to determine if the work has been completed prior to the advance of funds for the project.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P47_S0	Construction lending generally involves a greater degree of risk than commercial real estate or multi-family lending.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P48_S0	Repayment of a construction loan is, to a great degree, dependent upon the successful and timely completion of the construction of the subject project and the successful marketing of the sale or lease of the project.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P48_S1	Construction delays, slower than anticipated absorption or the financial impairment of the builder may negatively affect the borrower s ability to repay the loan.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P49_S0	For all construction loans, the Bank requires an independent appraisal, which includes information on market rents and/or comparable sales for competing projects.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P49_S1	The Bank also obtains personal guarantees and conducts environmental due diligence as appropriate.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P50_S0	The Bank also employs other means to mitigate the risk of the construction lending process.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P51_S0	On commercial construction projects that the developer maintains for rental, the Bank typically holds back funds for tenant improvements until a lease is executed.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P51_S1	For single family and condominium financing, the Bank generally requires payment for the release of a unit that exceeds the amount of the loan advance attributable to such unit.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P51_S2	The Bank s largest construction loan at December 31, 2014 was a $55.0 million loan secured by a first lien on a 244,450 square foot multi-tenanted retail shopping center project that is under construction in Clark, Union County, New Jersey.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P51_S3	The loan had an outstanding balance of $22.1 million at December 31, 2014 .
1178970_15_ITEM1_P51_S4	Construction of the project is approximately 48% complete.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P52_S0	The loan has a risk rating of 3 (loans rated 1-4 are deemed to be acceptable quality -see discussion of the Bank s nine-point risk rating system for loans under Allowance for Loan Losses in the Asset Quality section) and was performing in accordance with its terms and conditions as of December 31, 2014 .
1178970_15_ITEM1_P52_S1	The Bank sold a 50% participation interest in the construction loan to another financial institution, which reduced the Bank s committed exposure and outstanding balance to $27.5 million and $11.1 million, respectively.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P53_S0	The Bank underwrites commercial loans to corporations, partnerships and other businesses.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P53_S1	Commercial loans represented 21.0 % of the loan portfolio at December 31, 2014 .
1178970_15_ITEM1_P53_S2	The majority of the Bank s commercial loan customers are local businesses with revenues of less than $50.0 million.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P53_S3	The Bank primarily offers commercial loans for equipment purchases, lines of credit for working capital purposes, letters of credit and real estate loans where the borrower is the primary occupant of the property.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P53_S4	Most commercial loans are originated on a floating-rate basis and the majority of fixed-rate commercial term loans are fully amortized over a five-year period.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P53_S5	Owner-occupied commercial real estate loans are generally underwritten to terms consistent with those utilized for commercial real estate; however, the maximum loan-to-value ratio for owner-occupied commercial real estate loans is 80%.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P53_S6	The Bank also underwrites Small Business Administration ( SBA ) guaranteed loans and guaranteed or assisted loans through various state, county and municipal programs.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P53_S7	These governmental guarantees are typically used in cases where the borrower requires additional credit support.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P53_S8	The Bank has Preferred Lender status with the SBA, allowing a more streamlined application and approval process.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P54_S0	The underwriting of a commercial loan is based upon a review of the financial statements of the prospective borrower and guarantors.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P54_S1	In most cases the Bank obtains a general lien on accounts receivable and inventory, along with the specific collateral such as real estate or equipment, as appropriate.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P55_S0	Commercial loans generally bear higher interest rates than mortgage loans, but they also involve a higher risk of default since their repayment is generally dependent on the cash flow of the borrower s business.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P55_S1	As a result, the availability of funds for the repayment of commercial loans may be substantially dependent on the success of the business itself and the general economic environment.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P55_S2	The Bank s largest commercial loan as of December 31, 2014 was a $38.0 million line of credit to a general contracting company specializing in bridge and highway construction with a risk rating of "3" (loans rated 1-4 are deemed acceptable quality -see discussion of the Bank s nine-point risk rating system for loans under Allowance for Loan Losses in the Asset Quality section).
1178970_15_ITEM1_P55_S3	The line is used primarily for bid bonding and working capital purposes.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P55_S4	The Bank sold a participation interest of $10.0 million in the line of credit to another financial institution, which reduced the Bank s exposure to $28.0 million.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P55_S5	As of December 31, 2014 , the line of credit did not have an outstanding balance.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P56_S0	The Bank offers a variety of consumer loans to individuals.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P56_S1	Consumer loans represented 10.2 % of the loan portfolio at December 31, 2014 .
1178970_15_ITEM1_P57_S0	portfolio and indirect marine loans constituted 4.4% of the consumer loan portfolio as of December 31, 2014 .
1178970_15_ITEM1_P57_S1	The remainder of the consumer loan portfolio includes personal loans and unsecured lines of credit, direct auto loans and recreational vehicle loans, which represented 4.3% of the consumer loan portfolio.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P57_S2	The Bank no longer purchases indirect auto, marine or recreational vehicle loans.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P58_S0	Interest rates on home equity loans are fixed for a term not to exceed 20 years and the maximum loan amount is $500,000.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P59_S0	A portion of the home equity loan portfolio includes first lien product loans, under which the Bank has offered special rates to borrowers who refinance first mortgage loans on the home equity (first lien) basis.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P59_S1	As of December 31, 2014 , there was $291.9 million of first-lien home equity loans outstanding.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P59_S2	The Bank s home equity lines are made at floating interest rates and the Bank provides lines of credit of up to $350,000.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P59_S3	The approved home equity lines and utilization amounts as of December 31, 2014 were $529.1 million and $225.5 million, respectively, representing utilization of 42.6%.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P60_S0	Consumer loans generally entail greater credit risk than residential mortgage loans, particularly in the case of home equity loans and lines of credit secured by second lien positions, consumer loans that are unsecured or that are secured by assets that tend to depreciate, such as automobiles, boats and recreational vehicles.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P60_S1	Collateral repossessed by the Bank from a defaulted consumer loan may not provide an adequate source of repayment of the outstanding loan balance, and the remaining deficiency may warrant further substantial collection efforts against the borrower.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P60_S2	In addition, consumer loan collections are dependent upon the borrower s continued financial stability, and which is more likely to be adversely affected by job loss, divorce, illness or personal bankruptcy.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P60_S3	Furthermore, the application of various federal and state laws, including bankruptcy and insolvency laws, may limit the amount the Bank can recover on such loans.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P60_S4	The following table sets forth the Bank s loan origination, purchase and repayment activities for the periods indicated.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P61_S0	(1) Other items, net include charge-offs, deferred fees and expenses, discounts and premiums.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P61_S1	The Bank s Board of Directors approves the Lending Policy on an annual basis as well as on an interim basis as modifications are warranted.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P61_S2	The Lending Policy sets the Bank s lending authority for each type of loan.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P61_S3	The Bank s lending officers are assigned dollar authority limits based upon their experience and expertise.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P61_S4	All loan approvals require joint lending authority.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P61_S5	The largest individual lending authority is $10.0 million, which is only available to the Chief Executive Officer and Chief Lending Officer.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P61_S6	The authority of the Chief Lending Officer may be increased to $15.0 million for permanent commercial real estate loans when combined with the additional approval of the Chief Credit Officer.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P61_S7	Loans in excess of these limits, or which when combined with existing credits of the borrower or related borrowers exceed these limits, are presented to the management Credit Committee for approval.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P61_S8	The Credit Committee currently consists of eight senior officers including the Chief Executive Officer, the Chief Lending Officer, the Chief Financial Officer and the Chief Credit Officer, and requires a majority vote for credit approval.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P62_S0	While the Bank discourages loan policy exceptions, from time to time, based upon reasonable business considerations exceptions to the policy may be warranted.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P62_S1	The business reason and mitigants for the exception must be noted on the loan approval document.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P63_S0	The policy exception requires the approval of the Chief Lending Officer or the Department Manager of the lending department responsible for the underlying loan, if it is within his or her approval authority limit.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P63_S1	All other policy exceptions must be approved by the Credit Committee.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P63_S2	The Credit Administration Department reports the type and frequency of loan policy exceptions to the Credit Committee and the Risk Committee of the Board of Directors on a quarterly basis, or more frequently if necessary.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P64_S0	The Bank has adopted a risk rating system as part of the credit risk assessment of its loan portfolio.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P64_S1	The Bank s commercial real estate and commercial lending officers are required to assign a risk rating to each loan in their portfolio at origination.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P64_S2	When the lender learns of important financial developments, the risk rating is reviewed accordingly.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P64_S3	Risk ratings are subject to review by the Credit Administration Department.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P64_S4	Similarly, the Credit Committee can adjust a risk rating.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P64_S5	Quarterly, management s Credit Risk Management Committee meets to review all loans rated a watch ("5") or worse.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P64_S6	In addition, a loan review examination is performed by an independent third party which validates the risk ratings.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P64_S7	In addition, the Bank requires an annual review be performed for commercial and commercial real estate loans above certain dollar thresholds, depending on loan type, to help determine the appropriate risk ratings.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P64_S8	The risk ratings play an important role in the establishment of the loan loss provision and to confirm the adequacy of the allowance for loan losses.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P65_S0	The regulatory limit on total loans to any borrower or attributed to any one borrower is 15% of the Bank s unimpaired capital and surplus.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P65_S1	As of December 31, 2014 , the regulatory lending limit was $110.4 million.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P65_S2	The Bank s current internal policy limit on total loans to a borrower or related borrowers that constitute a group exposure is up to $80.0 million for loans with a risk rating of "2 " or better, up to $70.0 million for loans with a risk rating of "3" and up to $50.0 million for loans with a risk rating of "4".
1178970_15_ITEM1_P65_S3	Maximum group exposure limits may be lower depending on the type of loans involved.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P65_S4	The Bank reviews these group exposures on a quarterly basis.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P65_S5	The Bank also sets additional limits on size of loans by loan type.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P65_S6	At December 31, 2014 , the Bank s largest group exposure with an individual borrower and its related entities was $71.3 million, consisting of two commercial permanent mortgage loans totaling $39.8 million on a 250-unit apartment project in Woolwich Township, Gloucester County, New Jersey with risk ratings of "2", a construction mortgage loan of $22.0 million secured by a first lien on a newly-constructed 204-unit apartment project in Monroe Township, Gloucester County, New Jersey with a risk rating of "3", a line of credit of $7.5 million ($1.9 million outstanding) secured by a 108-unit apartment project in Allentown, Pennsylvania with a risk rating of 2 , and a line of credit of $2.0 million ($1.3 million outstanding) with a risk rating of 3 .
1178970_15_ITEM1_P66_S0	The borrower, headquartered in New Jersey, is an experienced real estate owner and developer in New Jersey and eastern Pennsylvania.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P66_S1	Management has determined that this exception to the internal group exposure policy limit is manageable and is mitigated by the borrower s diverse revenue mix, as well as its reputation and proven successful track record.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P66_S2	This lending relationship was approved as an exception to the internal policy limits by the management Credit Committee and reported to the Risk Committee of the Board of Directors, and conformed to the regulatory limit applicable to the Bank at the time of loan origination.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P66_S3	As of December 31, 2014 , all of the loans in this lending relationship were performing in accordance with their respective terms and conditions.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P66_S4	As of December 31, 2014 , the Bank had $1.8 billion in loans outstanding to its 50 largest borrowers and their related entities.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P67_S0	One of the Bank s key objectives has been and continues to be to maintain a high level of asset quality.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P67_S1	In addition to maintaining sound credit standards for new loan originations, the Bank employs proactive collection and workout processes in dealing with delinquent or problem loans.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P68_S0	The Bank actively markets properties that it acquires through foreclosure or otherwise in the loan collection process.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P69_S0	In the case of residential mortgage and consumer loans, the collections personnel in the Bank s Asset Recovery Department are responsible for collection activities from the sixteenth day of delinquency.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P69_S1	Collection efforts include automated notices of delinquency, telephone calls, letters and other notices to delinquent borrowers.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P69_S2	Foreclosure proceedings and other appropriate collection activities such as repossession of collateral are commenced within at least 90 to 120 days after a loan is delinquent provided a plan of repayment to cure the delinquency cannot be reached with the borrower.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P69_S3	Periodic inspections of real estate and other collateral are conducted throughout the collection process.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P70_S0	The Bank s collection procedures for Federal Housing Association ( FHA ) and Veteran s Administration ( VA ) one- to four-family mortgage loans follow the collection guidelines outlined by those agencies.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P71_S0	Real estate and other assets acquired through foreclosure or in connection with a loan workout are held as foreclosed assets.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P71_S1	The Bank carries other real estate owned and other foreclosed assets at the lower of their cost or their fair value less estimated selling costs.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P71_S2	The Bank attempts to sell the property at foreclosure sale or as soon as practical after the foreclosure sale through a proactive marketing effort.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P72_S0	The collection procedures for commercial real estate and commercial loans include sending periodic late notices and letters to a borrower once a loan is past due.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P72_S1	The Bank attempts to make direct contact with a borrower once a loan is 16 days past due, usually by telephone.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P73_S0	The Chief Lending Officer and Chief Credit Officer review all commercial real estate and commercial loan delinquencies on a weekly basis.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P73_S1	Generally, delinquent commercial real estate and commercial loans are transferred to the Asset Recovery Department for further action if the delinquency is not cured within a reasonable period of time, typically 90 days.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P73_S2	The Chief Lending Officer and Chief Credit Officer have the authority to transfer performing commercial real estate or commercial loans to the Asset Recovery Department if, in their opinion, a credit problem exists or is likely to occur.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P73_S3	Loans deemed uncollectible are proposed for charge-off on a monthly basis.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P73_S4	Any charge-off recommendation of $500,000 or greater is submitted to Executive Management for approval.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P74_S0	Delinquent Loans and Non-performing Loans and Assets.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P74_S1	The Bank s policies require that the Chief Credit Officer continuously monitor the status of the loan portfolios and report to the Board of Directors on a monthly basis.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P74_S2	These reports include information on impaired loans, delinquent loans, criticized and classified assets, and foreclosed assets.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P75_S0	An impaired loan is defined as a non-homogenous loan greater than $1.0 million for which it is probable, based on current information, that the Bank will not collect all amounts due under the contractual terms of the loan agreement.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P75_S1	Impaired loans also include all loans modified as troubled debt restructurings ( TDRs ).
1178970_15_ITEM1_P75_S2	A loan is deemed to be a TDR when a modification resulting in a concession is made by the Bank in an effort to mitigate potential loss arising from a borrower s financial difficulty.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P75_S3	Smaller balance homogeneous loans including residential mortgages and other consumer loans are evaluated collectively for impairment and are excluded from the definition of impaired loans, except for TDRs.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P76_S0	Impaired loans are individually identified and reviewed to determine that each loan s carrying value is not in excess of the fair value of the related collateral or the present value of the expected future cash flows.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P76_S1	As of December 31, 2014 , there were 147 impaired loans totaling $85.4 million, of which 143 loans totaling $81.7 million were TDRs.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P76_S2	Included in this total were 123 TDRs to 120 borrowers totaling $54.8 million that were performing in accordance with their restructured terms and which continued to accrue interest at December 31, 2014 .
1178970_15_ITEM1_P77_S0	Interest income stops accruing on loans when interest or principal payments are 90 days in arrears or earlier when the timely collectability of such interest or principal is doubtful.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P77_S1	When the accrual of interest on a loan is stopped, the loan is designated as a non-accrual loan and the outstanding unpaid interest previously credited is reversed.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P77_S2	A non-accrual loan is returned to accrual status when factors indicating doubtful collection no longer exist, the loan has been brought current and the borrower demonstrates some period (generally six months) of timely contractual payments.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P78_S0	Federal and state regulations as well as the Bank s policy require the Bank to utilize an internal risk rating system as a means of reporting problem and potential problem assets.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P78_S1	Under this system, the Bank classifies problem and potential problem assets as substandard, doubtful or loss assets.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P78_S2	An asset is considered substandard if it is inadequately protected by the current net worth and paying capacity of the obligor or of the collateral pledged, if any.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P78_S3	Substandard assets include those characterized by the distinct possibility that the Bank will sustain some loss if the deficiencies are not corrected.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P78_S4	Assets classified as doubtful have all of the weaknesses inherent in those classified substandard with the added characteristic that the weaknesses present make collection or liquidation in full, on the basis of currently existing facts, conditions, and values, highly questionable and improbable.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P79_S0	Assets classified as loss are those considered uncollectible and of such little value that their continuance as assets without the establishment of a specific loss reserve is not warranted.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P79_S1	Assets which do not currently expose the Bank to sufficient risk to warrant classification in one of the aforementioned categories, but possess weaknesses, are designated special mention.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P80_S0	General valuation allowances represent loss allowances which have been established to recognize the inherent risk associated with lending activities, but which, unlike specific allowances, have not been allocated to particular problem assets.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P81_S0	for loan losses in an amount deemed prudent by management.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P82_S0	When the Bank classifies one or more assets, or portions thereof, as loss, the Bank is required either to establish a specific allowance for losses equal to 100% of the amount of the asset so classified or to charge-off such amount.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P82_S1	The Bank s determination as to the classification of assets and the amount of the valuation allowances is subject to review by the FDIC and the New Jersey Department of Banking and Insurance, each of which can require the establishment of additional general or specific loss allowances.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P83_S0	The FDIC, in conjunction with the other federal banking agencies, issued an interagency policy statement on the allowance for loan and lease losses.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P83_S1	The policy statement provides guidance for financial institutions on both the responsibilities of the board of directors and management for the maintenance of adequate allowances, and guidance for banking agency examiners to use in determining the adequacy of general valuation allowances.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P83_S2	Generally, the policy statement reaffirms that institutions should have effective loan review systems and controls to identify, monitor and address asset quality problems; that loans deemed uncollectible are promptly charged off; and that the institution s process for determining an adequate level for its valuation allowance is based on a comprehensive, adequately documented, and consistently applied analysis of the institution s loan and lease portfolio.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P83_S3	While management believes that on the basis of information currently available to it, the allowance for loans losses is adequate as of December 31, 2014 , actual losses are dependent upon future events and, as such, further additions to the level of allowances for loan losses may become necessary.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P84_S0	Loans are classified in accordance with the risk rating system described previously.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P84_S1	At December 31, 2014 , $ 110.4 million of loans were classified as substandard, which consisted of $ 53.8 million in commercial and multi-family mortgage loans, $ 32.8 million in commercial loans, $ 17.2 million in residential loans, $ 2.6 million in construction loans and $ 3.9 million in consumer loans.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P84_S2	At that same date, loans classified as doubtful totaled $ 1.1 million, consisting of $1.1 million of commercial mortgage loans and $29,000 of commercial loans.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P84_S3	There were no loans classified as loss at December 31, 2014 .
1178970_15_ITEM1_P84_S4	As of December 31, 2014 , $ 71.7 million of loans were designated special mention.

1178970_15_ITEM1_P87_S0	Loans are generally placed on non-accrual status when they become 90 days or more past due or if they have been identified as presenting uncertainty with respect to the collectability of interest or principal.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P88_S0	Non-performing commercial loans decreased $ 9.9 million, to $ 12.3 million at December 31, 2014 , from $ 22.2 million at December 31, 2013 .
1178970_15_ITEM1_P88_S1	Non-performing commercial loans at December 31, 2014 consisted of 24 loans.

1178970_15_ITEM1_P88_S3	Contractual payments on four of these loans, based upon modified terms, were current at December 31, 2014 .

1178970_15_ITEM1_P88_S10	At December 31, 2014 , the Company held 16 non-performing commercial mortgage loans.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P88_S11	The largest non-performing commercial mortgage loan was a $12.3 million loan secured by a first mortgage on a 200,000 square foot office/industrial building located in Eatontown, New Jersey, which had been negatively impacted by the loss of a major tenant that relied upon contracts with the Federal government.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P88_S12	The loan was previously restructured and matured on June 1, 2014.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P88_S13	The loan maturity was not extended and the loan is presently in default.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P88_S14	There is no contractual commitment to advance additional funds to this borrower.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P88_S15	At December 31, 2014 , the Company held $ 5.1 million of foreclosed assets, compared with $ 5.5 million at December 31, 2013 .
1178970_15_ITEM1_P88_S16	Foreclosed assets at December 31, 2014 are carried at fair value based on recent appraisals and valuation estimates, less estimated selling costs.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P88_S17	Foreclosed assets consisted of $2.7 million of commercial real estate, $2.3 million of residential properties, and $60,000 of marine vessels at December 31, 2014 .
1178970_15_ITEM1_P88_S18	Non-performing assets totaled $ 59.0 million, or 0.69 % of total assets at December 31, 2014 , compared to $ 82.2 million, or 1.10 % of total assets at December 31, 2013 .
1178970_15_ITEM1_P88_S19	If the non-accrual loans had performed in accordance with their original terms, interest income would have increased by $1.9 million during the year ended December 31, 2014 .
1178970_15_ITEM1_P89_S0	The amount of cash basis interest income that was recognized on impaired loans during the year ended December 31, 2014 was not material.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P90_S0	The allowance for loan losses is a valuation account that reflects an evaluation of the probable losses in the loan portfolio.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P90_S1	The allowance for loan losses is maintained through provisions for loan losses that are charged to income.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P90_S2	Charge-offs against the allowance for loan losses are taken on loans where it is determined the collection of loan principal is unlikely.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P90_S3	Recoveries made on loans that have been charged-off are credited to the allowance for loan losses.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P91_S0	Management s evaluation of the adequacy of the allowance for loan losses includes the review of all loans on which the collectability of principal may not be reasonably assured.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P92_S0	For residential mortgage and consumer loans, this is determined primarily by delinquency and collateral values.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P92_S1	For commercial real estate and commercial loans, an extensive review of financial performance, payment history and collateral values is conducted on a quarterly basis.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P93_S0	As part of the evaluation of the adequacy of the allowance for loan losses, each quarter management prepares an analysis that categorizes the entire loan portfolio by certain risk characteristics such as loan type (residential mortgage, commercial mortgage, construction, commercial, etc.) and loan risk rating.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P93_S1	The factors considered in assessing the adequacy of the allowance for loan losses include the following:
1178970_15_ITEM1_P94_S0	duration of the current business cycle.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P95_S0	When assigning a risk rating to a loan, management utilizes the Bank s internal nine-point risk rating system.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P95_S1	Loans deemed to be acceptable quality are rated 1 through 4, with a rating of 1 established for loans with minimal risk.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P95_S2	Loans that are deemed to be of questionable quality are rated 5 (watch) or 6 (special mention).
1178970_15_ITEM1_P95_S3	Loans with adverse classifications (substandard, doubtful or loss) are rated 7, 8 or 9, respectively.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P95_S4	Commercial mortgage, commercial, multi-family and construction loans are rated individually, and each lending officer is responsible for risk rating loans in his or her portfolio.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P95_S5	These risk ratings are then reviewed by the department manager and/or the Chief Lending Officer and by the Credit Administration Department.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P95_S6	The risk ratings for loans requiring Credit Committee approval are periodically reviewed by the Credit Committee in the credit approval or renewal process.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P95_S7	The risk ratings are also confirmed through periodic loan review examinations, which are currently performed by an independent third party.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P95_S8	Reports by the independent third party are presented directly to the Audit and Risk Committees of the Board of Directors.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P96_S0	Each quarter, the lending groups prepare individual Credit Risk Management Reports for the Credit Administration Department.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P96_S1	These reports review all commercial loans and commercial mortgage loans that have been determined to involve above-average risk (risk rating of 5 or worse).
1178970_15_ITEM1_P96_S2	The Credit Risk Management Reports contain the reason for the risk rating assigned to each loan, status of the loan and any current developments.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P96_S3	These reports are submitted to a committee chaired by the Chief Credit Officer.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P96_S4	Each loan officer reviews the loan and the corresponding Credit Risk Management Report with the committee and the risk rating is evaluated for appropriateness.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P96_S5	Management assigns general valuation allowance ( GVA ) percentages to each risk rating category for use in allocating the allowance for loan losses, giving consideration to historical loss experience by loan type, as well as qualitative and environmental factors such as:
1178970_15_ITEM1_P97_S0	The appropriateness of these percentages is evaluated by management at least annually and monitored on a quarterly basis, with changes made when they are required.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P97_S1	In the second quarter of 2014, management completed its most recent evaluation of the GVA percentages.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P97_S2	As a result of that evaluation, certain GVA percentages applied to residential mortgage, commercial, multi-family and commercial mortgage loans were reduced to reflect the decrease in the historical loss experience and improvements in qualitative factors.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P97_S3	In addition, GVA percentages for marine loans were increased due to historical loss experience.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P97_S4	During the fourth quarter of 2014, management made certain changes and enhancements to its process and controls over measuring the GVA portion of the allowance for loan losses.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P97_S5	In connection with its periodic risk assessment and monitoring process, the Company re-evaluated a number of assumptions supporting the methodology including the look-back period used to evaluate the historical loss factors for its portfolios, as well as performing a study of its loss emergence period ("LEP") data.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P97_S6	As a result of this review, management updated a number of assumptions, including lengthening its LEP given continued improvements in market conditions.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P97_S7	Given these changes to the quantitative methodology, management reassessed its qualitative and environmental factors to align with the revised model assumptions.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P97_S8	The result of these changes was to allocate a greater portion of the allowance to the quantitative component of the GVA and less to the qualitative component.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P97_S9	The changes had no impact on the overall allowance.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P98_S0	The reserve factors applied to each loan risk rating are inherently subjective in nature.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P99_S0	Reserve factors are assigned to each of the risk rating categories.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P99_S1	This methodology permits adjustments to the allowance for loan losses in the event that, in management s judgment, significant conditions impacting the credit quality and collectability of the loan portfolio as of the evaluation date are not otherwise adequately reflected in the analysis.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P99_S2	The provision for loan losses is established after considering the allowance for loan loss analysis, the amount of the allowance for loan losses in relation to the total loan balance, loan portfolio growth, loan portfolio composition, loan delinquency trends and peer group analysis.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P99_S3	As a result of this process, management has established an unallocated portion of the allowance for loan losses.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P99_S4	The unallocated portion of the allowance for loan losses is warranted based on factors such as the geographic concentration of the loan portfolio, current economic conditions and imprecision related to collateral valuations.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P100_S0	Management believes the primary risks inherent in the portfolio are a decline in the economy, generally, a decline in real estate market values, rising unemployment or a protracted period of unemployment at elevated levels, increasing vacancy rates in commercial investment properties and possible increases in interest rates in the absence of economic improvement.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P100_S1	Any one or a combination of these events may adversely affect borrowers ability to repay the loans, resulting in increased delinquencies, loan losses and future levels of provisions.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P100_S2	Accordingly, the Company has provided for loan losses at the current level to address the current risk in its loan portfolio.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P100_S3	Management considers it important to maintain the ratio of the allowance for loan losses to total loans at an acceptable level given current economic conditions, interest rates and the composition of the portfolio.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P100_S4	Management will continue to review the entire loan portfolio to determine the extent, if any, to which further additional loan loss provisions may be deemed necessary.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P100_S5	The allowance for loan losses is maintained at a level that represents management s best estimate of probable losses related to specifically identified loans as well as probable losses inherent in the remaining loan portfolio.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P100_S6	There can be no assurance that the allowance for loan losses will be adequate to cover all losses that may in fact be realized in the future or that additional provisions for loan losses will not be required.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P101_S0	Analysis of the Allowance for Loan Losses.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P101_S1	The following table sets forth the analysis of the allowance for loan losses for the periods indicated.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P102_S0	Allocation of Allowance for Loan Losses.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P102_S1	The following table sets forth the allocation of the allowance for loan losses by loan category for the periods indicated.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P102_S2	This allocation is based on management s assessment, as of a given point in time, of the risk characteristics of each of the component parts of the total loan portfolio and is subject to changes as and when the risk factors of each such component part change.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P102_S3	The allocation is neither indicative of the specific amounts or the loan categories in which future charge-offs may be taken, nor is it an indicator of future loss trends.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P102_S4	The allocation of the allowance to each category does not restrict the use of the allowance to absorb losses in any category.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P103_S0	The Board of Directors annually approves the Investment Policy for the Bank and the Company.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P103_S1	The Chief Financial Officer and the Treasurer are authorized by the Board to implement the Investment Policy and establish investment strategies.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P103_S2	The Chief Executive Officer, Chief Financial Officer, Treasurer and Assistant Treasurer are authorized to make investment decisions consistent with the Investment Policy.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P103_S3	Investment transactions for the Bank are reported to the Board of Directors of the Bank on a monthly basis.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P103_S4	The Investment Policy is designed to generate a favorable rate of return, consistent with established guidelines for liquidity, safety, duration and diversification, and to complement the lending activities of the Bank.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P103_S5	Investment decisions are made in accordance with the policy and are based on credit quality, interest rate risk, balance sheet composition, market expectations, liquidity, income and collateral needs.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P103_S6	The Investment Policy does not currently permit the purchase of any securities that are below investment grade.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P103_S7	The investment strategy is to maximize the return on the investment portfolio consistent with the Investment Policy.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P103_S8	The investment strategy considers the Bank s and the Company s interest rate risk position as well as liquidity, loan demand and other factors.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P103_S9	Acceptable investment securities include U.S. Treasury and Agency obligations, collateralized mortgage obligations ( CMOs ), corporate debt obligations, municipal bonds, mortgage-backed securities, commercial paper, mutual funds, bankers acceptances and Federal funds.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P103_S10	Securities purchased for the investment portfolio require a minimum credit rating of A by Moody s or Standard Poor s at the time of purchase.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P104_S0	Securities in the investment portfolio are classified as held to maturity, available for sale or held for trading.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P104_S1	Securities that are classified as held to maturity are securities that the Bank or the Company has the intent and ability to hold until their contractual maturity date and are reported at cost.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P104_S2	Securities that are classified as available for sale are reported at fair value.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P104_S3	Available for sale securities include U.S. Treasury and Agency obligations, U.S. Agency and privately-issued CMOs, corporate debt obligations and equities.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P104_S4	Sales of securities may occur from time to time in response to changes in market rates and liquidity needs and to facilitate balance sheet reallocation to effectively manage interest rate risk.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P105_S0	At the present time, there are no securities that are classified as held for trading.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P105_S1	Management conducts a periodic review and evaluation of the securities portfolio to determine if any securities with a market value below book value were other-than-temporarily impaired.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P105_S2	If such an impairment were deemed other-than-temporary, management would measure the total credit-related component of the unrealized loss, and the Company would recognize that portion of the loss as a charge to current period earnings.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P105_S3	The remaining portion of the unrealized loss would be recognized as an adjustment to accumulated other comprehensive income.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P106_S0	The fair value of the securities portfolio is significantly affected by changes in interest rates.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P107_S0	the fair value of fixed-rate securities increases.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P107_S1	The market for non-investment grade, privately issued mortgage-backed securities remains illiquid and prices have not appreciated despite favorable movements in interest rates.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P107_S2	The Company evaluates if it has the intent to sell these securities and if it is more likely than not that the Company would be required to sell the securities before the anticipated recovery.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P108_S0	CMOs are a type of debt security issued by a special-purpose entity that aggregates pools of mortgages and mortgage-related securities and creates different classes of CMO securities with varying maturities and amortization schedules as well as a residual interest with each class possessing different risk characteristics.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P108_S1	In contrast to pass-through mortgage-backed securities from which cash flow is received (and prepayment risk is shared) pro rata by all securities holders, the cash flow from the mortgages or mortgage-related securities underlying CMOs is paid in accordance with predetermined priority to investors holding various tranches of such securities or obligations.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P108_S2	A particular tranche of CMOs may therefore carry prepayment risk that differs from that of both the underlying collateral and other tranches.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P108_S3	Accordingly, CMOs attempt to moderate risks associated with conventional mortgage-related securities resulting from unexpected prepayment activity.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P108_S4	In declining interest rate environments, the Bank attempts to purchase CMOs with principal lock-out periods, reducing prepayment risk in the investment portfolio.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P108_S5	During rising interest rate periods, the Bank s strategy is to purchase CMOs that are receiving principal payments that can be reinvested at higher current yields.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P108_S6	Investments in CMOs involve a risk that actual prepayments will differ from those estimated in pricing the security, which may result in adjustments to the net yield on such securities.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P108_S7	Additionally, the fair value of such securities may be adversely affected by changes in the market interest rates.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P108_S8	Management believes these securities may represent attractive alternatives relative to other investments due to the wide variety of maturity, repayment and interest rate options available.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P108_S9	At December 31, 2014 , the Bank held $5.7 million in privately-issued CMOs in the investment portfolio.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P108_S10	The Bank and the Company do not invest in collateralized debt obligations, mortgage-related securities secured by sub-prime loans, or any preferred equity securities.

1178970_15_ITEM1_P114_S0	(1) Yields are not tax equivalent SOURCES OF FUNDS General.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P115_S0	Primary sources of funds consist of principal and interest cash flows received from loans and mortgage-backed securities, contractual maturities on investments, deposits, Federal Home Loan Bank of New York ( FHLBNY ) advances and proceeds from sales of loans and investments.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P115_S1	These sources of funds are used for lending, investing and general corporate purposes, including acquisitions and common stock repurchases.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P116_S0	The Bank offers a variety of deposits for retail and business accounts.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P116_S1	Deposit products include savings accounts, checking accounts, interest-bearing checking accounts, money market deposit accounts and certificate of deposit accounts at varying interest rates and terms.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P116_S2	The Bank also offers IRA and KEOGH accounts.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P116_S3	Business customers are offered several checking account and savings plans, cash management services, remote deposit capture services, payroll origination services, escrow account management and business credit cards.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P117_S0	The Bank focuses on relationship banking for retail and business customers to enhance the customer experience.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P118_S0	Deposit activity is influenced by state and local economic conditions, changes in interest rates, internal pricing decisions and competition.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P118_S1	Deposits are primarily obtained from the areas surrounding the Bank s branch locations.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P118_S2	To attract and retain deposits, the Bank offers competitive rates, quality customer service and a wide variety of products and services that meet customers needs, including online and mobile banking.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P118_S3	Deposit pricing strategy is monitored monthly by the management Asset/Liability Committee and Pricing Committee.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P118_S4	Deposit pricing is set weekly by the Bank s Treasury Department.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P118_S5	When setting deposit pricing, the Bank considers competitive market rates, FHLBNY advance rates and rates on other sources of funds.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P119_S0	Core deposits, defined as savings accounts, interest and non-interest bearing checking accounts and money market deposit accounts represented 85.7 % of total deposits at December 31, 2014 and 84.5 % of total deposits at December 31, 2013 .
1178970_15_ITEM1_P119_S1	As of December 31, 2014 and December 31, 2013 , time deposits maturing in less than one year amounted to $ 568.5 million and $530.0 million, respectively.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P120_S0	The following table indicates the amount of certificates of deposit by time remaining until maturity as of December 31, 2014 .
1178970_15_ITEM1_P121_S0	The following table sets forth certain information regarding certificates of deposit.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P122_S0	At December 31, 2014 , the Bank had $ 1.51 billion of borrowed funds.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P122_S1	Borrowed funds consist primarily of FHLBNY advances and repurchase agreements.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P123_S0	Repurchase agreements are contracts for the sale of securities owned or borrowed by the Bank, with an agreement to repurchase those securities at an agreed-upon price and date.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P123_S1	The Bank uses wholesale repurchase agreements, as well as retail repurchase agreements as an investment vehicle for its commercial sweep checking product.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P123_S2	Bank policies limit the use of repurchase agreements to collateral consisting of U.S. Treasury obligations, U.S. government agency obligations or mortgage-related securities.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P123_S3	As a member of the FHLBNY, the Bank is eligible to obtain advances upon the security of the FHLBNY common stock owned and certain residential mortgage loans, provided certain standards related to credit-worthiness have been met.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P123_S4	FHLBNY advances are available pursuant to several credit programs, each of which has its own interest rate and range of maturities.

1178970_15_ITEM1_P125_S0	The following table sets forth certain information as to borrowings at the dates indicated.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P126_S0	As part of the Company s strategy to increase fee related income, the Company s wholly owned subsidiary, Beacon Trust Company ( Beacon ) is engaged in providing wealth management and asset management services.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P126_S1	In addition to its trust and estate administrative services, Beacon is also a provider of asset management services which are often introduced to existing clients through the Bank s extensive branch network.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P126_S2	Beacon offers a full range of asset management services to individuals, municipalities, non-profits, corporations and pension funds.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P126_S3	These services include investment management, asset allocation, trust and fiduciary services, financial planning, family office services, estate settlement services and custody.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P127_S0	Beacon focuses on delivering personalized investment strategies based on the client s risk profile.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P127_S1	These strategies are focused on maximizing clients investment returns, while minimizing expenses.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P128_S0	Most of the fee income generated by Beacon is based on assets under management.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P129_S0	On October 31, 2014, Beacon acquired the fiduciary account relationships of a bank in Suffolk County, New York.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P129_S1	On January 5, 2015, Beacon announced the signing of a definitive agreement to acquire the assets and liabilities of The MDE Group, Inc. and the equity interests of Acertus Capital Management, LLC, both Morristown, New Jersey based registered investment advisers under common ownership.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P129_S2	The transaction is currently awaiting regulatory approval from the New Jersey Department of Banking and Insurance and the satisfaction of customary closing conditions.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P130_S0	SUBSIDIARY ACTIVITIES PFS Insurance Services, Inc., formerly Provident Investment Services, Inc., is a wholly owned subsidiary of the Bank, and a New Jersey licensed insurance producer that sells insurance and investment products, including annuities to customers through a third-party networking arrangement.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P130_S1	Dudley Investment Corporation is a wholly owned subsidiary of the Bank which operates as a New Jersey Investment Company.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P130_S2	Dudley Investment Corporation owns all of the outstanding common stock of Gregory Investment Corporation.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P130_S3	Gregory Investment Corporation is a wholly owned subsidiary of Dudley Investment Corporation.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P130_S4	Gregory Investment Corporation operates as a Delaware Investment Company.
