1178970_15_ITEM1_P130_S5	Gregory Investment Corporation owns all of the outstanding common stock of PSB Funding Corporation.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P131_S0	PSB Funding Corporation is a majority owned subsidiary of Gregory Investment Corporation.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P131_S1	It was established as a New Jersey corporation to engage in the business of a real estate investment trust for the purpose of acquiring mortgage loans and other real estate related assets from the Bank.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P132_S0	TPB Realty, LLC, is a wholly owned subsidiary of the Bank formed to invest in real estate development joint ventures principally targeted at meeting the housing needs of low- and moderate-income communities in the Bank s market.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P132_S1	At December 31, 2014 , TPB Realty, LLC had total assets of $2.9 million.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P133_S0	Bergen Avenue Realty, LLC, is a wholly owned subsidiary of the Bank formed to manage and sell real estate acquired through foreclosure.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P133_S1	At December 31, 2014 , Bergen Avenue Realty, LLC had total assets of $2.5 million.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P134_S0	Bergen Delaware Realty, LLC, is a wholly owned subsidiary of the Bank formed to manage and sell real estate acquired through foreclosure.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P134_S1	At December 31, 2014 , Bergen Delaware Realty, LLC had total assets of $500,000.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P135_S0	Beacon Trust Company, a New Jersey limited purpose trust company, is a wholly owned subsidiary of the Bank.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P135_S1	Beacon Investment Advisory Services, Inc. is a wholly owned subsidiary of Beacon Trust Company, incorporated under Delaware law to acquire and conduct the business of The MDE Group, Inc. and Acertus Capital Management, LLC following consummation of the acquisition.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P135_S2	Team Capital Service Co., LLC is an inactive New Jersey limited liability company which became a wholly owned subsidiary of the Company by way of the Team Capital Bank acquisition.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P135_S3	Team Capital NJ Investment Co. is an inactive New Jersey corporation which became a wholly owned subsidiary of the Company by way of the Team Capital Bank acquisition.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P135_S4	As of December 31, 2014 , the Company had 912 full-time and 109 part-time employees.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P135_S5	None of the Company s employees are represented by a collective bargaining group.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P135_S6	The Company believes its working relationship with its employees is good.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P136_S0	REGULATION and SUPERVISION General As a bank holding company controlling the Bank, the Company is subject to the Bank Holding Company Act of 1956, as amended ( BHCA ), and the rules and regulations of the Federal Reserve Board under the BHCA.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P136_S1	The Company is also subject to the provisions of the New Jersey Banking Act of 1948 (the New Jersey Banking Act ) and the regulations of the Commissioner of the New Jersey Department of Banking and Insurance ( Commissioner ) under the New Jersey Banking Act applicable to bank holding companies.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P136_S2	The Company and the Bank are required to file reports with, and otherwise comply with the rules and regulations of the Federal Reserve Board and the Commissioner.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P136_S3	The Federal Reserve Board and the Commissioner conduct periodic examinations to assess the Company s compliance with various regulatory requirements.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P136_S4	The Company files certain reports with, and otherwise complies with, the rules and regulations of the SEC under the federal securities laws and the listing requirements of the New York Stock Exchange.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P137_S0	The Bank is a New Jersey chartered savings bank, and its deposit accounts are insured up to applicable limits by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation ( FDIC ).
1178970_15_ITEM1_P137_S1	The Bank is subject to extensive regulation, examination and supervision by the Commissioner as the issuer of its charter, and by the FDIC as its deposit insurer.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P137_S2	The Bank files reports with the Commissioner and the FDIC concerning its activities and financial condition, and it must obtain regulatory approval prior to entering into certain transactions, such as mergers with, or acquisitions of, other depository institutions and opening or acquiring branch offices.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P138_S0	Commissioner and the FDIC conduct periodic examinations to assess the Bank s compliance with various regulatory requirements.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P138_S1	This regulation and supervision establishes a comprehensive framework of activities in which a savings bank can engage and is intended primarily for the protection of the deposit insurance fund and depositors.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P138_S2	The regulatory structure also gives the regulatory authorities extensive discretion in connection with their supervisory and enforcement activities and examination policies, including policies with respect to the classification of assets and the establishment of adequate loan loss reserves for regulatory purposes.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P139_S0	Any change in applicable laws and regulations, whether by the Commissioner, the FDIC, the Federal Reserve Board or through legislation, could have a material adverse impact on the Company and the Bank and their operations.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P140_S0	The Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act of 2010 (the Dodd-Frank Act ) made extensive changes in the regulation of depository institutions and their holding companies.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P140_S1	Certain provisions of the Dodd-Frank Act are impacting the Company and the Bank.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P140_S2	For example, the Dodd-Frank Act created the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau as an independent bureau of the Federal Reserve Board.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P140_S3	The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has assumed responsibility for the implementation of the federal financial consumer protection and fair lending laws and regulations and has the authority to impose new requirements.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P140_S4	However, institutions of less than $10 billion in assets, such as the Bank, will continue to be examined for compliance with consumer protection and fair lending laws and regulations by, and be subject to the enforcement authority of, their principal regulator, although the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau will have back-up authority to examine and enforce consumer protection laws against all institutions, including those with less than $10 billion in assets.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P140_S5	The material laws and regulations applicable to the Company and the Bank are summarized below and elsewhere in the Form 10-K. New Jersey Banking Regulation Activity Powers.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P141_S0	The Bank derives its lending, investment and other activity powers primarily from the applicable provisions of the New Jersey Banking Act and its related regulations.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P141_S1	Under these laws and regulations, savings banks, including the Bank, generally may, subject to certain limits, invest in: (1) real estate mortgages; (2) consumer and commercial loans; (3) specific types of debt securities, including certain corporate debt securities and obligations of federal, state and local governments and agencies; (4) certain types of corporate equity securities; and (5) certain other assets.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P141_S2	A savings bank may also invest pursuant to a leeway power that permits investments not otherwise permitted by the New Jersey Banking Act, subject to certain restrictions imposed by the FDIC.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P142_S0	Leeway investments must comply with a number of limitations on the individual and aggregate amounts of leeway investments.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P142_S1	A savings bank may also exercise trust powers upon the approval of the Commissioner.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P142_S2	New Jersey savings banks may exercise those powers, rights, benefits or privileges authorized for national banks or out-of-state banks or for federal or out-of-state savings banks or savings associations, provided that before exercising any such power, right, benefit or privilege, prior approval by the Commissioner by regulation or by specific authorization is required.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P142_S3	The exercise of these lending, investment and activity powers is limited by federal law and the related regulations.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P142_S4	See Federal Banking Regulation Activity Restrictions on State-Chartered Bank below.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P143_S0	With certain specified exceptions, a New Jersey chartered savings bank may not make loans or extend credit to a single borrower and to entities related to the borrower in an aggregate amount that would exceed 15% of the bank s capital funds.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P143_S1	A New Jersey chartered savings bank may lend an additional 10% of the bank s capital funds if secured by collateral meeting the requirements of the New Jersey Banking Act.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P143_S2	The Bank currently complies with applicable loans-to-one-borrower limitations.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P144_S0	Under the New Jersey Banking Act, a stock savings bank may declare and pay a dividend on its capital stock only to the extent that the payment of the dividend would not impair the capital stock of the savings bank.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P144_S1	In addition, a stock savings bank may not pay a dividend unless the savings bank would, after the payment of the dividend, have a surplus of not less than 50% of its capital stock, or the payment of the dividend would not reduce the surplus.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P144_S2	Federal law may also limit the amount of dividends that may be paid by the bank.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P145_S0	Regulations of the Commissioner impose on New Jersey chartered depository institutions, including the Bank, minimum capital requirements similar to those imposed by the FDIC on insured state banks.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P145_S1	At December 31, 2014 , the Bank was considered well capitalized under FDIC guidelines.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P146_S0	The New Jersey Department of Banking and Insurance may examine the Company and the Bank whenever it deems an examination advisable.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P146_S1	The Department examines the Bank at least every two years.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P147_S0	The Commissioner may order any savings bank to discontinue any violation of law or unsafe or unsound business practice and may direct any director, officer, attorney or employee of a savings bank engaged in an objectionable activity, after the Commissioner has ordered the activity to be terminated, to show cause at a hearing before the Commissioner why such person should not be removed.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P148_S0	FDIC regulations require banks to maintain minimum levels of capital.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P148_S1	The FDIC regulations define two tiers, or classes, of capital.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P148_S2	Tier 1 capital is comprised of:
1178970_15_ITEM1_P149_S0	minority interests in consolidated subsidiaries minus all intangible assets, other than qualifying servicing rights and any net unrealized loss on marketable equity securities.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P150_S0	Tier 2 capital is comprised of:
1178970_15_ITEM1_P151_S0	up to 45% of pre-tax net unrealized holding gains on available for sale equity securities with readily determinable fair values.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P151_S1	The allowance for loan losses may be includible in Tier 2 capital up to a maximum of 1.25% of risk-weighted assets.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P151_S2	Overall, the amount of Tier 2 capital that may be included in total capital cannot exceed 100% of Tier 1 capital.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P152_S0	The FDIC regulations establish a minimum leverage capital requirement for banks in the strongest financial and managerial condition, with a rating of 1 (the highest examination rating of the FDIC for banks) under the Uniform Financial Institutions Rating System that are not anticipating or experiencing significant growth, of not less than a ratio of 3.0% of Tier 1 capital to total assets.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P152_S1	For all other banks, the minimum leverage capital requirement is 4.0%, unless a higher leverage capital ratio is warranted by the particular circumstances or risk profile of the bank.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P153_S0	The FDIC regulations also establish a risk-based capital standard.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P153_S1	The risk-based capital standard requires the maintenance of a ratio of total capital, which is defined as the sum of Tier 1 capital and Tier 2 capital, to risk-weighted assets of at least 8% and a ratio of Tier 1 capital to risk-weighted assets of at least 4%.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P153_S2	In determining the amount of a bank s risk-weighted assets, all assets, plus certain off balance sheet items, are multiplied by a risk-weight of 0% to 200%, based on the risks the FDIC believes are inherent in the type of asset or item.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P153_S3	The federal banking agencies, including the FDIC, have also adopted regulations to require an assessment of a bank s exposure to declines in the economic value of a bank s capital due to changes in interest rates when assessing such bank s capital adequacy.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P153_S4	Under such a risk assessment, examiners will evaluate a bank s capital for interest rate risk on a case-by-case basis, with consideration of both quantitative and qualitative factors.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P153_S5	According to the agencies, applicable considerations include:
1178970_15_ITEM1_P154_S0	the level of other risks at the bank for which capital is needed.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P154_S1	Institutions with significant interest rate risk may be required to maintain additional capital.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P155_S0	(1) For purposes of calculating Regulatory Tier 1 leverage capital, assets are based on adjusted total leverage assets.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P155_S1	In calculating Tier 1 risk-based capital and total risk-based capital, assets are based on total risk-weighted assets.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P155_S2	As of December 31, 2014 , the Bank was considered well capitalized under FDIC guidelines.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P156_S0	In July 2013, the FDIC and the other federal bank regulatory agencies issued a final rule that revises their leverage and risk-based capital requirements and the method for calculating risk-weighted assets to make them consistent with agreements that were reached by the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision and certain provisions of the Dodd-Frank Act.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P156_S1	Among other things, the rule establishes a new common equity Tier 1 minimum capital requirement (4.5% of risk-weighted assets), adopts a uniform minimum leverage capital ratio of 4%, increases the minimum Tier 1 capital to risk-based assets requirement (from 4% to 6% of risk-weighted assets) and assigns a higher risk weight (150%) to exposures that are more than 90 days past due or are on nonaccrual status and to certain commercial real estate facilities that finance the acquisition, development or construction of real property.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P156_S2	The final rule also requires unrealized gains and losses on certain available-for-sale securities holdings to be included for purposes of calculating regulatory capital requirements unless a one-time opt-in or opt-out is exercised.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P157_S0	The rule limits a banking organization s capital distributions and certain discretionary bonus payments to executive officers if the banking organization does not hold a capital conservation buffer consisting of 2.5% of common equity Tier 1 capital to risk-weighted assets in addition to the amount necessary to meet its minimum risk-based capital requirements.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P157_S1	The final rule is effective January 1, 2015.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P157_S2	The capital conservation buffer will be phased in from January 1, 2016 to January 1, 2019, when the full capital conservation buffer will be effective.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P158_S0	Federal law and FDIC regulations generally limit the activities and investments of state-chartered FDIC insured banks and their subsidiaries to those permissible for national banks and their subsidiaries, unless such activities and investments are specifically exempted by law or consented to by the FDIC.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P158_S1	Before making a new investment or engaging in a new activity that is not permissible for a national bank or otherwise permissible under federal law or FDIC regulations, an insured bank must seek approval from the FDIC to make such investment or engage in such activity.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P158_S2	The FDIC will not approve the activity unless the bank meets its minimum capital requirements and the FDIC determines that the activity does not present a significant risk to the FDIC insurance fund.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P159_S0	Certain activities of subsidiaries that are engaged in activities permitted for national banks only through a financial subsidiary are subject to additional restrictions.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P159_S1	Federal law permits a state-chartered savings bank to engage, through financial subsidiaries, in any activity in which a national bank may engage through a financial subsidiary and on substantially the same terms and conditions.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P159_S2	In general, the law permits a national bank that is well-capitalized and well-managed to conduct, through a financial subsidiary, any activity permitted for a financial holding company other than insurance underwriting, insurance investments, real estate investment or development or merchant banking.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P159_S3	The total assets of all such financial subsidiaries may not exceed the lesser of 45% of the bank s total assets or $50 billion.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P159_S4	The bank must have policies and procedures to assess the financial subsidiary s risk and protect the bank from such risk and potential liability, must not consolidate the financial subsidiary s assets with the bank s and must exclude from its own assets and equity all equity investments, including retained earnings, in the financial subsidiary.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P159_S5	The Bank currently meets all conditions necessary to establish and engage in permitted activities through financial subsidiaries.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P160_S0	The Bank is a member of the FHLB system which consists of twelve regional FHLBs, each subject to supervision and regulation by the Federal Housing Finance Agency ( FHFA ).
1178970_15_ITEM1_P160_S1	The FHLB provides a central credit facility primarily for member institutions.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P160_S2	The Bank, as a member of the FHLB of New York, is required to purchase and hold shares of capital stock in that FHLB in an amount as required by that FHLB s capital plan and minimum capital requirements.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P160_S3	The Bank is in compliance with these requirements.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P160_S4	The Bank has received dividends on its FHLB stock, although no assurance can be given that these dividends will continue to be paid.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P160_S5	For the year ended December 31, 2014 , dividends paid by the FHLB to the Bank totaled $1.7 million.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P161_S0	As a member institution of the FDIC, deposit accounts at the Bank are generally insured up to a maximum of $250,000 for each separately insured depositor.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P162_S0	Under the FDIC s risk-based assessment system, insured institutions are assigned a risk category based on supervisory evaluations, regulatory capital levels and certain other factors.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P162_S1	An institution s assessment rate depends upon the category to which it is assigned, and certain adjustments specified by FDIC regulations.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P162_S2	Institutions deemed less risky pay lower assessments.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P163_S0	The FDIC may adjust the scale uniformly, except that no adjustment can deviate more than two basis points from the base scale without notice and comment.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P164_S0	No institution may pay a dividend if in default of the federal deposit insurance assessment.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P165_S0	The Dodd-Frank Act required the FDIC to revise its procedures to base its assessments upon each insured institution s total assets less tangible equity instead of deposits.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P165_S1	The FDIC finalized a rule, effective April 1, 2011, that set the assessment range at 2.5 to 45 basis points of total assets less tangible equity.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P165_S2	On February 7, 2011, the FDIC issued a final rule that establishes a target size for the Deposit Insurance Fund ( DIF ) at 2 percent of insured deposits as mandated by the Dodd-Frank Act.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P165_S3	The rule also implements a lower assessment rate schedule when the DIF reaches 1.15 percent of total insured deposits.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P166_S0	The FDIC may terminate the insurance of an institution s deposits upon a finding that the institution has engaged in unsafe or unsound practices, is in an unsafe or unsound condition to continue operations or has violated any applicable law, regulation, rule, order or condition imposed by the FDIC.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P166_S1	Management is not aware of any practice, condition or violation that might lead to termination of the Bank s deposit insurance.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P167_S0	The FDIC has extensive enforcement authority over insured savings banks, including the Bank.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P167_S1	This enforcement authority includes, among other things, the ability to assess civil money penalties, to issue cease and desist orders and to remove directors and officers.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P167_S2	In general, these enforcement actions may be initiated in response to violations of law and to unsafe or unsound practices.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P168_S0	Transactions between an insured bank, such as the Bank, and any of its affiliates are governed by Sections 23A and 23B of the Federal Reserve Act and its implementing regulations.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P169_S0	An affiliate of a bank is any company or entity that controls, is controlled by or is under common control with the bank.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P169_S1	A subsidiary of a bank that is not also a depository institution, financial subsidiary or other entity defined by the regulation generally is not treated as an affiliate of the bank for purposes of Sections 23A and 23B. Section 23A:
1178970_15_ITEM1_P170_S0	requires that all such transactions be on terms that are consistent with safe and sound banking practices.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P171_S0	The term covered transaction includes the making of loans, purchase of assets, issuance of guarantees and other similar types of transactions.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P171_S1	Further, most loans by a bank to any of its affiliates must be secured by collateral in amounts ranging from 100 to 130 percent of the loan amounts.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P171_S2	In addition, any covered transaction by a bank with an affiliate and any purchase of assets or services by a bank from an affiliate must be on terms that are substantially the same, or at least as favorable to the bank, as those that would be provided to a non-affiliate.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P172_S0	Banks are subject to statutory prohibitions on certain tying arrangements.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P172_S1	A depository institution is prohibited, subject to certain exceptions, from extending credit to or offering any other service, or fixing or varying the consideration for such extension of credit or service, on the condition that the customer obtain some additional service from the institution or its affiliates or that the customer not obtain services of a competitor of the institution.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P173_S0	FDIC regulations require the Company and the Bank to disclose their privacy policies, including identifying with whom they share non-public personal information to customers at the time of establishing the customer relationship and annually thereafter.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P173_S1	The FDIC regulations also require the Company and the Bank to provide their customers with initial and annual notices that accurately reflect their privacy policies and practices.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P173_S2	In addition, the Company and the Bank are required to provide their customers with the ability to opt-out of having the Company and the Bank share their non-public personal information with unaffiliated third parties before they can disclose such information, subject to certain exceptions.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P174_S0	Community Reinvestment Act and Fair Lending Laws.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P175_S0	All FDIC insured institutions have a responsibility under the Community Reinvestment Act and related regulations to help meet the credit needs of their communities, including low- and moderate-income neighborhoods.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P176_S0	assess the institution s record of compliance with the Community Reinvestment Act.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P176_S1	Among other things, the current Community Reinvestment Act regulations rate an institution based upon its actual performance in meeting community needs.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P176_S2	In particular, the current evaluation system focuses on three tests:
1178970_15_ITEM1_P177_S0	a service test, to evaluate the institution s delivery of services through its branches, ATMs and other offices.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P178_S0	An institution s failure to comply with the provisions of the Community Reinvestment Act could, at a minimum, result in regulatory restrictions on its activities, including, but not limited to, engaging in acquisitions and mergers.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P178_S1	The Bank received an Outstanding Community Reinvestment Act rating in its most recently completed federal examination, which was conducted by the FDIC as of August 2011.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P178_S2	In addition, the Equal Credit Opportunity Act and the Fair Housing Act prohibit lenders from discriminating in their lending practices on the basis of characteristics specified in those statutes.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P178_S3	An institution s failure to comply with the Equal Credit Opportunity Act and the Fair Housing Act could result in enforcement actions by the FDIC, as well as other federal regulatory agencies and the Department of Justice.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P179_S0	Each federal banking agency, including the FDIC, has adopted guidelines establishing general standards relating to internal controls, information and internal audit systems, loan documentation, credit underwriting, interest rate exposure, asset growth, asset quality, earnings, compensation, fees and benefits.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P179_S1	In general, the guidelines require, among other things, appropriate systems and practices to identify and manage the risks and exposures specified in the guidelines.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P180_S0	The guidelines prohibit excessive compensation as an unsafe and unsound practice and describe compensation as excessive when the amounts paid are unreasonable or disproportionate to the services performed by an executive officer, employee, director, or principal stockholder.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P180_S1	In addition, FDIC regulations require a bank that is given notice by the FDIC that it is not satisfying any of such safety and soundness standards to submit a compliance plan to the FDIC.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P180_S2	If, after being so notified, a bank fails to submit an acceptable compliance plan or fails in any material respect to implement an accepted compliance plan, the FDIC may issue an order directing corrective and other actions of the types to which a significantly undercapitalized institution is subject under the prompt corrective action provisions discussed below.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P180_S3	If a bank fails to comply with such an order, the FDIC may seek to enforce such an order in judicial proceedings and to impose civil monetary penalties.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P181_S0	Federal law requires the FDIC and the other federal banking regulators to promptly resolve the problems of undercapitalized institutions.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P181_S1	Federal law also establishes five categories, consisting of well capitalized, adequately capitalized, undercapitalized, significantly undercapitalized and critically undercapitalized.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P181_S2	The FDIC s regulations define the five capital categories as follows:
1178970_15_ITEM1_P181_S3	An institution will be treated as well capitalized if:
1178970_15_ITEM1_P182_S0	its ratio of Tier 1 capital to total assets is at least 5%, and it is not subject to any order or directive by the FDIC to meet a specific capital level.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P183_S0	An institution will be treated as adequately capitalized if:
1178970_15_ITEM1_P184_S0	its ratio of Tier 1 capital to total assets is at least 4% (3% if the bank receives the highest rating under the Uniform Financial Institutions Rating System) and it is not a well-capitalized institution.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P184_S1	An institution will be treated as undercapitalized if:
1178970_15_ITEM1_P185_S0	its leverage ratio is less than 4% (or less than 3% if the institution receives the highest rating under the Uniform Financial Institutions Rating System).
1178970_15_ITEM1_P186_S0	An institution will be treated as significantly undercapitalized if:
1178970_15_ITEM1_P187_S0	its leverage ratio is less than 3%.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P187_S1	An institution that has a tangible capital to total assets ratio equal to or less than 2% would be deemed critically undercapitalized.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P187_S2	The FDIC is required, with some exceptions, to appoint a receiver or conservator for an insured state bank if that bank is critically undercapitalized.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P187_S3	The FDIC may also appoint a conservator or receiver for an insured state bank on the basis of the institution s financial condition or upon the occurrence of certain events, including:
1178970_15_ITEM1_P188_S0	insufficient capital, or the incurring or likely incurring of losses that will substantially deplete all of the institution s capital with no reasonable prospect of replenishment of capital without federal assistance.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P188_S1	The previously discussed final rule that increased capital requirements effective January 1, 2015 adjusts the prompt action categories accordingly.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P188_S2	Under the revised prompt corrective action requirements, insured depository institutions are required to meet the following in order to qualify as well capitalized : (1) a common equity Tier 1 risk-based capital ratio of 6.5% (new standard); (2) a Tier 1 risk-based capital ratio of 8% (increased from 6%); (3) a total risk-based capital ratio of 10% (unchanged from current rules) and (4) a Tier 1 leverage ratio of 5% (unchanged from the current rules).
1178970_15_ITEM1_P189_S0	Loans to a Bank s Insiders Federal Regulation.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P189_S1	A bank s loans to its executive officers, directors, any owner of 10% or more of its stock (each, an insider) and any of certain entities affiliated with any such person (an insider s related interest) are subject to the conditions and limitations imposed by Section 22(h) of the Federal Reserve Act and the Federal Reserve Board s Regulation O.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P189_S2	Under these restrictions, the aggregate amount of the loans to any insider and the insider s related interests may not exceed the loans-to-one-borrower limit applicable to national banks, which is comparable to the loans-to-one-borrower limit applicable to loans by the Bank.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P189_S3	All loans by a bank to all insiders and insiders related interests in the aggregate may not exceed the bank s unimpaired capital and unimpaired surplus.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P189_S4	With certain exceptions, loans to an executive officer, other than loans for the education of the officer s children and certain loans secured by the officer s residence may not exceed at any one time the higher of 2.5% of the bank s unimpaired capital and unimpaired surplus or $25,000, but in no event more than $100,000.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P189_S5	Regulation O also requires that any proposed loan to an insider or a related interest of that insider be approved in advance by a majority of the board of directors of the bank, with any interested directors not participating in the voting, if such loan, when aggregated with any existing loans to that insider and the insider s related interests, would exceed either (1) $500,000; or (2) the greater of $25,000 or 5% of the bank s unimpaired capital and surplus.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P190_S0	Generally, loans to insiders must be made on substantially the same terms as, and follow credit underwriting procedures that are not less stringent than, those that are prevailing at the time for comparable transactions with other persons, and not involve more than the normal risk of payment or present other unfavorable features.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P190_S1	An exception may be made for extensions of credit made pursuant to a benefit or compensation plan of a bank that is widely available to employees of the bank and that does not give any preference to insiders of the bank over other employees of the bank.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P190_S2	In addition, federal law prohibits extensions of credit to a bank s insiders and their related interests by any other institution that has a correspondent banking relationship with the bank, unless such extension of credit is on substantially the same terms as those prevailing at the time for comparable transactions with other persons and does not involve more than the normal risk of repayment or present other unfavorable features.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P191_S0	The Bank does not, as a matter of policy, make loans to its directors or to their immediate family members and related interests.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P192_S0	related interests under Regulation O, as discussed above.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P192_S1	The New Jersey Banking Act also provides that a savings bank that is in compliance with Regulation O is deemed to be in compliance with such provisions of the New Jersey Banking Act.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P193_S0	Federal Reserve System Under Federal Reserve Board regulations, the Bank is required to maintain non-interest earning reserves against its transaction accounts.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P193_S1	The Federal Reserve Board regulations generally require that reserves of 3% must be maintained against aggregate transaction accounts over $14.5 million and up to $103.6 million, and 10% against that portion of total transaction accounts in excess of up to $103.6 million.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P193_S2	The first $14.5 million of otherwise reservable balances are exempted from the reserve requirements.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P193_S3	The Bank is in compliance with these requirements.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P193_S4	These requirements are adjusted annually by the Federal Reserve Board.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P193_S5	Because required reserves must be maintained in the form of either vault cash, a non-interest bearing account at a Federal Reserve Bank or a pass-through account as defined by the Federal Reserve Board, the effect of this reserve requirement is to reduce the Bank s interest-earning assets.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P194_S0	The Bank is authorized to borrow from the Federal Reserve Bank discount window.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P195_S0	Internet Banking Technological developments continue to significantly alter the ways in which financial institutions conduct their business.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P195_S1	The growth of the Internet has caused banks to adopt and refine alternative distribution and marketing systems.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P195_S2	The federal bank regulatory agencies have conducted seminars and published materials targeted to various aspects of internet banking, and have indicated their intention to re-evaluate their regulations to ensure that they encourage banks efficiency and competitiveness consistent with safe and sound banking practices.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P195_S3	There can be no assurance that the bank regulatory agencies will adopt new regulations that will not materially affect the Bank s internet operations or restrict any such further operations.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P196_S0	The Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P197_S0	On July 21, 2010, the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (the Dodd-Frank Act ) was enacted.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P197_S1	This law has significantly changed the current bank regulatory structure and is affecting the lending, deposit, investment, trading and operating activities of depository institutions and their holding companies.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P198_S0	The Dodd-Frank Act requires various federal agencies to adopt a broad range of new implementing rules and regulations, and to prepare numerous studies and reports for Congress.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P198_S1	The federal agencies are given significant discretion in drafting the implementing rules and regulations, and consequently, many of the details and the full impact of the Dodd-Frank Act may not be known for some time.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P199_S0	A provision of the Dodd-Frank Act that became effective on July 1, 2011, repealed the federal prohibitions on paying interest on demand deposits, thus permitting depository institutions to pay interest on business transaction and other accounts.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P199_S1	The legislation also provided for originators of certain securitized loans to retain a percentage of the risk for transferred credits, directed the Federal Reserve Board to regulate pricing of certain debit card interchange fees and contained a number of reforms related to mortgage origination.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P200_S0	The Dodd-Frank Act required publicly traded companies to give stockholders a non-binding vote on executive compensation and so-called golden parachute payments.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P200_S1	The legislation also directed the Federal Reserve Board to promulgate rules prohibiting excessive compensation paid to bank holding company executives, regardless of whether the company is publicly traded or not.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P201_S0	The Dodd-Frank Act contained the so-called Volcker Rule, which generally prohibits banking organizations from engaging in proprietary trading and from investing in, sponsoring or having certain relationships with hedge or private equity funds ( covered funds ).
1178970_15_ITEM1_P201_S1	On December 13, 2013, federal agencies issued a final rule implementing the Volcker Rule which, among other things, requires banking organizations to restructure and limit certain of their investments in and relationships with covered funds.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P201_S2	The final rule unexpectedly included within the interests subject to its restrictions collateralized debt obligations backed by trust-preferred securities ( TRUPs CDOs ).
1178970_15_ITEM1_P201_S3	Many banking organizations had purchased such instruments because of their favorable tax, accounting and regulatory treatment and would have been subject to unexpected write-downs.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P201_S4	In response to concerns expressed by community banking organizations, the federal agencies subsequently issued an interim final rule which grandfathers TRUPS CDOs issued before May 19, 2010 if (i) acquired by a banking organization on or before December 10, 2013 and (ii) the organization reasonably believed the proceeds from the TRUPS CDOs were invested primarily in any trust preferred security or subordinated debt instrument issued by a depository institution holding company with less than $15 billion in assets or by a mutual holding company.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P201_S5	Neither the Company nor the Bank have investments in covered funds or TRUPS CDOs.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P202_S0	The USA PATRIOT Act The USA PATRIOT Act gives the federal government powers to address terrorist threats through enhanced domestic security measures, expanded surveillance powers, increased information sharing, and broadened anti-money laundering requirements.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P202_S1	By way of amendments to the Bank Secrecy Act, Title III of the USA PATRIOT Act included measures intended to encourage information sharing among bank regulatory agencies and law enforcement bodies.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P203_S0	affirmative obligations on a broad range of financial institutions, including banks, thrifts, brokers, dealers, credit unions, money transfer agents and parties registered under the Commodity Exchange Act.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P204_S0	The bank regulatory agencies have increased the regulatory scrutiny of the Bank Secrecy Act and anti-money laundering programs maintained by financial institutions.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P204_S1	Significant penalties and fines, as well as other supervisory orders may be imposed on a financial institution for non-compliance with these requirements.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P204_S2	In addition, the federal bank regulatory agencies must consider the effectiveness of financial institutions engaging in a merger transaction in combating money laundering activities.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P204_S3	The Bank has adopted policies and procedures which are in compliance with these requirements.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P204_S4	The Company is regulated as a bank holding company, and as such, is subject to examination, regulation and periodic reporting under the Bank Holding Company Act, as administered by the Federal Reserve Board.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P204_S5	The Federal Reserve Board has adopted capital adequacy guidelines for bank holding companies on a consolidated basis structured similarly, but not identically, to those of the FDIC for the Bank.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P204_S6	As of December 31, 2014 , the Company s total capital and Tier 1 capital ratios exceed these minimum capital requirements.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P205_S0	(1) For purposes of calculating Regulatory Tier 1 leverage capital, assets are based on adjusted total leverage assets.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P205_S1	In calculating Tier 1 risk-based capital and Total risk-based capital, assets are based on total risk-weighted assets.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P205_S2	As of December 31, 2014 , the Company was well capitalized under Federal Reserve Board guidelines.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P206_S0	The Dodd-Frank Act directs the Federal Reserve Board to issue consolidated capital requirements for depository institution holding companies that are not less stringent, both quantitatively and in terms of components of capital, than those applicable to institutions themselves.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P206_S1	The previously discussed final rule regarding regulatory capital requirements implements the Dodd-Frank Act as to bank holding company capital standards.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P206_S2	Consolidated regulatory capital requirements identical to those applicable to the subsidiary banks apply to bank holding companies (with greater than $500 million of assets) as of January 1, 2015.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P206_S3	As is the case with institutions themselves, the capital conservation buffer will be phased in between 2016 and 2019.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P207_S0	Regulations of the Federal Reserve Board provide that a bank holding company must serve as a source of strength to any of its subsidiary banks and must not conduct its activities in an unsafe or unsound manner.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P207_S1	Federal Reserve Board policies generally provide that bank holding companies should pay dividends only out of current earnings and only if the prospective rate of earnings retention in the holding company appears consistent with the organization s capital needs, asset quality and overall financial condition.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P208_S0	Under the prompt corrective action provisions discussed above, a bank holding company parent of an undercapitalized subsidiary bank would be directed to guarantee, within limitations, the capital restoration plan that is required of such an undercapitalized bank.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P208_S1	If the undercapitalized bank fails to file an acceptable capital restoration plan or fails to implement an accepted plan, the Federal Reserve Board may prohibit the bank holding company parent of the undercapitalized bank from paying any dividends or making any other form of capital distribution without the prior approval of the Federal Reserve Board.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P209_S0	As a bank holding company, the Company is required to obtain the prior approval of the Federal Reserve Board to acquire all, or substantially all, of the assets of any bank or bank holding company.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P209_S1	Prior Federal Reserve Board approval will be required for the Company to acquire direct or indirect ownership or control of any voting securities of any bank or bank holding company if, after giving effect to such acquisition, it would, directly or indirectly, own or control more than 5% of any class of voting shares of such bank or bank holding company.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P210_S0	A bank holding company is required to give the Federal Reserve Board prior written notice of any purchase or redemption of its outstanding equity securities if the gross consideration for the purchase or redemption, when combined with the net consideration paid for all such purchases or redemptions during the preceding 12 months will be equal to 10% or more of the company s consolidated net worth.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P211_S0	order or directive, or any condition imposed by, or written agreement with, the Federal Reserve Board.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P211_S1	Such notice and approval is not required for a bank holding company that would be treated as well capitalized under applicable regulations of the Federal Reserve Board, is well-managed, and that is not the subject of any unresolved supervisory issues.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P211_S2	In addition, a bank holding company which does not opt to become a financial holding company under applicable federal law is generally prohibited from engaging in, or acquiring direct or indirect control of any company engaged in non-banking activities.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P211_S3	One of the principal exceptions to this prohibition is for activities found by the Federal Reserve Board to be so closely related to banking or managing or controlling banks as to be permissible.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P211_S4	Some of the principal activities that the Federal Reserve Board has determined by regulation to be so closely related to banking as to be permissible are:
1178970_15_ITEM1_P212_S0	acquiring a savings and loan association.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P213_S0	Bank holding companies that qualify and opt to become a financial holding company may engage in activities that are financial in nature or incident to activities which are financial in nature.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P213_S1	Financial holding companies may engage in a broader array of activities including insurance and investment banking.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P214_S0	The Company filed an election to qualify as a financial holding company under federal regulations on January 31, 2014 which was deemed effective by the Federal Reserve Board on March 5, 2015.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P214_S1	Bank holding companies may qualify to become a financial holding company if at the time of the election and on a continuing basis:
1178970_15_ITEM1_P215_S0	each of its depository institution subsidiaries has at least a satisfactory Community Reinvestment Act rating at its most recent examination.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P216_S0	Under federal law, depository institutions are liable to the FDIC for losses suffered or anticipated by the FDIC in connection with the default of a commonly controlled depository institution or any assistance provided by the FDIC to such an institution in danger of default.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P216_S1	This law would potentially be applicable to the Company if it ever acquired as a separate subsidiary, a depository institution in addition to the Bank.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P217_S0	Under the New Jersey Banking Act, a company owning or controlling a savings bank is regulated as a bank holding company.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P217_S1	The New Jersey Banking Act defines the terms company and bank holding company as such terms are defined under the BHCA.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P217_S2	Each bank holding company controlling a New Jersey chartered bank or savings bank must file certain reports with the Commissioner and is subject to examination by the Commissioner.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P218_S0	Under federal law and under the New Jersey Banking Act, no person may acquire control of the Company or the Bank without first obtaining approval of such acquisition of control from the Federal Reserve Board and the Commissioner.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P219_S0	The Company s common stock is registered with the SEC under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P219_S1	The Company is subject to the information, proxy solicitation, insider trading restrictions and other requirements under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P219_S2	Investment Adviser Regulation Following the acquisition of the MDE Group, Inc. and Acertus Capital Management, LLC, each of Beacon Investment Advisory Services, Inc. and Acertus Capital Management, LLC will be investment advisers registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P219_S3	As such, they will be required to make certain filings with and be subject to periodic examination by, the Securities and Exchange Commission.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P220_S0	The Company is incorporated under the laws of the State of Delaware.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P220_S1	As a result, the rights of its stockholders are governed by the Delaware General Corporate Law and the Company s Certificate of Incorporation and Bylaws.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P221_S0	The Company is subject to federal income taxation in the same general manner as other corporations, with some exceptions discussed below.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P221_S1	The following discussion of federal taxation is intended only to summarize certain pertinent federal income tax matters and is not a comprehensive description of the tax rules applicable to the Company.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P221_S2	For federal income tax purposes, the Company currently reports its income and expenses on the accrual method of accounting and uses a tax year ending December 31 for filing its consolidated federal income tax returns.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P222_S0	Prior to the Small Business Protection Act of 1996 (the 1996 Act ), the Bank was permitted to establish a reserve for bad debts and to make annual additions to the reserve.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P222_S1	These additions could, within specified formula limits, be deducted in arriving at taxable income.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P223_S0	The Bank was required to use the direct charge-off method to compute its bad debt deduction beginning with its 1996 federal income tax return.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P224_S0	Savings institutions were required to recapture any excess reserves over those established as of December 31, 1987 (base year reserve).
1178970_15_ITEM1_P224_S1	Prior to the 1996 Act, bad debt reserves created prior to January 1, 1988 were subject to recapture into taxable income should the Bank fail to meet certain asset and definitional tests.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P224_S2	Federal legislation has eliminated these recapture rules.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P224_S3	Retained earnings at December 31, 2014 included approximately $51.8 million for which no provisions for income tax had been made.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P224_S4	This amount represents an allocation of income to bad debt deductions for tax purposes only.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P224_S5	Events that would result in taxation of these reserves include failure to qualify as a bank for tax purposes, distributions in complete or partial liquidation, stock redemptions and excess distributions to shareholders.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P224_S6	At December 31, 2014 , the Bank had an unrecognized tax liability of $21.2 million with respect to this reserve.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P225_S0	The Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended (the Code ), imposes an alternative minimum tax (AMT) at a rate of 20% on a base of regular taxable income plus certain tax preferences (alternative minimum taxable income or AMTI).
1178970_15_ITEM1_P225_S1	The AMT is payable to the extent such AMTI is in excess of an exemption amount and the AMT exceeds the regular income tax.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P225_S2	Net operating losses can offset no more than 90% of AMTI.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P226_S0	Certain payments of alternative minimum tax may be used as credits against regular tax liabilities in future years.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P226_S1	The Company has not been subject to the alternative minimum tax and has no such amounts available as credits for carryover.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P227_S0	Under the general rule, a financial institution may carry back net operating losses to the preceding two taxable years and forward to the succeeding 20 taxable years.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P227_S1	At December 31, 2014 , the Company had approximately $3,900,000 of Federal Net Operating Losses ("NOLs").
1178970_15_ITEM1_P227_S2	These NOLs were generated by entities the Company acquired in previous years and are subject to an annual Code Section 382 limitation.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P228_S0	The Company may exclude from its income 100% of dividends received from the Bank as a member of the same affiliated group of corporations.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P229_S0	State Taxation New Jersey State Taxation.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P229_S1	The Company and the Bank file New Jersey Corporation Business Tax returns.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P230_S0	Generally, the income of financial institutions in New Jersey, which is calculated based on federal taxable income subject to certain adjustments, is subject to New Jersey tax.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P230_S1	The Company and the Bank are currently subject to the corporate business tax ( CBT ) at 9% of apportioned taxable income.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P230_S2	New Jersey tax law does not and has not allowed for a taxpayer to file a tax return on a combined or consolidated basis with another member of the affiliated group where there is common ownership.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P230_S3	However, if the taxpayer cannot demonstrate by clear and convincing evidence that the tax filing discloses the true earnings of the taxpayer on its business carried on in the State of New Jersey, the Director of the New Jersey Division of Taxation may, at the director s discretion, require the taxpayer to file a consolidated return of the entire operations of the affiliated group or controlled group, including its own operations and income.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P230_S4	Due to the acquisition of Team Capital in the current year, the Bank is now subject to Pennsylvania Mutual Thrift Institutions Tax.
1178970_15_ITEM1_P230_S5	Mutual thrift institutions tax is imposed at the rate of 11.5 percent on net taxable income of mutual thrift institutions in Pennsylvania, including savings banks without capital stock, building and loan associations, savings and loan associations, and savings institutions having capital stock.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P0_S0	Historically low interest rates may adversely affect our net interest income and profitability.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P0_S1	The Federal Reserve Board continues to maintain interest rates at historically low levels through its targeted federal funds rate and until recently, the purchase of mortgage-backed securities.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P1_S0	As a general matter, our interest-bearing liabilities reprice or mature more quickly than our interest-earning assets, which has resulted in increases in net interest income in the short term.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P1_S1	Our ability to lower our interest expense is limited at these interest rate levels, while the average yield on our interest-earning assets may continue to decrease.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P1_S2	Accordingly, our net interest income (the difference between interest income earned on assets and interest expense paid on liabilities) may decrease, which may have an adverse affect on our profitability.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P1_S3	In the event the Federal Reserve Board changes its current stance by increasing short-term rates and long-term rates remain low, we may experience a flattening or inverted yield curve that would negatively impact our net interest margin and earnings.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P1_S4	Changes in interest rates could adversely affect our results of operations and financial condition.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P2_S0	Our financial condition and results of operations are significantly affected by changes in market interest rates.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P2_S1	Our results of operations substantially depend on our net interest income, which is the difference between the interest income we earn on our interest-earning assets and the interest expense we pay on our interest-bearing liabilities.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P2_S2	Our interest-bearing liabilities generally reprice or mature more quickly than our interest-earning assets.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P2_S3	If rates increase rapidly, we may have to increase the rates we pay on our deposits and borrowed funds more quickly than any changes in interest rates earned on our loans and investments, resulting in a negative effect on interest spreads and net interest income.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P2_S4	In addition, the effect of rising rates could be compounded if deposit customers move funds into higher yielding accounts.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P2_S5	Conversely, should market interest rates fall below current levels, our net interest margin could also be negatively affected if competitive pressures keep us from further reducing rates on our deposits, while the yields on our assets decrease more rapidly through loan prepayments and interest rate adjustments.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P2_S6	In the event of a 300 basis point increase in interest rates, whereby rates ramp up evenly over a twelve-month period, and assuming management took no actions to mitigate the effect of such change, we are projecting that our net interest income would decrease 4.0% or $9.8 million.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P2_S7	Changes in interest rates also affect the value of our interest-earning assets and in particular our securities portfolio.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P2_S8	Generally, the value of securities fluctuates inversely with changes in interest rates.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P2_S9	At December 31, 2014, our available for sale securities portfolio totaled $1.07 billion.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P2_S10	Unrealized gains and losses on securities available for sale are reported as a separate component of stockholders equity.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P2_S11	Decreases in the fair value of securities available for sale resulting from increases in interest rates therefore could have an adverse effect on stockholders equity.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P2_S12	We are also subject to prepayment and reinvestment risk related to interest rate movements.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P3_S0	Changes in interest rates can affect the average life of loans and mortgage related securities.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P3_S1	Decreases in interest rates can result in the prepayment or refinancing of loans and loans underlying mortgage related securities, resulting in accelerated cash flows subject to reinvestment at reduced market interest rates and increased premium amortization.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P3_S2	Under these circumstances, we are subject to reinvestment risk to the extent that such prepayments cannot be reinvested at a profitable spread in excess of our funding costs.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P4_S0	Increases in interest rates can result in reduced prepayments of loans and mortgage related securities, as borrowers retain existing loans to maintain lower borrowing costs.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P5_S0	We are subject to liquidity risk.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P5_S1	Liquidity risk is the potential that we will be unable to meet our obligations as they become due or capitalize on growth opportunities as they arise because of an inability to liquidate assets or obtain adequate funding on a timely basis at a reasonable cost within acceptable risk tolerances.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P6_S0	Liquidity is required to fund various obligations, including loan commitments to borrowers, loan originations, withdrawals by depositors, repayments of borrowings, operating expenses and capital expenditures.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P6_S1	Liquidity is derived primarily from retail deposit growth and retention; principal and interest payments on loans; the sale, maturity and prepayment of investment securities; net cash provided from operations; and access to other funding sources.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P6_S2	Our access to funding sources in amounts adequate to finance our activities could be impaired by factors specific to us or the financial services industry in general.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P6_S3	Factors detrimental to our access to liquidity sources include a decrease in the level of our business activity due to a market downturn or adverse regulatory action against us.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P6_S4	Our ability to borrow could also be impaired by factors that are not specific to us, such as a severe disruption of the financial markets or negative views and expectations about the prospects for the financial services industry.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P7_S0	If our allowance for loan losses is not sufficient to cover actual loan losses, our earnings could decrease.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P8_S0	We make various assumptions and judgments about the collectability of our loan portfolio, including the creditworthiness of our borrowers and the value of the real estate and other assets serving as collateral for the repayment of many of our loans.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P8_S1	In determining the amount of the allowance for loan losses, we rely on our loan quality reviews and credit risk ratings, our experience and our evaluation of economic conditions, among other factors.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P8_S2	If our assumptions prove to be incorrect, or if delinquencies or non-accrual and non-performing loans increase, the allowance for loan losses may not be sufficient to cover losses inherent in our loan portfolio, resulting in additions to our allowance.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P8_S3	Material additions to the allowance would materially decrease our net income.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P8_S4	Our emphasis on the continued diversification of our loan portfolio through the origination of commercial mortgage loans, commercial loans, and construction loans has been one of the more significant factors we have taken into account in evaluating our allowance for loan losses and provision for loan losses.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P8_S5	In the event we were to further increase the amount of such types of loans in our portfolio, we may decide to make additional or increased provisions for loans losses, which could adversely affect our earnings.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P8_S6	In addition, bank regulators periodically review our allowance for loan losses and may require us to increase our provision for loan losses or recognize further loan charge-offs.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P8_S7	Any increase in our allowance for loan losses or loan charge-offs as required by these regulatory authorities could have a material adverse effect on our results of operations and financial condition.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P8_S8	A downturn in the housing sector and related markets and elevated unemployment levels may adversely affect our business and financial results.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P8_S9	Our lending business and investments in mortgage-backed securities are tied in large part to the housing market.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P8_S10	Lower home prices, a heightened level of foreclosures, the protracted foreclosure process or elevated unemployment levels would adversely impact the credit performance of real estate related loans and collateral values.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P8_S11	These conditions could potentially cause a reduction in loan demand, and increases in our non-performing assets, net charge-offs and provisions for loan losses.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P8_S12	Such negative economic conditions could adversely impact our prospects for growth, asset and goodwill valuations, and could result in a decrease in our interest income and a material increase in our provision for loan losses.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P8_S13	Our commercial real estate, multi-family, and commercial loans expose us to increased lending risks.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P8_S14	A significant portion of our loan portfolio consists of commercial real estate, multi-family, commercial and, to a lesser extent, construction loans.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P8_S15	These loans are generally regarded as having a higher risk of default and loss than single-family residential mortgage loans, because repayment of these loans often depends on the successful operation of a business or of the underlying property.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P8_S16	In addition, our construction loans, commercial mortgage loans, multi-family loans and commercial loans have significantly larger average loan balances compared to our single-family residential mortgage loans.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P8_S17	Also, many of our borrowers of these types of loans have more than one loan outstanding with us.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P8_S18	Consequently, any adverse development with respect to one loan or one credit relationship can expose us to a significantly greater risk of loss compared to an adverse development with respect to one single-family residential mortgage loan.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P8_S19	Our continuing concentration of loans in our primary market area may increase our risk.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P8_S20	Our success is significantly affected by general economic conditions in northern and central New Jersey, and with the acquisition of Team Capital Bank in 2014, eastern Pennsylvania.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P8_S21	Unlike some larger banks that are more geographically diversified, we provide banking and financial services to customers mostly located in our primary markets.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P8_S22	Consequently, a downturn in economic conditions in our local markets would have a significant impact on our loan portfolios, the ability of borrowers to repay their loans and the value of the collateral securing our loans.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P8_S23	Adverse local economic conditions caused by inflation, recession, unemployment or other factors beyond our control would impact these local economic conditions and could negatively affect the financial results of our banking operations.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P8_S24	Additionally, because we have a significant amount of real estate loans, depressed real estate values and real estate sales may also have a negative effect on the ability of many of our borrowers to make timely repayments of their loans, which would have an adverse impact on our earnings and overall financial condition.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P9_S0	We target our business development and marketing strategy for loans to serve primarily the banking and financial services needs of small- to medium-sized businesses in northern and central New Jersey and eastern Pennsylvania.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P9_S1	These small- to medium-sized businesses generally have fewer financial resources in terms of capital or borrowing capacity than larger entities.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P9_S2	If general economic conditions negatively impact these businesses, our results of operations and financial condition may be adversely affected.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P9_S3	Risks associated with cyber-security could negatively affect our earnings.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P10_S0	The financial services industry has experienced an increase in both the number and severity of reported cyber attacks aimed at gaining unauthorized access to bank systems as a way to misappropriate assets and sensitive information, corrupt and destroy data, or cause operational disruptions.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P11_S0	We have established policies and procedures to prevent or limit the impact of security breaches, but such events may still occur or may not be adequately addressed if they do occur.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P11_S1	Although we rely on security safeguards to secure our data, these safeguards may not fully protect our systems from compromises or breaches.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P11_S2	We also rely on the integrity and security of a variety of third party processers, payment, clearing and settlement systems, as well as the various participants involved in these systems, many of which have no direct relationship with us.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P11_S3	Failure by these participants or their systems to protect our customers transaction data may put us at risk for possible losses due to fraud or operational disruption.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P11_S4	Our customers are also the target of cyber attacks and identity theft.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P11_S5	Large scale identity theft could result in customers' accounts being compromised and fraudulent activities being performed in their name.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P11_S6	We have implemented certain safeguards against these types of activities but they may not fully protect us from fraudulent financial losses.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P11_S7	The occurrence of a breach of security involving our customers' information, regardless of its origin, could damage our reputation and result in a loss of customers and business and subject us to additional regulatory scrutiny, and could expose us to litigation and possible financial liability.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P11_S8	Any of these events could have a material adverse effect on our financial condition and results of operations.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P12_S0	Because the financial services business involves a high volume of transactions, we face significant operational risks.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P12_S1	We operate in diverse market segments and rely on the ability of our employees, systems and third party providers to process a high number of transactions.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P12_S2	Operational risk is the risk of loss resulting from our operations, including but not limited to, the risk of fraud by employees or persons outside our company, the execution of unauthorized transactions by employees, errors relating to transaction processing and technology, breaches of the internal control system and compliance requirements, the occurrence of systems failures and disruptions, and business continuation and disaster recovery.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P12_S3	Insurance coverage may not be available for such losses, or where available, such losses may exceed insurance limits.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P12_S4	This risk of loss also includes the potential legal actions that could arise as a result of an operational deficiency or as a result of noncompliance with applicable regulatory standards, adverse business decisions or their implementation, and customer attrition due to potential negative publicity.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P12_S5	In the event of a breakdown in the internal control system, improper operation of systems or improper employee actions, we could suffer financial loss, face regulatory action, and suffer damage to our reputation.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P12_S6	We operate in a highly regulated environment and may be adversely affected by changes in laws and regulations.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P12_S7	We are subject to extensive regulation, supervision and examination by the New Jersey Department of Banking and Insurance, our chartering authority, and by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, as insurer of our deposits.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P12_S8	As a bank holding company, we are subject to regulation and oversight by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P12_S9	Such regulation and supervision govern the activities in which a bank and its holding company may engage and are intended primarily for the protection of the insurance fund and depositors.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P12_S10	These regulatory authorities have extensive discretion in connection with their supervisory and enforcement activities, including the requirement for additional capital, the imposition of restrictions on our operations, the classification of our assets, the adequacy of our allowance for loan losses, and our management of risks posed by our reliance on third party vendors.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P12_S11	Any change in such regulation and oversight, whether in the form of regulatory policy, regulations, or legislation, could have a material impact on our operations.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P12_S12	The potential exists for additional Federal or state laws and regulations regarding capital requirements, lending and funding practices and liquidity standards, and bank regulatory agencies are expected to remain active in responding to concerns and trends identified in examinations, including the potential issuance of formal enforcement orders.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P13_S0	Actions taken to date, as well as potential actions, may not have the beneficial effects that are intended.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P13_S1	In addition, new laws, regulations, and other regulatory changes could increase our costs of regulatory compliance and of doing business, and otherwise affect our operations.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P13_S2	New laws, regulations, and other regulatory changes, may significantly affect the markets in which we do business, the markets for and value of our loans and investments, and our ongoing operations, costs and profitability.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P13_S3	The Dodd-Frank Act, among other things, created the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, tightened capital standards and resulted in new laws and regulations that are expected to increase our costs of operations.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P14_S0	The Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (the Dodd-Frank Act ) has significantly changed the bank regulatory structure and affected the lending, deposit, investment, trading and operating activities of financial institutions and their holding companies.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P14_S1	The Dodd-Frank Act requires various federal agencies to adopt a broad range of new implementing rules and regulations, and to prepare numerous studies and reports for Congress.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P14_S2	The federal agencies were given significant discretion in drafting the implementing rules and regulations, and consequently, many of the details and much of the impacts of the Dodd-Frank Act are still not known.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P14_S3	However, we expect the legislation and implementing regulations may materially increase our operating and compliance costs.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P15_S0	management frameworks and stress testing, all of which increase operating costs and reduce earnings.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P15_S1	As we approach $10 billion in assets, we will be required to incur additional costs to address these additional requirements.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P16_S0	The Dodd-Frank Act also created the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau with broad powers to supervise and enforce consumer protection laws.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P16_S1	The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has broad rule-making authority for a wide range of consumer protection laws that apply to all banks and savings institutions, including the authority to prohibit unfair, deceptive or abusive acts and practices.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P17_S0	The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has examination and enforcement authority over all banks with more than $10 billion in assets.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P18_S0	The Dodd-Frank Act requires minimum leverage (Tier 1) and risk-based capital requirements for bank and savings and loan holding companies that are no less than those applicable to banks, and directs the federal banking regulators to implement new leverage and capital requirements that take into account off-balance sheet activities and other risks, including risks relating to securitized products and derivatives.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P18_S1	The final rules implementing these requirements, will increase the regulatory capital requirements applicable to the Bank.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P18_S2	These final rules became effective on January 1, 2015, with certain aspects of the final rules being phased in through 2019.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P19_S0	Our risk management program may not be effective in mitigating risk and reducing the potential for significant losses.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P19_S1	Our risk management program is designed to minimize risk and loss to us.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P19_S2	We seek to identify, measure, monitor, report and control our exposure to risk, including strategic, market, liquidity, compliance and operational risks.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P19_S3	While we use a broad and diversified set of risk monitoring, modeling and mitigation techniques, these techniques are inherently limited because they cannot anticipate the existence or future development of currently unanticipated or unknown risks.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P19_S4	Recent economic conditions and heightened regulatory scrutiny of the financial services industry, among other developments, have increased our level of risk.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P19_S5	Accordingly, we could suffer losses as a result of our failure to properly anticipate and manage these risks.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P19_S6	We may fail to realize the anticipated benefits of a recently announced wealth management acquisition.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P19_S7	On January 5, 2015, we announced the proposed acquisition of The MDE Group, Inc. and Acertus Capital Management, LLC by Beacon Trust Company, our wholly owned subsidiary.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P19_S8	The proposed acquisition remains subject to regulatory approvals.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P19_S9	We anticipate completing the acquisition in the second quarter of 2015.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P19_S10	The success of the proposed acquisition will depend on, among other things, our ability to combine the businesses of MDE/Acertus and Beacon Trust in a manner that does not materially disrupt the customer relationships of either company.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P19_S11	If we are unable to successfully achieve this objective, the anticipated benefits of the proposed acquisition may not be realized fully or at all, or may take longer to realize than expected.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P19_S12	MDE/Acertus and Beacon Trust have operated and, until completion of the acquisition, will continue to operate, independently.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P20_S0	It is possible that the integration process related to the proposed acquisition may result in the loss of key personnel, the disruption of our existing or the acquired business or inconsistencies in standards, controls, procedures and policies that may adversely impact its ability to maintain relationships with customers and employees, or to achieve the anticipated benefits of the proposed acquisition.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P20_S1	A general economic slowdown could adversely impact our wealth management fee income A general economic slowdown could affect the value of the assets under management in our wealth management business resulting in lower fee income and the departure of clients to seeking alternative investment opportunities with other wealth managers.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P20_S2	Strong competition within our market area may limit our growth and profitability.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P21_S0	Competition in the banking and financial services industry is intense.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P21_S1	In our market area, we compete with commercial banks, savings institutions, mortgage banking firms, credit unions, finance companies, investment advisers, wealth managers, mutual funds, insurance companies, and brokerage and investment banking firms operating locally and elsewhere.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P21_S2	In particular, over the past decade, our local markets have experienced the effects of substantial banking consolidation, and large out-of-state competitors have grown significantly.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P21_S3	There are also a number of strong locally-based competitors in our market.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P21_S4	Many of these competitors have substantially greater resources and lending limits than we do, and may offer certain deposit and loan pricing, services or credit criteria that we do not or cannot provide.
1178970_15_ITEM1A_P21_S5	Our profitability depends upon our continued ability to successfully compete in our market area.
