1178970_15_ITEM8_P133_S0	The Bank has a noncontributory defined benefit pension plan covering its full-time employees who had attained age 21 with at least one year of service as of April 1, 2003.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P133_S1	The pension plan was frozen on April 1, 2003.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P134_S0	All participants in the pension plan are 100% vested.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P134_S1	The pension plan s assets are invested in investment funds and group annuity contracts currently managed by the Principal Financial Group and Allmerica Financial.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P134_S2	Based on the measurement date of December 31, 2014 , management believes that no contributions will be made to the pension plan in 2015 .
1178970_15_ITEM8_P135_S0	In an effort to lower and reduce the volatility of its future pension costs, the Company offered a lump sum pension distribution option to its vested terminated employees in the quarter ended June 30, 2014.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P135_S1	For the year ended December 31, 2014 , the Plan paid $4.3 million to those employees that elected to receive lump sum pension distributions and the Company realized an associated charge of $1.3 million .
1178970_15_ITEM8_P135_S2	This charge was a pro rata share of the unrecognized losses recorded in other comprehensive income.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P136_S0	In addition to pension benefits, certain healthcare and life insurance benefits are currently made available to certain of the Bank s retired employees.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P136_S1	The costs of such benefits are accrued based on actuarial assumptions from the date of hire to the date the employee is fully eligible to receive the benefits.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P137_S0	Effective January 1, 2003, eligibility for retiree health care benefits was frozen as to new entrants and benefits were eliminated for employees with less than ten years of service as of December 31, 2002.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P137_S1	Effective January 1, 2007, eligibility for retiree life insurance benefits was frozen to new entrants and retiree life insurance benefits were eliminated for employees with less than ten years of service as of December 31, 2006.

1178970_15_ITEM8_P140_S0	The weighted average actuarial assumptions used in the plan determinations at December 31, 2014 , 2013 and 2012 were as follows:
1178970_15_ITEM8_P141_S0	The Company provides its actuary with certain rate assumptions used in measuring the benefit obligation.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P141_S1	The most significant of these is the discount rate used to calculate the period-end present value of the benefit obligations, and the expense to be included in the following year s financial statements.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P141_S2	A lower discount rate will result in a higher benefit obligation and expense, while a higher discount rate will result in a lower benefit obligation and expense.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P141_S3	The discount rate assumption was determined based on a cash flow-yield curve model specific to the Company s pension and post-retirement plans.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P141_S4	The Company compares this rate to certain market indices, such as long-term treasury bonds, or the Citigroup pension liability indices, for reasonableness.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P141_S5	A discount rate of 4.00% was selected for the December 31, 2014 measurement date and the 2013 expense calculation.

1178970_15_ITEM8_P145_S0	The Company s expected return on pension plan assets assumption is based on historical investment return experience and evaluation of input from the Investment Consultant and Committee managing the pension plan s assets.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P145_S1	The expected return on pension plan assets is also impacted by the target allocation of assets, which is based on the Company s goal of earning the highest rate of return while maintaining risk at acceptable levels.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P145_S2	Management strives to have pension plan assets sufficiently diversified so that adverse or unexpected results from one security class will not have a significant detrimental impact on the entire portfolio.

1178970_15_ITEM8_P150_S0	The Bank maintains a non-qualified supplemental retirement plan for certain senior officers of the Bank.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P150_S1	This plan was frozen as of April 1, 2003.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P151_S0	The Supplemental Executive Retirement Plan, which is unfunded, provides benefits in excess of the benefits permitted to be paid by the pension plan under provisions of the tax law.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P151_S1	Amounts expensed under this supplemental retirement plan amounted to $102,000 , $162,000 and $169,000 for the years 2014 , 2013 and 2012 , respectively.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P151_S2	At December 31, 2014 , and 2013 , $2,166,000 and $2,207,000 , respectively, were recorded in other liabilities on the consolidated statements of condition for this supplemental retirement plan.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P151_S3	A decrease of $198,000 , an increase of $56,000 , and a decrease of $49,000 , net of tax, were recorded in other comprehensive income for 2014 , 2013 and 2012 , respectively, in connection with this supplemental retirement plan.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P152_S0	The Bank maintains a Retirement Plan for the Board of Directors of the Bank, a non-qualified plan that provides cash payments for up to 10 years to eligible retired board members based on age and length of service requirements.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P152_S1	The maximum payment under this plan to a board member, who terminates service on or after the age of 72 with at least ten years of service on the board, is forty quarterly payments of $1,250 .
1178970_15_ITEM8_P152_S2	The Bank may suspend payments under this plan if it does not meet Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation or New Jersey Department of Banking and Insurance minimum capital requirements.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P152_S3	The Bank may terminate this plan at any time although such termination may not reduce or eliminate any benefit previously accrued to a board member without his or her consent.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P152_S4	The plan further provides that, in the event of a change in control (as defined in the plan), the undistributed balance of a director s accrued benefit will be distributed to him or her within 60 days of the change in control.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P152_S5	The Bank paid $15,000 to former board members under this plan for each of the years ended December 31, 2014 , 2013 and 2012 .
1178970_15_ITEM8_P152_S6	At December 31, 2014 and 2013 , $169,000 and $181,000 , respectively, were recorded in other liabilities on the consolidated statements of financial condition for this retirement plan.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P152_S7	A decrease of $7,400 , an increase of $6,000 , and an increase of $3,000 , net of tax, were recorded in other comprehensive income for 2014 , 2013 and 2012 , respectively, in connection with this plan.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P153_S0	The plan was amended in December 2005 to terminate benefits under this plan for any directors who had less than ten years of service on the board of directors of the Bank as of December 31, 2006.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P154_S0	The ESOP is a tax-qualified plan designed to invest primarily in the Company s common stock that provides employees with the opportunity to receive a funded retirement benefit from the Bank, based primarily on the value of the Company s common stock.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P154_S1	The ESOP purchased 4,769,464 shares of the Company s common stock at an average price of $17.09 per share with the proceeds of a loan from the Company to the ESOP.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P154_S2	The outstanding loan principal at December 31, 2014 , was $53.4 million .
1178970_15_ITEM8_P154_S3	Shares of the Company s common stock pledged as collateral for the loan are released from the pledge for allocation to participants as loan payments are made.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P154_S4	For the ESOP years ending December 31, 2014 and 2013 , 201,512 shares and 195,065 shares were released, respectively.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P154_S5	Unallocated ESOP shares held in suspense totaled 2,652,045 at December 31, 2014 , and had a fair value of $47.9 million .
1178970_15_ITEM8_P154_S6	ESOP compensation expense for the years ended December 31, 2014 , 2013 and 2012 was $2,654,000 , $2,559,000 and $2,030,000 , respectively.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P155_S0	The Supplemental Executive Savings Plan is a non-qualified plan that provides supplemental benefits to certain executives who are prevented from receiving the full benefits contemplated by the 401(k) Plan s and the ESOP s benefit formulas under tax law limits for tax-qualified plans.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P155_S1	The Supplemental Executive Savings Plan was frozen effective December 31, 2003, and all benefit distributions have been made.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P156_S0	Effective January 1, 2004, the Bank established a deferred compensation plan for executive management and key employees of the Bank, known as The Provident Bank Non-Qualified Supplemental Employee Stock Ownership Plan (the Supplemental ESOP ).
1178970_15_ITEM8_P156_S1	The Supplemental ESOP was amended and restated as the Non-Qualified Supplemental Defined Contribution Plan (the Supplemental DC Plan ), effective January 1, 2010.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P156_S2	The Supplemental DC Plan is a non-qualified plan that provides additional benefits to certain executives whose benefits under the 401(k) Plan and ESOP are limited by tax law limitations applicable to tax-qualified plans.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P156_S3	The Supplemental DC Plan requires a contribution by the Bank for each participant who also participates in the 401(k) Plan and ESOP equal to the amount that would have been contributed under the terms of the of the 401(k) Plan and ESOP but for the tax law limitations, less the amount actually contributed under the 401(k) Plan and ESOP.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P156_S4	The Supplemental DC Plan provides for a phantom stock allocation for qualified contributions that may not be accrued in the qualified ESOP and for matching contributions that may not be accrued in the qualified 401(k) Plan due to tax law limitations.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P156_S5	Under the Supplemental 401(k) provision, the estimated expense for the year ending December 31, 2014 , 2013 and 2012 was $10,500 , $7,000 and $7,500 , respectively, and included the matching contributions plus interest credited at an annual rate equal to the ten-year bond-equivalent yield on U.S. Treasury securities.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P156_S6	Under the Supplemental ESOP provision, the estimated expense for the year ending December 31, 2014 , 2013 and 2012 was $48,000 , $45,000 and $28,000 , respectively.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P156_S7	The phantom equity is treated as equity awards (expensed at the time of allocation) and not liability awards which would require periodic adjustment to market, as participants do not have an option to take their distribution in cash.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P157_S0	The Amended and Restated Long-Term Incentive Plan Upon stockholders approval of the Amended and Restated Long-Term Incentive Plan on April 4, 2014, shares available for stock awards and stock options under the 2008 Long-Term Equity Incentive Plan were reserved for issuance under the new Amended and Restated Long-Term Incentive Plan.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P157_S1	No additional grants of stock awards and stock options will be made under the 2008 Long-Term Equity Incentive Plan.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P157_S2	The new plan authorized the issuance of up to 3,686,510 shares of Company common stock with no more than 2,100,000 shares permitted to be issued as stock awards.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P157_S3	Shares previously awarded under the 2008 plans that are subsequently forfeited or expire may also be issued under the new plan.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P158_S0	Stock Awards As a general rule, restricted stock grants are held in escrow for the benefit of the award recipient until vested.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P158_S1	Awards outstanding generally vest in three or five annual installments, commencing one year from the date of the award.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P159_S0	Expense attributable to stock awards amounted to $6,359,000 , $4,869,000 and $3,658,000 for the years ended December 31, 2014 , 2013 and 2012 , respectively.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P159_S1	A summary status of the granted but unvested stock awards as of December 31, and changes during the year, is presented below:
1178970_15_ITEM8_P160_S0	As of December 31, 2014 , unrecognized compensation cost relating to unvested restricted stock totaled $1.1 million .
1178970_15_ITEM8_P160_S1	This amount will be recognized over a remaining weighted average period of 1.1 years.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P161_S0	Each stock option granted entitles the holder to purchase one share of the Company s common stock at an exercise price not less than the fair value of a share of the Company s common stock at the date of grant.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P161_S1	Options generally vest over a five -year period from the date of grant and expire no later than 10 years following the grant date.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P161_S2	Additionally, certain options are three-year performance vesting options, which may or may not vest depending upon the attainment of certain corporate financial targets.

1178970_15_ITEM8_P164_S0	The expense related to stock options is based on the fair value of the options at the date of the grant and is recognized ratably over the vesting period of the options.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P164_S1	Compensation expense related to the Company s stock option plan totaled $298,000 , $297,000 and $452,000 for 2014 , 2013 and 2012 , respectively.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P164_S2	The estimated fair values were determined on the dates of grant using the Black-Scholes Option pricing model.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P165_S0	The fair value of the Company stock option awards are expensed on a straight-line basis over the vesting period of the stock option.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P165_S1	The risk-free rate is based on the implied yield on a U.S. Treasury bond with a term approximating the expected term of the option.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P165_S2	The expected volatility computation is based on historical volatility over a period approximating the expected term of the option.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P165_S3	The dividend yield is based on the annual dividend payment per share, divided by the grant date stock price.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P166_S0	The expected option term is a function of the option life and the vesting period.

1178970_15_ITEM8_P168_S0	The weighted average fair value of options granted during 2014 , 2013 and 2012 was $1.64 , $3.49 and $3.37 per option, respectively.

1178970_15_ITEM8_P174_S1	This amount represented an allocation of income to bad debt deductions for tax purposes only.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P174_S2	Events that would result in taxation of these reserves include the failure to qualify as a bank for tax purposes, distributions in complete or partial liquidation, stock redemptions and excess distributions to stockholders.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P174_S3	At December 31, 2014 , the Company had an unrecognized tax liability of $21,160,000 with respect to this reserve.

1178970_15_ITEM8_P174_S6	There are approximately $3,900,000 available to offset future taxable income as of December 31, 2014 .
1178970_15_ITEM8_P174_S7	If not utilized, these carryforwards will expire in 2030.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P174_S8	Also, the Company New Jersey NOL carryforwards in the amount of $3,300,000 which are scheduled to expire in 2033 and Pennsylvania NOL carryforwards in the amount of $3,000,000 , which are set to expire in 2016.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P175_S0	The federal NOLs are subject to a combined annual Code Section 382 limitation in the amount of approximately $900,000 .
1178970_15_ITEM8_P176_S0	Management has determined that it is more likely than not that it will realize the net deferred tax asset based upon the nature and timing of the items listed above.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P176_S1	In order to fully realize the net deferred tax asset, the Company will need to generate future taxable income.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P176_S2	Management has projected that the Company will generate sufficient taxable income to utilize the net deferred tax asset; however, there can be no assurance that such levels of taxable income will be generated.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P177_S0	The Company s policy is to report interest and penalties, if any, related to unrecognized tax benefits in income tax expense.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P177_S1	The Company did not have any liabilities for uncertain tax positions or any known unrecognized tax benefits at December 31, 2014 and 2013 .
1178970_15_ITEM8_P178_S0	The Company and its subsidiaries file a consolidated U.S. Federal income tax return and each entity files a separate state income tax return.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P178_S1	The Company and its subsidiaries are no longer subject to income tax examinations by taxing authorities for years prior to 2011.

1178970_15_ITEM8_P181_S0	In the normal course of business, various commitments and contingent liabilities are outstanding which are not reflected in the accompanying consolidated financial statements.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P181_S1	In the opinion of management, the consolidated financial position of the Company will not be materially affected by the outcome of such commitments or contingent liabilities.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P182_S0	A substantial portion of the Bank s loans are one- to four-family residential first mortgage loans secured by real estate located in New Jersey.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P182_S1	Accordingly, the collectability of a substantial portion of the Bank s loan portfolio and the recovery of a substantial portion of the carrying amount of other real estate owned are susceptible to changes in local real estate market conditions.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P183_S0	(15) Regulatory Capital Requirements FDIC regulations require banks to maintain minimum levels of regulatory capital.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P183_S1	Under the regulations in effect at December 31, 2014 and 2013 , the Bank is required to maintain (i) a minimum leverage ratio of Tier 1 capital to total adjusted assets of 4.00% , and (ii) minimum ratios of Tier 1 and total capital to risk-weighted assets of 4.00% and 8.00% , respectively.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P184_S0	Under its prompt corrective action regulations, the FDIC is required to take certain supervisory actions (and may take additional discretionary actions) with respect to an undercapitalized institution.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P184_S1	Such actions could have a direct material effect on an institution s financial statements.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P185_S0	The regulations establish a framework for the classification of savings institutions into five categories: well capitalized, adequately capitalized, undercapitalized, significantly undercapitalized, and critically undercapitalized.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P186_S0	Generally, an institution is considered well capitalized if it has a leverage (Tier 1) capital ratio of at least 5.00% ; a Tier 1 risk-based capital ratio of at least 6.00% ; and a total risk-based capital ratio of at least 10.00% .
1178970_15_ITEM8_P187_S0	The foregoing capital ratios are based in part on specific quantitative measures of assets, liabilities and certain off-balance sheet items as calculated under regulatory accounting practices.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P187_S1	Capital amounts and classifications are also subject to qualitative judgments by the FDIC about capital components, risk weightings and other factors.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P187_S2	As of December 31, 2014 and 2013 , the Bank exceeded all minimum capital adequacy requirements to which it is subject.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P187_S3	Further, the most recent FDIC notification categorized the Bank as a well-capitalized institution under the prompt corrective action regulations.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P187_S4	There have been no conditions or events since that notification that management believes have changed the Bank s capital classification.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P188_S0	The Company is regulated as a bank holding company, and as such, is subject to examination, regulation and periodic reporting under the Bank Holding Company Act, as administered by the Federal Reserve Board ( FRB ).
1178970_15_ITEM8_P188_S1	The FRB has adopted capital adequacy guidelines for bank holding companies on a consolidated basis substantially similar to those of the FDIC for the Bank.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P188_S2	As of December 31, 2014 and 2013 , the Company was well capitalized under FRB guidelines.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P189_S0	Regulations of the FRB provide that a bank holding company must serve as a source of strength to any of its subsidiary banks and must not conduct its activities in an unsafe or unsound manner.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P189_S1	Under the prompt corrective action provisions discussed above, a bank holding company parent of an undercapitalized subsidiary bank would be directed to guarantee, within limitations, the capital restoration plan that is required of such an undercapitalized bank.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P189_S2	If the undercapitalized bank fails to file an acceptable capital restoration plan or fails to implement an accepted plan, the FRB may prohibit the bank holding company parent of the undercapitalized bank from paying any dividend or making any other form of capital distribution without the prior approval of the FRB.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P190_S0	The following is a summary of the Company s actual capital amounts and ratios as of December 31, 2014 and 2013 , compared to the FRB minimum capital adequacy requirements and the FRB requirements for classification as a well-capitalized institution (dollars in thousands).
1178970_15_ITEM8_P191_S0	The following is a summary of the Bank s actual capital amounts and ratios as of December 31, 2014 and 2013 , compared to the FDIC minimum capital adequacy requirements and the FDIC requirements for classification as a well-capitalized institution (dollars in thousands).
1178970_15_ITEM8_P192_S0	The Company utilizes fair value measurements to record fair value adjustments to certain assets and liabilities and to determine fair value disclosures.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P192_S1	The determination of fair values of financial instruments often requires the use of estimates.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P192_S2	Where quoted market values in an active market are not readily available, the Company utilizes various valuation techniques to estimate fair value.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P192_S3	Fair value is an estimate of the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P192_S4	However, in many instances fair value estimates may not be substantiated by comparison to independent markets and may not be realized in an immediate sale of the financial instrument.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P193_S0	GAAP establishes a fair value hierarchy that prioritizes the inputs to valuation techniques used to measure fair value.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P193_S1	The hierarchy gives the highest priority to unadjusted quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities (Level 1 measurements) and the lowest priority to unobservable inputs (Level 3 measurements).
1178970_15_ITEM8_P194_S0	Level 3: Prices or valuation techniques that require inputs that are both significant to the fair value measurement and unobservable (i.e., supported by little or no market activity).
1178970_15_ITEM8_P195_S0	A financial instrument s level within the fair value hierarchy is based on the lowest level of input that is significant to the fair value measurement.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P195_S1	The valuation techniques are based upon the unpaid principal balance only, and exclude any accrued interest or dividends at the measurement date.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P195_S2	Interest income and expense and dividend income are recorded within the consolidated statements of income depending on the nature of the instrument using the effective interest method based on acquired discount or premium.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P196_S0	The valuation techniques described below were used to measure fair value of financial instruments in the table below on a recurring basis as of December 31, 2014 and December 31, 2013 .
1178970_15_ITEM8_P197_S0	Securities Available for Sale For securities available for sale, fair value was estimated using a market approach.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P197_S1	he majority of the Company s securities are fixed income instruments that are not quoted on an exchange, but are traded in active markets.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P197_S2	Prices for these instruments are obtained through third party data service providers or dealer market participants with which the Company has historically transacted both purchases and sales of securities.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P197_S3	Prices obtained from these sources include market quotations and matrix pricing.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P198_S0	Matrix pricing, a Level 2 input, is a mathematical technique used principally to value certain securities to benchmark or to comparable securities.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P198_S1	The Company evaluates the quality of Level 2 matrix pricing through comparison to similar assets with greater liquidity and evaluation of projected cash flows.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P198_S2	As the Company is responsible for the determination of fair value, it performs quarterly analyses on the prices received from the pricing service to determine whether the prices are reasonable estimates of fair value.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P198_S3	Specifically, the Company compares the prices received from the pricing service to a secondary pricing source.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P198_S4	Additionally, the Company compares changes in the reported market values and returns to relevant market indices to test the reasonableness of the reported prices.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P198_S5	The Company s internal price verification procedures and review of fair value methodology documentation provided by independent pricing services has not historically resulted in adjustment in the prices obtained from the pricing service.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P198_S6	The Company also may hold equity securities and debt instruments issued by the U.S. government and U.S. government-sponsored agencies that are traded in active markets with readily accessible quoted market prices that are considered Level 1 inputs.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P199_S0	Derivatives The Company records all derivatives on the balance sheet at fair value.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P199_S1	The accounting for changes in the fair value of derivatives depends on the intended use of the derivative, whether the Company has elected to designate a derivative in a hedging relationship and apply hedge accounting and whether the hedging relationship has satisfied the criteria necessary to apply hedge accounting.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P199_S2	Currently, none of the Company s derivatives are designated in qualifying hedging relationships.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P199_S3	The existing interest rate derivatives result from a service provided to certain qualifying borrowers in a loan related transaction and, therefore, are not used to manage interest rate risk in the Company s assets or liabilities.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P199_S4	As such, all changes in fair value of the Company s derivatives are recognized directly in earnings.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P200_S0	The fair value of the Company's derivatives are determined using discounted cash flow analysis using observable market-based inputs, which are considered Level 2 inputs.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P201_S0	The valuation techniques described below were used to estimate fair value of financial instruments measured on a non-recurring basis as of December 31, 2014 and 2013 .
1178970_15_ITEM8_P201_S1	Collateral Dependent Impaired Loans For loans measured for impairment based on the fair value of the underlying collateral, fair value was estimated using a market approach.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P201_S2	The Company measures the fair value of collateral underlying impaired loans primarily through obtaining independent appraisals that rely upon quoted market prices for similar assets in active markets.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P201_S3	These appraisals include adjustments, on an individual case-by-case basis, to comparable assets based on the appraisers market knowledge and experience, as well as adjustments for estimated costs to sell of up to 6% .
1178970_15_ITEM8_P201_S4	The Company classifies these loans as Level 3 within the fair value hierarchy.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P202_S0	Foreclosed Assets Assets acquired through foreclosure or deed in lieu of foreclosure are carried at fair value, less estimated costs to sell of up to 6% .
1178970_15_ITEM8_P202_S1	Fair value is generally based on independent appraisals that rely upon quoted market prices for similar assets in active markets.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P202_S2	These appraisals include adjustments, on an individual case basis, to comparable assets based on the appraisers market knowledge and experience, and are classified as Level 3.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P203_S0	When an asset is acquired, the excess of the loan balance over fair value, less estimated costs to sell, is charged to the allowance for loan losses.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P204_S0	A reserve for foreclosed assets may be established to provide for possible write-downs and selling costs that occur subsequent to foreclosure.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P204_S1	Foreclosed assets are carried net of the related reserve.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P205_S0	Operating results from real estate owned, including rental income, operating expenses, and gains and losses realized from the sales of real estate owned, are recorded as incurred.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P205_S1	There were no changes to the valuation techniques for fair value measurements during the years ended December 31, 2014 and 2013 .
1178970_15_ITEM8_P206_S0	The following tables present the assets and liabilities reported on the consolidated statements of financial condition at their fair value as of December 31, 2014 and 2013 , by level within the fair value hierarchy (in thousands).
1178970_15_ITEM8_P207_S0	There were no transfers between Level 1 and Level 2 during the years ended December 31, 2014 and 2013 .
1178970_15_ITEM8_P208_S0	Other Fair Value Disclosures The Company is required to disclose estimated fair value of financial instruments, both assets and liabilities on and off the balance sheet, for which it is practicable to estimate fair value.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P208_S1	The following is a description of valuation methodologies used for those assets and liabilities.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P209_S0	Cash and Cash Equivalents For cash and due from banks, federal funds sold and short-term investments, the carrying amount approximates fair value.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P210_S0	Investment Securities Held to Maturity For investment securities held to maturity, fair value was estimated using a market approach.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P211_S0	The majority of the Company s securities are fixed income instruments that are not quoted on an exchange, but are traded in active markets.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P211_S1	Prices for these instruments are obtained through third party data service providers or dealer market participants with which the Company has historically transacted both purchases and sales of securities.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P211_S2	Prices obtained from these sources include market quotations and matrix pricing.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P212_S0	Matrix pricing, a Level 2 input, is a mathematical technique used principally to value certain securities to benchmark or comparable securities.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P212_S1	The Company evaluates the quality of Level 2 matrix pricing through comparison to similar assets with greater liquidity and evaluation of projected cash flows.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P212_S2	As the Company is responsible for the determination of fair value, it performs quarterly analyses on the prices received from the pricing service to determine whether the prices are reasonable estimates of fair value.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P212_S3	Specifically, the Company compares the prices received from the pricing service to a secondary pricing source.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P212_S4	Additionally, the Company compares changes in the reported market values and returns to relevant market indices to test the reasonableness of the reported prices.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P212_S5	The Company s internal price verification procedures and review of fair value methodology documentation provided by independent pricing services has not historically resulted in adjustment in the prices obtained from the pricing service.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P212_S6	The Company also holds debt instruments issued by the U.S. government and U.S. government agencies that are traded in active markets with readily accessible quoted market prices that are considered Level 1 within the fair value hierarchy.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P213_S0	The carrying value of FHLBNY stock was its cost.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P213_S1	The fair value of FHLBNY stock is based on redemption at par value.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P213_S2	The Company classifies the estimated fair value as Level 1 within the fair value hierarchy.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P214_S0	Loans Fair values are estimated for portfolios of loans with similar financial characteristics.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P214_S1	Loans are segregated by type such as commercial mortgage, residential mortgage, commercial, construction and consumer.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P214_S2	Each loan category is further segmented into fixed and adjustable rate interest terms and into performing and non-performing categories.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P214_S3	The fair value of performing loans was estimated using a combination of techniques, including a discounted cash flow model that utilizes a discount rate that reflects the Company s current pricing for loans with similar characteristics and remaining maturity, adjusted by an amount for estimated credit losses inherent in the portfolio at the balance sheet date.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P214_S4	The rates take into account the expected yield curve, as well as an adjustment for prepayment risk, when applicable.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P215_S0	The Company classifies the estimated fair value of its loan portfolio as Level 3.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P215_S1	The fair value for significant non-performing loans was based on recent external appraisals of collateral securing such loans, adjusted for the timing of anticipated cash flows.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P215_S2	The Company classifies the estimated fair value of its non-performing loan portfolio as Level 3.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P215_S3	Deposits The fair value of deposits with no stated maturity, such as non-interest bearing demand deposits and savings deposits, was equal to the amount payable on demand and classified as Level 1.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P215_S4	The estimated fair value of certificates of deposit was based on the discounted value of contractual cash flows.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P215_S5	The discount rate was estimated using the Company s current rates offered for deposits with similar remaining maturities.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P216_S0	The Company classifies the estimated fair value of its certificates of deposit portfolio as Level 2.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P216_S1	The fair value of borrowed funds was estimated by discounting future cash flows using rates available for debt with similar terms and maturities and is classified by the Company as Level 2 within the fair value hierarchy.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P217_S0	For fixed rate loan commitments, fair value also considers the difference between current levels of interest rates and the committed rates.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P217_S1	The fair value estimates of commitments to extend credit and letters of credit are deemed immaterial.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P217_S2	Limitations Fair value estimates are made at a specific point in time, based on relevant market information and information about the financial instrument.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P217_S3	These estimates do not reflect any premium or discount that could result from offering for sale at one time the Company s entire holdings of a particular financial instrument.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P218_S0	Because no market exists for a significant portion of the Company s financial instruments, fair value estimates are based on judgments regarding future expected loss experience, current economic conditions, risk characteristics of various financial instruments, and other factors.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P218_S1	These estimates are subjective in nature and involve uncertainties and matters of significant judgment and, therefore, cannot be determined with precision.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P218_S2	Changes in assumptions could significantly affect the estimates.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P219_S0	Fair value estimates are based on existing on- and off-balance sheet financial instruments without attempting to estimate the value of anticipated future business and the value of assets and liabilities that are not considered financial instruments.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P219_S1	Significant assets and liabilities that are not considered financial assets or liabilities include goodwill and other intangibles, deferred tax assets and premises and equipment.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P219_S2	In addition, the tax ramifications related to the realization of the unrealized gains and losses can have a significant effect on fair value estimates and have not been considered in the estimates.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P220_S0	The following tables present the Company s financial instruments at their carrying and fair values as of December 31, 2014 and December 31, 2013 .
1178970_15_ITEM8_P220_S1	Fair values are presented by level within the fair value hierarchy.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P221_S0	The following tables are a summary of certain quarterly financial data for the years ended December 31, 2014 and 2013 .

1178970_15_ITEM8_P227_S0	(1) This item is included in the computation of net periodic benefit cost.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P228_S0	The Company is exposed to certain risks arising from both its business operations and economic conditions.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P228_S1	The Company principally manages its exposures to a wide variety of business and operational risks through management of its core business activities.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P228_S2	The Company manages economic risks, including interest rate, liquidity, and credit risk, primarily by managing the amount, sources, and duration of its assets and liabilities.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P228_S3	The Company s existing interest rate derivatives result from a service provided to certain qualifying borrowers in a loan related transaction and, therefore, are not used to manage interest rate risk in the Company s assets or liabilities.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P228_S4	The Company manages a matched book with respect to its derivative instruments in order to minimize its net risk exposure resulting from such transactions.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P228_S5	The table below presents the fair value of the Company s derivative financial instruments as well as their classification on the Consolidated Statements of Financial Condition as of December 31, 2014 (in thousands):
1178970_15_ITEM8_P229_S0	Fair Value Derivatives not designated as a hedging instruments:
1178970_15_ITEM8_P230_S0	None of the Company s derivatives are designated in qualifying hedging relationships.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P230_S1	Derivatives not designated as hedges are not speculative and result from a service the Company provides to certain customers, which the Company implemented during 2014.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P231_S0	The Company executes interest rate swaps with commercial banking customers to facilitate their respective risk management strategies.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P231_S1	Those interest rate swaps are simultaneously hedged by offsetting interest rate swaps that the Company executes with a third party, such that the Company minimizes its net risk exposure resulting from such transactions.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P231_S2	As the interest rate swaps associated with this program do not meet the strict hedge accounting requirements, changes in the fair value of both the customer swaps and the offsetting swaps are recognized directly in earnings.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P231_S3	As of December 31, 2014 , the Company had nine interest rate swaps with an aggregate notional amount of $94.9 million related to this program.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P232_S0	The tables below present the effect of the Company s derivative financial instruments on the Consolidated Statements of Income for the year ended December 31, 2014 (in thousands).
1178970_15_ITEM8_P233_S0	Year ended December 31, 2014 Derivatives not designated as a hedging instruments:
1178970_15_ITEM8_P234_S0	The Company has agreements with certain of its derivative counterparties that contain a provision that if the Company defaults on any of its indebtedness, including default where repayment of the indebtedness has not been accelerated by the lender, then the Company could also be declared in default on its derivative obligations.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P234_S1	The Company also has agreements with certain of its derivative counterparties that contain a provision that if the Company fails to maintain its status as a well / adequate capitalized institution, then the counterparty could terminate the derivative positions and the Company would be required to settle its obligations under the agreements.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P235_S0	As of December 31, 2014 , the termination value of derivatives in a net liability position, which includes accrued interest but excludes any adjustment for nonperformance risk, related to these agreements was $2,084,000 .
1178970_15_ITEM8_P235_S1	The Company has minimum collateral posting thresholds with certain of its derivative counterparties, and has posted collateral of $1,250,000 against its obligations under these agreements.
1178970_15_ITEM8_P235_S2	If the Company had breached any of these provisions at December 31, 2014 , it could have been required to settle its obligations under the agreements at the termination value.
1178970_15_ITEM9A_P0_S0	Evaluation of Disclosure Controls and Procedures Christopher Martin, the Company s Principal Executive Officer, and Thomas M. Lyons, the Company s Principal Accounting Officer, conducted an evaluation of the effectiveness of the Company s disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Rule 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended) as of December 31, 2014 .
1178970_15_ITEM9A_P0_S1	Based upon their evaluation, they each found that the Company s disclosure controls and procedures were effective.
1178970_15_ITEM9A_P1_S0	The management of Provident Financial Services, Inc. (the Company ) is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting.
1178970_15_ITEM9A_P1_S1	The Company s internal control system is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance to the Company s management and board of directors regarding the preparation and fair presentation of published financial statements.
1178970_15_ITEM9A_P1_S2	The Company s internal control over financial reporting includes policies and procedures that pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect transactions and dispositions of assets; provide reasonable assurances that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and the directors of the Company; and provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use or disposition of the Company s assets that could have a material effect on its financial statements.
1178970_15_ITEM9A_P1_S3	All internal control systems, no matter how well designed, have inherent limitations.
1178970_15_ITEM9A_P1_S4	Therefore, even those systems determined to be effective can provide only reasonable assurance with respect to financial statement preparation and presentation.
1178970_15_ITEM9A_P1_S5	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
1178970_15_ITEM9A_P2_S0	During the fourth quarter management identified a material weakness in internal control relating to the determination of the qualitative factors considered by management in the allowance for loan loss estimation process.
1178970_15_ITEM9A_P2_S1	No restatement of prior period financial statements and no change in previously released financial results were required as a result of this finding.
1178970_15_ITEM9A_P2_S2	Management remediated this weakness by enhancing the documentation and controls over the process supporting the qualitative factors considered in the estimation of the allowance for loan losses.
1178970_15_ITEM9A_P2_S3	Except for the foregoing, there was no change in the Company s internal control over financial reporting in the quarter ended December 31, 2014 that has materially affected, or is reasonably likely to materially affect, the Company s internal control over financial reporting.
1178970_15_ITEM9A_P3_S0	Management assessed the effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2014 In making this assessment, we used the criteria set forth by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission in Internal Control-Integrated Framework ( COSO ) (1992).
1178970_15_ITEM9A_P3_S1	Based on the assessment management believes that, as of December 31, 2014 , the Company s internal control over financial reporting is effective based on those criteria.
1178970_15_ITEM9A_P3_S2	The Company s independent registered public accounting firm that audited the consolidated financial statements has issued an audit report on the effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2014 .
1178970_15_ITEM9A_P3_S3	This report appears on page 57.

1178970_15_ITEM15_P16_S0	On January 29, 2015, the Company s Board of Directors, on the recommendation of its Compensation Committee, approved an annual performance-based incentive plan for the payment of incentive cash compensation to certain officers and employees of The Provident Bank, the Company s wholly owned savings bank subsidiary (the Plan ), including senior executive officers.
1178970_15_ITEM15_P16_S1	The Plan provides for cash incentive payments based primarily on the Company s 2015 financial performance compared with certain targets (the Corporate Targets ).
1178970_15_ITEM15_P16_S2	Incentive Payments based on the Company s 2015 financial performance may be made if the Company meets or exceeds 90% of any of the Corporate Targets ( Threshold ).
1178970_15_ITEM15_P16_S3	For senior executive officers (including the Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer and the Chief Financial Officer), 100% of the incentive payment that may be made under the Plan will be based on the Company s 2015 performance using the following Corporate Targets that relate to the Company s business plan and strategic objectives: (i) earnings per share (weighted 40%); (ii) net income (weighted 40%); and (iii) efficiency ratio (weighted 20%).
1178970_15_ITEM15_P16_S4	For other officers and employees eligible to participate in the Plan, a portion of the incentive payment that may be made under the Plan will be based on the Company s 2015 performance using the same Corporate Targets.
1178970_15_ITEM15_P16_S5	A portion of the incentive payment will also be based on individual performance against personal goals and objectives, and may be paid whether or not Corporate Targets have been met.
1178970_15_ITEM15_P16_S6	Incentive payments will be a percentage of the employee s base salary.
1178970_15_ITEM15_P16_S7	Using estimated 2015 base salary levels and the current number of employees that could participate in the Plan (520 persons), the total cash incentive payments that may be made for 2015 would range from approximately $1.8 million at the Threshold level up to $13.3 million at the Maximum level.
