1178970_16_ITEM1A_P26_S0	The second step test compares the implied fair value of the reporting unit s goodwill with the carrying amount of that goodwill.
1178970_16_ITEM1A_P26_S1	An impairment loss would be recorded to the extent that the carrying amount of goodwill exceeds its implied value.
1178970_16_ITEM1A_P27_S0	Fair value may be determined using market prices, comparison to similar assets, market multiples, discounted cash flow analysis and other factors.
1178970_16_ITEM1A_P28_S0	Estimated cash flows may extend far into the future and by their nature are difficult to determine over an extended time frame.
1178970_16_ITEM1A_P28_S1	Factors that may significantly affect the estimates include specific industry or market sector conditions, changes in revenue growth trends, customer behavior, competitive forces, cost structures and changes in discount rates.
1178970_16_ITEM1A_P28_S2	It is possible that our future impairment testing could result in an impairment of the value of goodwill or other identified intangible assets, or both.
1178970_16_ITEM1A_P28_S3	If we determine impairment exists at a given point in time, our earnings and the book value of the related intangible asset(s) will be reduced by the amount of the impairment.
1178970_16_ITEM1A_P28_S4	In any event, the results of impairment testing on goodwill and other identified intangible assets have no impact on our tangible book value or regulatory capital levels.
1178970_16_ITEM1B_P0_S0	There are no unresolved comments from the staff of the SEC to report.
1178970_16_ITEM2_P0_S0	Property At December 31, 2015 , the Bank conducted business through 87 full-service branch offices located in Hudson, Bergen, Essex, Hunterdon, Mercer, Middlesex, Monmouth, Morris, Ocean, Passaic, Somerset, Union and Warren counties in New Jersey, and in Bucks, Lehigh and Northampton counties in Pennsylvania.
1178970_16_ITEM2_P0_S1	The aggregate net book value of premises and equipment was $ 89.0 million at December 31, 2015 .
1178970_16_ITEM2_P1_S0	The Company s executive offices are located in a leased facility at 239 Washington Street, Jersey City, New Jersey, which is also the Bank s Main Office.
1178970_16_ITEM2_P1_S1	The Bank s administrative offices are located in a leased facility at 100 Wood Avenue South, Iselin, New Jersey.
1178970_16_ITEM3_P0_S0	The Company is involved in various legal actions and claims arising in the normal course of its business.
1178970_16_ITEM3_P0_S1	In the opinion of management, these legal actions and claims are not expected to have a material adverse impact on the Company s financial condition and results of operations.
1178970_16_ITEM5_P0_S0	The Company s common stock trades on the New York Stock Exchange ( NYSE ) under the symbol PFS.
1178970_16_ITEM5_P0_S1	Trading in the Company s common stock commenced on January 16, 2003.
1178970_16_ITEM5_P0_S2	As of February 1, 2016, there were 83,209,293 shares of the Company s common stock issued and 65,794,731 shares outstanding, and approximately 5,270 stockholders of record.
1178970_16_ITEM5_P0_S3	The table below shows the high and low closing prices reported on the NYSE for the Company s common stock, as well as the cash dividends paid per common share during the periods indicated.
1178970_16_ITEM5_P1_S0	On January 28, 2016, the Board of Directors declared a quarterly cash dividend of $0.17 per common share, which was paid on February 26, 2016, to common stockholders of record as of the close of business on February 12, 2016.
1178970_16_ITEM5_P1_S1	The Company s Board of Directors intends to review the payment of dividends quarterly and plans to continue to maintain a regular quarterly cash dividend in the future, subject to financial condition, results of operations, tax considerations, industry standards, economic conditions, regulatory restrictions that affect the payment of dividends by the Bank to the Company and other relevant factors.
1178970_16_ITEM5_P1_S2	The Company is subject to the requirements of Delaware law that generally limit dividends to an amount equal to the difference between the amount by which total assets exceed total liabilities and the amount equal to the aggregate par value of the outstanding shares of capital stock.
1178970_16_ITEM5_P1_S3	If there is no difference between these amounts, dividends are limited to net income for the current and/or immediately preceding year.
1178970_16_ITEM5_P1_S4	In addition, Federal Reserve Board guidance sets forth the supervisory expectation that bank holding companies will inform and consult with Federal Reserve Board staff in advance of issuing a dividend that exceeds earnings for the quarter and should inform the Federal Reserve Board and should eliminate, defer or significantly reduce dividends if (i) net income available to stockholders for the past four quarters, net of dividends previously paid during that period, is not sufficient to fully fund the dividends, (ii) prospective rate of earnings retention is not consistent with the bank holding company s capital needs and overall current and prospective financial condition, or (iii) the bank holding company will not meet, or is in danger of not meeting, its minimum regulatory capital adequacy ratios.
1178970_16_ITEM5_P2_S0	Stock Performance Graph Set forth below is a stock performance graph comparing (a) the cumulative total return on the Company s common stock for the period December 31, 2010 through December 31, 2015 , (b) the cumulative total return on stocks included in the Russell 2000 Index over such period, and (c) the cumulative total return of the SNL Thrift Index over such period.
1178970_16_ITEM5_P3_S0	The SNL Thrift Index, produced by SNL Financial LC, contains all thrift institutions traded on the New York and NASDAQ stock exchanges.
1178970_16_ITEM5_P4_S0	Cumulative return assumes the reinvestment of dividends and is expressed in dollars based on an assumed investment of $100 on December 31, 2010.

1178970_16_ITEM5_P5_S1	The repurchase program has no expiration date.

1178970_16_ITEM6_P0_S0	The summary information presented below at or for each of the periods presented is derived in part from and should be read in conjunction with the consolidated financial statements of the Company presented in Item 8.
1178970_16_ITEM6_P1_S0	(1) Loans are shown net of allowance for loan losses, deferred fees and unearned discount.
1178970_16_ITEM6_P2_S0	(1) Averages presented are daily averages.
1178970_16_ITEM6_P2_S1	(2) Net interest income divided by average interest earning assets.
1178970_16_ITEM6_P2_S2	(3) Represents the ratio of non-interest expense divided by the sum of net interest income and non-interest income.
1178970_16_ITEM6_P3_S0	(4) Leverage capital ratios are presented as a percentage of quarterly average tangible assets.
1178970_16_ITEM6_P3_S1	Risk-based capital ratios are presented as a percentage of risk-weighted assets.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P0_S0	General On January 15, 2003, the Company became the holding company for the Bank, following the completion of the conversion of the Bank to a New Jersey-chartered capital stock savings bank.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P1_S0	The Company issued an aggregate of 59,618,300 shares of its common stock in a subscription offering to eligible depositors.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P1_S1	Concurrent with the conversion, the Company contributed an additional 1,920,000 shares of its common stock and $4.8 million in cash to The Provident Bank Foundation, a charitable foundation established by the Bank.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P2_S0	The Company conducts business through its subsidiary, the Bank, a community- and customer-oriented bank currently operating 87 full-service branches throughout northern and central New Jersey, as well as Bucks, Lehigh and Northampton counties in Pennsylvania.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P2_S1	Strategy Established in 1839, the Bank is the oldest New Jersey-chartered bank in the state.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P2_S2	The Bank offers a full range of retail and commercial loan and deposit products, and emphasizes personal service and convenience.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P2_S3	The Bank s strategy is to grow profitably through a commitment to credit quality and expanding market share by acquiring, retaining and expanding customer relationships, while carefully managing interest rate risk.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P2_S4	In recent years, the Bank has focused on commercial real estate, multi-family and commercial loans as part of its strategy to diversify the loan portfolio and reduce interest rate risk.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P2_S5	These types of loans generally have adjustable rates that initially are higher than residential mortgage loans and generally have a higher rate of risk.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P3_S0	The Bank s credit policy focuses on quality underwriting standards and close monitoring of the loan portfolio.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P3_S1	At December 31, 2015 , these commercial loan types accounted for 72.1% of the loan portfolio and retail loans accounted for 27.9% .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P3_S2	The Company intends to continue to focus on commercial real estate, multi-family and commercial lending relationships.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P3_S3	The Company s relationship banking strategy focuses on increasing core accounts and expanding relationships through its branch network, mobile banking, online banking and telephone banking touch points.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P3_S4	The Company continues to evaluate opportunities to increase market share by expanding within existing and contiguous markets.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P4_S0	Core deposits, consisting of savings and demand deposit accounts, are generally a stable, relatively inexpensive source of funds.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P4_S1	At December 31, 2015 , core deposits were 87.5% of total deposits.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P5_S0	The Company s results of operations are primarily dependent upon net interest income, the difference between interest earned on interest-earning assets and the interest paid on interest-bearing liabilities.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P5_S1	Changes in interest rates could have an adverse effect on net interest income to the extent the Company s interest-bearing assets and interest-bearing liabilities reprice or mature at different times or relative interest rates.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P5_S2	An increase in interest rates generally would result in a decrease in the Company s average interest rate spread and net interest income, which could have a negative effect on profitability.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P6_S0	The Company generates non-interest income such as income from retail and business account fees, loan servicing fees, loan origination fees, loan level swap fees, appreciation in the cash surrender value of Bank-owned life insurance, income from loan or securities sales, fees from wealth management services and investment product sales and other fees.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P6_S1	The Company s operating expenses consist primarily of compensation and benefits expense, occupancy and equipment expense, data processing expense, the amortization of intangible assets, marketing and advertising expense and other general and administrative expenses.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P6_S2	The Company s results of operations are also affected by general economic conditions, changes in market interest rates, changes in asset quality, changes in asset values, actions of regulatory agencies and government policies.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P7_S0	Acquisitions On April 1, 2015, Beacon Trust Company ("Beacon"), a wholly owned subsidiary of The Provident Bank, completed its acquisition of certain assets and liabilities of The MDE Group, Inc. and the equity interests of Acertus Capital Management, LLC (together "MDE"), both Morristown, New Jersey-based registered investment advisory firms that manage assets for affluent and high net-worth clients.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P7_S1	MDE was acquired with both cash and contingent consideration.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P7_S2	The Company recognized goodwill of $18.3 million and a customer relationship intangible of $7.0 million related to the acquisition.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P7_S3	The Company recognized a contingent consideration liability at its fair value of $338,000.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P7_S4	The contingent consideration arrangement requires the Company to pay additional cash consideration to MDE s former stakeholders four years after the closing of the acquisition if certain revenue targets are met.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P7_S5	The fair value of the contingent consideration was estimated using a discounted cash flow model.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P7_S6	The acquisition agreement limits the total payment to a maximum of $12.5 million, to be determined based on actual future results.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P8_S0	On October 31, 2014, Beacon acquired the fiduciary account relationships of Suffolk County National Bank, a subsidiary of Suffolk Bancorp, in Suffolk County, New York.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P8_S1	On May 30, 2014, the Company completed its acquisition of Team Capital Bank ("Team Capital"), which after purchase accounting adjustments added $964.0 million to total assets, $631.2 million to loans, and $769.9 million to deposits.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P8_S2	Total consideration paid for Team Capital was $115.1 million: $31.6 million in cash and 4.9 million shares of common stock valued at $83.5 million on the acquisition date.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P8_S3	Team Capital was merged with and into the Company's subsidiary, The Provident Bank as of the close of business on the date of acquisition.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P8_S4	The merger added twelve branches to The Provident Bank branch network, with five branches in Pennsylvania and seven in New Jersey.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P9_S0	The Company considers certain accounting policies to be critically important to the fair presentation of its financial condition and results of operations.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P9_S1	These policies require management to make complex judgments on matters which by their nature have elements of uncertainty.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P9_S2	The sensitivity of the Company s consolidated financial statements to these critical accounting policies, and the assumptions and estimates applied, could have a significant impact on its financial condition and results of operations.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P9_S3	These assumptions, estimates and judgments made by management can be influenced by a number of factors, including the general economic environment.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P9_S4	The Company has identified the following as critical accounting policies:
1178970_16_ITEM7_P10_S0	Valuation of deferred tax assets The calculation of the allowance for loan losses is a critical accounting policy of the Company.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P11_S0	The allowance for loan losses is a valuation account that reflects management s evaluation of the probable losses in the loan portfolio.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P11_S1	The Company maintains the allowance for loan losses through provisions for loan losses that are charged to income.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P11_S2	Charge-offs against the allowance for loan losses are taken on loans where management determines that the collection of loan principal is unlikely.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P11_S3	Recoveries made on loans that have been charged-off are credited to the allowance for loan losses.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P11_S4	The Company s evaluation of the adequacy of the allowance for loan losses includes a review of all loans on which the collectibility of principal may not be reasonably assured.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P11_S5	For residential mortgage and consumer loans, this is determined primarily by delinquency and collateral values.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P11_S6	For commercial real estate and commercial loans, an extensive review of financial performance, payment history and collateral values is conducted on a quarterly basis.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P12_S0	As part of the evaluation of the adequacy of the allowance for loan losses, each quarter management prepares an analysis that categorizes the entire loan portfolio by certain risk characteristics such as loan type (residential mortgage, commercial mortgage, construction, commercial, etc.) and loan risk rating.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P12_S1	When assigning a risk rating to a loan, management utilizes a nine point internal risk rating system.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P12_S2	Loans deemed to be acceptable quality are rated 1 through 4, with a rating of 1 established for loans with minimal risk.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P12_S3	Loans deemed to be of questionable quality are rated 5 (watch) or 6 (special mention).
1178970_16_ITEM7_P12_S4	Loans with adverse classifications (substandard, doubtful or loss) are rated 7, 8 or 9, respectively.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P12_S5	Commercial mortgage, commercial and construction loans are rated individually and each lending officer is responsible for risk rating loans in their portfolio.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P12_S6	These risk ratings are then reviewed by the department manager and/or the Chief Lending Officer and the Credit Administration Department.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P12_S7	The risk ratings are also confirmed through periodic loan review examinations, which are currently performed by an independent third party, and periodically by the Credit Committee in the credit renewal or approval.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P12_S8	In addition, the Bank requires an annual review be performed for commercial and commercial real estate loans above certain dollar thresholds, depending on loan type, to help determine the appropriate risk rating.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P13_S0	Management estimates the amount of loan losses for groups of loans by applying quantitative loss factors to loan segments at the risk rating level, and applying qualitative adjustments to each loan segment at the portfolio level.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P13_S1	Quantitative loss factors give consideration to historical loss experience by loan type based upon an appropriate look back period and adjusted for a loss emergence period.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P13_S2	Quantitative loss factors are evaluated at least annually.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P13_S3	Qualitative adjustments give consideration to other qualitative or environmental factors such as trends and levels of delinquencies, impaired loans, charge-offs, recoveries and loan volumes, as well as national and local economic trends and conditions.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P13_S4	Qualitative adjustments reflect risks in the loan portfolio not captured by the quantitative loss factors and, as such, are evaluated from a risk level perspective relative to the risk levels present over the look back period.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P13_S5	Qualitative adjustments are evaluated at least quarterly.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P13_S6	The reserves resulting from the application of both of these sets of loss factors are combined to arrive at the allowance for loan losses.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P14_S0	Management believes the primary risks inherent in the portfolio are a general decline in the economy, a decline in real estate market values, rising unemployment or a protracted period of elevated unemployment, increasing vacancy rates in commercial investment properties and possible increases in interest rates in the absence of economic improvement.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P14_S1	Any one or a combination of these events may adversely affect borrowers ability to repay the loans, resulting in increased delinquencies, loan losses and future levels of provisions.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P14_S2	Accordingly, the Company has provided for loan losses at the current level to address the current risk in its loan portfolio.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P14_S3	Management considers it important to maintain the ratio of the allowance for loan losses to total loans at an acceptable level given current economic conditions, interest rates and the composition of the portfolio.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P14_S4	Although management believes that the Company has established and maintained the allowance for loan losses at appropriate levels, additions may be necessary if future economic and other conditions differ substantially from the current operating environment.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P14_S5	Management evaluates its estimates and assumptions on an ongoing basis giving consideration to historical experience and other factors, including the current economic environment, which management believes to be reasonable under the circumstances.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P14_S6	Such estimates and assumptions are adjusted when facts and circumstances dictate.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P14_S7	Illiquid credit markets, volatile securities markets, and declines in the housing and commercial real estate markets and the economy generally have combined to increase the uncertainty inherent in such estimates and assumptions.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P15_S0	As future events and their effects cannot be determined with precision, actual results could differ significantly from these estimates.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P15_S1	Changes in estimates resulting from continuing changes in the economic environment will be reflected in the financial statements in future periods.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P15_S2	In addition, various regulatory agencies periodically review the adequacy of the Company s allowance for loan losses as an integral part of their examination process.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P15_S3	Such agencies may require the Company to recognize additions to the allowance or additional write-downs based on their judgments about information available to them at the time of their examination.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P15_S4	Although management uses the best information available, the level of the allowance for loan losses remains an estimate that is subject to significant judgment and short-term change.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P15_S5	Additional critical accounting policies relate to judgments about other asset impairments, including goodwill, investment securities and deferred tax assets.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P16_S0	Goodwill is evaluated for impairment on an annual basis, or more frequently if events or changes in circumstances indicate potential impairment between annual measurement dates.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P16_S1	Management qualitatively determines whether it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying amount before performing Step 1 of the goodwill impairment test.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P16_S2	If an entity concludes that it is more likely than not that the fair value of a reporting unit is less than its carrying amount, the entity would be required to perform Step 1 of the assessment and then, if needed, Step 2 to determine whether goodwill is impaired.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P16_S3	However, if it is more likely than not that the fair value of the reporting unit is more than its carrying amount, the entity does not need to apply the two-step impairment test.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P17_S0	For this analysis, the Reporting Unit is defined as the Bank, which includes all core and retail banking operations of the Company but excludes the assets, liabilities, equity, earnings and operations held exclusively at the Company level.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P18_S0	The guidance provides certain factors an entity should consider in its qualitative assessment in determining whether it is more likely than not that a reporting unit s fair value is less than its carrying amount.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P19_S0	Macroeconomic conditions, such as deterioration in economic condition and limited access to capital.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P20_S0	Industry and market considerations, such as increased competition, regulatory developments and decline in market-dependent multiples.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P21_S0	Cost factors, such as increased labor costs, cost of materials and other operating costs.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P22_S0	Overall financial performance, such as declining cash flows and decline in revenue or earnings.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P23_S0	Other relevant entity-specific events, such as changes in management, strategy or customers, litigation and contemplation of bankruptcy.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P24_S0	Reporting unit events, such as selling or disposing a portion of a reporting unit and a change in composition of assets.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P25_S0	The Company may, based upon its qualitative assessment, or at its option, perform the two-step process to evaluate the potential impairment of goodwill.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P25_S1	If, based upon Step 1, the fair value of the Reporting Unit exceeds its carrying amount, goodwill of the Reporting Unit is considered not impaired.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P25_S2	However, if the carrying amount of the Reporting Unit exceeds its fair value, an additional test must be performed.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P26_S0	The second step test compares the implied fair value of the Reporting Unit s goodwill with the carrying amount of that goodwill.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P26_S1	An impairment loss would be recorded to the extent that the carrying amount of goodwill exceeds its implied fair value.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P26_S2	The Company completed its annual goodwill impairment test as of September 30, 2015.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P26_S3	Based upon its qualitative assessment of goodwill, the Company concluded it is more likely than not that the fair value of the reporting unit exceeds its carrying amount, such that goodwill was not impaired and no further quantitative analysis (Step 1) was warranted.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P27_S0	The Company s available for sale securities portfolio is carried at estimated fair value, with any unrealized gains or losses, net of taxes, reported as accumulated other comprehensive income or loss in stockholders equity.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P27_S1	Estimated fair values are based on market quotations or matrix pricing as discussed in Note 16 to the consolidated financial statements.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P28_S0	Securities which the Company has the positive intent and ability to hold to maturity are classified as held to maturity and carried at amortized cost.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P28_S1	Management conducts a periodic review and evaluation of the securities portfolio to determine if any declines in the fair values of securities are other-than-temporary.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P28_S2	In this evaluation, if such a decline were deemed other-than-temporary, Management would measure the total credit-related component of the unrealized loss, and recognize that portion of the loss as a charge to current period earnings.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P28_S3	The remaining portion of the unrealized loss would be recognized as an adjustment to accumulated other comprehensive income.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P29_S0	The fair value of the securities portfolio is significantly affected by changes in interest rates.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P29_S1	In general, as interest rates rise, the fair value of fixed-rate securities decreases and as interest rates fall, the fair value of fixed-rate securities increases.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P29_S2	The Company determines if it has the intent to sell these securities or if it is more likely than not that the Company would be required to sell the securities before the anticipated recovery.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P29_S3	If either exists, the decline in value is considered other-than-temporary.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P29_S4	In its evaluations, the Company did not recognize an other-than-temporary impairment charge on securities for 2015 and 2014, while in 2013, the Company recognized an other-than-temporary impairment of $434,000.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P30_S0	The determination of whether deferred tax assets will be realizable is predicated on the reversal of existing deferred tax liabilities, utilization against carry-back years and estimates of future taxable income.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P30_S1	Such estimates are subject to management s judgment.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P31_S0	A valuation allowance is established when management is unable to conclude that it is more likely than not that it will realize deferred tax assets based on the nature and timing of these items.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P31_S1	The Company did not require a valuation allowance at December 31, 2015 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P32_S0	Analysis of Net Interest Income Net interest income represents the difference between income on interest-earning assets and expense on interest-bearing liabilities.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P32_S1	Net interest income depends on the relative amounts of interest-earning assets and interest-bearing liabilities and the rates of interest earned on such assets and paid on such liabilities.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P32_S2	The following table sets forth certain information for the years ended December 31, 2015 , 2014 and 2013 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P32_S3	For the periods indicated, the total dollar amount of interest income from average interest-earning assets and the resultant yields, as well as the interest expense on average interest-bearing liabilities is expressed both in dollars and rates.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P32_S4	No tax equivalent adjustments were made.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P33_S0	(1) Average outstanding balance amounts are at amortized cost.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P33_S1	(2) Average outstanding balances are net of the allowance for loan losses, deferred loan fees and expenses, and loan premiums and discounts and include non-accrual loans.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P33_S2	(3) Net interest income divided by average interest-earning assets.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P34_S0	The following table presents the extent to which changes in interest rates and changes in the volume of interest-earning assets and interest-bearing liabilities have affected interest income and interest expense during the periods indicated.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P34_S1	Information is provided in each category with respect to: (i) changes attributable to changes in volume (changes in volume multiplied by prior rate); (ii) changes attributable to changes in rate (changes in rate multiplied by prior volume); and (iii) the net change.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P34_S2	The changes attributable to the combined impact of volume and rate have been allocated proportionately to the changes due to volume and the changes due to rate.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P35_S0	Comparison of Financial Condition at December 31, 2015 and December 31, 2014 Total assets increased $388.3 million , or 4.6% , to $8.91 billion at December 31, 2015 , from $8.52 billion at December 31, 2014 , primarily due to a $452.2 million increase in total loans and a $21.9 million increase in intangible assets, partially offset by a $97.3 million decrease in total investments.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P35_S1	Total loans increased $452.2 million , or 7.4% , to $6.54 billion at December 31, 2015 , from $6.09 billion at December 31, 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P35_S2	For the year ended December 31, 2015 , loan originations totaling $2.66 billion and loan purchases of $95.3 million were partially offset by repayments of $2.28 billion and loan sales of $11.9 million.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P35_S3	Multi-family loans increased $191.8 million to $1.23 billion at December 31, 2015, compared to $1.04 billion at December 31, 2014, commercial loans increased $170.7 million to $1.43 billion at December 31, 2015, compared to $1.26 billion at December 31, 2014, construction loans increased $110.5 million to $331.6 million at December 31, 2015, compared to $221.1 million at December 31, 2014, commercial real estate loans increased $20.3 million to $1.72 billion at December 31, 2015, compared to $1.70 billion at December 31, 2014, residential mortgage loans increased $2.6 million to $1.26 billion at December 31, 2015, compared to $1.25 billion at December 31, 2014, and consumer loans decreased $45.4 million to $566.2 million at December 31, 2015, compared to $611.6 million at December 31, 2014.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P35_S4	Commercial loans, consisting of commercial real estate, multi-family, construction and commercial loans, totaled $4.72 billion , accounting for 72.1% of the loan portfolio at December 31, 2015 , compared to $4.22 billion , or 69.4% of the loan portfolio at December 31, 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P35_S5	The Company intends to continue to focus on the origination of commercially-oriented loans.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P36_S0	Retail loans, which consist of one- to four-family residential mortgage and consumer loans, such as fixed-rate home equity loans and lines of credit, totaled $1.82 billion and accounted for 27.9% of the loan portfolio at December 31, 2015 , compared to $1.86 billion , or 30.6% , of the loan portfolio at December 31, 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P37_S0	The Company does not originate or purchase sub-prime or option ARM loans.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P38_S0	Prior to September 30, 2008, the Company originated Alt-A mortgages in the form of stated income loans with a maximum loan-to-value ratio of 50% on a limited basis.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P38_S1	The balance of these Alt-A loans at December 31, 2015 was $6.2 million.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P38_S2	Of this total, 6 loans totaling $1.0 million were 90 days or more delinquent.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P38_S3	These loans were allocated total loss reserves of $70,506.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P39_S0	The Company participates in loans originated by other banks, including participations designated as Shared National Credits ( SNC ).
1178970_16_ITEM7_P39_S1	The Company s gross commitments and outstanding balances as a participant in SNCs were $220.5 million and $155.7 million, respectively, at December 31, 2015 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P39_S2	At December 31, 2015 , no SNC relationships were classified as substandard.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P40_S0	The Company had outstanding junior lien mortgages totaling $247.0 million at December 31, 2015 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P40_S1	Of this total, 27 loans totaling $2.0 million were 90 days or more delinquent.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P40_S2	These 27 loans were allocated total loss reserves of $488,000.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P40_S3	At December 31, 2015 , the Company had outstanding indirect marine loans totaling $18.9 million.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P40_S4	Of this total, 3 loans totaling $315,000 were 90 days or more delinquent.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P41_S0	Marine loans are currently made only on a direct, limited accommodation basis to existing customers.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P41_S1	The allowance for loan losses decreased $310,000 to $61.4 million at December 31, 2015 , as a result of net charge-offs of $4.7 million , partially offset by provisions for loan losses of $4.4 million during 2015 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P41_S2	The reduction in the allowance for loan losses was a function of an improvement in the weighted average risk rating of the loan portfolio and a decline in non-performing loans.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P41_S3	Total non-performing loans at December 31, 2015 were $44.5 million, or 0.68% of total loans, compared with $53.9 million, or 0.88% of total loans at December 31, 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P41_S4	At December 31, 2015 , impaired loans totaled $50.9 million with related specific reserves of $2.3 million , compared with impaired loans totaling $85.4 million with related specific reserves of $7.1 million at December 31, 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P41_S5	Within total impaired loans, there were $33.4 million of loans for which the present value of expected future cash flows or current collateral valuations exceeded the carrying amounts of the loans and for which no specific reserves were required in accordance with GAAP.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P41_S6	At December 31, 2015 , the Company s allowance for loan losses was 0.94 % of total loans, compared with 1.01 % of total loans at December 31, 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P41_S7	The decline in the loan coverage ratio from December 31, 2014 , resulted from an overall improvement in asset quality.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P41_S8	Non-performing commercial mortgage loans decreased $18.8 million to $1.3 million at December 31, 2015 , from $20.0 million at December 31, 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P41_S9	At December 31, 2015 , the Company held 8 non-performing commercial mortgage loans.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P41_S10	The largest non-performing commercial mortgage loan was a $609,000 loan secured by a first mortgage on a mixed-use property located in Franklin Township, New Jersey.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P41_S11	The loan is presently in default.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P41_S12	There is no contractual commitment to advance additional funds to this borrower.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P41_S13	Non-performing commercial loans increased $11.5 million , to $23.9 million at December 31, 2015 , from $12.3 million at December 31, 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P41_S14	Non-performing commercial loans at December 31, 2015 consisted of 27 loans.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P41_S15	The largest non-performing commercial loan relationship consisted of four loans to a health and fitness club with outstanding balances totaling $6.8 million at December 31, 2015 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P41_S16	All of the loans are secured by liens on commercial property.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P41_S17	These five loans are presently in default.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P41_S18	Non-performing constructions loans amounted to $2.4 million at December 31, 2015 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P41_S19	Non-performing construction loans consisted of a single loan to a health and fitness club, which combined with four non-performing commercial loans comprises a $9.2 million loan relationship with this borrower.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P41_S20	This non-performing construction loan is presently in default.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P41_S21	There were no non-performing construction loans on December 31, 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P41_S22	Non-performing residential mortgage loans decreased $5.2 million to $ 12.0 million at December 31, 2015 , from $17.2 million at December 31, 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P41_S23	Gross charge-offs of residential loans were $1.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P41_S24	At December 31, 2015 , the Company held $10.5 million of foreclosed assets, compared with $5.1 million at December 31, 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P41_S25	Foreclosed assets are carried at fair value based on recent appraisals and valuation estimates, less estimated selling costs.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P41_S26	Foreclosed assets consisted primarily of $5.2 million of residential properties, $5.1 million of commercial real estate and $274,000 of marine vessels at December 31, 2015 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P41_S27	Non-performing assets totaled $55.1 million, or 0.62% of total assets at December 31, 2015 , compared to $59.0 million, or 0.69% of total assets, at December 31, 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P41_S28	If the non-accrual loans had performed in accordance with their original terms, interest income would have increased by $1.2 million during the year ended December 31, 2015 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P42_S0	The amount of cash basis interest income that was recognized on impaired loans during the years ended December 31, 2015 and 2014 was not material.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P42_S1	Total deposits increased $131.5 million , or 2.3% , during the year ended December 31, 2015 to $5.92 billion from $5.79 billion at December 31, 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P42_S2	Core deposits, which consist of savings and demand deposit accounts, increased $217.4 million , or 4.4% , to $5.18 billion at December 31, 2015 , while time deposits decreased $86.0 million to $739.7 million at December 31, 2015.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P43_S0	$139.9 million and $115.5 million, respectively, to $1.19 billion and $1.54 billion, respectively, at December 31, 2015 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P43_S1	Core deposits represented 87.5% of total deposits at December 31, 2015 , compared to 85.7% at December 31, 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P43_S2	Borrowed funds increased $197.8 million , or 13.1% , during the year ended December 31, 2015 , to $1.71 billion .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P43_S3	Borrowed funds represented 19.2% of total assets at December 31, 2015 , an increase from 17.7% at December 31, 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P43_S4	Total stockholders equity increased $52.0 million , or 4.5%, to $1.20 billion at December 31, 2015 , from $1.14 billion at December 31, 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P43_S5	This increase resulted from net income of $83.7 million , the allocation of shares to stock-based compensation plans of $9.4 million, exercised stock options of $3.2 million, and the reissuance of shares for the dividend reinvestment program of $1.4 million, partially offset by cash dividends paid to stockholders of $41.3 million, other comprehensive loss of $2.6 million and common stock repurchases of $2.0 million.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P43_S6	Common stock repurchases for the year ended December 31, 2015 totaled 108,589 shares at an average cost of $18.32 per share.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P43_S7	At December 31, 2015 , 3.3 million shares remained eligible for repurchase under the current authorization.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P44_S0	Comparison of Operating Results for the Years Ended December 31, 2015 and December 31, 2014 General.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P44_S1	Net income for the year ended December 31, 2015 was $83.7 million , compared to $73.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P44_S2	Basic and diluted earnings per share were $1.33 for the year ended December 31, 2015 , compared to basic and diluted earnings per share of $1.22 for 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P44_S3	Net income for the year ended December 31, 2015 was favorably impacted by year-over-year growth in both average loans outstanding and average non-interest bearing deposits, growth in non-interest income and improved asset quality.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P44_S4	These factors helped offset the unfavorable impact of compression in the net interest margin.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P44_S5	Net interest income increased $11.0 million to $249.9 million for 2015 , from $238.9 million for 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P44_S6	The average interest rate spread declined 11 basis point to 3.07% for 2015 , from 3.18% for 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P44_S7	The net interest margin decreased 10 basis point to 3.20% for 2015 , compared to 3.30% for 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P44_S8	For the year ended December 31, 2015 , net interest income was favorably impacted by the growth in average loans outstanding and average non-interest bearing demand deposits, mitigating the effects of compression in the net interest margin.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P44_S9	Interest income increased $12.4 million , or 4.4% , to $291.8 million for 2015 , compared to $279.4 million for 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P44_S10	The increase in interest income was attributable to an increase in average earning asset balances, partially offset by a decrease in the yield on average interest-earning assets.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P44_S11	Average interest-earning assets increased $577.4 million, or 8.0% , to $7.82 billion for 2015 , compared to $7.24 billion for 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P44_S12	The average outstanding loan balances increased $615.8 million, or 11.0% , to $6.22 billion for 2015 from $5.60 billion for 2014 , the average balance of securities available for sale decreased $102.2 million, or 9.0% , to $1.03 billion for 2015 , compared to $1.13 billion for 2014 , and the average balance of investment securities held to maturity increased $53.3 million, or 12.7% , to $473.4 million for 2015 , compared to $420.2 million for 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P44_S13	The yield on interest-earning assets decreased 13 basis points to 3.73% for 2015 , from 3.86% for 2014 , with a reduction in the weighted average yield on total loans and investment securities, partially offset by an increase in the weighted average yield on the Federal Home Loan Bank stock.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P44_S14	Interest expense increased $1.4 million , or 3.5% , to $41.9 million for 2015 , from $40.5 million for 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P44_S15	The increase in interest expense was attributable to an increase in average borrowings, which funded a portion of the growth in average interest-earning assets, partially offset by a shift in the funding composition to lower-costing core deposits from time deposits and a reduction in the average cost of borrowings.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P44_S16	Also offsetting the increase in interest expense was a $157.6 million, or 16.4% , increase in average non-interest bearing demand deposits to $1.12 billion for 2015 , from $959.8 million for 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P44_S17	The average rate paid on interest-bearing liabilities decreased 2 basis points to 0.66% for 2015 , compared to 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P44_S18	The average rate paid on interest-bearing deposits decreased 2 basis points to 0.31% for 2015 , from 0.33% for 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P44_S19	The average rate paid on borrowings decreased 17 basis points to 1.71% for 2015 , from 1.88% for 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P44_S20	The average balance of interest-bearing liabilities increased $394.6 million to $6.33 billion for 2015 , compared to $5.93 billion for 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P44_S21	Average interest-bearing deposits increased $129.1 million, or 2.8% , to $4.72 billion for 2015 , from $4.60 billion for 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P44_S22	Within average interest-bearing deposits, average interest-bearing core deposits increased $163.6 million, or 4.3% , for 2015 , compared with 2014 , while average time deposits decreased $34.5 million, or 4.2% , for 2015 , compared with 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P44_S23	Average outstanding borrowings increased $265.5 million, or 19.8 %, to $1.60 billion for 2015 , compared with $1.34 billion for 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P45_S0	Provisions for loan losses are charged to operations to maintain the allowance for loan losses at a level management considers necessary to absorb probable credit losses inherent in the loan portfolio.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P45_S1	In determining the level of the allowance for loan losses, management considers past and current loss experience, evaluations of real estate collateral, current economic conditions, volume and type of lending, adverse situations that may affect a borrower s ability to repay the loan and the levels of non-performing and other classified loans.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P45_S2	The amount of the allowance is based on estimates and the ultimate losses may vary from such estimates as more information becomes available or later events change.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P45_S3	Management assesses the adequacy of the allowance for loan losses on a quarterly basis and makes provisions for loan losses, if necessary, in order to maintain the adequacy of the allowance.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P46_S0	origination of commercial loans has been one of the more significant factors management has considered in evaluating the allowance for loan losses and provision for loan losses for the past several years.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P46_S1	In the event the Company further increases the amount of such types of loans in the portfolio, management may determine that additional or increased provisions for loan losses are necessary, which could adversely affect earnings.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P46_S2	The provision for loan losses was $4.4 million in 2015 , compared to $4.7 million in 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P46_S3	The decrease in the provision for loan losses was primarily attributable to a decline in non-performing loans and an improvement in the weighted average credit risk ratings of the loan portfolio.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P46_S4	Net charge-offs for 2015 were $4.7 million , compared to $7.6 million for 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P46_S5	Total charge-offs for the year ended December 31, 2015 were $8.8 million , compared to $10.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P46_S6	Recoveries for the year ended December 31, 2015 , were $4.2 million , compared to $3.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P46_S7	The allowance for loan losses at December 31, 2015 was $61.4 million , or 0.94% of total loans, compared to $61.7 million , or 1.01% of total loans, at December 31, 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P46_S8	At December 31, 2015 , non-performing loans as a percentage of total loans were 0.68% , compared to 0.88% at December 31, 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P46_S9	Non-performing assets as a percentage of total assets were 0.62% at December 31, 2015 , compared to 0.69% at December 31, 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P46_S10	At December 31, 2015 , non-performing loans were $44.5 million, compared to $53.9 million at December 31, 2014 , and non-performing assets were $55.1 million at December 31, 2015 , compared to $59.0 million at December 31, 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P46_S11	For the year ended December 31, 2015 , non-interest income totaled $55.2 million , an increase of $14.1 million , or 34.1% , compared to 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P46_S12	Wealth management income increased $7.4 million to $16.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2015, largely due to $7.0 million in fees resulting from assets under management acquired in the MDE transaction, combined with $450,000 of increased fee income from the Company's existing wealth management business.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P46_S13	Fee income increased $4.4 million , to $26.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 , primarily due to a $2.1 million increase in prepayment fees on commercial loans, a $1.3 million increase in deposit related fees and a $710,000 increase in ATM and debit card revenue.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P46_S14	Also contributing to the increase in non-interest income, was an increase in other income of $2.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2015, compared with 2014 , principally due to a $2.8 million increase in net fees recognized on loan level interest rate swap transactions, partially offset by a $528,000 decrease in net gains recognized on loan sales and a non-recurring $486,000 net gain recognized on the prepayment of FHLB borrowings acquired from Team Capital in the prior year.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P46_S15	Net gains on securities transactions for the year ended December 31, 2015 increased $403,000 as compared to 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P46_S16	Non-interest expense for the year ended December 31, 2015 was $ 180.6 million, an increase of $10.6 million from the year ended December 31, 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P46_S17	Compensation and benefits expense increased $7.5 million to $99.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 , compared to the year ended December 31, 2014 , due to increased salary expense associated with new employees from both Team Capital and MDE, additional salary expense associated with annual merit increases, an increase in the accrual for incentive compensation and an increase in employee medical benefits expense, partially offset by lower stock-based compensation, severance and pension costs.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P46_S18	The decline in pension costs was largely due to the $1.3 million lump-sum pension distributions made to vested retired employees in 2014.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P46_S19	Net occupancy costs increased $2.1 million , to $26.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 , compared to same period in 2014 , principally due to additional costs related to facilities acquired in the Team Capital acquisition and increased depreciation expense.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P46_S20	The amortization of intangibles increased $1.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 , compared with the same period in 2014 , primarily due to increases in both the core deposit intangible and customer relationship intangible amortization related to the Team Capital and MDE acquisitions, respectively.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P46_S21	Other operating expenses increased $1.1 million to $28.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2015 , compared to $27.7 million for the same period in 2014 , primarily due to valuation adjustments related to foreclosed real estate, and increases in business development and personnel recruitment expenses.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P46_S22	Partially offsetting these increases in non-interest expense, data processing costs decreased $969,000 to $12.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2015, compared with the year ended December 31, 2014, principally due to $2.4 million of non-recurring core system contract termination costs related to the Team Capital acquisition in 2014, partially offset by increased software maintenance costs and telecommunication expenses.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P46_S23	Additionally, advertising and promotion expense decreased $782,000 to $4.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2015, compared to $5.0 million for the same period in 2014, largely due to post-merger promotional activities within the former Team Capital marketplace incurred in the prior year.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P46_S24	For the year ended December 31, 2015 , the Company s income tax expense was $36.4 million, compared with $31.8 million, for the same period in 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P46_S25	The Company s effective tax rate was 30.3% for the year ended December 31, 2015 , compared with 30.2% for the year ended December 31, 2014 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P46_S26	For the year ended December 31, 2015 , the increases in income tax expense and the effective tax rate were a function of growth in pre-tax income, with a greater portion of income derived from taxable sources.

1178970_16_ITEM7_P48_S0	basic and diluted earnings per share of $1.23 for 2013 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P48_S1	Operating results for year ended December 31, 2014 included non-recurring items associated with the acquisition of Team Capital Bank of $3.9 million, net of taxes.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P48_S2	Additionally, earnings for the year ended December 31, 2014 were impacted by a $788,000, net of tax, non-cash charge due to the recognition of a pro rata portion of unrealized losses related to lump sum distributions from the Company's previously frozen pension plan.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P48_S3	Net income for the year ended December 31, 2013 included the non-core write-off of a deferred tax asset related to expired non-qualified stock options issued shortly after the Company's 2003 initial public offering.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P48_S4	The write-off in 2013 of the related $3.9 million deferred tax asset resulted in a $3.2 million charge to income tax expense and a $735,000 charge to equity in the third quarter of 2013 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P48_S5	Net interest income increased $22.9 million to $238.9 million for 2014 , from $216.0 million for 2013 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P48_S6	The average net interest rate spread declined 1 basis point to 3.18% for 2014 , from 3.19% for 2013 .

1178970_16_ITEM7_P48_S8	For the year ended December 31, 2014 , net interest income was favorably impacted by the assets acquired from Team Capital and growth in non-interest bearing demand deposits, which was mitigated by compression in the net interest margin.

1178970_16_ITEM7_P48_S10	The increase in interest income was attributable to an increase in average earning asset balances, partially offset by a decrease in the yield on average earning assets.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P48_S11	Average interest-earning assets increased $712.8 million, or 10.9%, to $7.24 billion for 2014 , compared to $6.53 billion for 2013 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P48_S12	The average outstanding loan balances increased $677.3 million, or 13.8%, to $5.60 billion for 2014 from $4.92 billion for 2013 , the average balance of securities available for sale decreased $56.8 million, or 4.8%, to $1.13 billion for 2014 , compared to $1.19 billion for 2013, and the average balance of investment securities held to maturity increased $66.5 million, or 18.8%, to $420.2 million for 2014 , compared to $353.6 million for 2013 .

1178970_16_ITEM7_P48_S14	Interest expense increased $3.7 million , or 10.1% , to $40.5 million for 2014 , from $36.8 million for 2013 .
1178970_16_ITEM7_P48_S15	The increase in interest expense was attributable to an increase in average borrowings, which funded a portion of the growth in average interest-earning assets, partially offset by a shift in the funding composition to lower-costing core deposits from time deposits and a reduction in the average cost of borrowings.
1178970_16_ITEM7_P48_S16	Also offsetting the increase in interest expense was a $120.5 million, or 14.4% increase in average non-interest bearing demand deposits to $959.8 million for 2014 , from $839.3 million for 2013 .

1178970_16_ITEM7_P48_S22	Within average interest-bearing deposits, average interest-bearing core deposits increased $195.6 million, or 5.5%, for 2014 , compared with 2013 , while average time deposits decreased $59.7 million, or 6.79%, for 2014, compared with 2013 .
