1178970_17_ITEM8_P180_S1	In the opinion of management, these legal actions and claims are not expected to have a material adverse impact on the Company s financial condition and results of operations.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P181_S0	A substantial portion of the Bank s loans are secured by real estate located in New Jersey.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P181_S1	Accordingly, the collectability of a substantial portion of the Bank s loan portfolio and the recovery of a substantial portion of the carrying amount of other real estate owned are susceptible to changes in local real estate market conditions.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P182_S0	(15) Regulatory Capital Requirements FDIC regulations require banks to maintain minimum levels of regulatory capital.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P182_S1	Under the regulations in effect at December 31, 2016 , the Bank is required to maintain: (1) a Tier 1 capital to total assets leverage ratio of 4.0% ; (2) a common equity Tier 1 capital to risk-based assets ratio of 4.5% ; (3) a Tier 1 capital to risk-based assets ratio of 6.0% ; and (4) a total capital to risk-based assets ratio of 8.0% .
1178970_17_ITEM8_P182_S2	In addition to establishing the minimum regulatory capital requirements, the regulations limit capital distributions and certain discretionary bonus payments to management if the institution does not hold a capital conservation buffer consisting of 2.5% of common equity Tier 1 capital to risk-weighted asset above the amount necessary to meet its minimum risk-based capital requirements.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P182_S3	The capital conservation buffer requirement was effective on January 1, 2016 at 0.625% of risk-weighted assets and will increase each year until fully implemented at 2.5% on January 1, 2019.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P183_S0	Under its prompt corrective action regulations, the FDIC is required to take certain supervisory actions (and may take additional discretionary actions) with respect to an undercapitalized institution.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P183_S1	Such actions could have a direct material effect on an institution s financial statements.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P184_S0	The regulations establish a framework for the classification of savings institutions into five categories: well capitalized, adequately capitalized, undercapitalized, significantly undercapitalized, and critically undercapitalized.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P184_S1	Generally, an institution is considered well capitalized if it has: a leverage (Tier 1) capital ratio of at least 5.00% ; a common equity Tier 1 risk-based capital ratio of 6.50% ; a Tier 1 risk-based capital ratio of at least 8.00% ; and a total risk-based capital ratio of at least 10.00% .
1178970_17_ITEM8_P185_S0	The foregoing capital ratios are based in part on specific quantitative measures of assets, liabilities and certain off-balance sheet items as calculated under regulatory accounting practices.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P185_S1	Capital amounts and classifications are also subject to qualitative judgments by the FDIC about capital components, risk weightings and other factors.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P185_S2	As of December 31, 2016 and 2015 , the Bank exceeded all minimum capital adequacy requirements to which it is subject.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P185_S3	Further, the most recent FDIC notification categorized the Bank as a well-capitalized institution under the prompt corrective action regulations.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P185_S4	There have been no conditions or events since that notification that management believes have changed the Bank s capital classification.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P186_S0	The Company is regulated as a bank holding company, and as such, is subject to examination, regulation and periodic reporting under the Bank Holding Company Act, as administered by the Federal Reserve Board ( FRB ).
1178970_17_ITEM8_P186_S1	The FRB has adopted capital adequacy guidelines for bank holding companies on a consolidated basis substantially similar to those of the FDIC for the Bank.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P186_S2	As of December 31, 2016 and 2015 , the Company was well capitalized under FRB guidelines.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P187_S0	Regulations of the FRB provide that a bank holding company must serve as a source of strength to any of its subsidiary banks and must not conduct its activities in an unsafe or unsound manner.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P187_S1	Under the prompt corrective action provisions discussed above, a bank holding company parent of an undercapitalized subsidiary bank would be directed to guarantee, within limitations, the capital restoration plan that is required of such an undercapitalized bank.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P187_S2	If the undercapitalized bank fails to file an acceptable capital restoration plan or fails to implement an accepted plan, the FRB may prohibit the bank holding company parent of the undercapitalized bank from paying any dividend or making any other form of capital distribution without the prior approval of the FRB.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P188_S0	The following table shows the Company s actual capital amounts and ratios as of December 31, 2016 and 2015 , compared to the FRB minimum capital adequacy requirements and the FRB requirements for classification as a well-capitalized institution (dollars in thousands).
1178970_17_ITEM8_P189_S0	The following table shows the Bank s actual capital amounts and ratios as of December 31, 2016 and 2015 , compared to the FDIC minimum capital adequacy requirements and the FDIC requirements for classification as a well-capitalized institution (dollars in thousands).
1178970_17_ITEM8_P190_S0	The Company utilizes fair value measurements to record fair value adjustments to certain assets and liabilities and to determine fair value disclosures.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P190_S1	The determination of fair values of financial instruments often requires the use of estimates.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P190_S2	Where quoted market values in an active market are not readily available, the Company utilizes various valuation techniques to estimate fair value.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P190_S3	Fair value is an estimate of the price that would be received to sell an asset or paid to transfer a liability in an orderly transaction between market participants at the measurement date.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P190_S4	However, in many instances fair value estimates may not be substantiated by comparison to independent markets and may not be realized in an immediate sale of the financial instrument.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P191_S0	GAAP establishes a fair value hierarchy that prioritizes the inputs to valuation techniques used to measure fair value.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P191_S1	The hierarchy gives the highest priority to unadjusted quoted prices in active markets for identical assets or liabilities (Level 1 measurements) and the lowest priority to unobservable inputs (Level 3 measurements).
1178970_17_ITEM8_P191_S2	The three levels of fair value hierarchy are as follows:
1178970_17_ITEM8_P192_S0	Level 3: Prices or valuation techniques that require inputs that are both significant to the fair value measurement and unobservable (i.e., supported by little or no market activity).
1178970_17_ITEM8_P193_S0	A financial instrument s level within the fair value hierarchy is based on the lowest level of input that is significant to the fair value measurement.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P193_S1	The valuation techniques are based upon the unpaid principal balance only, and exclude any accrued interest or dividends at the measurement date.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P193_S2	Interest income and expense and dividend income are recorded within the consolidated statements of income depending on the nature of the instrument using the effective interest method based on acquired discount or premium.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P194_S0	The valuation techniques described below were used to measure fair value of financial instruments in the table below on a recurring basis as of December 31, 2016 and December 31, 2015 .
1178970_17_ITEM8_P195_S0	Securities Available for Sale For securities available for sale, fair value was estimated using a market approach.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P196_S0	The majority of the Company s securities are fixed income instruments that are not quoted on an exchange, but are traded in active markets.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P196_S1	Prices for these instruments are obtained through third party data service providers or dealer market participants with which the Company has historically transacted both purchases and sales of securities.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P196_S2	Prices obtained from these sources include market quotations and matrix pricing.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P197_S0	Matrix pricing, a Level 2 input, is a mathematical technique used principally to value certain securities to benchmark or to comparable securities.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P197_S1	The Company evaluates the quality of Level 2 matrix pricing through comparison to similar assets with greater liquidity and evaluation of projected cash flows.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P197_S2	As the Company is responsible for the determination of fair value, it performs quarterly analyses on the prices received from the pricing service to determine whether the prices are reasonable estimates of fair value.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P197_S3	Specifically, the Company compares the prices received from the pricing service to a secondary pricing source.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P197_S4	Additionally, the Company compares changes in the reported market values and returns to relevant market indices to test the reasonableness of the reported prices.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P197_S5	The Company s internal price verification procedures and review of fair value methodology documentation provided by independent pricing services has not historically resulted in adjustment in the prices obtained from the pricing service.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P197_S6	The Company also may hold equity securities and debt instruments issued by the U.S. government and U.S. government-sponsored agencies that are traded in active markets with readily accessible quoted market prices that are considered Level 1 inputs.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P198_S0	Derivatives The Company records all derivatives on the statement of financial condition at fair value.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P198_S1	The accounting for changes in the fair value of derivatives depends on the intended use of the derivative, whether the Company has elected to designate a derivative in a hedging relationship and apply hedge accounting and whether the hedging relationship has satisfied the criteria necessary to apply hedge accounting.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P199_S0	The existing interest rate derivatives result from a service provided to certain qualifying borrowers in a loan related transaction and, therefore, are not used to manage interest rate risk in the Company s assets or liabilities.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P199_S1	As such, all changes in fair value of the Company s derivatives are recognized directly in earnings.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P199_S2	The Company also uses interest rate swaps as part of its interest rate risk management strategy.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P199_S3	Interest rate swaps designated as cash flow hedges, and which satisfy hedge accounting requirements, involve the receipt of variable amounts from a counterparty in exchange for the Company making fixed-rate payments over the life of the agreements without the exchange of the underlying notional amount.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P199_S4	These derivatives were used to hedge the variable cash outflows associated with FHLBNY borrowings.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P199_S5	The effective portion of changes in the fair value of these derivatives are recorded in accumulated other comprehensive income, and are subsequently reclassified into earnings in the period that the hedged forecasted transaction affects earnings.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P199_S6	The ineffective portion of the change in fair value of these derivatives are recognized directly in earnings.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P200_S0	The fair value of the Company's derivatives are determined using discounted cash flow analysis using observable market-based inputs, which are considered Level 2 inputs.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P201_S0	The valuation techniques described below were used to estimate fair value of financial instruments measured on a non-recurring basis as of December 31, 2016 and 2015 .
1178970_17_ITEM8_P201_S1	Collateral Dependent Impaired Loans For loans measured for impairment based on the fair value of the underlying collateral, fair value was estimated using a market approach.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P201_S2	The Company measures the fair value of collateral underlying impaired loans primarily through obtaining independent appraisals that rely upon quoted market prices for similar assets.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P201_S3	These appraisals include adjustments, on an individual case-by-case basis, to comparable assets based on the appraisers market knowledge and experience, as well as adjustments for estimated costs to sell which range between 5% and 10% .
1178970_17_ITEM8_P201_S4	The Company classifies these loans as Level 3 within the fair value hierarchy.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P202_S0	Foreclosed Assets Assets acquired through foreclosure or deed in lieu of foreclosure are carried at fair value, less estimated costs, which range between 5% and 10% .
1178970_17_ITEM8_P202_S1	Fair value is generally based on independent appraisals that rely upon quoted market prices for similar assets.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P202_S2	These appraisals include adjustments, on an individual case basis, to comparable assets based on the appraisers market knowledge and experience, and are classified as Level 3.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P203_S0	When an asset is acquired, the excess of the loan balance over fair value, less estimated costs to sell, is charged to the allowance for loan losses.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P204_S0	A reserve for foreclosed assets may be established to provide for possible write-downs and selling costs that occur subsequent to foreclosure.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P204_S1	Foreclosed assets are carried net of the related reserve.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P205_S0	Operating results from real estate owned, including rental income, operating expenses, and gains and losses realized from the sales of real estate owned, are recorded as incurred.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P205_S1	There were no changes to the valuation techniques for fair value measurements during the years ended December 31, 2016 and 2015 .
1178970_17_ITEM8_P206_S0	The following tables present the assets and liabilities reported on the consolidated statements of financial condition at their fair value as of December 31, 2016 and 2015 , by level within the fair value hierarchy (in thousands).
1178970_17_ITEM8_P207_S0	There were no transfers between Level 1, Level 2 and Level 3 during the years ended December 31, 2016 and 2015 .
1178970_17_ITEM8_P208_S0	Other Fair Value Disclosures The Company is required to disclose estimated fair value of financial instruments, both assets and liabilities on and off the balance sheet, for which it is practicable to estimate fair value.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P208_S1	The following is a description of valuation methodologies used for those assets and liabilities.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P209_S0	Cash and Cash Equivalents For cash and due from banks, federal funds sold and short-term investments, the carrying amount approximates fair value.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P210_S0	Investment Securities Held to Maturity For investment securities held to maturity, fair value was estimated using a market approach.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P211_S0	The majority of the Company s securities are fixed income instruments that are not quoted on an exchange, but are traded in active markets.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P211_S1	Prices for these instruments are obtained through third party data service providers or dealer market participants with which the Company has historically transacted both purchases and sales of securities.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P211_S2	Prices obtained from these sources include market quotations and matrix pricing.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P212_S0	Matrix pricing, a Level 2 input, is a mathematical technique used principally to value certain securities to benchmark or comparable securities.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P212_S1	The Company evaluates the quality of Level 2 matrix pricing through comparison to similar assets with greater liquidity and evaluation of projected cash flows.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P212_S2	As the Company is responsible for the determination of fair value, it performs quarterly analyses on the prices received from the pricing service to determine whether the prices are reasonable estimates of fair value.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P212_S3	Specifically, the Company compares the prices received from the pricing service to a secondary pricing source.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P212_S4	Additionally, the Company compares changes in the reported market values and returns to relevant market indices to test the reasonableness of the reported prices.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P212_S5	The Company s internal price verification procedures and review of fair value methodology documentation provided by independent pricing services has not historically resulted in adjustment in the prices obtained from the pricing service.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P212_S6	The Company also holds debt instruments issued by the U.S. government and U.S. government agencies that are traded in active markets with readily accessible quoted market prices that are considered Level 1 within the fair value hierarchy.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P213_S0	The carrying value of FHLBNY stock was its cost.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P213_S1	The fair value of FHLBNY stock is based on redemption at par value.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P213_S2	The Company classifies the estimated fair value as Level 1 within the fair value hierarchy.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P214_S0	Loans Fair values are estimated for portfolios of loans with similar financial characteristics.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P214_S1	Loans are segregated by type such as commercial mortgage, residential mortgage, commercial, construction and consumer.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P214_S2	Each loan category is further segmented into fixed and adjustable rate interest terms and into performing and non-performing categories.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P214_S3	The fair value of performing loans was estimated using a combination of techniques, including a discounted cash flow model that utilizes a discount rate that reflects the Company s current pricing for loans with similar characteristics and remaining maturity, adjusted by an amount for estimated credit losses inherent in the portfolio at the balance sheet date.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P214_S4	The rates take into account the expected yield curve, as well as an adjustment for prepayment risk, when applicable.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P215_S0	The Company classifies the estimated fair value of its loan portfolio as Level 3.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P215_S1	The fair value for significant non-performing loans was based on recent external appraisals of collateral securing such loans, adjusted for the timing of anticipated cash flows.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P215_S2	The Company classifies the estimated fair value of its non-performing loan portfolio as Level 3.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P215_S3	Deposits The fair value of deposits with no stated maturity, such as non-interest bearing demand deposits and savings deposits, was equal to the amount payable on demand and classified as Level 1.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P215_S4	The estimated fair value of certificates of deposit was based on the discounted value of contractual cash flows.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P215_S5	The discount rate was estimated using the Company s current rates offered for deposits with similar remaining maturities.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P216_S0	The Company classifies the estimated fair value of its certificates of deposit portfolio as Level 2.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P216_S1	The fair value of borrowed funds was estimated by discounting future cash flows using rates available for debt with similar terms and maturities and was classified by the Company as Level 2 within the fair value hierarchy.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P216_S2	The fair value of commitments to extend credit and letters of credit was estimated using the fees currently charged to enter into similar agreements, taking into account the remaining terms of the agreements and the present creditworthiness of the counterparties.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P217_S0	For fixed rate loan commitments, fair value also considers the difference between current levels of interest rates and the committed rates.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P217_S1	The fair value estimates of commitments to extend credit and letters of credit are deemed immaterial.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P217_S2	Limitations Fair value estimates are made at a specific point in time, based on relevant market information and information about the financial instrument.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P217_S3	These estimates do not reflect any premium or discount that could result from offering for sale at one time the Company s entire holdings of a particular financial instrument.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P218_S0	Because no market exists for a significant portion of the Company s financial instruments, fair value estimates are based on judgments regarding future expected loss experience, current economic conditions, risk characteristics of various financial instruments, and other factors.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P218_S1	These estimates are subjective in nature and involve uncertainties and matters of significant judgment and, therefore, cannot be determined with precision.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P218_S2	Changes in assumptions could significantly affect the estimates.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P219_S0	Fair value estimates are based on existing on- and off-balance sheet financial instruments without attempting to estimate the value of anticipated future business and the value of assets and liabilities that are not considered financial instruments.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P219_S1	Significant assets and liabilities that are not considered financial assets or liabilities include goodwill and other intangibles, deferred tax assets and premises and equipment.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P219_S2	In addition, the tax ramifications related to the realization of the unrealized gains and losses can have a significant effect on fair value estimates and have not been considered in the estimates.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P220_S0	The following tables present the Company s financial instruments at their carrying and fair values as of December 31, 2016 and December 31, 2015 .
1178970_17_ITEM8_P220_S1	Fair values are presented by level within the fair value hierarchy.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P221_S0	The following tables are a summary of certain quarterly financial data for the years ended December 31, 2016 and 2015 .
1178970_17_ITEM8_P222_S0	The following is a reconciliation of the outstanding shares used in the basic and diluted earnings per share calculations.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P223_S0	Anti-dilutive stock options and awards totaling 432,895 shares, 469,018 shares and 988,931 shares at December 31, 2016 , 2015 and 2014 , respectively, were excluded from the earnings per share calculations.

1178970_17_ITEM8_P226_S0	The following table summarizes the reclassifications out of accumulated other comprehensive (loss) income for the years ended December 31, 2016 , 2015 and 2014 (in thousands):
1178970_17_ITEM8_P227_S0	(1) This item is included in the computation of net periodic benefit cost.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P228_S0	The Company is exposed to certain risks arising from both its business operations and economic conditions.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P228_S1	The Company principally manages its exposures to a wide variety of business and operational risks through management of its core business activities.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P228_S2	The Company manages economic risks, including interest rate, liquidity, and credit risk, primarily by managing the amount, sources, and duration of its assets and liabilities.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P228_S3	Derivatives not designated in qualifying hedging relationships are not speculative and result from a service the Company provides to certain qualifying commercial borrowers in loan related transactions and, therefore, are not used to manage interest rate risk in the Company s assets or liabilities.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P229_S0	The Company executes interest rate swaps with commercial banking customers to facilitate their respective risk management strategies.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P229_S1	Those interest rate swaps are simultaneously hedged by offsetting interest rate swaps that the Company executes with a third party, such that the Company minimizes its net risk exposure resulting from such transactions.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P230_S0	The interest rate swap agreement which the Company executes with the commercial borrower is collateralized by the borrower's property financed by the Company.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P230_S1	As the interest rate swaps associated with this program do not meet the hedge accounting requirements, changes in the fair value of both the customer swaps and the offsetting swaps are recognized directly in earnings.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P231_S0	For the years ended December 31, 2016 and December 31, 2015 , the Company had 36 and 23 interest rate swaps with an aggregate notional amount of $582.2 million and $391.4 million , respectively, related to this program.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P231_S1	The Company has credit derivatives resulting from participations in interest rate swaps provided to external lenders as part of loan participation arrangements, therefore, are not used to manage interest rate risk in the Company's assets or liabilities.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P232_S0	Cash flow Hedges of Interest Rate Risk.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P232_S1	The Company s objective in using interest rate derivatives is to add stability to interest expense and to manage its exposure to interest rate movements.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P232_S2	To accomplish this objective, the Company primarily uses interest rate swaps as part of its interest rate risk management strategy.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P233_S0	Interest rate swaps designated as cash flow hedges involve the receipt of variable amounts from a counterparty in exchange for the Company making fixed-rate payments over the life of the agreements without exchange of the underlying notional amount.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P233_S1	The effective portion of changes in the fair value of derivatives designated and that qualify as cash flow hedges are recorded in accumulated other comprehensive income and are subsequently reclassified into earnings in the period that the hedged forecasted transaction affects earnings.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P233_S2	During the year ended December 31, 2016 , such derivatives were used to hedge the variable cash outflows associated with Federal Home Loan Bank borrowings.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P234_S0	The ineffective portion of the change in fair value of the derivatives is recognized directly in earnings.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P234_S1	The Company implemented this program during the quarter ended September 30, 2015.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P234_S2	During the years ended December 31, 2016 and 2015, the Company s did not record any hedge ineffectiveness.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P234_S3	Amounts reported in accumulated other comprehensive (loss) income related to derivatives will be reclassified to interest expense as interest payments are made on the Company s debt.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P234_S4	During the next twelve months, the Company estimates that $159,000 will be reclassified as an increase to interest expense.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P235_S0	As of December 31, 2016 , the Company had one outstanding interest rate derivative with a notional amount of $40.0 million that was designated as a cash flow hedge of interest rate risk.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P235_S1	The table below presents the fair value of the Company s derivative financial instruments as well as their classification on the Consolidated Statements of Financial Condition as of December 31, 2016 and 2015 (in thousands):

1178970_17_ITEM8_P237_S0	Derivatives designated as a hedging instrument:
1178970_17_ITEM8_P238_S0	Fair Value Derivatives not designated as a hedging instruments:
1178970_17_ITEM8_P239_S0	Derivatives designated as a hedging instrument:
1178970_17_ITEM8_P240_S0	The tables below present the effect of the Company s derivative financial instruments on the Consolidated Statements of Income for the years ended December 31, 2016 , 2015 and 2014 (in thousands).
1178970_17_ITEM8_P241_S0	The Company has agreements with certain of its derivative counterparties that contain a provision that if the Company defaults on any of its indebtedness, including default where repayment of the indebtedness has not been accelerated by the lender, then the Company could also be declared in default on its derivative obligations.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P241_S1	In addition, the Company has agreements with certain of its derivative counterparties that contain a provision that if the Company fails to maintain its status as a well/adequate capitalized institution, then the counterparty could terminate the derivative positions and the Company would be required to settle its obligations under the agreements.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P241_S2	As of December 31, 2016 , the termination value of derivatives in a net liability position, which includes accrued interest, was $1.4 million .
1178970_17_ITEM8_P241_S3	The Company has minimum collateral posting thresholds with certain of its derivative counterparties, and has posted collateral of $220,000 against its obligations under these agreements.
1178970_17_ITEM8_P241_S4	If the Company had breached any of these provisions at December 31, 2016 , it could have been required to settle its obligations under the agreements at the termination value.
1178970_17_ITEM9A_P0_S0	Evaluation of Disclosure Controls and Procedures Christopher Martin, the Company s Principal Executive Officer, and Thomas M. Lyons, the Company s Principal Accounting Officer, conducted an evaluation of the effectiveness of the Company s disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Rule 13a-15(e) and 15d-15(e) under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended) as of December 31, 2016 .
1178970_17_ITEM9A_P0_S1	Based upon their evaluation, they each found that the Company s disclosure controls and procedures were effective.
1178970_17_ITEM9A_P1_S0	The management of the Company is responsible for establishing and maintaining adequate internal control over financial reporting.
1178970_17_ITEM9A_P1_S1	The Company s internal control system is a process designed to provide reasonable assurance to the Company s management and board of directors regarding the preparation and fair presentation of published financial statements.
1178970_17_ITEM9A_P1_S2	The Company s internal control over financial reporting includes policies and procedures that pertain to the maintenance of records that, in reasonable detail, accurately and fairly reflect transactions and dispositions of assets; provide reasonable assurances that transactions are recorded as necessary to permit preparation of financial statements in accordance with U.S. generally accepted accounting principles, and that receipts and expenditures are being made only in accordance with authorizations of management and the directors of the Company; and provide reasonable assurance regarding prevention or timely detection of unauthorized acquisition, use or disposition of the Company s assets that could have a material effect on its financial statements.
1178970_17_ITEM9A_P1_S3	All internal control systems, no matter how well designed, have inherent limitations.
1178970_17_ITEM9A_P1_S4	Therefore, even those systems determined to be effective can provide only reasonable assurance with respect to financial statement preparation and presentation.
1178970_17_ITEM9A_P1_S5	Also, projections of any evaluation of effectiveness to future periods are subject to the risk that controls may become inadequate because of changes in conditions, or that the degree of compliance with the policies or procedures may deteriorate.
1178970_17_ITEM9A_P2_S0	Management assessed the effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2016 .
1178970_17_ITEM9A_P2_S1	In making this assessment, we used the criteria set forth by the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission in Internal Control-Integrated Framework ( COSO ) (2013).
1178970_17_ITEM9A_P2_S2	Based on the assessment management believes that, as of December 31, 2016 , the Company s internal control over financial reporting is effective based on those criteria.
1178970_17_ITEM9A_P2_S3	The Company s independent registered public accounting firm that audited the consolidated financial statements has issued an audit report on the effectiveness of the Company s internal control over financial reporting as of December 31, 2016 .
1178970_17_ITEM9A_P2_S4	This report appears on page 57.
