1178970_18_ITEM1_P134_S5	The regulatory structure also gives the regulatory authorities extensive discretion in connection with their supervisory and enforcement activities and examination policies, including policies with respect to the classification of assets and the establishment of adequate loan loss reserves for regulatory purposes.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P135_S0	Any change in applicable laws and regulations, whether by the Commissioner, the FDIC, the Federal Reserve Board or through legislation, could have a material adverse impact on the Company and the Bank and their operations.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P136_S0	The Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act of 2010 (the Dodd-Frank Act ) made extensive changes in the regulation of depository institutions and their holding companies.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P136_S1	Certain provisions of the Dodd-Frank Act have impacted, and will continue to impact the Company and the Bank.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P136_S2	For example, the Dodd-Frank Act created the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau as an independent bureau of the Federal Reserve Board.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P136_S3	The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has assumed responsibility for the implementation of the federal financial consumer protection and fair lending laws and regulations and has the authority to impose new requirements.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P137_S0	authority of their principal regulator, although the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has back-up authority to examine and enforce consumer protection laws against all institutions, including those with less than $10 billion in assets.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P138_S0	As of December 31, 2017 , the Bank had consolidated assets of $9.85 billion .
1178970_18_ITEM1_P139_S0	The Dodd-Frank Act established several measures that apply to institutions and holding companies once they reach $10 billion in assets.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P140_S0	In addition to Consumer Financial Protection Bureau compliance examinations, as discussed above, limits on debit card interchange fees apply, which will reduce the Bank s fee income.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P140_S1	Certain enhanced prudential standards will also become applicable such as additional risk management requirements, both from a framework and corporate governance perspective.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P140_S2	Stress testing requirements and related filing requirements, which involve assessing the potential impact on the Bank and Company of various scenarios prescribed by the federal regulatory agencies, also become applicable.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P140_S3	These and other supervisory and regulatory implications of crossing the $10 billion threshold would likely result in increased regulatory costs.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P141_S0	The material laws and regulations applicable to the Company and the Bank are summarized below and elsewhere in this Annual Report on Form 10-K. New Jersey Banking Regulation Activity Powers.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P142_S0	The Bank derives its lending, investment and other activity powers primarily from the applicable provisions of the New Jersey Banking Act and its related regulations.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P142_S1	Under these laws and regulations, savings banks, including the Bank, generally may, subject to certain limits, invest in: (1) real estate mortgages; (2) consumer and commercial loans; (3) specific types of debt securities, including certain corporate debt securities and obligations of federal, state and local governments and agencies; (4) certain types of corporate equity securities; and (5) certain other assets.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P142_S2	A savings bank may also invest pursuant to a leeway power that permits investments not otherwise permitted by the New Jersey Banking Act, subject to certain restrictions imposed by the FDIC.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P142_S3	Leeway investments must comply with a number of limitations on the individual and aggregate amounts of such investments.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P142_S4	A savings bank may also exercise trust powers upon the approval of the Commissioner.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P142_S5	New Jersey savings banks may exercise those powers, rights, benefits or privileges authorized for national banks or out-of-state banks or for federal or out-of-state savings banks or savings associations, provided that before exercising any such power, right, benefit or privilege, prior approval by the Commissioner by regulation or by specific authorization is required.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P142_S6	The exercise of these lending, investment and activity powers is limited by federal law and the related regulations.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P142_S7	See Federal Banking Regulation-Activity Restrictions on State-Chartered Bank below.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P143_S0	With certain specified exceptions, a New Jersey chartered savings bank may not make loans or extend credit to a single borrower and to entities related to the borrower in an aggregate amount that would exceed 15% of the bank s capital funds.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P143_S1	A New Jersey chartered savings bank may lend an additional 10% of the bank s capital funds if secured by collateral meeting the requirements of the New Jersey Banking Act.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P143_S2	The Bank currently complies with applicable loans-to-one-borrower limitations.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P144_S0	Under the New Jersey Banking Act, a stock savings bank may declare and pay a dividend on its capital stock only to the extent that the payment of the dividend would not impair the capital stock of the savings bank.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P144_S1	In addition, a stock savings bank may not pay a dividend unless the savings bank would, after the payment of the dividend, have a surplus of not less than 50% of its capital stock, or the payment of the dividend would not reduce the surplus.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P144_S2	Federal law may also limit the amount of dividends that may be paid by the Bank.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P145_S0	Regulations of the Commissioner impose on New Jersey chartered depository institutions, including the Bank, minimum capital requirements similar to those imposed by the FDIC on insured state banks.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P145_S1	At December 31, 2017 , the Bank was considered well capitalized under FDIC guidelines.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P146_S0	The New Jersey Department of Banking and Insurance may examine the Company and the Bank whenever it deems an examination advisable.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P146_S1	The Department examines the Bank at least every two years.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P147_S0	The Commissioner may order any savings bank to discontinue any violation of law or unsafe or unsound business practice and may direct any director, officer, attorney or employee of a savings bank engaged in an objectionable activity, after the Commissioner has ordered the activity to be terminated, to show cause at a hearing before the Commissioner why such person should not be removed.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P148_S0	Federal regulations require federally insured depository institutions to meet several minimum capital standards: a common equity Tier 1 capital to risk-based assets ratio of 4.5%, a Tier 1 capital to risk-based assets ratio of 6.0%, a total capital to risk-based assets of 8.0%, and a 4.0% Tier 1 capital to total assets leverage ratio.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P148_S1	These capital requirements are the result of a final rule implementing recommendations of the Basel Committee on Banking Supervision and certain requirements of the Dodd-Frank Act, and were effective January 1, 2015.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P149_S0	In determining the amount of risk-weighted assets for purposes of calculating risk-based capital ratios, all assets, including certain off-balance sheet assets (e.g., recourse obligations, direct credit substitutes, residual interests) are multiplied by a risk weight factor assigned by the regulations based on the risks believed inherent in the type of asset.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P149_S1	Higher levels of capital are required for asset categories believed to present greater risk.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P150_S0	Common equity Tier 1 capital is generally defined as common stockholders equity and retained earnings.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P150_S1	Tier 1 capital is generally defined as common equity Tier 1 and additional Tier 1 capital.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P150_S2	Additional Tier 1 capital includes certain noncumulative perpetual preferred stock and related surplus and minority interests in equity accounts of consolidated subsidiaries.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P150_S3	Total capital includes Tier 1 capital (common equity Tier 1 capital plus additional Tier 1 capital) and Tier 2 capital.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P150_S4	Tier 2 capital is comprised of capital instruments and related surplus, meeting specified requirements, and may include cumulative preferred stock and long-term perpetual preferred stock, mandatory convertible securities, intermediate preferred stock and subordinated debt.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P150_S5	Also included in Tier 2 capital is the allowance for loan and lease losses limited to a maximum of 1.25% of risk-weighted assets and, for institutions that have exercised an opt-out election regarding the treatment of Accumulated Other Comprehensive Income, up to 45% of net unrealized gains on available-for-sale equity securities with readily determinable fair market values.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P151_S0	Calculation of all types of regulatory capital is subject to deductions and adjustments specified in the regulations.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P151_S1	In assessing an institution s capital adequacy, the FDIC takes into consideration, not only these numeric factors, but qualitative factors as well, and has the authority to establish higher capital requirements for individual institutions where deemed necessary.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P151_S2	In addition to establishing the minimum regulatory capital requirements, the regulations limit capital distributions and certain discretionary bonus payments to management if the institution does not hold a capital conservation buffer consisting of 2.5% of common equity Tier 1 capital to risk-weighted asset above the amount necessary to meet its minimum risk-based capital requirements.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P151_S3	The capital conservation buffer requirement was effective on January 1, 2016 at 0.625% of risk-weighted assets and will increase each year until fully implemented at 2.5% on January 1, 2019.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P151_S4	The capital conservation buffer during the calendar year 2017 was 1.25% and increased to 1.875% on January 1, 2018.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P151_S5	The following table shows the Bank s Tier 1 leverage ratio, common equity Tier 1 risk-based capital ratio, Tier 1 risk-based capital ratio, and total risk-based capital ratio, at December 31, 2017 :
1178970_18_ITEM1_P152_S0	(1) For purposes of calculating regulatory Tier 1 leverage capital, assets are based on adjusted total leverage assets.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P152_S1	In calculating common equity Tier 1 risk-based capital, Tier 1 risk-based capital and total risk-based capital, assets are based on total risk-weighted assets.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P152_S2	As of December 31, 2017 , the Bank was considered well capitalized under FDIC guidelines.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P153_S0	Federal law and FDIC regulations generally limit the activities and investments of state-chartered FDIC insured banks and their subsidiaries to those permissible for national banks and their subsidiaries, unless such activities and investments are specifically exempted by law or consented to by the FDIC.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P153_S1	Before making a new investment or engaging in a new activity that is not permissible for a national bank or otherwise permissible under federal law or FDIC regulations, an insured bank must seek approval from the FDIC to make such investment or engage in such activity.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P154_S0	the FDIC determines that the activity does not present a significant risk to the FDIC insurance fund.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P155_S0	Certain activities of subsidiaries that are engaged in activities permitted for national banks only through a financial subsidiary are subject to additional restrictions.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P155_S1	Federal law permits a state-chartered savings bank to engage, through financial subsidiaries, in any activity in which a national bank may engage through a financial subsidiary and on substantially the same terms and conditions.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P155_S2	In general, the law permits a national bank that is well-capitalized and well-managed to conduct, through a financial subsidiary, any activity permitted for a financial holding company other than insurance underwriting, insurance investments, real estate investment or development or merchant banking.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P155_S3	The total assets of all such financial subsidiaries may not exceed the lesser of 45% of the bank s total assets or $50 billion.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P155_S4	The bank must have policies and procedures to assess the financial subsidiary s risk and protect the bank from such risk and potential liability, must not consolidate the financial subsidiary s assets with the bank s and must exclude from its own assets and equity all equity investments, including retained earnings, in the financial subsidiary.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P155_S5	The Bank currently meets all conditions necessary to establish and engage in permitted activities through financial subsidiaries.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P156_S0	The Bank is a member of the FHLB system which consists of twelve regional FHLBs, each subject to supervision and regulation by the Federal Housing Finance Agency ( FHFA ).
1178970_18_ITEM1_P156_S1	The FHLB provides a central credit facility primarily for member institutions.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P156_S2	As a member of the FHLB of New York, the Bank is required to purchase and hold shares of capital stock in that FHLB in an amount as required by that FHLB s capital plan and minimum capital requirements.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P156_S3	The Bank is in compliance with these requirements.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P156_S4	The Bank has received dividends on its FHLBNY stock, although no assurance can be given that these dividends will continue to be paid.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P156_S5	For the year ended December 31, 2017 , dividends paid by the FHLBNY to the Bank totaled $4.1 million .
1178970_18_ITEM1_P157_S0	As a member institution of the FDIC, deposit accounts at the Bank are generally insured by the FDIC s Deposit Insurance Fund ( DIF ) up to a maximum of $250,000 for each separately insured depositor.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P158_S0	Under the FDIC s risk-based assessment system, insured institutions were originally assigned a risk category based on supervisory evaluations, regulatory capital levels and certain other factors.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P158_S1	An institution s assessment rate depended upon the category to which it was assigned, and certain adjustments specified by FDIC regulations.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P158_S2	Institutions deemed less risky paid lower assessments.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P158_S3	No institution may pay a dividend if it is in default of its federal deposit insurance assessment.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P159_S0	The Dodd-Frank Act required the FDIC to revise its procedures to base its assessments upon each insured institution s total assets less tangible equity instead of deposits.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P159_S1	The FDIC finalized a rule, effective April 1, 2011, that set the assessment range (inclusive of possible adjustments) at 25 to 45 basis points of total assets less tangible equity.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P159_S2	However, as described below, there were recent changes to both the FDIC s assessment range and its risk-based assessment procedures.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P160_S0	The FDIC has established a long range target size for the DIF of 2 percent of insured deposits.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P160_S1	The FDIC s regulations also provided for a lower assessment rate schedule when the DIF reached 1.15% of total insured deposits.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P160_S2	The 1.15% ratio was achieved as of June 30, 2016.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P160_S3	As a result, effective July 1, 2016, the assessment range (inclusive of possible adjustments) has been lowered to 1.5 to 30 basis points for banks of less than $10 billion in consolidated assets.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P161_S0	The Dodd-Frank Act requires banks of greater than $10 billion of assets to pay to increase the DIF reserve ratio from 1.15% to 1.35%.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P161_S1	Consequently, also effective July 1, 2016, banks of greater than $10 billion of assets now pay a surcharge of 4.5 basis points on assets above $10 billion until the earlier of the reserve ratio reaching 1.35% or December 31, 2018 (when a short fall assessment would be applied).
1178970_18_ITEM1_P161_S2	At the same time, the FDIC eliminated the risk categories.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P161_S3	Most institutions are now assessed based on financial ratios derived from statistical models that estimate the probability of a bank s failure within three years.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P161_S4	Banks of greater than $10 billion are assessed based on a rate derived from a scorecard which assesses certain factors such as examination ratings, financial measures related to the bank s ability to withstand stress and measures of loss severity to the DIF if the bank should fail.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P162_S0	The FDIC has extensive enforcement authority over insured savings banks, including the Bank.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P162_S1	This enforcement authority includes, among other things, the ability to assess civil money penalties, to issue cease and desist orders and to remove directors and officers.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P162_S2	In general, these enforcement actions may be initiated in response to violations of law and to unsafe or unsound practices.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P163_S0	Transactions between an insured bank, such as the Bank, and any of its affiliates are governed by Sections 23A and 23B of the Federal Reserve Act and its implementing regulations.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P164_S0	An affiliate of a bank is any company or entity that controls, is controlled by or is under common control with the bank.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P164_S1	A subsidiary of a bank that is not also a depository institution, financial subsidiary or other entity defined by the regulation generally is not treated as an affiliate of the bank for purposes of Sections 23A and 23B.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P165_S0	requires that all such transactions be on terms that are consistent with safe and sound banking practices.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P166_S0	The term covered transaction includes the making of loans, purchase of assets, issuance of guarantees and other similar types of transactions.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P166_S1	Further, most loans by a bank to any of its affiliates must be secured by collateral in amounts ranging from 100 to 130 percent of the loan amounts.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P166_S2	In addition, any covered transaction by a bank with an affiliate and any purchase of assets or services by a bank from an affiliate must be on terms that are substantially the same, or at least as favorable to the bank, as those that would be provided to a non-affiliate.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P167_S0	Banks are subject to statutory prohibitions on certain tying arrangements.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P167_S1	A depository institution is prohibited, subject to certain exceptions, from extending credit to or offering any other service, or fixing or varying the consideration for such extension of credit or service, on the condition that the customer obtain some additional service from the institution or its affiliates or that the customer not obtain services of a competitor of the institution.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P168_S0	FDIC regulations require the Company and the Bank to disclose their privacy policies, including identifying with whom they share non-public personal information to customers at the time of establishing the customer relationship and annually thereafter.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P168_S1	The FDIC regulations also require the Company and the Bank to provide their customers with initial and annual notices that accurately reflect their privacy policies and practices.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P168_S2	In addition, the Company and the Bank are required to provide their customers with the ability to opt-out of having the Company and the Bank share their non-public personal information with unaffiliated third parties before they can disclose such information, subject to certain exceptions.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P169_S0	Community Reinvestment Act and Fair Lending Laws.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P170_S0	All FDIC insured institutions have a responsibility under the Community Reinvestment Act and related regulations to help meet the credit needs of their entire communities, including low- and moderate-income neighborhoods and borrowers (i.e. assessment(s)).
1178970_18_ITEM1_P170_S1	In connection with its examination of a state chartered savings bank, the FDIC is required to assess the institution s record of compliance with the Community Reinvestment Act.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P170_S2	Among other things, the current Community Reinvestment Act regulations rate an institution based upon its actual performance in meeting community needs.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P170_S3	In particular, the current examination and evaluation process focuses on three tests:
1178970_18_ITEM1_P171_S0	a service test, to evaluate the institution s systems for delivering retail banking services through its branches, ATMs and other offices and access facilities, including the distribution of its branches, ATMs and other offices/access facilities, and the institution s record of opening and closing branches.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P172_S0	An institution s failure to comply with the provisions of the Community Reinvestment Act could, at a minimum, result in regulatory restrictions on its activities, including, but not limited to, engaging in acquisitions and mergers.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P172_S1	The Bank received an Outstanding Community Reinvestment Act rating in its most recently completed federal examination, which was conducted by the FDIC as of December 2014.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P173_S0	In addition, the Equal Credit Opportunity Act and the Fair Housing Act prohibit lenders from discriminating in their lending practices on the basis of the borrower s characteristics as specified in those statutes.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P173_S1	An institution s failure to comply with the Equal Credit Opportunity Act and/or the Fair Housing Act could result in enforcement actions by the FDIC, as well as other federal regulatory agencies and the Department of Justice.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P174_S0	Each federal banking agency, including the FDIC, has adopted guidelines establishing general standards relating to internal controls, information and internal audit systems, loan documentation, credit underwriting, interest rate exposure, asset growth, asset quality, earnings, compensation, fees and benefits.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P174_S1	In general, the guidelines require, among other things, appropriate systems and practices to identify and manage the risks and exposures specified in the guidelines.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P175_S0	the amounts paid are unreasonable or disproportionate to the services performed by an executive officer, employee, director, or principal stockholder.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P175_S1	In addition, FDIC regulations require a bank that is given notice by the FDIC that it is not satisfying any of such safety and soundness standards to submit a compliance plan to the FDIC.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P175_S2	If, after being so notified, a bank fails to submit an acceptable compliance plan or fails in any material respect to implement an accepted compliance plan, the FDIC may issue an order directing corrective and other actions of the types to which a significantly undercapitalized institution is subject under the prompt corrective action provisions discussed below.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P175_S3	If a bank fails to comply with such an order, the FDIC may seek to enforce such an order in judicial proceedings and to impose civil monetary penalties.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P176_S0	Federal law requires the FDIC and the other federal banking regulators to promptly resolve the problems of undercapitalized institutions.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P176_S1	Federal law also establishes five categories, consisting of well capitalized, adequately capitalized, undercapitalized, significantly undercapitalized and critically undercapitalized.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P176_S2	The FDIC s regulations define the five capital categories as follows:
1178970_18_ITEM1_P176_S3	An institution will be treated as well capitalized if:
1178970_18_ITEM1_P177_S0	its ratio of Tier 1 capital to total assets is at least 5%, and it is not subject to any order or directive by the FDIC to meet a specific capital level.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P178_S0	An institution will be treated as adequately capitalized if:
1178970_18_ITEM1_P179_S0	its ratio of Tier 1 capital to total assets is at least 4% and it is not a well-capitalized institution.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P179_S1	An institution will be treated as undercapitalized if:
1178970_18_ITEM1_P180_S0	its leverage ratio is less than 4% An institution will be treated as significantly undercapitalized if:
1178970_18_ITEM1_P181_S0	its leverage ratio is less than 3%.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P181_S1	An institution that has a tangible capital to total assets ratio equal to or less than 2% would be deemed critically undercapitalized.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P181_S2	The FDIC is required, with some exceptions, to appoint a receiver or conservator for an insured state bank if that bank is critically undercapitalized.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P181_S3	The FDIC may also appoint a conservator or receiver for an insured state bank on the basis of the institution s financial condition or upon the occurrence of certain events, including:
1178970_18_ITEM1_P182_S0	insufficient capital, or the incurring or likely incurring of losses that will substantially deplete all of the institution s capital with no reasonable prospect of replenishment of capital without federal assistance.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P182_S1	The previously discussed final rule that increased capital requirements effective January 1, 2015 adjusted the prompt action categories as reflected above.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P183_S0	Loans to a Bank s Insiders Federal Regulation.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P183_S1	A bank s loans to its executive officers, directors, any owner of 10% or more of its stock (each, an insider) and any of certain entities affiliated with any such person (an insider s related interest) are subject to the conditions and limitations imposed by Section 22(h) of the Federal Reserve Act and the Federal Reserve Board s Regulation O.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P183_S2	Under these restrictions, the aggregate amount of the loans to any insider and the insider s related interests may not exceed the loans-to-one-borrower limit applicable to national banks, which is comparable to the loans-to-one-borrower limit applicable to loans by the Bank.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P183_S3	All loans by a bank to all insiders and insiders related interests in the aggregate may not exceed the bank s unimpaired capital and unimpaired surplus.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P183_S4	With certain exceptions, loans to an executive officer, other than loans for the education of the officer s children and certain loans secured by the officer s residence may not exceed at any one time the higher of 2.5% of the bank s unimpaired capital and unimpaired surplus or $25,000, but in no event more than $100,000.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P183_S5	Regulation O also requires that any proposed loan to an insider or a related interest of that insider be approved in advance by a majority of the board of directors of the bank, with any interested directors not participating in the voting, if such loan, when aggregated with any existing loans to that insider and the insider s related interests, would exceed either (1) $500,000; or (2) the greater of $25,000 or 5% of the bank s unimpaired capital and surplus.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P184_S0	Generally, loans to insiders must be made on substantially the same terms as, and follow credit underwriting procedures that are not less stringent than, those prevailing at the time for, comparable transactions with other persons, and not involve more than the normal risk of payment or present other unfavorable features.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P184_S1	An exception may be made for extensions of credit made pursuant to a benefit or compensation plan of a bank that is widely available to employees of the bank and that does not give any preference to insiders of the bank over other employees of the bank.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P184_S2	In addition, federal law prohibits extensions of credit to a bank s insiders and their related interests by any other institution that has a correspondent banking relationship with the bank, unless such extension of credit is on substantially the same terms as those prevailing at the time for comparable transactions with other persons and does not involve more than the normal risk of repayment or present other unfavorable features.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P185_S0	The Bank does not, as a matter of policy, make loans to its directors or to their immediate family members and related interests.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P186_S0	Provisions of the New Jersey Banking Act impose conditions and limitations on the liabilities owed to a savings bank by its directors and executive officers and by corporations and partnerships controlled by such persons that are comparable in many respects to the conditions and limitations imposed on the loans and extensions of credit to insiders and their related interests under Regulation O, as discussed above.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P186_S1	The New Jersey Banking Act also provides that a savings bank that is in compliance with Regulation O is deemed to be in compliance with such provisions of the New Jersey Banking Act.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P187_S0	Federal Reserve System Under Federal Reserve Board regulations, the Bank is required to maintain non-interest earning reserves against its transaction accounts.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P187_S1	For 2018, the Federal Reserve Board regulations generally require that reserves of 3% must be maintained against aggregate transaction accounts over $16.0 million and up to $122.3 million, and 10% against that portion of total transaction accounts in excess of up to $122.3 million.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P187_S2	The first $16.0 million of otherwise reservable balances are exempted from the reserve requirements.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P187_S3	The Bank is in compliance with these requirements.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P187_S4	These requirements are adjusted annually by the Federal Reserve Board.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P187_S5	Because required reserves must be maintained in the form of either vault cash, a non-interest bearing account at a Federal Reserve Bank or a pass-through account as defined by the Federal Reserve Board, the effect of this reserve requirement is to reduce the Bank s interest-earning assets.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P188_S0	The Bank is authorized to borrow from the Federal Reserve Bank discount window.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P189_S0	Internet Banking Technological developments continue to significantly alter the ways in which financial institutions and their customers conduct their business.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P189_S1	The growth of the Internet has caused banks to adopt and refine alternative distribution and marketing systems.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P189_S2	The federal bank regulatory agencies have targeted various aspects of internet banking, including the security and systems.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P189_S3	There can be no assurance that the bank regulatory agencies will adopt new regulations that will not materially affect the Bank s Internet operations or restrict any such further operations.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P190_S0	The USA PATRIOT Act The USA PATRIOT Act gives the federal government powers to address terrorist threats through enhanced domestic security measures, expanded surveillance powers, increased information sharing, and broadened anti-money laundering requirements.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P190_S1	By way of amendments to the Bank Secrecy Act, Title III of the USA PATRIOT Act included measures intended to encourage information sharing among bank regulatory agencies and law enforcement bodies.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P190_S2	Further, certain provisions of Title III imposed affirmative obligations on a broad range of financial institutions, including banks, thrifts, brokers, dealers, credit unions, money transfer agents and parties registered under the Commodity Exchange Act.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P191_S0	The bank regulatory agencies have increased the regulatory scrutiny of the Bank Secrecy Act and anti-money laundering programs maintained by financial institutions.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P191_S1	Significant penalties and fines, as well as other supervisory orders may be imposed on a financial institution for non-compliance with these requirements.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P191_S2	In addition, the federal bank regulatory agencies must consider the effectiveness of financial institutions engaging in a merger transaction in combating money laundering activities.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P191_S3	The Bank has adopted policies and procedures which are in compliance with these requirements.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P191_S4	The Company is regulated as a bank holding company, and as such, is subject to examination, regulation and periodic reporting under the Bank Holding Company Act, as administered by the Federal Reserve Board.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P191_S5	The Federal Reserve Board has adopted capital adequacy guidelines for bank holding companies on a consolidated basis.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P191_S6	The Dodd-Frank Act directed the Federal Reserve Board to issue consolidated capital requirements for depository institution holding companies that are not less stringent, both quantitatively and in terms of components of capital, than those applicable to institutions themselves.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P191_S7	The previously discussed final rule regarding regulatory capital requirements implemented the Dodd-Frank Act as to bank holding company capital standards.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P191_S8	Consolidated regulatory capital requirements identical to those applicable to the subsidiary banks applied to bank holding companies (with greater than $1 billion of assets) as of January 1, 2015.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P191_S9	As is the case with institutions themselves, the capital conservation buffer was effective on January 1, 2016, and will increase each year until fully implemented on January 1, 2019.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P191_S10	As of December 31, 2017 , the Company s regulatory capital ratios exceed these minimum capital requirements.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P191_S11	The following table shows the Company s Tier 1 leverage capital ratio, common equity Tier 1 risk-based capital ratio, Tier 1 risk-based capital ratio and the total risk-based capital ratio as of December 31, 2017 .
1178970_18_ITEM1_P192_S0	(1) For purposes of calculating regulatory Tier 1 leverage capital, assets are based on adjusted total leverage assets.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P192_S1	In calculating common equity Tier 1 capital, Tier 1 risk-based capital and total risk-based capital, assets are based on total risk-weighted assets.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P192_S2	As of December 31, 2017 , the Company was well capitalized under Federal Reserve Board guidelines.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P193_S0	Regulations of the Federal Reserve Board provide that a bank holding company must serve as a source of strength to any of its subsidiary banks and must not conduct its activities in an unsafe or unsound manner.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P193_S1	Federal Reserve Board policies generally provide that bank holding companies should pay dividends only out of current earnings and only if the prospective rate of earnings retention in the holding company appears consistent with the organization s capital needs, asset quality and overall financial condition.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P194_S0	Under the prompt corrective action provisions discussed above, a bank holding company parent of an undercapitalized subsidiary bank would be directed to guarantee, within limitations, the capital restoration plan that is required of such an undercapitalized bank.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P194_S1	If the undercapitalized bank fails to file an acceptable capital restoration plan or fails to implement an accepted plan, the Federal Reserve Board may prohibit the bank holding company parent of the undercapitalized bank from paying any dividends or making any other form of capital distribution without the prior approval of the Federal Reserve Board.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P195_S0	As a bank holding company, the Company is required to obtain the prior approval of the Federal Reserve Board to acquire all, or substantially all, of the assets of any bank or bank holding company.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P195_S1	Prior Federal Reserve Board approval will be required for the Company to acquire direct or indirect ownership or control of any voting securities of any bank or bank holding company if, after giving effect to such acquisition, it would, directly or indirectly, own or control more than 5% of any class of voting shares of such bank or bank holding company.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P196_S0	A bank holding company is required to give the Federal Reserve Board prior written notice of any purchase or redemption of its outstanding equity securities if the gross consideration for the purchase or redemption, when combined with the net consideration paid for all such purchases or redemptions during the preceding 12 months will be equal to 10% or more of the company s consolidated net worth.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P196_S1	The Federal Reserve Board may disapprove such a purchase or redemption if it determines that the proposal would constitute an unsafe and unsound practice, or would violate any law, regulation, Federal Reserve Board order or directive, or any condition imposed by, or written agreement with, the Federal Reserve Board.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P196_S2	Such notice and approval is not required for a bank holding company that would be treated as well capitalized under applicable regulations of the Federal Reserve Board, is well-managed, and that is not the subject of any unresolved supervisory issues.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P196_S3	In addition, a bank holding company which does not opt to become a financial holding company under applicable federal law is generally prohibited from engaging in, or acquiring direct or indirect control of any company engaged in non-banking activities.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P196_S4	One of the principal exceptions to this prohibition is for activities found by the Federal Reserve Board to be so closely related to banking or managing or controlling banks as to be permissible.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P196_S5	Some of the principal activities that the Federal Reserve Board has determined by regulation to be so closely related to banking as to be permissible are:
1178970_18_ITEM1_P197_S0	acquiring a savings and loan association.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P198_S0	Bank holding companies that qualify and opt to become a financial holding company may engage in activities that are financial in nature or incident to activities which are financial in nature.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P198_S1	Financial holding companies may engage in a broader array of activities including insurance and investment banking.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P199_S0	Bank holding companies may qualify to become a financial holding company if at the time of the election and on a continuing basis:
1178970_18_ITEM1_P200_S0	each of its depository institution subsidiaries has at least a Satisfactory Community Reinvestment Act rating at its most recent examination.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P201_S0	The Company filed an election to qualify as a financial holding company under federal regulations on January 31, 2014 which was deemed effective by the Federal Reserve Board on March 5, 2015.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P202_S0	Under federal law, depository institutions are liable to the FDIC for losses suffered or anticipated by the FDIC in connection with the default of a commonly controlled depository institution or any assistance provided by the FDIC to such an institution in danger of default.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P202_S1	This law would potentially be applicable to the Company if it ever acquired as a separate subsidiary, a depository institution in addition to the Bank.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P203_S0	Under the New Jersey Banking Act, a company owning or controlling a savings bank is regulated as a bank holding company.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P203_S1	The New Jersey Banking Act defines the terms company and bank holding company as such terms are defined under the BHCA.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P203_S2	Each bank holding company controlling a New Jersey chartered bank or savings bank must file certain reports with the Commissioner and is subject to examination by the Commissioner.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P204_S0	Under federal law and under the New Jersey Banking Act, no person may acquire control of the Company or the Bank without first obtaining approval of such acquisition of control from the Federal Reserve Board and the Commissioner.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P205_S0	The Company s common stock is registered with the SEC under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P205_S1	The Company is subject to the information, proxy solicitation, insider trading restrictions and other requirements under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P206_S0	Investment Adviser Regulation Beacon Investment Advisory Services, Inc. is an investment adviser registered with the SEC.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P206_S1	As such, it is required to make certain filings with and is subject to periodic examination by, the SEC.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P207_S0	The Company is incorporated under the laws of the State of Delaware.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P207_S1	As a result, the rights of its stockholders are governed by the Delaware General Corporate Law and the Company s Certificate of Incorporation and Bylaws.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P207_S2	The Company is subject to federal income taxation in the same general manner as other corporations, with some exceptions discussed below.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P207_S3	The following discussion of federal taxation is intended only to summarize certain pertinent federal income tax matters and is not a comprehensive description of the tax rules applicable to the Company.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P208_S0	On December 22, 2017, the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act ("Tax Act") was enacted.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P208_S1	Included as part of the law, was a permanent reduction in the federal corporate income tax rate from 35% to 21% effective January 1, 2018.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P208_S2	Based upon the change in the tax rate, the Company revalued its net deferred tax asset at December 31, 2017 to reflect the reduced rate that will apply in future periods when theses deferred taxes are settled or realized.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P208_S3	As a result of the enactment of the Tax Act, the Company recognized an additional tax expense of $3.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2017.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P208_S4	For federal income tax purposes, the Company currently reports its income and expenses on the accrual method of accounting and uses a tax year ending December 31 for filing its consolidated federal income tax returns.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P209_S0	Prior to the Small Business Protection Act of 1996 (the 1996 Act ), the Bank was permitted to establish a reserve for bad debts and to make annual additions to the reserve.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P209_S1	These additions could, within specified formula limits, be deducted in arriving at taxable income.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P210_S0	The Bank was required to use the direct charge-off method to compute its bad debt deduction beginning with its 1996 federal income tax return.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P211_S0	Savings institutions were required to recapture any excess reserves over those established as of December 31, 1987 (base year reserve).
1178970_18_ITEM1_P211_S1	Prior to the 1996 Act, bad debt reserves created prior to January 1, 1988 were subject to recapture into taxable income should the Bank fail to meet certain asset and definitional tests.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P211_S2	Federal legislation has eliminated these recapture rules.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P211_S3	Retained earnings at December 31, 2017 included approximately $51.8 million for which no provisions for income tax had been made.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P211_S4	This amount represents an allocation of income to bad debt deductions for tax purposes only.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P211_S5	Events that would result in taxation of these reserves include failure to qualify as a bank for tax purposes, distributions in complete or partial liquidation, stock redemptions and excess distributions to shareholders.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P211_S6	At December 31, 2017 , the Bank had an unrecognized tax liability of $13.7 million with respect to this reserve.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P212_S0	The Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended (the Code ), imposes an alternative minimum tax (AMT) at a rate of 20% on a base of regular taxable income plus certain tax preferences (alternative minimum taxable income or AMTI).
1178970_18_ITEM1_P212_S1	The AMT is payable to the extent such AMTI is in excess of an exemption amount and the AMT exceeds the regular income tax.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P212_S2	Net operating losses can offset no more than 90% of AMTI.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P213_S0	Certain payments of alternative minimum tax may be used as credits against regular tax liabilities in future years.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P213_S1	The Company has not been subject to the alternative minimum tax and has no such amounts available as credits for carryover.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P213_S2	The recently enacted Tax Act repeals the corporate AMT effective for tax years beginning after December 31, 2017.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P214_S0	Under the general rule, a financial institution may carry back net operating losses to the preceding two taxable years and forward to the succeeding 20 taxable years.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P214_S1	At December 31, 2017 , the Company had approximately $1.3 million of Federal Net Operating Losses ("NOLs").
1178970_18_ITEM1_P214_S2	These NOLs were generated by entities the Company acquired in previous years and are subject to an annual Code Section 382 limitation.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P214_S3	The Tax Act limits limits the NOL deduction for a given year to 80% of taxable income, effective with respect to losses arising in tax years beginning after December 31, 2017.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P215_S0	pre-enactment carryback provision for NOLs and provides for the indefinite carryforward of NOLs arrising in tax years ending after December 31, 2017.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P216_S0	The Company may exclude from its income 100% of dividends received from the Bank as a member of the same affiliated group of corporations.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P217_S0	State Taxation New Jersey State Taxation.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P217_S1	The Company and the Bank file New Jersey Corporation Business Tax returns.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P218_S0	Generally, the income of financial institutions in New Jersey, which is calculated based on federal taxable income subject to certain adjustments, is subject to New Jersey tax.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P218_S1	The Company and the Bank are currently subject to the corporation business tax at 9% of apportioned taxable income.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P219_S0	New Jersey tax law does not and has not allowed for a taxpayer to file a tax return on a combined or consolidated basis with another member of the affiliated group where there is common ownership.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P219_S1	However, if the taxpayer cannot demonstrate by clear and convincing evidence that the tax filing discloses the true earnings of the taxpayer on its business carried on in the State of New Jersey, the Director of the New Jersey Division of Taxation may, at the director s discretion, require the taxpayer to file a consolidated return of the entire operations of the affiliated group or controlled group, including its own operations and income.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P220_S0	The Bank is subject to Pennsylvania Mutual Thrift Institutions Tax.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P220_S1	Mutual thrift institutions tax is imposed at the rate of 11.5% on net taxable income of mutual thrift institutions in Pennsylvania, including savings banks without capital stock, building and loan associations, savings and loan associations, and savings institutions having capital stock.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P221_S0	In 2014, New York State enacted significant and comprehensive reforms to its corporate tax system that went into effect January 1, 2015.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P221_S1	The new legislation resulted in significant changes to the method of calculating income taxes for banks, including changes to future period tax rates, rules relating to the sourcing of income, and the elimination of the banking corporation tax so that banking corporations will now be taxed under New York State s corporate franchise tax.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P222_S0	The corporate franchise tax is based on the combined entire net income of the Company and its affiliates allocable and apportionable to New York State and taxed at a rate of 6.5%.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P222_S1	The amount of revenues that are sourced to New York State under the new legislation can be expected to fluctuate over time.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P223_S0	Surcharge allocable to business activities carried on in the Metropolitan Commuter Transportation District.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P223_S1	The MTA surcharge for 2017 was 28.3% of a recomputed New York State franchise tax, calculated using a 6.5% tax rate on allocated and apportioned entire net income.
1178970_18_ITEM1_P223_S2	The Bank is currently under audit with respect to its New York State combined franchise tax return for tax years 2015 and 2016.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P0_S0	Changes in interest rates could adversely affect our results of operations and financial condition.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P0_S1	Our financial condition and results of operations are significantly affected by changes in market interest rates, and the degree to which these changes disparately impact short-term and long-term interest rates.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P0_S2	Our results of operations substantially depend on our net interest income, which is the difference between the interest income we earn on our interest-earning assets and the interest expense we pay on our interest-bearing liabilities.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P1_S0	The Federal Reserve Board has maintained interest rates at historically low levels through its targeted federal funds rate and recently shifted its strategy to a measured approach of increasing the targeted federal funds rate.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P2_S0	If the Federal Reserve Board s recent policy action to increase short-term rates does not result in a commensurate increase in long-term rates, we may experience a flattening or inverted yield curve that could negatively impact our net interest margin and earnings.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P2_S1	Our interest-bearing liabilities may be subject to repricing or maturing more quickly than our interest-earning assets.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P2_S2	If rates increase rapidly, we may have to increase the rates we pay on our deposits and borrowed funds more quickly than we can increase the interest rates we earn on our loans and investments, resulting in a negative effect on interest spreads and net interest income.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P2_S3	In addition, the effect of rising rates could be compounded if deposit customers move funds into higher yielding accounts.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P2_S4	In the event of a 300 basis point increase in interest rates, whereby rates ramp up evenly over a twelve-month period, and assuming management took no actions to mitigate the effect of such change, we are projecting that our net interest income would decrease 3.8% or $11.2 million .
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P3_S0	negatively affected if competitive pressures keep us from further reducing rates on our deposits, while the yields on our assets decrease through loan prepayments and interest rate adjustments.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P3_S1	Changes in interest rates also affect the value of our interest-earning assets and in particular our securities portfolio.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P3_S2	Generally, the value of securities fluctuates inversely with changes in interest rates.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P3_S3	At December 31, 2017 , our available for sale securities portfolio totaled $1.04 billion .
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P3_S4	Unrealized gains and losses on securities available for sale are reported as a separate component of stockholders equity.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P3_S5	Decreases in the fair value of securities available for sale resulting from increases in interest rates therefore could have a temporary adverse effect on stockholders equity.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P4_S0	We are also subject to other financial risks related to interest rate movements.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P5_S0	Changes in interest rates can affect the average lives of loans and mortgage related securities.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P5_S1	Increases in interest rates can result in extending the average lives of our loans and mortgage related securities, thereby reducing the amount of cash flows available to invest in higher-yielding assets.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P5_S2	Decreases in interest rates can result in the prepayment or refinancing of loans and loans underlying mortgage related securities, resulting in accelerated cash flows subject to reinvestment at reduced market interest rates and increased premium amortization.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P6_S0	We are subject to liquidity risk.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P6_S1	Liquidity risk is the potential that we will be unable to meet our obligations as they become due or capitalize on growth opportunities as they arise because of an inability to liquidate assets or obtain adequate funding on a timely basis at a reasonable cost.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P7_S0	Liquidity is required to fund various obligations, including loan originations and commitments, withdrawals by depositors, repayments of borrowings, operating expenses and capital expenditures.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P7_S1	Liquidity is derived primarily from deposit growth and retention; principal and interest payments, sales, maturities, and prepayments of loans and investment securities; net cash provided from operations; and access to other funding sources.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P7_S2	Our access to funding sources in amounts adequate to finance our activities could be impaired by factors specific to us or the financial services industry in general.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P7_S3	Factors detrimental to our access to liquidity sources include a decrease in the level of our business activity due to a market downturn, lack of competitiveness, or adverse regulatory action against us.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P7_S4	Our ability to borrow could also be impaired by factors that are not specific to us, such as a severe disruption of the financial markets or negative views and expectations about the prospects for the financial services industry.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P7_S5	If our allowance for loan losses is not sufficient to cover actual loan losses, our earnings could decrease.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P8_S0	We make various assumptions and judgments about the collectability of our loan portfolio, including the creditworthiness of our borrowers and the value of the real estate and other assets serving as collateral for the repayment of many of our loans.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P8_S1	In determining the amount of the allowance for loan losses, we rely on our loan quality reviews and credit risk ratings, loan portfolio trends, our experience and our evaluation of economic conditions, among other factors.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P8_S2	If our assumptions prove to be incorrect, or if delinquencies or non-accrual and non-performing loans increase, the allowance for loan losses may not be sufficient to cover losses inherent in our loan portfolio, resulting in additions to our allowance.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P8_S3	Material additions to the allowance would materially decrease our net income.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P8_S4	Bank regulators periodically review our allowance for loan losses and may require us to increase our provision for loan losses or recognize further loan charge-offs.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P9_S0	In 2016, the Financial Accounting Standards Board released an updated standard for determining credit losses, which fundamentally changes how financial institutions calculate their allowance reserves.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P9_S1	The new standard, which will become effective for reporting periods effective January 1, 2020, will require us to adopt a Current Expected Credit Loss model that measures projected credit losses over the estimated life of the asset.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P9_S2	This approach is a significant departure from the current accounting standard, which estimates potential credit losses based on losses considered to be probable and reasonably estimable.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P9_S3	When adopted, this new standard may increase our allowance for credit losses, which could materially affect our financial condition and future results of operations.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P9_S4	The extent of the increase, if any, will ultimately depend upon the nature and characteristics of our loan portfolio at the adoption date, as well as the macroeconomic assumptions and forecasts used at that date.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P9_S5	Therefore, the potential financial impact is currently unknown.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P10_S0	Our commercial real estate, multi-family, and commercial loans expose us to increased lending risks.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P10_S1	A significant portion of our loan portfolio consists of commercial real estate, multi-family, commercial and, to a lesser extent, construction loans.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P10_S2	These loans are generally regarded as having a higher risk of default and loss than single-family residential mortgage loans, because repayment of these loans often depends on the successful operation of a business or of the underlying property.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P10_S3	In addition, our construction loans, multi-family loans, commercial mortgage loans and commercial loans have significantly larger average loan balances compared to our single-family residential mortgage loans.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P10_S4	Also, many of our borrowers of these types of loans have more than one loan outstanding with us.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P10_S5	Consequently, any adverse development with respect to one loan or one credit relationship can expose us to a significantly greater risk of loss compared to an adverse development with respect to one single-family residential mortgage loan.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P11_S0	We may be adversely affected by recent changes in U.S. tax laws.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P11_S1	The Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, which was enacted in December 2017, is likely to have both positive and negative effects on our financial performance.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P11_S2	For example, the new legislation will result in a reduction in our federal corporate tax rate from 35% to 21% beginning in 2018, which will have a favorable impact on our earnings and capital generation abilities.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P11_S3	However, the new legislation also enacted limitations on certain deductions that will have an impact on the banking industry, borrowers and the market for single-family residential real estate.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P11_S4	These limitations include (1) a lower limit on the deductibility of mortgage interest on single-family residential mortgage loans, (2) the elimination of interest deductions for certain home equity loans, (3) a limitation on the deductibility of business interest expense, and (4) a limitation on the deductibility of property taxes and state and local income taxes.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P11_S5	As a result of the enactment of this legislation, the Company recognized an additional tax expense of $3.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2017.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P12_S0	The recent changes in the tax laws may have an adverse effect on the market for, and the valuation of, residential properties, and on the demand for such loans in the future, and could make it harder for borrowers to make their loan payments.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P12_S1	In addition, these recent changes may also have a disproportionate effect on taxpayers in states with high residential home prices and high state and local taxes, like New Jersey.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P13_S0	If home ownership becomes less attractive, demand for mortgage loans could decrease.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P13_S1	The value of the properties securing loans in our loan portfolio may be adversely impacted as a result of the changing economics of home ownership, which could require an increase in our provision for loan losses, which would reduce our profitability and could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P13_S2	If bank regulators impose limitations on our commercial real estate lending activities, earnings could be adversely affected.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P14_S0	The FDIC, the OCC and the FRB (collectively, the Agencies ) have issued joint guidance entitled Concentrations in Commercial Real Estate Lending, Sound Risk Management Practices (the CRE Guidance ).
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P14_S1	Although the CRE Guidance did not establish specific lending limits, it provides that a bank s commercial real estate lending exposure may receive increased supervisory scrutiny where total non-owner occupied commercial real estate loans, including loans secured by apartment buildings, investor commercial real estate and construction and land loans ( CRE Loans ), represent 300% or more of an institution s total risk-based capital and the outstanding balance of the CRE Loan portfolio has increased by 50% or more during the preceding 36 months.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P14_S2	While our level of CRE Loans equaled 453% of total risk-based capital at December 31, 2017, our CRE Loan portfolio has not increased by 50% or more during the preceding 36 months.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P15_S0	In December 2015, the Agencies released a new statement on prudent risk management for commercial real estate lending (the 2015 Statement ).
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P15_S1	In the 2015 Statement, the Agencies express concerns about easing commercial real estate underwriting standards, direct financial institutions to maintain underwriting discipline and exercise risk management practices to identify, measure and monitor lending risks, and indicate that the Agencies will continue to pay special attention to commercial real estate lending activities and concentrations going forward.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P16_S0	If our regulators were to impose restrictions on the amount of commercial real estate loans we can hold in our loan portfolio, or require higher capital ratios as a result of the level of commercial real estate loans held, our earnings or our ability to engage in certain merger and acquisition activity could be adversely affected.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P16_S1	Our continuing concentration of loans in our primary market area may increase our risk.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P16_S2	Our success is significantly affected by general economic conditions in northern and central New Jersey, and eastern Pennsylvania.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P16_S3	Unlike some larger banks that are more geographically diversified, we provide banking and financial services to customers mostly located in our primary markets.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P16_S4	Consequently, a downturn in economic conditions in our local markets would have a significant impact on our loan portfolios, the ability of borrowers to meet their loan payment obligations and the value of the collateral securing our loans.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P16_S5	Adverse local economic conditions caused by inflation, recession, unemployment or other factors beyond our control would impact these local economic conditions and could negatively affect the financial results of our banking operations.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P16_S6	Additionally, because we have a significant amount of real estate loans, depressed real estate values and real estate sales could also have a negative effect on the ability of many of our borrowers to make timely repayments of their loans, which would have an adverse impact on our earnings and overall financial condition.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P17_S0	We target our business development and marketing strategy for loans to serve primarily the banking and financial services needs of small- to medium-sized businesses in northern and central New Jersey and eastern Pennsylvania.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P17_S1	These businesses generally have fewer financial resources in terms of capital or borrowing capacity than larger entities.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P17_S2	If general economic conditions negatively impact these businesses, our results of operations and financial condition may be adversely affected.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P17_S3	Risks associated with cyber-security could negatively affect our earnings.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P18_S0	The financial services industry continues to experience increasing numbers of severe cyber-attacks aimed at gaining unauthorized access to systems and data, or obstructing access to bank systems as a way to misappropriate assets and sensitive information, corrupt and destroy data, or cause operational disruptions.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P19_S0	We have established policies, processes, and tools to limit the impact of cyber-attacks, but such events may still occur or may not be adequately addressed if they do occur.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P19_S1	Although we rely on security safeguards to secure our data, these safeguards may not fully protect our systems from compromises or breaches.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P20_S0	We also rely on the integrity and security of a variety of third party processors, payment clearing and settlement systems, as well as the various participants involved in these systems, many of which have no direct relationship with us.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P20_S1	Failure by these participants or their systems to protect our customers transaction data and maintain operational resiliency may put us at risk for possible losses due to fraud or operational disruption.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P20_S2	Our customers are also the target of cyber-attacks and identity theft.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P20_S3	Large scale identity theft could result in customers' accounts being compromised and fraudulent activities being performed in their name.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P20_S4	We have implemented safeguards against these types of activities but they may not fully protect us from fraudulent financial losses.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P20_S5	The occurrence of a breach of security involving our customers' information, regardless of its origin, could damage our reputation and result in a loss of customers and business, and subject us to additional regulatory scrutiny, and could expose us to litigation and possible financial liability.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P20_S6	Any of these events could have a material adverse effect on our financial condition and results of operations.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P21_S0	We operate in a highly regulated environment and may be adversely affected by changes in laws and regulations.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P21_S1	We are subject to extensive regulation, supervision and examination by the New Jersey Department of Banking and Insurance, our chartering authority, and by the FDIC, as insurer of our deposits.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P21_S2	As a bank holding company, we are subject to regulation and oversight by the Federal Reserve Board.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P21_S3	Such regulation and supervision govern the activities in which a bank and its holding company may engage and are intended primarily for the protection of the insurance fund and depositors.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P21_S4	These regulatory authorities have extensive discretion in connection with their supervisory and enforcement activities, including the requirement for additional capital, the imposition of restrictions on our operations, the classification of our assets, the adequacy of our allowance for loan losses, and our management of risks posed by our reliance on third party vendors.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P21_S5	Any change in such regulation and oversight, whether in the form of regulatory policy, regulations, or legislation, could have a material impact on our operations.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P21_S6	The potential exists for additional Federal or state laws and regulations regarding capital requirements, lending and funding practices and liquidity standards, and bank regulatory agencies are expected to remain active in responding to concerns and trends identified in examinations, including the potential issuance of formal enforcement orders.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P22_S0	Actions taken to date, as well as potential actions, may not have the beneficial effects that are intended.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P22_S1	In addition, new laws, regulations, and other regulatory changes could increase our costs of regulatory compliance and of doing business, and otherwise affect our operations.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P22_S2	New laws, regulations, and other regulatory changes, may significantly affect the markets in which we do business, the markets for and value of our loans and investments, and our ongoing operations, costs and profitability.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P22_S3	We will be subject to heightened regulatory requirements when we exceed total assets of $10 billion.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P22_S4	Provident's total assets were $9.85 billion at December 31, 2017 .
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P22_S5	Banks with assets in excess of $10 billion are subject to requirements imposed by the Dodd-Frank Act and its implementing regulations including the examination authority of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau to assess our compliance with federal consumer financial laws, imposition of higher FDIC premiums, reduced debit card interchange fees, enhanced risk management frameworks and stress testing, all of which increase operating costs and reduce earnings.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P22_S6	As we approach $10 billion in assets, we are incurring additional costs to prepare for the implementation of these imposed requirements.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P22_S7	We may be required to invest more significant management attention and resources to evaluate and continue to make any changes necessary to comply with new statutory and regulatory requirements under the Dodd-Frank Act.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P22_S8	Further, federal financial regulators may require us to accelerate our actions and investments to prepare for compliance before we exceed $10 billion in total consolidated assets, and may suspend or delay certain regulatory actions, such as approving a merger agreement, if they deem our preparations to be inadequate.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P22_S9	Upon reaching this threshold, we face the risk that we may fail to meet these requirements, which may negatively impact our results of operations and financial condition.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P22_S10	While we cannot predict what effect any presently contemplated or future changes in the laws or regulations or their interpretations would have on us, these changes could be materially adverse to our investors.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P22_S11	A general economic slowdown or uncertainty that produces either reduced returns or excessive market volatility could adversely impact our wealth management fee income.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P22_S12	A general economic slowdown could affect the value of the assets under management in our wealth management business resulting in lower fee income.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P22_S13	Furthermore, conditions that produce extended market volatility could affect our ability to provide our clients with an adequate return, thereby impacting our ability to attract new clients or causing existing clients to seek more stable investment opportunities with alternative wealth advisors.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P22_S14	Strong competition within our market area may limit our growth and profitability.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P22_S15	Competition in the banking and financial services industry is intense and expanding with entrants into our market providing new and innovative technology-driven financial solutions.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P22_S16	Our profitability depends upon our continued ability to successfully compete in our market area.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P22_S17	We compete with commercial banks, savings institutions, mortgage banking firms, credit unions, finance companies, investment advisers, wealth managers, mutual funds, insurance companies, online lenders, and brokerage and investment banking firms operating both locally and elsewhere.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P23_S0	In particular, over the past decade, our local markets have experienced the effects of substantial banking consolidation, and large out-of-state competitors have grown significantly.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P23_S1	Many of these competitors have substantially greater resources and lending limits than we do, and may offer certain deposit and loan pricing, services or credit criteria that we do not or cannot provide.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P23_S2	There are also a number of strong locally-based competitors with large capital positions in our market who may deploy aggressive strategies to drive growth, take our customers and win market share.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P23_S3	Furthermore, key components of the financial services value chain have been replicated by digital innovation, commonly referred to as Fintech.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P23_S4	The adoption of these Fintech solutions within our market area may cause greater and faster disruption to our business model if we are unable to keep pace with, or invest wisely in, these enabling technologies.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P24_S0	Because the financial services business involves a high volume of transactions, we face significant operational risks.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P24_S1	We operate in diverse market segments and rely on the ability of our employees, systems and third party providers, who are used extensively in support of our operations, to process a high number of transactions.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P24_S2	Operational risk is the risk of loss resulting from our operations, including but not limited to, the risk of fraud by employees or persons outside our company, the execution of unauthorized transactions by employees, errors relating to transaction processing and technology, breaches of the internal control system and compliance requirements, the occurrence of systems failures and disruptions, and business continuation and disaster recovery.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P24_S3	Insurance coverage may not be available for such losses, or where available, such losses may exceed insurance limits.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P24_S4	This risk of loss also includes the potential legal actions that could arise as a result of an operational deficiency or as a result of noncompliance with applicable regulatory standards, adverse business decisions or their implementation, and customer attrition due to potential negative publicity.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P24_S5	While we maintain a risk management program that is designed to minimize risk, we could suffer losses, face regulatory action, and suffer damage to our reputation as a result of our failure to properly anticipate and manage these risks.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P24_S6	Acts of terrorism and other external events could impact our ability to conduct business.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P24_S7	Our business is subject to risk from external events.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P25_S0	Financial institutions have been, and continue to be, targets of terrorist threats aimed at compromising their operating and communication systems.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P25_S1	The metropolitan New York and Philadelphia areas remain central targets for potential acts of terrorism, including cyber terrorism, which could affect not only our operations but those of our customers.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P25_S2	Events such as these may become more common in the future and could cause significant damage such as disrupt power and communication services, impact the stability of our facilities and result in additional expenses, impair the ability of our borrowers to repay their loans, reduce the value of collateral securing the repayment of our loans, which could result in the loss of revenue.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P25_S3	While we have established and regularly test disaster recovery procedures, the occurrence of any such event could have a material adverse effect on our business, operations and financial condition.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P26_S0	We hold certain intangible assets that could be classified as impaired in the future.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P26_S1	If these assets are considered to be either partially or fully impaired in the future, our earnings could decline.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P27_S0	We record all assets acquired and liabilities assumed by the Company in purchase acquisitions, including goodwill and other intangible assets, at fair value.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P27_S1	At December 31, 2017 , goodwill totaling $411.6 million was not amortized but remains subject to impairment tests at least annually, or more often if events or circumstances indicate it may be impaired.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P27_S2	Other intangible assets are amortized over their estimated useful lives and are subject to impairment tests if events or circumstances indicate a potential inability to realize the carrying amount.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P27_S3	The initial recording and subsequent impairment testing of goodwill and other intangible assets requires subjective judgments about the estimates of the fair value of assets acquired.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P27_S4	It is possible that our future impairment testing could result in an impairment of the value of goodwill or other identified intangible assets, or both.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P27_S5	If we determine impairment exists at a given point in time, our earnings and the book value of the related intangible asset(s) will be reduced by the amount of the impairment.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P27_S6	In any event, the results of impairment testing on goodwill and other identified intangible assets have no impact on our tangible book value or regulatory capital levels.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P27_S7	A State Bank in New Jersey could be disruptive to our overall strategies and potentially reduce the level of public funds held on deposit with us.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P28_S0	We maintain a large and relatively stable level of deposits from local government entities, primarily through relationships we have cultivated with New Jersey municipalities.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P28_S1	These moneys are a relatively low-cost source used to fund our loans and investments.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P29_S0	The State of New Jersey is considering creating a State Bank, whose purpose would be to promote small businesses, fair educational lending, housing, infrastructure improvements, community development, economic development, commerce, and industry in the State.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P29_S1	As currently proposed, it intends to permit State funds, including funds from State institutions and any State public source, to be held by the State Bank.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P29_S2	There can be no assurance that legislation to create a State Bank will pass or whether it will pass as currently proposed.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P29_S3	Given the degree of our funding reliance on many New Jersey-based public entities and the potential scope of the proposed State Bank s lending activities, we are uncertain of the impact this proposal may have on us.
1178970_18_ITEM1A_P29_S4	If we are unable to retain the current level of public funds on deposit, we may need to increase the costs associated with our funding needs, which could have a negative impact on our net income.
1178970_18_ITEM1B_P0_S0	There are no unresolved comments from the staff of the SEC to report.
