1178970_18_ITEM2_P0_S0	Property At December 31, 2017 , the Bank conducted business through 84 full-service branch offices located in Hudson, Bergen, Essex, Hunterdon, Mercer, Middlesex, Monmouth, Morris, Ocean, Passaic, Somerset, Union and Warren counties in New Jersey, and in Bucks, Lehigh and Northampton counties in Pennsylvania.
1178970_18_ITEM2_P0_S1	The Bank maintains satellite loan production offices in Convent Station, Flemington, Paramus and Princeton, New Jersey, as well as in Bethlehem, Newtown and Wayne, Pennsylvania.
1178970_18_ITEM2_P0_S2	The aggregate net book value of premises and equipment was $63.2 million at December 31, 2017 .
1178970_18_ITEM2_P0_S3	On December 13, 2017, the Company completed the sale and leaseback of 12 of its New Jersey banking offices, which had a net book value of $14.5 million.
1178970_18_ITEM2_P0_S4	Net proceeds from the sale totaled $20.7 million.
1178970_18_ITEM2_P0_S5	The transaction did not have a significant immediate impact on the Company s financial statements as the resultant net gain on sale will be recognized over the 10 year term of the leases as a reduction of rent expense.
1178970_18_ITEM2_P1_S0	The Company s executive offices are located in a leased facility at 239 Washington Street, Jersey City, New Jersey, which is also the Bank s Main Office.
1178970_18_ITEM2_P1_S1	The Bank s administrative offices are located in a leased facility at 100 Wood Avenue South, Iselin, New Jersey.
1178970_18_ITEM3_P0_S0	The Company is involved in various legal actions and claims arising in the normal course of its business.
1178970_18_ITEM3_P0_S1	In the opinion of management, these legal actions and claims are not expected to have a material adverse impact on the Company s financial condition and results of operations.
1178970_18_ITEM5_P0_S0	The Company s common stock trades on the New York Stock Exchange ( NYSE ) under the symbol PFS.
1178970_18_ITEM5_P0_S1	Trading in the Company s common stock commenced on January 16, 2003.
1178970_18_ITEM5_P0_S2	As of February 1, 2018, there were 83,209,293 shares of the Company s common stock issued and 66,842,531 shares outstanding, and approximately 4,935 stockholders of record.
1178970_18_ITEM5_P0_S3	The table below shows the high and low closing prices reported on the NYSE for the Company s common stock, as well as the cash dividends paid per common share during the periods indicated.
1178970_18_ITEM5_P1_S0	The $0.35 cash dividend paid per common share in the fourth quarter of 2017 included a $0.15 special cash dividend declared by the Board of Directors on November 16, 2017 and paid on December 22, 2017.
1178970_18_ITEM5_P1_S1	On January 26, 2018 , the Board of Directors declared a quarterly cash dividend of $0.20 per common share, which was paid on February 28, 2018, to common stockholders of record as of the close of business on February 15, 2018.
1178970_18_ITEM5_P1_S2	The Company s Board of Directors intends to review the payment of dividends quarterly and plans to continue to maintain a regular quarterly cash dividend in the future, subject to financial condition, results of operations, tax considerations, industry standards, economic conditions, regulatory restrictions that affect the payment of dividends by the Bank to the Company and other relevant factors.
1178970_18_ITEM5_P1_S3	The Company is subject to the requirements of Delaware law that generally limit dividends to an amount equal to the difference between the amount by which total assets exceed total liabilities and the amount equal to the aggregate par value of the outstanding shares of capital stock.
1178970_18_ITEM5_P1_S4	If there is no difference between these amounts, dividends are limited to net income for the current and/or immediately preceding year.
1178970_18_ITEM5_P1_S5	In addition, Federal Reserve Board guidance sets forth the supervisory expectation that bank holding companies will inform and consult with Federal Reserve Board staff in advance of issuing a dividend that exceeds earnings for the quarter and should inform the Federal Reserve Board and should eliminate, defer or significantly reduce dividends if: (i) net income available to stockholders for the past four quarters, net of dividends previously paid during that period, is not sufficient to fully fund the dividends; (ii) prospective rate of earnings retention is not consistent with the bank holding company s capital needs and overall current and prospective financial condition; or (iii) the bank holding company will not meet, or is in danger of not meeting, its minimum regulatory capital adequacy ratios.
1178970_18_ITEM5_P2_S0	Stock Performance Graph Set forth below is a stock performance graph comparing (a) the cumulative total return on the Company s common stock for the period December 31, 2012 through December 31, 2017 , (b) the cumulative total return on stocks included in the Russell 2000 Index over such period, and (c) the cumulative total return of the SNL Thrift Index over such period.
1178970_18_ITEM5_P3_S0	The SNL Thrift Index, produced by SNL Financial LC, contains all thrift institutions traded on the NYSE and NASDAQ stock exchange.
1178970_18_ITEM5_P4_S0	Cumulative return assumes the reinvestment of dividends and is expressed in dollars based on an assumed investment of $100 on December 31, 2012.

1178970_18_ITEM6_P0_S0	The summary information presented below at or for each of the periods presented is derived in part from and should be read in conjunction with the consolidated financial statements of the Company presented in Item 8.
1178970_18_ITEM6_P1_S0	(1) Loans are shown net of allowance for loan losses, deferred fees and unearned discount.
1178970_18_ITEM6_P2_S0	(1) Averages presented are daily averages.
1178970_18_ITEM6_P2_S1	(2) Net interest income divided by average interest earning assets.
1178970_18_ITEM6_P2_S2	(3) Represents the ratio of non-interest expense divided by the sum of net interest income and non-interest income.
1178970_18_ITEM6_P3_S0	(4) Leverage capital ratios are presented as a percentage of quarterly average tangible assets.

1178970_18_ITEM7_P0_S0	General On January 15, 2003, the Company became the holding company for the Bank, following the completion of the conversion of the Bank to a New Jersey-chartered capital stock savings bank.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P1_S0	The Company issued an aggregate of 59,618,300 shares of its common stock in a subscription offering to eligible depositors.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P1_S1	Concurrent with the conversion, the Company contributed an additional 1,920,000 shares of its common stock and $4.8 million in cash to The Provident Bank Foundation, a charitable foundation established by the Bank.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P2_S0	The Company conducts business through its subsidiary, the Bank, a community- and customer-oriented bank currently operating full-service branches and loan production offices throughout northern and central New Jersey, as well as Bucks, Lehigh and Northampton counties in Pennsylvania.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P2_S1	Strategy Established in 1839, the Bank is the oldest New Jersey-chartered bank in the state.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P2_S2	The Bank offers a full range of retail and commercial loan and deposit products, and emphasizes personal service and convenience.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P2_S3	The Bank s strategy is to grow profitably through a commitment to credit quality and expanding market share by acquiring, retaining and expanding customer relationships, while carefully managing interest rate risk.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P2_S4	In recent years, the Bank has focused on commercial mortgage, multi-family, construction and commercial loans as part of its strategy to diversify the loan portfolio and reduce interest rate risk.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P2_S5	These types of loans generally have adjustable rates that initially are higher than residential mortgage loans and generally have a higher rate of risk.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P3_S0	The Bank s credit policy focuses on quality underwriting standards and close monitoring of the loan portfolio.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P3_S1	At December 31, 2017 , these commercial loan types accounted for 77.9% of the loan portfolio and retail loans accounted for 22.1% .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P3_S2	The Company intends to continue to focus on commercial mortgage, multi-family, construction and commercial lending relationships.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P4_S0	The Company s relationship banking strategy focuses on increasing core accounts and expanding relationships through its branch network, mobile banking, online banking and telephone banking touch points.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P4_S1	The Company continues to evaluate opportunities to increase market share by expanding within existing and contiguous markets.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P5_S0	Core deposits, consisting of savings and demand deposit accounts, are generally a stable, relatively inexpensive source of funds.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P5_S1	At December 31, 2017 , core deposits were 90.5% of total deposits.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P6_S0	The Company s results of operations are primarily dependent upon net interest income, the difference between interest earned on interest-earning assets and the interest paid on interest-bearing liabilities.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P6_S1	Changes in interest rates could have an adverse effect on net interest income to the extent the Company s interest-bearing assets and interest-bearing liabilities reprice or mature at different times or relative interest rates.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P6_S2	An increase in interest rates generally would result in a decrease in the Company s average interest rate spread and net interest income, which could have a negative effect on profitability.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P7_S0	The Company generates non-interest income such as income from retail and business account fees, loan servicing fees, loan origination fees, loan level swap fees, appreciation in the cash surrender value of Bank-owned life insurance, income from loan or securities sales, fees from wealth management services and investment product sales and other fees.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P7_S1	The Company s operating expenses consist primarily of compensation and benefits expense, occupancy and equipment expense, data processing expense, the amortization of intangible assets, marketing and advertising expense and other general and administrative expenses.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P7_S2	The Company s results of operations are also affected by general economic conditions, changes in market interest rates, changes in asset quality, changes in asset values, actions of regulatory agencies and government policies.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P8_S0	The Company considers certain accounting policies to be critically important to the fair presentation of its financial condition and results of operations.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P8_S1	These policies require management to make complex judgments on matters which by their nature have elements of uncertainty.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P8_S2	The sensitivity of the Company s consolidated financial statements to these critical accounting policies, and the assumptions and estimates applied, could have a significant impact on its financial condition and results of operations.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P8_S3	These assumptions, estimates and judgments made by management can be influenced by a number of factors, including the general economic environment.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P8_S4	The Company has identified the following as critical accounting policies:
1178970_18_ITEM7_P9_S0	Valuation of deferred tax assets The calculation of the allowance for loan losses is a critical accounting policy of the Company.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P10_S0	The allowance for loan losses is a valuation account that reflects management s evaluation of the probable losses in the loan portfolio.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P10_S1	The Company maintains the allowance for loan losses through provisions for loan losses that are charged to income.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P10_S2	Charge-offs against the allowance for loan losses are taken on loans where management determines that the collection of loan principal is unlikely.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P10_S3	Recoveries made on loans that have been charged-off are credited to the allowance for loan losses.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P10_S4	Management's evaluation of the adequacy of the allowance for loan losses includes a review of all loans on which the collectability of principal may not be reasonably assured.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P11_S0	For residential mortgage and consumer loans, this is determined primarily by delinquency status.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P11_S1	For commercial mortgage, multi-family, construction and commercial loans, an extensive review of financial performance, payment history and collateral values is conducted on a quarterly basis.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P12_S0	As part of the evaluation of the adequacy of the allowance for loan losses, each quarter management prepares an analysis that categorizes the entire loan portfolio by certain risk characteristics such as loan type (residential mortgage, commercial mortgage, construction, commercial, etc.) and loan risk rating.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P12_S1	When assigning a risk rating to a loan, management utilizes a nine point internal risk rating system.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P12_S2	Loans deemed to be acceptable quality are rated 1 through 4, with a rating of 1 established for loans with minimal risk.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P12_S3	Loans deemed to be of questionable quality are rated 5 (watch) or 6 (special mention).
1178970_18_ITEM7_P12_S4	Loans with adverse classifications (substandard, doubtful or loss) are rated 7, 8 or 9, respectively.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P12_S5	Commercial mortgage, multi-family, construction and commercial loans are rated individually and each lending officer is responsible for risk rating loans in their portfolio.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P12_S6	These risk ratings are then reviewed by the department manager and/or the Chief Lending Officer and the Credit Department.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P12_S7	The risk ratings are also confirmed through periodic loan review examinations, which are currently performed by an independent third party, and periodically by the Credit Committee in the credit renewal or approval process.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P12_S8	In addition, the Bank requires an annual review be performed for commercial and commercial real estate loans above certain dollar thresholds, depending on loan type, to help determine the appropriate risk rating.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P13_S0	Management estimates the amount of loan losses for groups of loans by applying quantitative loss factors to loan segments at the risk rating level, and applying qualitative adjustments to each loan segment at the portfolio level.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P13_S1	Quantitative loss factors give consideration to historical loss experience by loan type based upon an appropriate look-back period and adjusted for a loss emergence period.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P13_S2	Quantitative loss factors are evaluated at least annually.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P13_S3	Management completed its annual evaluation of the quantitative loss factors for the quarter ended September 30, 2017.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P14_S0	Qualitative adjustments give consideration to other qualitative or environmental factors such as trends and levels of delinquencies, impaired loans, charge-offs, recoveries and loan volumes, as well as national and local economic trends and conditions.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P14_S1	Qualitative adjustments reflect risks in the loan portfolio not captured by the quantitative loss factors and, as such, are evaluated from a risk level perspective relative to the risk levels present over the look-back period.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P14_S2	Qualitative adjustments are evaluated at least quarterly.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P14_S3	The reserves resulting from the application of both of these sets of loss factors are combined to arrive at the allowance for loan losses.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P15_S0	Management believes the primary risks inherent in the portfolio are a general decline in the economy, a decline in real estate market values, rising unemployment or a protracted period of elevated unemployment, increasing vacancy rates in commercial investment properties and possible increases in interest rates in the absence of economic improvement.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P15_S1	Any one or a combination of these events may adversely affect borrowers ability to repay the loans, resulting in increased delinquencies, loan losses and future levels of provisions.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P15_S2	Accordingly, the Company has provided for loan losses at the current level to address the current risk in its loan portfolio.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P15_S3	Management considers it important to maintain the ratio of the allowance for loan losses to total loans at an acceptable level given current economic conditions, interest rates and the composition of the portfolio.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P15_S4	Although management believes that the Company has established and maintained the allowance for loan losses at appropriate levels, additions may be necessary if future economic and other conditions differ substantially from the current operating environment.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P16_S0	experience and other factors, including the current economic environment, which management believes to be reasonable under the circumstances.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P16_S1	Such estimates and assumptions are adjusted when facts and circumstances dictate.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P16_S2	Illiquid credit markets, volatile securities markets, and declines in the housing and commercial real estate markets and the economy generally have combined to increase the uncertainty inherent in such estimates and assumptions.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P17_S0	As future events and their effects cannot be determined with precision, actual results could differ significantly from these estimates.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P17_S1	Changes in estimates resulting from continuing changes in the economic environment will be reflected in the financial statements in future periods.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P17_S2	In addition, various regulatory agencies periodically review the adequacy of the Company s allowance for loan losses as an integral part of their examination process.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P17_S3	Such agencies may require the Company to recognize additions to the allowance or additional write-downs based on their judgments about information available to them at the time of their examination.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P17_S4	Although management uses the best information available, the level of the allowance for loan losses remains an estimate that is subject to significant judgment and short-term change.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P18_S0	The Company s available for sale securities portfolio is carried at estimated fair value, with any unrealized gains or losses, net of taxes, reported as accumulated other comprehensive income or loss in Stockholders Equity.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P18_S1	Estimated fair values are based on market quotations or matrix pricing as discussed in Note 5 to the consolidated financial statements.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P19_S0	Securities which the Company has the positive intent and ability to hold to maturity are classified as held to maturity and carried at amortized cost.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P19_S1	Management conducts a periodic review and evaluation of the securities portfolio to determine if any declines in the fair values of securities are other-than-temporary.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P19_S2	In this evaluation, if such a decline were deemed other-than-temporary, management would measure the total credit-related component of the unrealized loss, and recognize that portion of the loss as a charge to current period earnings.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P19_S3	The remaining portion of the unrealized loss would be recognized as an adjustment to accumulated other comprehensive income.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P20_S0	The fair value of the securities portfolio is significantly affected by changes in interest rates.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P20_S1	In general, as interest rates rise, the fair value of fixed-rate securities decreases and as interest rates fall, the fair value of fixed-rate securities increases.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P20_S2	The Company determines if it has the intent to sell these securities or if it is more likely than not that the Company would be required to sell the securities before the anticipated recovery.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P20_S3	If either exists, the entire decline in value is considered other-than-temporary and would be recognized as an expense in the current period.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P20_S4	In its evaluations, the Company did not recognize an other-than-temporary impairment charge on securities for the years ended 2017 , 2016 and 2015 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P21_S0	The determination of whether deferred tax assets will be realizable is predicated on the reversal of existing deferred tax liabilities and estimates of future taxable income.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P21_S1	Such estimates are subject to management s judgment.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P22_S0	A valuation allowance is established when management is unable to conclude that it is more likely than not that it will realize deferred tax assets based on the nature and timing of these items.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P22_S1	The Company did not require a valuation allowance at December 31, 2017 and 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P23_S0	Analysis of Net Interest Income Net interest income represents the difference between income on interest-earning assets and expense on interest-bearing liabilities.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P23_S1	Net interest income depends on the relative amounts of interest-earning assets and interest-bearing liabilities and the rates of interest earned on such assets and paid on such liabilities.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P23_S2	The following table sets forth certain information for the years ended December 31, 2017 , 2016 and 2015 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P23_S3	For the periods indicated, the total dollar amount of interest income from average interest-earning assets and the resultant yields, as well as the interest expense on average interest-bearing liabilities is expressed both in dollars and rates.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P23_S4	No tax equivalent adjustments were made.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P24_S0	(1) Average outstanding balance amounts are at amortized cost.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P24_S1	(2) Average outstanding balances are net of the allowance for loan losses, deferred loan fees and expenses, and loan premiums and discounts and include non-accrual loans.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P24_S2	(3) Net interest income divided by average interest-earning assets.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P25_S0	The following table presents the extent to which changes in interest rates and changes in the volume of interest-earning assets and interest-bearing liabilities have affected interest income and interest expense during the periods indicated.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P25_S1	Information is provided in each category with respect to: (i) changes attributable to changes in volume (changes in volume multiplied by prior rate); (ii) changes attributable to changes in rate (changes in rate multiplied by prior volume); and (iii) the net change.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P25_S2	The changes attributable to the combined impact of volume and rate have been allocated proportionately to the changes due to volume and the changes due to rate.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P26_S0	Comparison of Financial Condition at December 31, 2017 and December 31, 2016 Total assets increased $344.8 million , or 3.6% , to $9.85 billion at December 31, 2017 , from $9.50 billion at December 31, 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P26_S1	The increase in total assets was primarily due to a $322.2 million increase in total loans and a $46.5 million increase in total cash and cash equivalents, partially offset by a $20.9 million decrease in premises and equipment and a $7.6 million decrease in total investments.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P26_S2	Total loans increased $322.2 million , or 4.6% , to $7.33 billion at December 31, 2017 , from $7.00 billion at December 31, 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P26_S3	For the year ended December 31, 2017 , loan originations, including advances on lines of credit, totaling $3.70 billion was partially offset by repayments of $3.34 billion and loan sales of $24.9 million .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P26_S4	The loan portfolio had net increases of $192.5 million in commercial mortgage loans, $127.8 million in construction loans, $114.4 million in commercial loans and $1.8 million in multi-family mortgage loans, partially offset by net decreases of $69.3 million in residential mortgage loans and $42.8 million in consumer loans.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P26_S5	Commercial loans, consisting of commercial real estate, multi-family, construction and commercial loans, totaled $5.71 billion , accounting for 77.9% of the loan portfolio at December 31, 2017 , compared to $5.28 billion , or 75.3% of the loan portfolio at December 31, 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P26_S6	The Company intends to continue to focus on the origination of commercially-oriented loans.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P27_S0	Retail loans, which consist of one- to four-family residential mortgage and consumer loans, such as fixed-rate home equity loans and lines of credit, totaled $1.62 billion and accounted for 22.1% of the loan portfolio at December 31, 2017 , compared to $1.73 billion , or 24.7% , of the loan portfolio at December 31, 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P27_S1	The Company does not originate or purchase sub-prime or option ARM loans.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P28_S0	Prior to September 30, 2008, the Company originated Alt-A mortgages in the form of stated income loans with a maximum loan-to-value ratio of 50% on a limited basis.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P29_S0	The balance of these Alt-A loans at December 31, 2017 was $4.2 million.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P29_S1	Of this total, there were no loans that were 90 days or more delinquent.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P30_S0	The Company participates in loans originated by other banks, including participations designated as Shared National Credits ( SNC ).
1178970_18_ITEM7_P30_S1	The Company s gross commitments and outstanding balances as a participant in SNCs were $342.5 million and $223.9 million, respectively, at December 31, 2017 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P30_S2	At December 31, 2017 , no SNC relationships were classified as substandard.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P31_S0	The Company had outstanding junior lien mortgages totaling $205.1 million at December 31, 2017 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P31_S1	Of this total, 24 loans totaling $1.3 million were 90 days or more delinquent, and were allocated total loss reserves of $238,000.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P31_S2	The allowance for loan losses decreased $1.7 million to $60.2 million at December 31, 2017 , as a result of net charge-offs of $7.3 million during 2017 , partially offset by provisions for loan losses of $5.6 million .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P31_S3	The decrease in the allowance for loan losses was a function of the decline in non-performing loans, partially offset by the growth in the loan portfolio.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P31_S4	Total non-performing loans at December 31, 2017 were $34.9 million , or 0.48% of total loans, compared with $42.4 million , or 0.61% of total loans at December 31, 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P31_S5	At December 31, 2017 , impaired loans totaled $52.0 million with related specific reserves of $2.7 million , compared with impaired loans totaling $52.0 million with related specific reserves of $2.3 million at December 31, 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P31_S6	Within total impaired loans, there were $31.4 million of loans for which the present value of expected future cash flows or current collateral valuations exceeded the carrying amounts of the loans and for which no specific reserves were required in accordance with GAAP.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P31_S7	At December 31, 2017 , the Company s allowance for loan losses was 0.82 % of total loans, compared with 0.88% of total loans at December 31, 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P31_S8	The decline in the loan coverage ratio from December 31, 2016 , resulted from an overall improvement in asset quality.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P31_S9	Non-performing commercial mortgage loans decreased $403,000 to $7.1 million at December 31, 2017 , from $7.5 million at December 31, 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P31_S10	At December 31, 2017 , the Company held 10 non-performing commercial mortgage loans.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P31_S11	The largest non-performing commercial mortgage loan was a $2.9 million loan secured by a first mortgage on a retail property located in Washington Township, New Jersey.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P31_S12	The loan is presently in default.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P31_S13	There is no contractual commitment to advance additional funds to this borrower.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P31_S14	Non-performing commercial loans increased $456,000 to $17.2 million at December 31, 2017 , from $16.8 million at December 31, 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P31_S15	Non-performing commercial loans at December 31, 2017 consisted of 30 loans.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P31_S16	The largest non-performing commercial loan relationship consisted of two loans to a health and fitness club with total outstanding balances of $8.4 million at December 31, 2017 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P31_S17	Both of these loans are secured by liens on a commercial property.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P31_S18	These loans are currently paying in accordance with their restructured terms.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P31_S19	There were no non-performing constructions loans at December 31, 2017 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P31_S20	Non-performing constructions loans at the prior year-end were $2.5 million .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P31_S21	At December 31, 2017 , the Company held $6.9 million of foreclosed assets, compared with $8.0 million at December 31, 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P31_S22	Foreclosed assets are carried at fair value based on recent appraisals and valuation estimates, less estimated selling costs.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P31_S23	During the year ended December 31, 2017 , there were 16 additions to foreclosed assets with a carrying value of $3.8 million and 26 properties sold with a carrying value of $4.3 million.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P31_S24	Foreclosed assets at December 31, 2017 consisted of $3.9 million of commercial real estate and $3.0 million of residential real estate.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P31_S25	Non-performing assets totaled $41.8 million , or 0.42% of total assets at December 31, 2017 , compared to $50.4 million , or 0.53% of total assets at December 31, 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P31_S26	If the non-accrual loans had performed in accordance with their original terms, interest income would have increased by $1.9 million during the year ended December 31, 2017 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P32_S0	The amount of cash basis interest income that was recognized on impaired loans during the year ended December 31, 2017 was not material.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P32_S1	Total deposits increased $160.5 million , or 2.4% , during the year ended December 31, 2017 to $6.71 billion .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P32_S2	Total core deposits, which consist of savings and demand deposit accounts, increased $176.9 million , or 3.0% , to $6.08 billion at December 31, 2017 , while time deposits decreased $16.4 million to $634.8 million at December 31, 2017 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P32_S3	The increase in core deposits for the year ended December 31, 2017 was largely attributable to a $140.0 million increase in interest bearing demand deposits and a $103.6 million increase in non-interest bearing demand deposits, partially offset by a $50.7 million decrease in money market deposits and a $16.0 million decrease in savings deposits.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P32_S4	At December 31, 2017 , core deposits represented 90.5% of total deposits compared to 90.1% at December 31, 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P32_S5	Borrowed funds increased $129.8 million , or 8.0% , during the year ended December 31, 2017 , to $1.74 billion , as wholesale funds, combined with net deposit inflows, were used to fund the Company's asset growth.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P32_S6	Borrowed funds represented 17.7% of total assets at December 31, 2017 , an increase from 17.0% at December 31, 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P33_S0	Total stockholders equity increased $46.9 million , or 3.7% , to $1.30 billion at December 31, 2017 , from $1.25 billion at December 31, 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P33_S1	This increase resulted from net income earned during the year of $93.9 million , the allocation of shares to stock-based compensation plans of $11.5 million, exercised stock options of $3.0 million, and the reissuance of shares for the dividend reinvestment program of $2.1 million, partially offset by cash dividends paid to stockholders of $60.0 million , a $2.7 million other comprehensive loss and common stock repurchases of $1.2 million.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P33_S2	Common stock repurchases for the year ended December 31, 2017 , which were made in connection with withholding to cover income taxes on stock-based compensation, totaled 45,123 shares at an average cost of $27.08 per share.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P33_S3	At December 31, 2017 , approximately 3.1 million shares remained eligible for repurchase under the current authorizations.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P34_S0	Comparison of Operating Results for the Years Ended December 31, 2017 and December 31, 2016 General.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P34_S1	Net income for the year ended December 31, 2017 was $93.9 million , compared to $87.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P34_S2	Basic and diluted earnings per share were $1.46 and $1.45 for the year ended December 31, 2017 , respectively, compared to basic and diluted earnings per share of $1.38 for 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P34_S3	As a result of the enactment of the Tax Act on December 22, 2017, the Company recognized additional tax expense of $3.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2017 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P34_S4	Offsetting the effect of the change in tax law, earnings for the year ended December 31, 2017 were favorably impacted by year-over-year growth in average loans outstanding, growth in both average non-interest bearing and interest bearing core deposits and expansion of the net interest margin.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P34_S5	The improvement in the net interest margin was driven by the upward repricing of adjustable rate assets and relatively stable cost of funds.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P34_S6	Net interest income increased $19.6 million to $278.2 million for 2017 , from $258.6 million for 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P34_S7	The average interest rate spread increased nine basis points to 3.07% for 2017 , from 2.98% for 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P34_S8	The net interest margin increased ten basis points to 3.21% for 2017 , compared to 3.11% for 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P34_S9	For the year ended December 31, 2017 , the increase in net interest income was largely due to growth in average loans outstanding, growth in average core deposits, and expansion in the net interest margin.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P34_S10	Interest income increased $21.5 million , or 7.1% , to $323.8 million for 2017 , compared to $302.3 million for 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P34_S11	The increase in interest income was attributable to an increase in average earning asset balances and an increase in the yield on average interest-earning assets.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P34_S12	Average interest-earning assets increased $343.1 million, or 4.1% , to $8.65 billion for 2017 , compared to $8.31 billion for 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P34_S13	The average outstanding loan balances increased $301.7 million, or 4.5% , to $6.97 billion for 2017 from $6.67 billion for 2016 , the average balance of securities available for sale increased $35.8 million, or 3.5% , to $1.04 billion for 2017 , compared to $1.01 billion for 2016 , and the average balance of investment securities held to maturity increased $8.7 million, or 1.8% , to $487.6 million for 2017 , compared to $478.9 million for 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P34_S14	The yield on interest-earning assets increased ten basis points to 3.74% for 2017 , from 3.64% for 2016 , mainly due to increases in the weighted average yields on total loans, FHLBNY stock and the securities available for sale portfolio.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P34_S15	Interest expense increased $1.9 million , or 4.3% , to $45.6 million for 2017 , from $43.7 million for 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P34_S16	The increase in interest expense was primarily attributable to an increase in average interest-bearing deposits for the year, which combined with an increase in non-interest bearing deposits largely funded the growth in average interest-earning assets.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P34_S17	The increase in interest expense was partially offset by a shift in the funding composition to lower-costing core deposits from time deposits and borrowings.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P34_S18	The average rate paid on interest-bearing liabilities increased one basis point to 0.67% for 2017 , compared to 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P34_S19	The average rate paid on interest-bearing deposits increased four basis points to 0.37% for 2017 , from 0.33% for 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P34_S20	The average rate paid on borrowings decreased four basis points to 1.66% for 2017 , from 1.70% for 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P34_S21	The average balance of interest-bearing liabilities increased $154.2 million to $6.81 billion for 2017 , compared to $6.66 billion for 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P34_S22	Average interest-bearing deposits increased $149.6 million, or 2.9% , to $5.23 billion for 2017 , from $5.08 billion for 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P34_S23	Within average interest-bearing deposits, average interest-bearing core deposits increased $226.2 million, or 5.2% for 2017 , compared with 2016 , while average time deposits decreased $76.6 million, or 10.6% for 2017 , compared with 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P34_S24	Average non-interest bearing demand deposits increased $123.1 million, or 9.9% , to $1.37 billion for 2017 , from $1.24 billion for 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P34_S25	Average outstanding borrowings decreased $4.7 million, or 0.3 %, to $1.58 billion for 2017 , compared to 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P35_S0	Provisions for loan losses are charged to operations in order to maintain the allowance for loan losses at a level management considers necessary to absorb probable credit losses inherent in the loan portfolio.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P35_S1	In determining the level of the allowance for loan losses, management considers past and current loss experience, evaluations of real estate collateral, current economic conditions, volume and type of lending, adverse situations that may affect a borrower s ability to repay the loan and the levels of non-performing and other classified loans.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P35_S2	The amount of the allowance is based on estimates, and the ultimate losses may vary from such estimates as more information becomes available or later events change.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P35_S3	Management assesses the adequacy of the allowance for loan losses on a quarterly basis and makes provisions for loan losses, if necessary, in order to maintain the adequacy of the allowance.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P36_S0	the allowance for loan losses and provision for loan losses for the past several years.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P36_S1	As the Company looks to further increase the amount of such types of loans in the portfolio, management may determine that additional or increased provisions for loan losses are necessary, which could adversely affect earnings.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P36_S2	The provision for loan losses was $5.6 million in 2017 , compared to $5.4 million in 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P36_S3	The increase in the provision for loan losses was primarily attributable to year-over-year growth in the loan portfolio.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P36_S4	Net charge-offs for 2017 were $7.3 million , compared to $4.9 million for 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P36_S5	Total charge-offs for the year ended December 31, 2017 were $8.9 million , compared to $7.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P36_S6	Recoveries for the year ended December 31, 2017 , were $1.7 million , compared to $2.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P36_S7	The allowance for loan losses at December 31, 2017 was $60.2 million , or 0.82% of total loans, compared to $61.9 million , or 0.88% of total loans, at December 31, 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P36_S8	At December 31, 2017 , non-performing loans as a percentage of total loans were 0.48% , compared to 0.61% at December 31, 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P36_S9	Non-performing assets as a percentage of total assets were 0.42% at December 31, 2017 , compared to 0.53% at December 31, 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P36_S10	At December 31, 2017 , non-performing loans were $34.9 million , compared to $42.4 million at December 31, 2016 , and non-performing assets were $41.8 million at December 31, 2017 , compared to $50.4 million at December 31, 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P36_S11	For the year ended December 31, 2017 , non-interest income totaled $55.7 million , an increase of $304,000 , compared to the same period in 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P36_S12	Income from Bank-owned life insurance increased $1.2 million to $6.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2017 , compared to the same period in 2016 , primarily due to the recognition of death benefit claims.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P36_S13	Fee income also increased $1.2 million to $27.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2017, compared to the same period in 2016 , largely due to a $657,000 increase in commercial loan prepayment fee income, a $397,000 increase in deposit related fee income and a $229,000 increase in merchant fee income, partially offset by a $218,000 decrease in income from non-deposit investment products and a $43,000 decrease in debit card revenue.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P36_S14	Partially offsetting these increases in non-interest income, other income decreased $2.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2017 , compared with the same period in 2016 , mainly due to a $910,000 decrease in net fees on loan-level interest rate swap transactions, a $583,000 decrease in net gains recognized on loan sales and a $335,000 non-recurring gain recognized on the sale of deposits resulting from a strategic branch divestiture in the prior year.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P36_S15	Non-interest expense for the year ended December 31, 2017 was $187.8 million , an increase of $4.0 million from the year ended December 31, 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P36_S16	Compensation and benefits expense increased $3.2 million to $109.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2017 , compared to $106.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P36_S17	This increase was primarily due to additional salary expense related to annual merit increases, an increase in the accrual for incentive compensation and an increase in stock-based compensation, partially offset by a decrease in retirement benefit costs.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P36_S18	Other operating expenses increased $1.2 million to $28.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2017 , compared to $27.6 million for the same period in 2016 , largely due to increases in consulting and debit card maintenance expenses, partially offset by a decrease in loan collection expense.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P36_S19	Data processing costs increased $694,000 to $13.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2017 , compared with the same period in 2016 , due to increased software maintenance and telecommunication costs.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P36_S20	Net occupancy costs increased $437,000 , to $25.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2017 , compared to the same period in 2016 , resulting from an increase in snow removal costs, combined with an increase in facilities maintenance costs.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P36_S21	Partially offsetting these increases in non-interest expense, FDIC insurance expense decreased $1.0 million to $3.9 million for year ended December 31, 2017 , compared to $4.9 million for the same period in 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P36_S22	This decrease was primarily due to the FDIC's reduction of assessment rates for depository institutions with less than $10.0 billion in assets, which became effective in the quarter ended September 30, 2016.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P36_S23	Additionally, amortization of intangibles decreased $721,000 for the year ended December 31, 2017 , compared with the same period in 2016 , as a result of scheduled reductions in amortization.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P36_S24	For the year ended December 31, 2017 , the Company s income tax expense was $46.5 million , compared with $37.0 million , for the same period in 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P36_S25	The Company s effective tax rate was 33.1% for the year ended December 31, 2017 , compared with 29.6% for the year ended December 31, 2016 .
1178970_18_ITEM7_P36_S26	For the year ended December 31, 2017 , the increases in income tax expense and the effective tax rate were a function of growth in pre-tax income and the enactment of the Tax Act, which resulted in additional tax expense of $3.9 million.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P37_S0	Comparison of Operating Results for the Years Ended December 31, 2016 and December 31, 2015 General.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P37_S1	Net income for the year ended December 31, 2016 was $87.8 million, compared to $83.7 million for the year ended December 31, 2015.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P37_S2	Basic and diluted earnings per share were $1.38 for the year ended December 31, 2016, compared to basic and diluted earnings per share of $1.33 for 2015.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P37_S3	Net income for the year ended December 31, 2016 was favorably impacted by year-over-year growth in average loans outstanding resulting from organic originations, and increases in both average interest bearing core deposits and average non-interest bearing demand deposits, partially offset by compression in the net interest margin.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P37_S4	The growth in average core deposits mitigated the Company's need to utilize higher-cost borrowings to fund loan growth.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P38_S0	Net interest income increased $8.7 million to $258.6 million for 2016, from $249.9 million for 2015.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P38_S1	The average interest rate spread decreased nine basis points to 2.98% for 2016, from 3.07% for 2015.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P38_S2	The net interest margin decreased nine basis points to 3.11% for 2016, compared to 3.20% for 2015.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P38_S3	For the year ended December 31, 2016, net interest income was favorably impacted by the growth in average loans outstanding and growth in average core deposits, mitigating the effects of compression in the net interest margin.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P38_S4	Interest income increased $10.5 million, or 3.6%, to $302.3 million for 2016, compared to $291.8 million for 2015.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P38_S5	The increase in interest income was attributable to an increase in average earning asset balances, partially offset by a decrease in the yield on average interest-earning assets.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P38_S6	Average interest-earning assets increased $490.9 million, or 6.3%, to $8.31 billion for 2016, compared to $7.82 billion for 2015.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P38_S7	The average outstanding loan balances increased $454.4 million, or 7.3%, to $6.67 billion for 2016 from $6.22 billion for 2015, the average balance of securities available for sale decreased $20.3 million, or 2.0%, to $1.01 billion for 2016, compared to $1.03 billion for 2015, and the average balance of investment securities held to maturity increased $5.5 million, or 1.2%, to $478.9 million for 2016, compared to $473.4 million for 2015.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P38_S8	The yield on interest-earning assets decreased nine basis points to 3.64% for 2016, from 3.73% for 2015, due to a reduction in both the weighted average yield on total loans and securities available for sale, partially offset by an increase in the weighted average yield on FHLBNY stock.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P38_S9	Interest expense increased $1.8 million, or 4.4%, to $43.7 million for 2016, from $41.9 million for 2015.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P38_S10	The increase in interest expense was primarily attributable to an increase in average interest-bearing deposits for the year, which largely funded the growth in average interest-earning assets.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P38_S11	The increase in interest expense was partially offset by a shift in the funding composition to lower-costing core deposits from time deposits and borrowings.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P38_S12	The average rate paid on interest-bearing liabilities remained unchanged at 0.66% for 2016, compared to 2015.

1178970_18_ITEM7_P38_S14	The average rate paid on borrowings decreased one basis point to 1.70% for 2016, from 1.71% for 2015.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P38_S15	The average balance of interest-bearing liabilities increased $327.4 million to $6.66 billion for 2016, compared to $6.33 billion for 2015.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P38_S16	Average interest-bearing deposits increased $354.1 million, or 7.5%, to $5.08 billion for 2016, from $4.72 billion for 2015.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P38_S17	Within average interest-bearing deposits, average interest-bearing core deposits increased $412.5 million, or 10.5%, for 2016, compared with 2015, while average time deposits decreased $58.4 million, or 7.5%, for 2016, compared with 2015.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P38_S18	Average non-interest bearing demand deposits increased $125.9 million, or 11.3%, to $1.24 billion for 2016, from $1.12 billion for 2015.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P38_S19	Average outstanding borrowings decreased $26.7 million, or 1.7%, to $1.58 billion for 2016, compared with $1.60 billion for 2015.

1178970_18_ITEM7_P38_S24	Recoveries for the year ended December 31, 2016, were $2.0 million, compared to $4.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2015.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P38_S25	The allowance for loan losses at December 31, 2016 was $61.9 million, or 0.88% of total loans, compared to $61.4 million, or 0.94% of total loans, at December 31, 2015.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P38_S26	At December 31, 2016, non-performing loans as a percentage of total loans were 0.61%, compared to 0.68% at December 31, 2015.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P38_S27	Non-performing assets as a percentage of total assets were 0.53% at December 31, 2016, compared to 0.62% at December 31, 2015.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P38_S28	At December 31, 2016, non-performing loans were $42.4 million, compared to $44.5 million at December 31, 2015, and non-performing assets were $50.4 million at December 31, 2016, compared to $55.1 million at December 31, 2015.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P38_S29	For the year ended December 31, 2016, non-interest income totaled $55.4 million, an increase of $171,000, compared to the same period in 2015.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P38_S30	Wealth management income increased $718,000 to $17.6 million for the year ended December 31, 2016, largely due to fees from assets under management acquired in the MDE acquisition, which closed on April 1, 2015.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P38_S31	This increase in wealth management income was offset in part by a reduction in income associated with the licensing of indices to exchange traded fund ("ETF") providers, along with a shift in the mix of assets under management which negatively impacted fees earned.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P38_S32	Also contributing to the increase in non-interest income, other income increased $153,000 for the year ended December 31, 2016, compared with the same period in 2015, primarily due to a $1.2 million increase in net gains recognized on loan sales and a $335,000 gain recognized on the sale of deposits resulting from a strategic branch divestiture, largely offset by a $1.4 million decrease in net fees on loan-level interest rate swap transactions.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P38_S33	Partially offsetting these increases in non-interest income, net gains on securities transactions and fee income decreased $590,000 and $235,000, respectively, for the year ended December 31, 2016, compared to the same period in 2015.
1178970_18_ITEM7_P38_S34	The decrease in fee income was largely due to a $1.4 million decrease in prepayment fees on commercial loans, partially offset by increases of $708,000 and $529,000 in deposit fees and loan related fee income, respectively.
